fields.headline: I am a liar and a moron (apparently)
fields.standfirst:
Nothing raises readers' passions quite like the Arab-Israeli crisis

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Nothing raises readers' passions quite like the Arab-Israeli crisis
fields.body:
Guardian columnists now put email addresses at the bottom of their articles to enable readers to engage in a mature and sensible debate with the writers in a way that is simply impossible within the confines of the letters page. Last week, I wrote about the Middle East.

"You are a moron" (thank you, the Lipschitz family); "It's not part of your heritage so fuck you" (G Kawalick); "Palestine = genocide = Satan = your wicked, evil lies. Send them back to hell where they came from. Evil's not the way, liar" (J Bell).

"Sham on you." [sic]; "You are just one of many Jew-haters in the world"; "I hope you and your rag will join the human race"; "Self-hating Jew!"; "Anti-semite!"; "I suspect your other readers will be accusing you of being an anti-semite. They are wrong. You have to be intelligent to be an anti-semite."

Well, it's good to know that a certain amount of mordant Jewish insult-humour has survived the week. My own humour was a little frayed after dealing with close to 200 messages, especially as the 30% that supported the thrust of my criticisms of Israel were sometimes as alarming as those in opposition. And these, remember, are from Guardian readers. Good grief, what are the immoderate people like?

There was one regret. I used the word "lebensraum" in connection with the Israeli settlements in the occupied territories, and thus myself fell into the trap that so distorts argument about the Middle East, where the past does not inform the present, but enslaves it. No threat can ever be put to one side. No grievance can be shelved. Jewish suffering can be made to justify Jewish oppression.

It is particularly instructive to report on the Middle East and Vietnam in quick succession. In Vietnam, the war is already ancient history. Here, no history can be ancient, no matter how questionable. "One of my classmates went to live in Hebron about 16 years ago," wrote one correspondent. "He made that decision so he could live in the place where Abraham had bought a field and a cave to bury his family. Is that so bad?"

It wouldn't have been, if Abraham's cave were in Israel. It isn't. It's in an area where the effect of Jewish settlement is simply to make peace more difficult. And, in the case of some settlers, it has to be said, that is precisely the intent.

The settlements are not the sole obstacle to a lasting peace. But they are a massive one. Constantly, we hear of Israel's willingness to give away 92, 95, 98% of the West Bank, figures that remind me of those food packets: "Guaranteed 92% fat-free", ie 8% fat. Long-term peace depends on the coexistence of two passably prosperous and contented states. That will be hard enough to achieve, given that the state of Palestine will be in two disconnected slices. If those slices are Gorgonzola, punched full of holes for settlements, the problems will be increased hugely.

The analogy with South Africa can be pushed too far. But the belief that black South Africans could be confined to separate Bantustans, delineated on a map drawn up for the whites' convenience, was catastrophic for the notion that the whites had any honourable intentions.

And, on the ground, you see the reminders again and again: in the casual racism and suspicion of Israeli officialdom; in the humiliating arrangements for Palestinians at the borders (when the borders are open); in the imposition of social controls designed to protect one side but with the inevitable downside of humiliating the other.

Don't believe me? As I was writing the paragraph above, a report came through via the Jerusalem Post, quoting Ami Ayalon, the former head of Israel's General Security Service, who yesterday used the word "apartheid" to describe elements of Israel's policy, saying Palestinians were forced to go through extreme measures before they could enter Israel or take their produce there. "We must remember", he added, "that Israel's neighbours may not always love the reality we are forcing on to them." Many of my correspondents believe that Palestinian discontent is something entirely whipped up by Yasser Arafat.

I believe in Israel but, to have any meaning, Israel has to have moral authority. Sure, it must safeguard its people and defend itself from predators. But that cannot be its only destiny. The darkness may now be closing in once more, and the brief moment when peace might have been possible is perhaps passing. It is not possible to blame this wholly on the Arabs.

Let's keep hold of this: Israel has the right to exist; Palestine has the right to exist. Israel exists; Palestine does not. Those who care for Israel's future would be safeguarding it best if they worked to ensure that Palestine had a future too.

Matthewengel@ndirect.co.uk

webTitle: Forget Florida, it's Nice we should be worried about

fields.headline: Forget Florida, it's Nice we should be worried about
fields.standfirst: There is little cause for optimism at this week's EU summit
fields.trailText: Seldom has the future of Europe rested more heavily in the hands of one man than it does in those of the French president, Jacques Chirac, at Nice. He can make or break this week's EU summit.
fields.body:
Seldom has the future of Europe rested more heavily in the hands of one man than it does in those of the French president, Jacques Chirac, at Nice. He can make or break this week's EU summit. The moment is apt, and telling. Chirac's predicament is a perfect emblem of Europe's. On the one hand, it is more about symbol than substance, a very Europe thing. Yet the way he jumps will also declare a firm choice between the nation and the collective. It goes to the heart of what the EU purports to be - a project, it must be said, that sits perilously in the balance at the start of 2001.

The danger Nice presents is not of strides towards the superstate of legend, but of failing to make an inch of progress towards a better functioning EU; not of destroying the nation state, but draining all reality out of the ambition for a European state system; not of fathering a Greater Europe but proving the EU has lost the visionary idea of what it is supposed to be. That's about the size of it, Jacques. We'll soon be seeing what this mercurial, tainted but durable leader is made of.

There are many issues at Nice, but the fount from which answers will cascade is whether France and Germany shall any longer be exactly equal members. So far Chirac has insisted: yes. The voting weights each is allocated, he says, must continue to reflect the parity with which they entered the EEC in 1958 at the hand of the founding fathers, who spoke not only for Franco-German equality but for an overweighting for smaller members like Belgium and Holland too. Though reunified Germany now has 20m more citizens than France, Chirac says, it should seek no greater voting weight.

This is an indefensible position. Not only is it unfair to Germany, it would have destructive consequences lower down the line. The most viable proposal on the table is for France, Italy and Britain to have 30 votes in EU councils, while Germany gets 32 or 33. If something like this doesn't happen, there will be turmoil elsewhere. Spain, with 20m fewer people than France or Britain, will, since population is deemed not an issue, demand to be in the 30-vote league as well. Belgium, a smaller country than the Netherlands, will insist on retaining the same vote count. Smaller applicant countries will demand to be treated like Sweden and Finland. None of this will be acceptable to larger countries skewered by such arrangements.

What's being proposed, in other words, exchanges a post-second world war philosophy of semi-equality for a post-cold war philosophy of numerical legitimacy. Only that way can public support be mobilised in the larger countries. Numbers are now perceived to count for more than they did. Yet France, by rejecting that, is capable of wrecking the only platform on which a Treaty of Nice can hope to be built. At present she is also rejecting the more blurry alternative, which would retain present parities but superimpose on them direct population counts, the so-called double majority, which would again give Germany more clout but not so obviously.

Chirac has his problems. At the same time as running this summit, he coexists alongside his socialist rival, prime minister Lionel Jospin, while preparing to fight him in a presidential election. On the other hand, there's not much evidence that Jospin is personally so hung up on parity with the Germans. Domestically Chirac could defuse the issue by striking a deal with him. But there's more than politics involved here. Chirac, the post-Gaullist, is psychologically resistant. All logic is against him, and just about every other member of the EU stands to suffer if he does not move. The first thing to watch this weekend is whether the man with more wrecking power than Margaret Thatcher ever had chooses to deploy it.

If he's prepared to yield, some other important things might begin to flow. With the weights thus adjusted, qualified majority voting has more acceptance. From notorious nation-killer QMV more readily emerges as the oil for Europe's necessary momentum. An essential decision has been made, some pain endured, some faith expressed, some enlargement facilitated, some breadth of vision shown such as would be unimaginable to the Tory activists in Esher and Walton who worked hard to run one of the few remaining pro-Europe MPs out of the party last night.

But on the whole, no one can be optimistic about Nice, even if Chirac sacrifices the order that is now outdated. What is my pessimism based on? The fact that few leaders, even outside the immediate context of a summit negotiation, seem prepared to contemplate a reassessment of national sovereignty in areas that matter. For Britain the neuralgic issue is tax - any tax, any reform, any pooling of power no matter how valuable to every country including this one, any tax decision of any kind. The same blanket political ban, on different issues for different countries, proves that Britain is not the only place where rational discussion is hard to find in the arenas that count.

What makes this doubly perplexing is the relative strength of most of the national leaders involved. It is true that elections drive some of them. For the French duet this probably makes the defence of cultural heritage, the purpose of their veto on trade issues, unavoidable. Elsewhere, Schröder of Germany surveys a decimated opposition. Aznar of Spain has just been re-elected. Italy, though the most fragile of the governments, is never going to argue over the EU. Tony Blair, while tied to his tax pledge, has little to fear from the baseless Tory ranting on other matters. He could play a constructive role, not entirely terrified of the response of the press when he gets home. The phobic press, after all, has decided on its story already. Nothing he says or does could make it moderate its inexhaustible campaign to mislead the British public.

This is, admittedly, the hardest moment to take a reading on what will happen. Every country is negotiating. Sufficient unto the day is the final deal thereof. There are inducements to make one. For one thing, proof that the EU cannot agree on basic structures for survival and enlargement would knock the bottom out of the euro's recovery. For another, the frustration among applicant countries, at the sight of the rich man's club unable to rise above political discomfort, would become justifiably extreme.

While some leaders have advanced the debate about what sort of entity the EU should seek to be, few have troubled to go on reminding their voters of more basic truths about why it should exist at all, and what that means. So they all come to Nice defensively limping.

Florida has been big news for weeks. It has become an absorbing soap opera. Take your pick between goodies and baddies, they're easily understood. As it turns out, there may be little to choose between them. Nice is, by comparison, not easy. It's much harder to report and grasp. But the difference between its outcomes could be enormous. For Britain, it matters more than Florida. Watching the two carefully, maybe we can start to see that.

hugoyoung@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Arsenal 2 - 2 Bayern Munich
fields.trailText:
Arsenal: Manninger, Luzhny, Keown, Adams, Cole; Ljungberg, Grimandi, Vieira, Pires; Kanu, Henry.
Bayern Munich: Kahn; Kuffour, Sforza, Linke; Sagnol, Effenberg, Tarnat, Jeremies; Scholl; Elber, Salihamidzic.
fields.body:
Arsenal: Manninger, Luzhny, Keown, Adams, Cole; Ljungberg, Grimandi, Vieira, Pires; Kanu, Henry.
Bayern Munich: Kahn; Kuffour, Sforza, Linke; Sagnol, Effenberg, Tarnat, Jeremies; Scholl; Elber, Salihamidzic.

Referee: Stefano Braschi (Italy)

1 Arsenal kick off. Bayern take possession early on and pass the ball around, probing the Arsenal midfield.
3 GOAL Pires takes the ball down the left, crosses the ball low into the centre and in comes to Kanu after a quick dummy from Henry. Kanu, surrounded by three defenders plays the ball into the path of the advancing Henry, who shoots low and hard past Kahn into the net.
6 Arsenal continue to make a good start, going forward again through Ljungberg. he moves forward into the box, trying to find room for a shot. When it comes it cannons off a Bayern defender for a corner. Cole's corner is headed away by the German defence.
10 Henry finds himself in space in the Bayern half, and although three defenders quickly surround him, he manages to get in a shot to test Kahn.
11 It's Kanu's turn to find himself in space this time, and from around 30 yards out he fires a shot in so hard that Kahn can only punch it away. Arsenal are certainly playing with purpose.
13 Ljungberg skins Tarnat in his own half, advances forward into central midfield and the Bayern defence have to scramble the ball away yet again. After a Bayern clearance, the Gunners put together another neat passing movement before Ljungberg's shot is deflected into Kahn's arms.
17 A Pires corner falls tantalisingly into the bayern box with a period of head tennis to follow. Bayern's defence look unsettled, and Arsenal and the crowd call for a penalty, whicvh the referee dismisses out of hand (replays show that a penalty appeal is justified). Bayern suddenly break upfield through Salihamidzic, a move which is only stopped by Viera on the edge of the Arsenal box. Free kick.
18 Bayern's free kick rebounds off the Arsenal wall and the ball is cleared.
22 Ashley Cole breaks forward through midfield, playing with confidence and composure, so much so that he tries a shot from around 25 yds out, which balloons high over the bar.
24 Bayern are starting to make bright counters. They're helped by Manninger, who sends a back pass from Viera straight into the path of Scholl, who fails to capitalise on the chance.
28 Another Arsenal attack is stopped on the edge of the Bayern area by a foul on Ljungberg by Sforza (who receives yellow card for his troubles). Pires dummies the free kick, leaving it to Henry to shoot into the wall.
30 Ljungberg is causing the bayern team all kinds of problems, attacking from midfield. On this occassion he skips past Linke on the touchline, cutting the ball back for Kanu, who fires wide on the nearpost.
33 Salihamidzic takes the ball forward into the Arsenal half, only to be brought down by Cole. Tarnat's free kick - from 35 yds out - is ineffectual, hoofed away by the Arsenal defence on the edge of the box.
35 Arsenal threaten the Bayern defence yet again. They get into the Bayern box through Pires, who cuts it back. Grimandi takes too long on the ball, and is forced to play it across to Luzhny. The move breaks down, the ball going out for the Gunners fourth corner. Pires takes it, and yet again the Bayern defence display vampiric tendencies before the ball falls to Adams, whose header is deflected onto the post before Bayern hustle it away.
39 Bayern's best chance comes after a deep ball falls to the feet of Elber, who lays it back to Scholl. His shot narrowly curls past the wrong side of the post.
42 Salihamidzic and Cole are having a right old tussle on the Arsenal left, Cole bringing the Bosnian down again. The resulting free kick is played into the Arsenal box, only for Linke to head high and wide.
45 The half is played out by Arsenal, whose dominance over the first half will give Ottmar Hitzfeld something to say to his players in the dressing room.

46 Substitution Bayern's Paulo Sergio comes on for Sagnol at the start of the second half.
47 A Bayern attack moves into the Arsenal half, and Effenberg's ball into the Arsenal box has to be scrambled away.
48 Pires takes Arsenal's seventh corner (Bayern haven't had one), only for Kanu to head wide.
50 Arsenal on the attack yet again through Viera, who threads a beautiful low ball into the path of Ljungberg, whose shot hits the side netting.
52 End-to-end stuff at the moment, with Effenberg doing his best to get his team into dangerous positions. Arsenal look equally dangerous on the break. Ljungberg is continuing to give the Germans problems.
54 GOAL Henry breaks free down the right, but with no immediate support. He holds the ball up well until Kanu arrives at the edge of the box, passing perfectly into the Nigerian's path. Kanu smashes the ball wide of the diving Kahn and into the corner. Cracking goal.
56 GOAL After the restart, Bayern get a free kick on the Arsenal left. Effenberg crosses the ball into the box, landing at the feet of Elber. He can't control it, so he pokes it back to Tarnat on the edge of the area, who lashes a finely judged shot inside the near post. Back to a one-goal margin.
60 The match is becoming very competitive, with hard tackles going in on both sides. It's also more evenly balanced than in the first half, Bayern starting to show their their capabilities.
64 GOAL Bayern get a free kick five yards outside Arsenal's box. After a dummy - for which an Arsenal player is booked for encroachment - Scholl floats a delightful ball over the wall, leaving Manninger stranded and looking on as it goes in the top corner.
68 Sergio has a chance from a long ball, but is unable to test Manninger.
70 Jeremies and Grimandi are involved in a scuffle off the ball and, although it's Jeremies who wrestles the Frenchman to the ground, the referee decides to book Grimandi.
75 Substitution Wenger sends on Wiltord for Pires.
76 Scholl gets free in the Arsenal box, and tries to turn Cole. The young defender is up to the task, though, and manges to shepherd the German international away from the danger zone.
78 Wiltord makes an impression almost straight away, firing a low shot on target, which Kahn collects gratefully.
80 Substitution Lauren comes on for a stiff-looking Luzhny.
82 Substitution Zickler comes on for Scholl, who has looked one of Bayern's best players.
84 Wiltord's fresh legs are giving the Bayern defence some problems, and he wins a corner. A searching ball deep into the box is finally headed away from the queue of Arsenal players itching for a chance on goal.
86 Elber goes down theatrically, Adams nearly taking his shirt off in attempting to lift him from the ground. The free kick comes to nought, much to the crowd's joy.
88 Both teams are trying to find the space to produce somethig to decide the match. Jeremies gets his fully deserved yellow card at last for a foul on Ljungberg.
90 It's all Arsenal in the final minutes, with Ljungberg still the driving force. A free kick for Arsenal goes the other way, after Keown jostles the Bayern defence a little too much. Wenger is not happy.
92 Referee blows the whistle for full time. A point dropped for Arsenal?
Arsenal 2 - 2 Bayern Munich

Pires dummies the free kick, leaving it to Henry to shoot into the wall. 30 Ljungberg is causing the bayern team all kinds of problems, attacking from midfield. On this occassion he skips past Linke on the touchline, cutting the ball back for Kanu, who fires wide on the nearpost. 33 Salihamidzic takes the ball forward into the Arsenal half, only to be brought down by Cole. Tarnat's free kick - from 35 yds out - is ineffectual, hoofed away by the Arsenal defence on the edge of the box. 35 Arsenal threaten the Bayern defence yet again. They get into the Bayern box through Pires, who cuts it back. Grimandi takes too long on the ball, and is forced to play it across to Luzhny. The move breaks down, the ball going out for the Gunners fourth corner. Pires takes it, and yet again the Bayern defence display vampiric tendencies before the ball falls to Adams, whose header is deflected onto the post before Bayern hustle it away. 39 Bayern's best chance comes after a deep ball falls to the feet of Elber, who lays it back to Scholl. His shot narrowly curls past the wrong side of the post. 42 Salihamidzic and Cole are having a right old tussle on the Arsenal left, Cole bringing the Bosnian down again. The resulting free kick is played into the Arsenal box, only for Linke to head high and wide. 45 The half is played out by Arsenal, whose dominance over the first half will give Ottmar Hitzfeld something to say to his players in the dressing room. 46 Substitution Bayern's Paulo Sergio comes on for Sagnol at the start of the second half. 47 A Bayern attack moves into the Arsenal half, and Effenberg's ball into the Arsenal box has to be scrambled away. 48 Pires takes Arsenal's seventh corner (Bayern haven't had one), only for Kanu to head wide. 50 Arsenal on the attack yet again through Viera, who threads a beautiful low ball into the path of Ljungberg, whose shot hits the side netting. 52 End-to-end stuff at the moment, with Effenberg doing his best to get his team into dangerous positions. Arsenal look equally dangerous on the break. Ljungberg is continuing to give the Germans problems. 54 GOAL Henry breaks free down the right, but with no immediate support. He holds the ball up well until Kanu arrives at the edge of the box, passing perfectly into the Nigerian's path. Kanu smashes the ball wide of the diving Kahn and into the corner. Cracking goal. 56 GOAL After the restart, Bayern get a free kick on the Arsenal left. Effenberg crosses the ball into the box, landing at the feet of Elber. He can't control it, so he pokes it back to Tarnat on the edge of the area, who lashes a finely judged shot inside the near post. Back to a one-goal margin. 60 The match is becoming very competitive, with hard tackles going in on both sides. It's also more evenly balanced than in the first half, Bayern starting to show their their capabilities. 64 GOAL Bayern get a free kick five yards outside Arsenal's box. After a dummy - for which an Arsenal player is booked for encroachment - Scholl floats a delightful ball over the wall, leaving Manninger stranded and looking on as it goes in the top corner. 68 Sergio has a chance from a long ball, but is unable to test Manninger. 70 Jeremies and Grimandi are involved in a scuffle off the ball and, although it's Jeremies who wrestles the Frenchman to the ground, the referee decides to book Grimandi. 75 Substitution Wenger sends on Wiltord for Pires. 76 Scholl gets free in the Arsenal box, and tries to turn Cole. The young defender is up to the task, though, and manges to shepherd the German international away from the danger zone. 78 Wiltord makes an impression almost straight away, firing a low shot on target, which Kahn collects gratefully. 80 Substitution Lauren comes on for a stiff-looking Luzhny. 82 Substitution Zickler comes on for Scholl, who has looked one of Bayern's best players. 84 Wiltord's fresh legs are giving the Bayern defence some problems, and he wins a corner. A searching ball deep into the box is finally headed away from the queue of Arsenal players itching for a chance on goal. 86 Elber goes down theatrically, Adams nearly taking his shirt off in attempting to lift him from the ground. The free kick comes to nought, much to the crowd's joy. 88 Both teams are trying to find the space to produce somethig to decide the match. Jeremies gets his fully deserved yellow card at last for a foul on Ljungberg. 90 It's all Arsenal in the final minutes, with Ljungberg still the driving force. A free kick for Arsenal goes the other way, after Keown jostles the Bayern defence a little too much. Wenger is not happy. 92 Referee blows the whistle for full time. A point dropped for Arsenal? Arsenal 2 - 2 Bayern Munich

webTitle: Survey finds charities are not cutting costs

fields.headline: Survey finds charities are not cutting costs
fields.trailText: Annual charity survey finds little evidence of cost cutting and that only 30% of charities use the internet for fundraising. By Nicola Hill
fields.body:
Only 30% of charities use the internet for fundraising, according to a survey of 150 charities.

The annual charity survey, which looks at how charities generate income and reduce costs, conducted by solicitors Charles Russell, also found little evidence of efforts to cut costs.

Despite public concern about too many charities, 87% said they are not considering merging. An equal proportion is not planning to reduce the workforce and 67% are not anticipating any reorganisation of their charity.

Senior representatives of charities said the main priorities for raising money were maintaining investment income, applying for public funding and securing income from grant-making bodies.

A surprising 47% of respondents did not see organising appeals as important and 53% did not plan to exploit intellectual property as a way of raising money. Only 48% thought legacy income was important.

However 42% are considering using more volunteers. But David Green, head of the employment group at Charles Russell, warned that volunteers should not be seen as cheap labour. "Care must be taken by employers not to create more overheads and potential causes for legal claims by making the wrong arrangements with volunteers," he said.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Sabine
fields.trailText: I read that you'll be travelling all across the US by train - that's a great plan, I've done it too! You'll see the most beautiful landscapes: no highways next to you, you'll travel through the midst of nature - the tours through the Rocky Mountains or through New Mexico and Arizona are simply breathtaking.
fields.body:
Hi Sam,
You are probably now (almost) in New York, I hope you'll enjoy it! I just wanted to write you because I read that you'll be travelling all across the US by train - that's a great plan, I've done it too! I don't know how much you know about the US railway system, so maybe I should warn you by saying that in its normal condition, it's much worse than the British Rail system after the Hatfield crash. Delays of many hours or even days are a normal feature of a trip with Amtrak. If you tell Americans you take the train there, they'll think your crazy (no, you're just european!!! You will probably also be the only person walking through cities except for places like New York and San Francisco which are comparatively 'european' cities). But let them think what they want, you have a great plan. I can assure you that my Amtrak-trips were the greatest part of studying in the States for a couple of months last year. You'll see the most beautiful landscapes with no highways next to you; you'll travel through the midst of nature - the tours through the Rocky Mountains or through New Mexico and Arizona are simply breathtaking. The Amtrak trains are huge compared to european trains, and they make these wonderful warning noises when they drive through cities. You will get to meet lots of different people on these trains (many of whom will be making the first train trip of their life, no matter what their age!), and you can sleep pretty well on the regular seats (trains are mostly not very crowded).

Well, I just envy you for being able to make that trip, and if you get stuck for eight hours just 10 minutes before a station and are not allowed to get off - don't panic, it's part of the Amtrak experience. Ask them for a reimbursement and just enjoy the social interaction that takes place in such situations! And maybe you'll just be really lucky and everything will go on time; even better! Anyway, I'm sure you'll have a great trip and I'm looking forward to reading about it on the Guardian website!

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Clara
fields.trailText: My best advice for you would be to keep a record of everything you do. A diary, photos and any little souvenir you think is relevant. NB: don't carry around a didgeridoo - too many people do and I think they all regret it!
fields.body:
Sam,
I feel like we have swapped lives! Two years ago, I had just returned from a year's trip round the world (the best year of my life). Now I am a civil servant in a large government department - bizarrely, having just applied to get into the press office! - with the only travel I do every day on the northern line! Ugh, I know where I would rather be.

My best advice for you would be to keep a record of everything you do. A diary, photos and any little souvenir you think is relevant. For me, it was shells - they're small (ie can fit into a rucksack) and pretty, and take me back to the sea in an instant. NB: don't carry around a didgeridoo - too many people do and I think they all regret it! My second piece of advice is: talk to everyone. My trip was made by the people I met. My third piece of advice is: take earplugs. Without a doubt, the best piece of equipment I had.

Finally - if you want to swim with dolphins (was it you? I know it was one of the three of you) then Kaikoura (NZ) is the place to do it. I spent nine months in total in New Zealand so have loads of advice if you need it. In fact, I am a total NZ bore so I won't start.....

Besides, my colleague Rachel needs to use the laptop. I'm not sure which government department you were in, but this one is still slightly behind the times on our networked IT system so I have to use a laptop for emails.

Enjoy your trip!

fields.headline: Wild globalisation
fields.standfirst:
Irresponsible Americans? A leading academic predicts an anarchic future for the rest of us, while green activists call for radical action

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The breakdown of the meeting on climate change in the Hague and the continuing uncertainty surrounding the American presidency mark a new and dangerous point in international affairs.
fields.body:
The breakdown of the meeting on climate change in the Hague and the continuing uncertainty surrounding the American presidency mark a new and dangerous point in international affairs. The world's major states cannot agree on policies to deal with global warming. The United States faces years of indecisive government, with Washington paralysed by score-settling and legislative gridlock. Against this background, there can be no concerted action to cope with the environmental crisis. The world is set on a course of wild globalisation.

In itself, the collapse of the climate talks two weeks ago in the Hague is not particularly significant. The meeting was an attempt to ratify the 1997 Kyoto convention on reducing greenhouse gases. Its failure has been widely put at the door of the Americans, but the Europeans were probably equally to blame in not following up concessions offered by the American delegation in the later stages of the talks.

Whoever was most at fault, it is vital to understand that the Kyoto protocol is itself a wholly inadequate response to the hazards facing the global environment. The protocol aimed to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases to a few percentage points beneath their levels a decade ago. But even if that goal could be achieved, it would not halt climate change. The consensus among scientists is that global warming is already irreversible. According to some estimates, levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere would double even if every country in the world cut its emissions below 1990 levels.

In fact, there is not the remotest prospect of this happening. It is not just that imposing the necessary fiscal measures is politically impossible in the US, and - as has been evident since the fuel protests in September - far from easy in Europe. It is that climate change and industrialisation in developing countries are indissolubly linked. China and India account for more greenhouse gases than the whole of Europe. The impact of industrial development in such developing countries on global warming is rising steeply. Yet, no doubt rightly, developing countries are not covered by the Kyoto protocol. It is grossly inequitable to demand that poor countries should impose controls on their industries which many of the richest countries flout daily. Why should the path of development that the world's richest countries adopted - at whatever cost to the environment - be closed to its poorest?

Insofar as it is man-made, global warming flows inexorably from worldwide industrialisation. It is only in countries where industrial production has largely collapsed (as it has in Russia) that greenhouse gas emissions have fallen substantially. None of the world's poor countries can afford to curb industrial development. Despite valiant efforts at family planning, most of them have populations that are growing rapidly. They have no choice but to go all-out for economic growth. Yet, in a cruel paradox, it is the world's poorest countries that stand to suffer most from climate change. Some, such as Bangladesh and Samoa, face being flooded while others, such as Nigeria, face being ravaged by desert. In a worst-case scenario that some scientists are taking seriously, billions of people in developing countries will face a more inhospitable environment before the 21st century is over.

Against this background, the collapse of the climate talks is a warning. The level of international cooperation that is required to make even a dent in the world's worsening environmental problems is going to be increasingly difficult to achieve. Even if, as Michael Meacher has urged, the Kyoto process is restarted, it will be done in daunting circumstances. Whatever the outcome of the legal charades that are being played out in Washington, the incoming American president is unlikely to be able to persuade Congress to accept environmental measures of the kind that the American delegation seemed ready to contemplate in the Hague. The window of opportunity that may have existed a couple of weeks ago has closed.

It seems almost inevitable that the next American administration will be more inward looking, and more hamstrung by Congress, than that led by Mr Clinton. If so, the future is bleak. To think that the rest of the world can go ahead and solve its environmental problems without the Americans is mere folly. It is not only that the US has itself an enormous impact on the global environment. The whole structure of global governance - the WTO, the IMF, the World Bank and so on - is an American construction. Without active American involvement, nothing can be done to reform it. The risk is that it will become weak and irrelevant, as - led by the US - more and more countries try to solve their problems unilaterally.

Some environmentalists welcome this outcome. And it is true that it means the end of the Washington consensus (the belief that the best framework for globalisation is a worldwide free market). That belief has led to repeated disasters, as countries with differing needs and circumstances have been forced into implementing rigid and ineffective free market policies. But, contrary to the fond hopes of some environmentalists, the break-up of the flawed Washington consensus does not mean that a wiser approach to global development is on the horizon. It means that we are in for an anarchic free-for-all, in which globalisation will go on unchecked.

The dangers of wild globalisation are legion. If world markets become more turbulent, pressures for protectionism may be irresistible, particularly in the US. Most worryingly, wars may be fought over shrinking resources such as oil and even, in some regions, water. With the re-emergence of such Malthusian conflicts, international cooperation may be tested to destruction. The lesson of the Hague, and of political paralysis in the US, is that it is unwise to expect too much of our political leaders. In a time of wild globalisation, our best hope may be that new technologies will be developed which enable technical fixes to be found for environmental problems that have proved to be politically insoluble.

• John Gray is professor of European thought at the LSE.

webTitle: Mandelson a disaster says Sinn Fein

fields.headline: Mandelson a disaster says Sinn Fein
fields.trailText: Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's education minister, yesterday launched a scathing attack on Peter Mandelson, describing him as a "peace wrecker" who was ill-equipped to resolve the deadlock in the peace process.
fields.body:
Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's education minister, yesterday launched a scathing attack on Peter Mandelson, describing him as a "peace wrecker" who was ill-equipped to resolve the deadlock in the peace process.

In his most outspoken attack on the Blair government, Mr McGuinness denounced the Northern Ireland secretary as a "political disaster" who had spent his time in Belfast courting unionism.

Speaking in Australia, Mr McGuinness said: "We have a peace wrecker rather than a peace maker. If the present crisis is to be resolved I very much doubt whether Peter Mandelson has the integrity to recognise this, much less acknowledge it. In short [he] is a political disaster."

Mr McGuinness rounded on Mr Mandelson for watering down the Patten report on policing and for failing to reduce security measures in Northern Ireland. His remarks underlined the tensions between republicans and the government which were exacerbated in October when David Trimble imposed a ban on Sinn Fein attending meetings of a special cross-border ministerial council.

Although Mr Mandelson criticised Mr Trimble's action, Sinn Fein is angry with the government for stepping up pressure on the IRA to negotiate with the international disarmament body. Sinn Fein says it is wrong to demand that the IRA should "engage" with the commission when the government has allegedly failed to live up to its commitments to scale down security measures, particularly in border areas.

Sinn Fein is also threatening to boycott the new police board unless the government introduces fundamental concessions in a special plan which will implement the Police Act. Sinn Fein wants a commitment that the police board will have greater independence and an assurance that Chris Patten's recommendation for a neutral badge will be implemented. Mr Mandelson will rule on the badge if the police board cannot reach agreement.

The government yesterday dismissed Mr McGuinness's criticism. A Northern Ireland Office spokesman said: "Since Peter Mandelson came to Northern Ireland we have achieved devolution and the power-sharing executive."

One source suggested that Mr McGuinness's remarks demonstrated Sinn Fein's frustration after Mr Patten called on nationalists to end their campaign against the Police Act and to join the new force.

There are signs the SDLP might heed Mr Patten's advice and take its three seats on the police board. Tony Blair is said to have held a productive meeting last week with Seamus Mallon, the party's deputy leader, who outlined a seven-point plan which would allow the SDLP to join the board.

His demands included independent judicial reviews into the controversial killings of three Roman Catholics, including that of the Belfast solicitor Pat Finucane, and a commitment to implement the Patten recommendations on merging the RUC's anti-terrorist special branch with its CID division.

A government source said ministers were relaxed about Mr Mallon's demands. It is understood Mr Mallon was told the government would keep open the option of judicial inquiries into the killings once a series of investigations had been completed. Sir Ronnie Flanagan, the RUC chief constable, is also expected to outline a timetable for the merging of special branch and CID within the next few weeks.

The political atmosphere in Northern Ireland is intensifying ahead of next week's visit to the province by President Clinton. There are hopes that the SDLP will make a decision on taking its seats on the police board to coincide with the president's visit.

The row between Sinn Fein and the government came as John Hume, the leader of the SDLP, formally resigned his seat in the Northern Ireland assembly yesterday. His decision, announced in August, will allow him to concentrate on his work as MP for Foyle and as an MEP .

webTitle: Won over by Westminster Independent MP eyes new seat

fields.headline: Won over by Westminster Independent MP eyes new seat
fields.trailText:
Martin Bell, the white-suited Independent MP for Tatton, heightened speculation that he
         will stand for Parliament again last night after announcing a press conference to discuss
         his plans in a Tory-held constitutency later this week.
fields.body:
Martin Bell, the white-suited Independent MP for Tatton, heightened speculation that he will stand for Parliament again last night after announcing a press conference to discuss his plans in a Tory-held constitutency later this week.

The former BBC war correspondent is to meet journalists on Friday at a hotel in Brentwood and Ongar, an Essex constituency that is one of the Tories' safest seats.

The move comes after local Conservatives approached him expressing concern that some 200 members of an evangelical church had flooded the local constituency and voted their members into key posts.

Mr Bell, who defeated Neil Hamilton, the former Tory minister at the centre of the cash-for-questions scandal, at the last election, promised in 1997 that he would not seek re-election in his existing con stituency. But the 62-year-old has been looking for a new seat after admitting that being an MP was "very agreeable, working in this wonderful palace, with the illusion of being at the centre of things".

Brentwood and Ongar, which had a Tory majority of 9,690 in 1997, was investigated by Central Office after claims that the local Peniel Pentecostal Church had conducted a campaign of "entryism" in order to win control of its Conservative association. The investigation found no proof of malpractice and Eric Pickles, the sitting MP, has denied the group has undue influence.

fields.headline: General Augusto Pinochet
fields.standfirst: Lord Lamont has been honoured by the Pinochet Foundation. Here's our guide to the best sites on Chile's former dictator
fields.trailText: NetNotes: Lord Lamont has been honoured by the Pinochet Foundation. Here's our guide to the best sites on Chile's former dictator.
fields.body:
1. Former chancellor Norman Lamont has received a medal for his "extraordinary and valiant attitude" in defending Chile's former dictator Augusto Pinochet.

2. Lamont, hailed as a "prominent Englishman" by the Pinochet Foundation, is chiefly remembered in Britain for presiding over sterling's humiliating ejection from the European exchange rate mechanism on Black Wednesday, then refusing to resign as chancellor.

3. Pinochet is to stand trial in Chile accused of a litany of human rights abuses including kidnapping, murder, torture, illegal burial and illicit association. But don't let that put you off.

4. Pinochet seized power from Salvadore Allende's democratically elected leftwing government in a US-backed military coup in 1973. He ruled Chile as a dictator until 1990.

5. The general's prosecution in his home country follows his arrest in London in 1998. Spanish judge Baltasar Garzon had requested his extradition to face trial for crimes against Spanish citizens.

6. But after 18 months of legal wrangling, Pinochet was sent home to Chile in March this year after the home secretary, Jack Straw, accepted a medical report that he was not well enough to stand trial.

7. Apart from Lamont, Pinochet's other pals in Britain include former prime minister Margaret Thatcher, who "took tea" with the despot and addressed a rally of Pinochet fans at a Tory party conference. Pity his British victims weren't around to join in the fun.

8. The poorly general heroically summoned the strength to attend a homecoming rally and again defied medical experts at his birthday party.

9. But the mood had changed in Chile during the senator-for-life's absence, and he was stripped of his immunity so he could be tried for his alleged atrocities.

10. What of the newly-decorated Lamont? The ex-chancellor is expected to concentrate on his career as a talented songwriter. Oh no, hang on, that's a different Norman Lamont. The one I'm thinking of looks more like a badger.

fields.headline: Hague pledges £8bn tax cuts
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague today pledged that a Conservative government would cut tax by £8bn over its first three years, but still match Labour's planned spending on schools.
fields.body:
William Hague today pledged that a Conservative government would cut tax by £8bn over its first three years, but still match Labour's planned spending on schools.

The Conservatives have already said that they will match Labour's spending plans for the national health service. Today's pledge puts in place another key element of their tax and spending proposals.

Today's announcement was intended to counter Labour's claims that Tory plans would mean cuts of £16bn to public services.

Speaking at the Institute of Economic Affairs conference in Whitehall, Mr Hague said: "Whether Labour like it or not, our plans can be achieved while continuing to spend more on necessary public services. No savings will come from either the NHS budget or the schools budget."

He added: "The next Conservative government will match Labour's spending plans on the NHS and schools pound for pound ... Our plans mean that the next Conservative government will be able to give £8bn or so of savings back to the hard-working people of this country by reducing their taxes, which means the most serious and solid programme of taxation ever offered by a political party in Britain."

Mr Hague's speech was followed by an address from the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, in which he detailed how the Tories would find many of the savings to finance their tax cuts.

Last week Westminster was awash with speculation that Mr Portillo was disillusioned with politics, but today he and his leader were at pains to emphasise their unity of purpose, taking time to be photographed together and sitting next to one another on the podium.

Labour sought to hijack the event, parking an advertising van outside the venue carrying a poster portraying Mr Hague and Mr Portillo, accompanied by the slogan: "Mr Boom and Bust, would you trust these two men with the economy?"

webTitle: Minister announces £18m funding package to target domestic abuse

fields.headline: Minister announces £18m funding package to target domestic abuse
fields.trailText: David Mitchell looks at measures to tackle violence in the home in Scotland
fields.body:
A major drive to tackle the growing problem of domestic abuse in Scotland has been launched by first minister Henry McLeish with the unveiling of an £18.3 million funding package and a new public awareness campaign.

The package includes £10 million to provide 300 extra refuge places for women and children and £4.5 million to take forward a number of Scotland-wide initiatives, including prevention strategies, better access to services and improved data collection.

A further £3 million will help provide specialist staff for children, information in ethnic community languages and for surgeries in rural areas, while £818,000 goes to women's aid groups to improve facilities for children and young people, and disability access to refuges and offices.

The funding announcement follows the recommendations of the Scottish Partnership on Domestic Abuse, a multi-agency group formed in 1998 to set minimum levels of service and look at the needs of special groups, such as ethnic minority communities and women in rural areas.

Mr McLeish said: We all have a role in addressing domestic abuse. It is a crime, it is a violation of human rights and it should not be tolerated or excused. We want to create a society where we can all live free from fear, especially in our homes.

He also unveiled a new advertising campaign, to be run over Christmas and New Year, which will build on the executives previous award-winning campaign. Using strong black and white images, it will reinforce the message that domestic abuse does not recognise social class or age, is not necessarily physical and it affects children.

Raising awareness about domestic abuse inevitably leads to a rise in the demand for services. That is why we are funding a comprehensive strategy to help develop services both at national and local level, he said.

Research has shown that the previous campaign impacted on public attitudes, increased use of the national helpline and led to a rise in the number of incidents reported to the police and women's aid.

The funding package follows the launch of a Scotland-wide strategy to eliminate domestic abuse. Produced by the Scottish Partnership on Domestic Abuse, it includes a three-year action plan, good practice guidelines and service standards, and what people approaching agencies about domestic abuse should expect.

Scottish Womens Aid, which represents 39 local womens aid groups across Scotland, hopes to gain a large chunk of the new money for refuge places. Last year requests for help rose by 3% and it was forced to find alternative accommodation for 3,215 women and 4,318 children because there werent enough places. But while welcoming the cash injection, it repeated its call for more secure core funding.

The Scottish Executive is obviously taking domestic abuse seriously and giving it a high profile. The message has been given out to abused women and children, and to the perpetrators of domestic abuse, that Scotland will not tolerate it, said national worker Evelyn Hay.

But we hope that in the future they will consider secure core funding for local womens aid groups to provide essential services. At the moment, local groups have to approach local authorities for funding and responses can vary widely from area to area.

They are living sometimes from year to year and having to fundraise themselves. That doesnt allow us to offer the best service to women. Advertising campaigns and raised public awareness increase the demand for services but you need extra resources put into them.

Social work directors have also called for more secure funding. Domestic abuse is a long-term issue and it needs long-term energy. If they really want to see a change, the money has to be more mainstream. Ring-fenced funding would ensure that it gets the attention it deserves across Scotland, said Harriet Dempster, spokesperson for the Association of Directors of Social Work.

Dempster said domestic abuse was a serious issue for Scotland. Significant problems with alcohol abuse made women more vulnerable since it could often be the trigger for violence. The executives commitment to taking the issue seriously is very much welcome but to have an impact it has to be linked in with other strategies, such as social inclusion and childrens services plans, and not seen as a separate or peripheral activity, she said.

webTitle: Tories head for winter of discontent

fields.headline: Tories head for winter of discontent
fields.standfirst: The air of unreality surrounding Tory plans for £8bn in tax cuts is a sign that the party has  succumbed to despair about the next election, writes Julian Glover
fields.trailText: Comment: The air of unreality surrounding Tory plans for £8bn in tax cuts is a sign that the party has succumbed to despair about the next election, writes Julian Glover
fields.body:
It's not the despair. I can stand the despair. It's the hope," cried John Cleese in the film Clockwise, as he raced to avoid a disaster that looked certain to everyone else but him.

Today's Tory party is in the same state. It has despair by the bucket-load. Any objective analysis of the party's prospects at next year's general election suggests that it is heading for a second landslide defeat.

Optimistic Labour MPs are even wondering whether the government might not increase its majority. That isn't good news for the Conservative party - but at least it is the sort of news Tory MPs are used to. They know how to cope with it: stiff upper lip and all that.

But creeping onto their horizon is a kind of hope. It is this which has caused the party to throw a collective wobbly this week. Suddenly the stakes seem higher and the issues worth fighting over.

The hope began to arrive in the autumn, when the petrol crisis briefly put the opposition ahead in the polls. Then there was an unexpectedly upbeat mood at the Tory party conference. The poll lead has gone but now the government faces disruption on the rail network: the sort of issue that ought to drive its support down in the polls.

In the House of Lords, too, the opposition almost managed to derail the government's legislative programme. Though it failed, it did delay the Queen's speech and warm up the issue of the part-privatisation of air traffic control.

But all this opportunity has come to naught. Labour's lead is back at 10 points and the party won three by-elections last week without breaking sweat.

Conservatives, having only just got used to the idea that they might recover in time for the election, are now faced with the possibility that things may yet get worse. Hence their deep gloom.

This has come across strongly in the odd behaviour of the shadow chancellor Michael Portillo. By both ruling himself in and out of contention in a future contest for the party leadership he has left Tories more bewildered than ever about their future.

And in announcing today a programme of tax cuts worth £8bn he has shown that he has already written off the election. Not that the cuts are a bad idea in themselves: they differentiate the opposition from the government and will appeal to some voters.

But the proposals have a horribly limp air about them. New Labour, when in opposition, would never have put forward something so half-baked.

Among the most obvious faults are the doubts about where the £8bn will come from. £1bn of the savings is supposed to come from efficiency savings in government. No one really thinks large sums like this can be found easily.

It is a reliable rule that when a party talks of attacking benefit fraud and cutting red tape, it has run out anything sensible to say. Add to this is the opposition's promise to cut the price of beer and it begins to look a very desperate project indeed. Many Tories - perhaps not the party's leader - know this.

That fact, and their knowledge that the government has been let off a painful hook, means that for Conservatives at least this will be a winter of discontent.

webTitle: Catholics try to halt tests on cloning

fields.headline: Catholics try to halt tests on cloning
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The Catholic University in Rome is to set up a research centre in an attempt to provide an alternative to the cloning of human embryos for medical research, it has emerged.
fields.body:
The Catholic University in Rome is to set up a research centre in an attempt to provide an alternative to the cloning of human embryos for medical research, it has emerged.

The university plans to create a "placenta bank" to store stem cells which they hope will allow them to regenerate human organs and tissue without the need for cloning.

The development comes as MPs in the UK prepare to debate a proposed extension to the 1990 Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act which would allow therapeutic cloning, the creation of embryos with a genetic make-up identical to a living adult for medical research. The law in Britain already allows research on human embryos up to 14 days old for fertility treatments.

Scientists believe research into stem cells harvested from embryos could lead to treatments for illness including Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's.

But the Catholic church has protested that therapeutic cloning will lead to cloned human beings because the basic scientific method is the same.

The alternative research facility was revealed yesterday by Cardinal Thomas Winning, the leader of Scotland's Roman Catholics and chairman of the bioethics committee of the Bishops' Conferences of the UK and Ireland. He said the placenta bank offered possibilities which could prove greater than those in therapeutic cloning.

Writing in The Herald, Cardinal Winning said: "In recent months, it has become increasingly clear that there is an ethical alternative to cloning embryos. This involves the harvesting of cells either from an adult or from a newborn baby's umbilical cord. Such cells can then be "trained" to grow in the same way as embryo-clone cells and may offer the same hope of treatment without any of the ethical problems associated with cloning."

A spokesman for the Catholic church in Scotland, Father Paul Murray, said they were aware that the science was not yet there to use placental or adult stem cells for therapeutic purposes, but argued that the same could be said for embryo research.

"Most of the science is still relatively far off," he said. "That is why it is a significant time in terms of choosing a particular road to go down. Our fear is that the British government has decided almost exclusively to go down the road of therapeutic cloning research on embryos."

Experts said that more work would need to be done on adult or umbilical blood stem cells before they could be said to hold the key to fighting disease.

James Lovell-Badge of the Institute of Medical Research said that, in theory, stem cells from the blood of an umbilical cord could treat diseases of the blood, but there was no evidence they could be used for anything else. It had not been shown that cells from the placenta can give rise to any other tissue type.

However there was no harm in further research in this area. "It is just a long way off in terms of any potential therapy.

"Our view generally is that we would love to do research on embryonic stem cells because we know their potential to give rise to any cell in the body. However, we would also support research on other sources of stem cells whether from an adult or foetal cord blood."

fields.headline: BBC guidelines for TalkSport's coverage
fields.trailText: How the BBC lawyers tied TalkSport's unofficial coverage in red tape. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Who says BBC lawyers don't earn their keep?

The following schedule details how the BBC's small-print merchants demanded that the audiences for different sports be notified of the nature of TalkSport's unofficial coverage.

Athletics - at the beginning and end of off-tube commentary and at 15-minute intervals throughout.

Boxing - at the beginning and immediately after the end of off-tube commentary, and between each round.

Cricket - at the beginning and end of off-tube commentary, at 15-minute intervals throughout, and within one minute of each wicket being taken (although if wickets are taken within five minutes of one another a disclaimer will not need to be given for the later of the wickets taken).

Football - at the beginning, middle and end of each half, at the beginning and end of any extra time and within one minute of each goal being scored (although if goals are scored within five minutes of one another a disclaimer will not need to be given for the later of the goals scored).

Formula 1 motor racing - at the beginning and end of the off-tube commentary, at 15-minute intervals throughout and immediately after a race is won.

Golf - at the beginning and end of the off-tube commentary, at 15-minute intervals throughout and immediately after a game is won.

Horseracing - at the beginning and immediately after the end of each race (rather than of each meeting).

Rowing - at the beginning and immediately after the end of each race and at 15-minute intervals throughout.

Rugby (league and union)- at beginning, middle and end of each half and the beginning and end of any extra time.

Tennis - at the beginning and immediately after the end of each match (or if only part of a match is broadcast, the beginning and end of the parts broadcast) and at 15-minute intervals throughout.

All other events* - at the beginning and end of each off-tube commentary and at 15-minute intervals throughout.

*For the avoidance of doubt this category includes (but is not limited to) wrestling, badminton, equestrian events, swimming, volleyball, archery, netball, hockey, diving, darts, bowls, snooker and pool.

The following schedule details how the BBC's small-print merchants demanded that the audiences for different sports be notified of the nature of TalkSport's unofficial coverage. Athletics - at the beginning and end of off-tube commentary and at 15-minute intervals throughout. Boxing - at the beginning and immediately after the end of off-tube commentary, and between each round. Cricket - at the beginning and end of off-tube commentary, at 15-minute intervals throughout, and within one minute of each wicket being taken (although if wickets are taken within five minutes of one another a disclaimer will not need to be given for the later of the wickets taken). Football - at the beginning, middle and end of each half, at the beginning and end of any extra time and within one minute of each goal being scored (although if goals are scored within five minutes of one another a disclaimer will not need to be given for the later of the goals scored). Formula 1 motor racing - at the beginning and end of the off-tube commentary, at 15-minute intervals throughout and immediately after a race is won. Golf - at the beginning and end of the off-tube commentary, at 15-minute intervals throughout and immediately after a game is won. Horseracing - at the beginning and immediately after the end of each race (rather than of each meeting). Rowing - at the beginning and immediately after the end of each race and at 15-minute intervals throughout. Rugby (league and union)- at beginning, middle and end of each half and the beginning and end of any extra time. Tennis - at the beginning and immediately after the end of each match (or if only part of a match is broadcast, the beginning and end of the parts broadcast) and at 15-minute intervals throughout. All other events* - at the beginning and end of each off-tube commentary and at 15-minute intervals throughout. *For the avoidance of doubt this category includes (but is not limited to) wrestling, badminton, equestrian events, swimming, volleyball, archery, netball, hockey, diving, darts, bowls, snooker and pool.

fields.headline: Radio rivals claim sports victory
fields.standfirst: Dec 5: TalkSport hails victory in sports row
fields.trailText: 5pm update:TalkSport and the BBC claimed victory after today's out-of-court settlement over commentary of sporting events, writes Jason Deans. Dec 5: TalkSport claims victory in sports row
fields.body:
Both sides were claiming victory after today's out-of-court settlement allowing commercial radio station TalkSport to provide unofficial commentary on sporting events to which the BBC holds exclusive rights.

Kelvin MacKenzie, chairman and chief executive of TalkSport owner the Wireless Group, declared himself to be "very chirpy" about the deal, saying the BBC had got a "bloody nose" in the High Court action, which the corporation itself initiated.

But despite the deal, TalkSport is unlikely to repeat the tactics it adopted for Euro 2000 and the Sydney Olympics, when commentary on the events was provided from a hotel room TV, with simulated crowd effects.

Mr MacKenzie said: "The chances of us doing it again are very small. But any time there's a lockout, like with the EBU [and Euro 2000 and Olympic rights], we will do it."

Jenny Abramsky, the BBC director of radio, said the agreement was a "victory for sport".

Ms Abramsky added: "The whole market for broadcast rights would have collapsed and sport might have lost a great deal of money if this hijacking of sports events had been allowed to continue unchecked."

TalkSport was unable to bid for the radio rights to Euro 2000 and the Olympics because it was not a member of the EBU, the umbrella organisation for European public service broadcasters that sub-licenses media rights to major sporting events.

Mr MacKenzie said he was "very confident" TalkSport would now finally be admitted to the EBU, after being refused membership three times.

webTitle: TalkSport hails victory in sports row with BBC

fields.headline: TalkSport hails victory in sports row
fields.trailText: Radio station TalkSport has claimed a victory in its battle to cover sporting events to which the BBC holds the rights. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Radio station TalkSport, which is owned by Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group, has claimed a victory in its battle to cover sporting events to which the BBC holds the rights.

The deal follows legal action taken by the BBC after an incident in June it emerged the station was covering Euro2000 football matches by simply watching the games in an Amsterdam hotel TV.

TalkSport and the BBC today reached a deal allowing the commercial radio outfit to commentate on sporting events by describing the action it sees on TV, as long as it frequently makes clear coverage is unofficial.

The agreement will come into play whenever the station has coverage of sporting events for which the BBC holds the rights, such as Wimbledon.

The conditions mean TalkSport will have to spell out that the commentary is unofficial, that the event is being followed on TV and how any background noise is obtained.

If the station does not comply the BBC will head to the High Court to obtain an injunction.

Listeners will have to be told the coverage is unofficial at the beginning and end of each broadcast and at 15-minute intervals, as well as during the action. In the case of football that will be after a goal is scored, or for cricket, when a wicket is taken.

TalkSport said today it planned to exercise the right to broadcast off TV every time it was excluded from the process of being able to bid for rights.

Mike Parry, head of sport for TalkSport, said: "Whenever we are shut out from the bidding process for any reason, then we will exercise our right.

"That could mean, for example, doing commentary of the Grand National off the telly from Hereford racecourse.

"We will keep all our options open - but this settlement means we are no longer going to be locked out of any major sports event by the BBC here or anywhere in the world."

The Wireless Group, which owns TalkSport, has lodged a formal complaint with the European Commission over the activities of the European Broadcasting Union, which sells TV and radio rights bundled together.

The station has been turned down three times for membership of the EBU, which meant it could not bid for the TV and radio rights for Euro 2000 and the Olympics.

webTitle: The legal battle for the White House

fields.headline: The legal battle for the White House
fields.standfirst: The US courts are deciding who will be the next US president. Derek Brown explains why
fields.trailText: The US courts are deciding who will be the next US president. We explain why.
fields.body:
What's the latest?
The US supreme court has asked the Florida supreme court to clarify its ruling allowing extended manual recounts of the vote in three counties. The Florida court will offer that clarification today. If it rescinds its earlier ruling, Gore is effectively finished.

Other, less crucial legal arguments will be heard in federal courts. In one, Bush lawyers will demand that recounts be disallowed. In another, the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People will allege that voting rights were systematically denied to black people in Florida. But it all turns on the judgment of the court in the Florida state capital, Tallahassee.

Hasn't Gore already lost his case in Florida?
On Monday, a circuit judge threw out his demand for manual recounts in the crucial three counties. But now Democrat lawyers are appealing against that ruling.

What's the latest deadline?
Florida needs to appoint its 25 electoral college voters - and therefore the president of the USA - by December 12, six days before the college conclave.

If the electoral and legal wrangling is not over by then, the strongly Republican state legislature has threatened to appoint the electors itself, as it is legally entitled to do. That will automatically send Bush to the White House.

By the way, who got the most votes?
Across the nation, vice president Al Gore got a quarter of a million more votes than governor George W Bush in an incredibly close race. He claims to have got more in Florida too, but the official tally puts the Republican ahead by 930, out of 6m.

Why does Florida matter so much?
Because US presidents are not elected directly but through an electoral college. In 48 of the 50 states, the candidate who finishes top collects all of that state's votes in the college (in the two oddballs, Maine and Nebraska, the candidate who comes second is given one of the college votes as well). As things stand, neither Gore nor Bush has yet achieved a majority in the electoral college.

How is the electoral college organised?
The college has 538 seats. A candidate needs 270 electoral college votes to win. Roughly, college votes are allocated to states by population.

As the largest state, California has 54 votes in the electoral college. New York is second with 33. Seven sparsely populated states, plus the District of Columbia, have three votes each, the minimum allowed.

Who got to vote?
All US citizens aged over 18 have the right to vote - although this is qualified by a range of conditions, including, in some states, the long-term loss of voting rights by anyone sent to prison. It is this clause that has disqualified many poor, black citizens in the southern states, including Florida.

webTitle: McGurk takes editorial control of Scotsman titles

fields.headline: McGurk takes editorial control of Scotsman titles
fields.trailText: Scotland on Sunday editor John McGurk has been made editorial director of all Scotsman titles.
fields.body:
Scotland on Sunday editor John McGurk has been made editorial director of all Scotsman titles.

This gives him overall editorial responsibility for The Scotsman, The Evening News and The Herald and Post.

His promotion, which takes effect in January, will undoubtedly lead to a fresh round of speculation about Scotsman editor Rebecca Hardy.

webTitle: Are quangos a threat to local democracy?

fields.headline: Are quangos a threat to local democracy?
fields.standfirst: Simon Parker examines the problems faced by local government in dealing with unelected bodies
fields.trailText: Watford borough council leader Vince Muspratt does not have many positive experiences of dealing with quangos. Earlier in the year, when his council opposed the siting of a new hospital that it believed would seriously inconvenience local residents, it had to deal with one health authority, two health trusts and two community health councils, each with a different view. He is still involved in discussions about improving a bottleneck junction between roads run by his county council and the Highways Agency. The two bodies are not working with each other. The list goes on.
fields.body:
Watford borough council leader Vince Muspratt does not have many positive experiences of dealing with quangos. Earlier in the year, when his council opposed the siting of a new hospital that it believed would seriously inconvenience local residents, it had to deal with one health authority, two health trusts and two community health councils, each with a different view. He is still involved in discussions about improving a bottleneck junction between roads run by his county council and the Highways Agency. The two bodies are not working with each other. The list goes on.

"The key thing about local democracy is the people's right to representation. It's exceptionally difficult to properly get people's views represented across all the bodies currently in existence," says Mr Muspratt.

A report to be launched later this week by the Local Government Information Unit, Advance of the Quango State, suggests that Watford's experience is far from unique. Not only is this lack of coordination between the country's quangos and local government hampering council efforts to get things done, but the report says the current trend of giving unelected bodies more and more power could seriously harm the role of local authorities and the principle of local democracy.

Why have quangos become so popular? Because, says report co-author and University of Birmingham academic Chris Skelcher: "Ministers are much more able to control quangos than local authorities."

Quangos currently fulfil a vast range of functions that impact heavily on the day-to-day lives of local people, from further education to housing and health. Most new policy initiatives rely on bodies such as Learning and Skills Councils, despite the fact that these organisations operate under a very relaxed regime of openness and accountability.

Only 62% of executive quangos - those such as the Environment Agency that deliver policy - are subject to a full public audit, only 3% have to release reports of their meetings, and just 15% have to hold their meetings in public. They are accountable only upwards, to Whitehall, and although councillors are sometimes represented on their boards, the report argues that this has done little to connect quangos with the communities they are intended to serve.

Despite this, quangos are beginning to challenge local government's role in delivering key policy pledges on education, social services and regeneration. Ministers are passing an unprecedented amount of schools funding directly to head teachers, to the extent that the LGIU report argues that state schools are themselves becoming quangos. Economic development powers have gone to regional development agencies and social care could soon be delivered through joint trusts set up with the NHS.

The nightmare scenario, says Chris Skelcher, is that this trend of passing more responsibilities to quangos will continue, and that councils could become little more than a low spending administrative rump - local administration, rather than local government.

The Conservatives agree. Regional spokesman Tim Loughton says his party would audit the role of all quangos to identify which bodies can be scrapped or have their functions transferred to more local organisations. It is worth noting, however, that despite its reliance on quangos, the government has actually cut their numbers since 1997.

The number of national executive quangos has remained steady at around 300. But around 60 advisory quangos have been culled, leaving 544. This, however, masks a period of flux as some bodies were wound up, rebranded or had their powers devolved to the regions. The figures do not include the host of short term policy task forces the government has set up.

The NHS national plan may prove the first step towards a solution for local government. The plan includes measures to strengthen the powers of local politicians to scrutinise the health service, and these are likely to be carried forward in the Queen's speech this week. The LGIU report recommends that this kind of scrutiny power should be extended to cover all local quangos, and that the quangos themselves should be placed under a duty to cooperate with councils. It also calls for a far tougher openness regime.

Unless these recommendations are implemented, local government may be condemned to watching its powers slipping away to unelected bodies over which authorities have little influence. As the report says: "The current mixture of token representation and cooperation does not and could not measure up to the scale of the challenge. However hard they try, local authorities are not empowered or equipped to bridge the gap between the quango state and local communities, or even to coordinate the activities of all the quangoes in their areas."
