fields.headline: Dropped, Slapped, and Piqued
fields.trailText: JONES CLEARED OF ALL ABUSE CHARGES
fields.body:
JONES CLEARED OF ALL ABUSE CHARGES

Former Southampton manager David Jones walked free from court this afternoon after all 14 charges made against him of sexually abusing boys were dropped. The judge at Liverpool Crown Court told Jones, 44, that he would "leave this court as you entered it - a free man".

The trial had earlier been halted after a witness failed to give evidence against Jones. The jury were instructed to return not guilty verdicts on two charges of indecent assault and two charges of causing actual bodily harm, before they were discharged because Jones "would not receive a fair trial before the same jury" on the ten remaining charges.

All ten of these charges were later dropped when the prosecution told the judge it "would not be right, proper or just" to seek a retrial. Upon leaving the court, Jones hugged his wife Ann and said he felt "very happy" at the outcome of what he described as a "total nightmare".

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR

Dec 5: click here

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

STANLEY: THE MAN, THE MIRACLE

So close have the Fiver and Stanley Victor Collymore become over the years that we can actually communicate telepathically. So when we woke up late on Saturday night screaming the words "Stanley's in trouble!" we knew within seconds that Stanley had been lamped in some "members only" club in Brum, probably by some lairy Blues fans. We spent the rest of the night crying. Tears of laughter that is, as we realised what a classic Stanley moment this was.

Stanley returned to training with Bradford this morning, nursing a few bruises and wincing at the newspapers which had cleverly managed to fit "nightclub beatdown" and "Ulrika Jonsson" into the same article. This being Stanley, it wasn't just the media who had to have their say. Big Bantam Geoffrey Richmond opened his ribcage to reveal: "Our hearts go out to Stan. He is a member of the Bradford City family."

Meanwhile, Boss Bantam Jim Jefferies mused: "I have had no trouble with Stan at all. One day he wasn't at training and everybody thought he wouldn't turn up but you can't blame him if his plane was directed to Manchester instead of Leeds because of fog." Of course you can't. Jim went on to reveal that he and Stanley have since reached a compromise whereby Stanley flies from the Midlands to Yorkshire (all of, ooh, 114 miles) - but the night before!

Anyway, we're not here to slag Stanley's travel arrangements. Especially when Birmingham City are around. Unable to resist sticking their tuppence/17.92 Euros worth into the debate, the club today released a statement to this effect: "Birmingham City wish to make it quite clear that it has no association with the person or persons who apparently carried out an assault on Stan Collymore as has been reported today." You mean it wasn't a sponsored hit? When Stanley's involved, wonders never cease.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I have almost had as long a career with Walkers as I did with football. They have had me doing all kinds of crazy stunts and taken the mickey out of my ears. I dread to think what they will come up with next!" - A chuckling Gary Lineker announces his new exclusive £1.5m contract to advertise Walkers Crisps. Rumours that those "crazy" crisp-manufacturing cats intend to put Gary in a basque, stuff his mouth with a plastic ball and beat him off to the point of unconsciousness remain just that.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EL TEL'S NORTHERN HELL

Poor old Terry Venables has only been working in Not London for one day, but he's already displaying the classic symptoms of the cockney in exile. That's right: the 'omesick Londoner is loudly opining on the subjects of England, foreigners and the war. Why did Match of the Day magazine have to mention Sven-Goran Eriksson when he was obviously at such a low ebb?

"By choosing to go to a foreign situation we've chosen to say we are not a power any more, but we, the FA, will show you the way forward. Show you how clever we are because we are designer people now, we're not old farts any more," sniffed an in-no-way-bitter Venables during his exclusive interview with the Ferg-less mag. "If Hoddle and Keegan had done well, I'd celebrate like mad. I've nothing against Eriksson - he looks like a gentleman - I just find it difficult. Put it this way, I don't think it's a good idea."

And after revelations like that, it was only a matter of time before Venables compared the selection of a football team to a six-year international conflict involving genocide: "It's like saying, 'We're in the war and we've got no generals. Well, what's Rommel doing? Is he available?'" Terry was then asked if his comments were slightly hypocritical given his stewardship of the Australian national team. He replied by opening his mouth and going "naaaaahhhh" for over seven minutes, saying "that's different" with a cheeky east-end wink, and offering to buy everyone an eel.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Liverpool are in the hunt for Barcelona's highly-rated wingback Gabri. Sammy Lee was spotted watching Barca's last match against Celta Vigo, according to Planet Football, and the Reds could be tempted to make a bid for the 21-year-old now the Spanish transfer window has opened.

Leicester are on the verge of signing Seth Johnson from Derby. If the move for the left-sided midfielder goes through, winger Steve Guppy may be on his way to Southampton.

Aston Villa are poised to re-sign Steve Staunton on a free transfer from Liverpool. Villa manager John Gregory is optimistic that the deal for 31-year-old defender will be completed within the next 24 hours.

Wolves are to open talks with Sunderland in a bid to sign defender Paul Butler for around £1m. Since the Republic of Ireland international joined the Molineux club on loan last month, they have lost just once.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Gary Megson has signed a new three-year contract with West Brom after leading the Baggies to third place in the First Division.

Newcastle have dismissed reports that skipper Alan Shearer is to undergo an exploratory operation on a knee injury.

Everton striker Francis Jeffers will be out of action for six weeks after he underwent an ankle operation today.

Former Liverpool, Nottingham Forest and Hibernian midfielder Peter Cormack has been appointed as manager of Cowdenbeath.

Manchester United have retained their place at the top of the Deloitte & Touche/Four Four Two Rich List for the third year running, ahead of Bayern Munich and Real Madrid. Chelsea are fourth, with Arsenal and Liverpool 10th and 11th respectively. Rangers are the top Scottish club, two places ahead of Celtic in 18th. Meanwhile, United are reportedly planning a tour of Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand next summer.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (10pm) Have they ever called this The Champions Match? Well, then.

The Big Match (1.35am) Arsenal's latest humiliation kick for kick.

Football Extra (3.10am) Known to some as the Nationwide Football League Football Highlights Extra Show. But not us.

Channel 4: Football Italia (2.35am) In bed with Peter Brackley.

Channel 5: Argentinian Football (4.30am) In bed with a surprisingly awake Diego Maradona.

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11pm) From the land that brought you Frank McAvennie. God knows why we just thought of him.

fields.bodyText: JONES CLEARED OF ALL ABUSE CHARGES Former Southampton manager David Jones walked free from court this afternoon after all 14 charges made against him of sexually abusing boys were dropped. The judge at Liverpool Crown Court told Jones, 44, that he would "leave this court as you entered it - a free man". The trial had earlier been halted after a witness failed to give evidence against Jones. The jury were instructed to return not guilty verdicts on two charges of indecent assault and two charges of causing actual bodily harm, before they were discharged because Jones "would not receive a fair trial before the same jury" on the ten remaining charges. All ten of these charges were later dropped when the prosecution told the judge it "would not be right, proper or just" to seek a retrial. Upon leaving the court, Jones hugged his wife Ann and said he felt "very happy" at the outcome of what he described as a "total nightmare". * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR Dec 5: click here * * * * * * * * * * * * * STANLEY: THE MAN, THE MIRACLE So close have the Fiver and Stanley Victor Collymore become over the years that we can actually communicate telepathically. So when we woke up late on Saturday night screaming the words "Stanley's in trouble!" we knew within seconds that Stanley had been lamped in some "members only" club in Brum, probably by some lairy Blues fans. We spent the rest of the night crying. Tears of laughter that is, as we realised what a classic Stanley moment this was. Stanley returned to training with Bradford this morning, nursing a few bruises and wincing at the newspapers which had cleverly managed to fit "nightclub beatdown" and "Ulrika Jonsson" into the same article. This being Stanley, it wasn't just the media who had to have their say. Big Bantam Geoffrey Richmond opened his ribcage to reveal: "Our hearts go out to Stan. He is a member of the Bradford City family." Meanwhile, Boss Bantam Jim Jefferies mused: "I have had no trouble with Stan at all. One day he wasn't at training and everybody thought he wouldn't turn up but you can't blame him if his plane was directed to Manchester instead of Leeds because of fog." Of course you can't. Jim went on to reveal that he and Stanley have since reached a compromise whereby Stanley flies from the Midlands to Yorkshire (all of, ooh, 114 miles) - but the night before! Anyway, we're not here to slag Stanley's travel arrangements. Especially when Birmingham City are around. Unable to resist sticking their tuppence/17.92 Euros worth into the debate, the club today released a statement to this effect: "Birmingham City wish to make it quite clear that it has no association with the person or persons who apparently carried out an assault on Stan Collymore as has been reported today." You mean it wasn't a sponsored hit? When Stanley's involved, wonders never cease. * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "I have almost had as long a career with Walkers as I did with football. They have had me doing all kinds of crazy stunts and taken the mickey out of my ears. I dread to think what they will come up with next!" - A chuckling Gary Lineker announces his new exclusive £1.5m contract to advertise Walkers Crisps. Rumours that those "crazy" crisp-manufacturing cats intend to put Gary in a basque, stuff his mouth with a plastic ball and beat him off to the point of unconsciousness remain just that. * * * * * * * * * * * * * EL TEL'S NORTHERN HELL Poor old Terry Venables has only been working in Not London for one day, but he's already displaying the classic symptoms of the cockney in exile. That's right: the 'omesick Londoner is loudly opining on the subjects of England, foreigners and the war. Why did Match of the Day magazine have to mention Sven-Goran Eriksson when he was obviously at such a low ebb? "By choosing to go to a foreign situation we've chosen to say we are not a power any more, but we, the FA, will show you the way forward. Show you how clever we are because we are designer people now, we're not old farts any more," sniffed an in-no-way-bitter Venables during his exclusive interview with the Ferg-less mag. "If Hoddle and Keegan had done well, I'd celebrate like mad. I've nothing against Eriksson - he looks like a gentleman - I just find it difficult. Put it this way, I don't think it's a good idea." webTitle: Sex abuse inquiry at Oratory school

fields.headline: Sex abuse inquiry at Oratory school
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The inquiry centres on a former chaplain and governor at the Roman Catholic state school in Fulham, south-west London, at which Prime Minister Tony Blair's two eldest sons are pupils.
fields.body:
An investigation was under way today into allegations of child abuse at the London Oratory school.

The inquiry centres on a former chaplain and governor at the Roman Catholic state school in Fulham, south-west London, at which Prime Minister Tony Blair's two eldest sons are pupils.

Police and social services acted after pupils alleged they were abused by Father David Martin, who died of a suspected Aids-related illness two years ago.

Martin was alleged to have met at least six pupils in his rooms at the London Oratory church, to which the highly regarded school is affiliated.

Two boys were said to have expressed fears that they might have contracted the HIV virus from the 44-year-old Scots-born priest, who died in September 1998.

There is no suggestion that Mr Blair's sons are involved in the allegations or the investigation.

A Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "Allegations of abuse at a London school have been received by the Hammersmith and Fulham child protection team.

"The allegations are being investigated."

ChildLine founder and chairman Esther Rantzen confirmed that the telephone helpline had been contacted by children who made allegations of abuse at the Oratory school.

She refused to discuss the case further, but said: "As a journalist, I have received for years letters making allegations against priests working in the Roman Catholic church, so I am very aware of the problem.

"I also know that this does occur from time to time in schools and I know how difficult it is to investigate these circumstances when they occur in schools," she told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

"Children who are sexually abused are very often frightened, guilty and ashamed and take the blame on themselves.

"When this happens inside a school, they often feel that they have to protect even their own parents, who sent them there for their own good, and they don't want to hurt their parents by revealing what has happened.

"So there are a great deal of areas in which we need to reassure children in order to ensure the truth comes out."

A spokeswoman for Hammersmith and Fulham council confirmed that a child protection team investigation was under way.

As school chaplain, Martin was employed by the church, not the school, so it is not clear whether he was subject to police checks before working with pupils, she said.

Martin entered the priesthood as a novice in 1988 after a 10-year career as a stockbroker in the City of London, the Daily Mail reported.

He was ordained by the late Cardinal Basil Hume, archbishop of Westminster, in 1994.

Martin died four years later from bronchopneumonia in the hospital of St John and St Elizabeth, Westminster.

The 1,360-pupil Catholic boys' school, which admits girls in the sixth form, was founded by the Fathers of the London Oratory in 1863.

webTitle: Sex abuse haunts the Catholic church

fields.headline: Sex abuse haunts the Catholic church
fields.standfirst:
The London Oratory school allegations leave the Roman Catholic church mired even further in child abuse scandals, writes Stephen Bates, religious affairs correspondent of the Guardian

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The London Oratory school allegations leave the Roman Catholic church mired even further in child abuse scandals, writes Stephen Bates, religious affairs correspondent of the Guardian
fields.body:
The Roman Catholic church appeared even deeper in the mire over allegations of child abuse among the priesthood yesterday following the latest disclosures about a priest-counsellor at London's Oratory school who died two years ago, apparently of an Aids-related infection and who may (or may not) have abused pupils.

The claims surrounding 44 year-old Father David Martin, who was a chaplain at the school for four terms before his death, suggest that he may have assaulted at least one pupil, though apparently off school premises. The case is being investigated by the police and Hammersmith and Fulham's child protection unit.

The allegations remain vague and unsubstantiated, for the victim who made his claims in a semi-anonymous letter last week has not yet been identified, but the church's overall problem appears only to be getting worse. It is increasingly trapped in a mire of nasty allegations about appalling abuses and breaches of trust and its plaintive cries that only a very small number of priests are concerned is in danger of being submerged. It looks like special pleading or, worse, defensiveness and cover-up.

The church hoped it was getting ahead of the game by appointing a committee under that irreproachable figure of public rectitude Lord Nolan to review its guidelines for handling allegations of sex abuse, but it is becoming aware that, with cases popping up before the courts every few months, it is an issue that will continue to haunt and undermine it.

Part of the trouble is that, for an institution with so much reverence for authority, it has had surprisingly few mechanisms in place for expelling errant clergy. There is no doubt too that for much too long it regarded such claims with complacency and a concern to protect its priests rather than its children. Such revelations have come close to sinking the authority of the Catholic church in Ireland.

The church makes an irresistible target too, giving fertile ground for claims of hypocrisy, moral turpitude and knowing gossip about the essential weirdness of priestly celibacy in a society which has steadily lost respect for spiritual beliefs and replaced them with a sometimes rancorous and often self-righteous obsession with blame.

It is difficult to know how Catholicism in Britain can emerge from this as a source of moral authority beyond the doors of its churches without putting in place much sterner tests for the priesthood and more draconian punishment for those convicted - though this in itself is difficult when so many allegations remain nebulous and unsubstantiated. Surely it cannot come to the point where priests are unable to meet any of their congregations except through the impermeable barrier of the confessional grille?

webTitle: The diary of a junior doctor

fields.headline: Death wishes
fields.standfirst: The diary of a junior doctor
fields.trailText: The diary of a junior doctor
fields.body:
Medicine has taken over my entire field of vision. I can't look at my girlfriend's forearms without thinking how easy and satisfying it would be to gently slip a cannula into her prominent, lovely veins. When we kiss, I'm feeling up her spine and assessing where I could best insert a lumbar puncture needle. I've managed to cut down on calling the ward from my mobile after work, but I can't stop making diagnoses on the bus.

You will be relieved to hear that we have all been washing our hands with unswerving diligence, which is more than I can say for some of our patients, one of whom I interrupted this morning urinating in his NHS water jug because his bottle was full. People on the cusp of dependence, I suspect, don't like asking for help, and I can see a lot of myself in some of the things they do. Which is why I felt particularly awkward on his behalf when the consultant came back from answering a call and poured him out a glass of water, explaining that he has to keep drinking if we're ever going to take his drip down. Needless to say we (the patient and I) kept our traps shut.

Death and disease continue unabated, but self-inflicted suffering seems to be all the rage among the patients coming my way in the casualty department this month. Teenage suicide attempts are always a treat, because (like deep vein thromboses) they're quick to manage and a good way to keep your numbers up in A&E. There's nothing like a reputation for ploughing through patients and clearing the waiting list in the run up to the Christmas rush.

Junkies, on the other hand, are a different story. First of all, let me put my cards on the table. As a Guardian-reading liberal wet, I tend to believe that heroin addicts are victims of society, and that their victimisation is counter-productive, the source of most of their problems, and emblematic of our victimisation of the morally weak in society in general.

Which is all very well until they steal my video recorder, or pitch up in casualty at one in the morning covered in vomit. Opiate overdoses, in the textbook, are very easy to manage: you get intra-venous access and hit them with an antidote called naloxone, which I am tempted to suggest should be handed out at needle exchanges to save us all the worry.

Now I don't know if you've ever looked at the arms of your average junkie, but by the time they get in deep enough to overdose, they have usually knocked off every vein in their body. The company they keep tends to be friendly to the point of total social disinhibition, and companions are over-eager to get involved in the workings of the casualty department. It's a shame that it would be frowned upon to ask for their help getting into a vein, because I imagine that they would be far better at it than me.

The other thing that textbooks tend not to mention about giving naloxone is that the moment it kicks in, the patient kicks out and sits bolt upright, bright-eyed and bushy-tailed, demanding to know what the fuck you think you are doing, wasting £10-worth of prime smack he worked really rather hard for, and shouts his head off for half an hour. Then, just when you are about to get away, the antidote wears off, they slip back into respiratory arrest, and start trying to choke on their own vomit again. This is no fun at all.

But the worst thing is that people just keep on trying to die on me, against the best efforts of everyone around them. So on Thursday night I had yet another family trying to blackmail me into shoving tubes in to feed their dying matriarch who, despite speaking not a word of English, was very clearly both well-oriented and determined to pass away peacefully (and thank God it was a week night so I could safely leave the decision for her own team to make the next morning).

And this morning, a man who I had looked after for three weeks, who I had caught laughing at the papers every morning ("It's all just a load of nonsense, I'm so glad I'm leaving it all behind"), who sat me down the first time we met in A&E and somehow made me share all my aspirations with him before telling me that I had it all wrong, that the most important thing in life was the person you chose to spend it with, and that when his wife of 53 years passed away he knew he was going to follow her soon . . . this morning he finally willed himself to death.

webTitle: Comment: The NHS let my brother down

fields.headline: 'He can't come back in two months.He'll be dead'
fields.standfirst: Lost notes, a postponed operation, evasive doctors . . . Keith Harper on how the NHS let down his dying brother
fields.trailText: Lost notes, a postponed operation, evasive doctors . . . Keith Harper on how the NHS let down his dying brother.
fields.body:
My brother has died of cancer, painfully and bravely, after an impossible and agonising 13-month fight for life during which members of the medical profession, with the notable exception of his GP, were reluctant to tell him what was happening. Perhaps they did not know.

His final indignity in this traumatic period occurred barely a month before he died. With extreme difficulty he hauled himself out of his bed to attend a regular appointment at Milton Keynes hospital. On arrival he waited two hours for the results of a blood test. They never came. He was then informed by a doctor that his notes had been lost and that he should come back in two months. Shaking with rage and shattered at the callous reaction, his poor wife blazed out: "You can't possibly see him again. In two months he'll be dead."

Several months after he finally passed away came a further example of the appalling lack of organisation and concern at Milton Keynes when his widow took a call from the hospital. "We're just checking up on Mr Harper and to see whether he needs another apppointment."

My brother Nigel had cancer of the neck. At his death, his entire body was a shell, riddled with disease. His weight had almost halved: as his illness developed, eating had become progressively more difficult. He barely picked at his food and kept himself going mainly with liquids. To help him eat, the hospital suggested that a shunt could be inserted into his stomach so that he could be fed intravenously. It is a simple operation and a proposal to which, as always, he willingly agreed, even though people who have experienced the procedure will know the results are not always straightforward and far from comfortable. The patient, usually asleep, lies in bed and slowly receives nourishment directly into the stomach over a period of hours.

Once again the hospital let him down, as he braced himself to take this next hurdle. On the day the shunt was due to be inserted, he arrived for the operation only to be told that a mistake had been made and that it could not go ahead.

I was about to take him on a final visit to some of his favourite haunts, among them the Lakes and the Beaulieu motor museum in Hampshire. "Good idea, it'll do him good," said the hospital. But the opposite was the case. We had to abandon the trip halfway up the M6. He was in so much agony and stooped in pain that we were forced to come home. The operation was eventually performed, bringing him much-needed relief, but he never went out again.

My brother bore his illness with immense courage and fortitude, never once complaining about the enormous and endless pain from which he suffered. But the doctors, either through misplaced kindness or lack of communication, could not bring themselves to tell him what was wrong and what were his chances of survival.

It was obvious to his family that his was a terminal case. Nigel was a heavy smoker, one clear reason for his cancer. But the hospital authorities, maybe fearful of being honest, jocularly suggested that he would come to no harm if he continued to smoke throughout his treatment. If he had realised death was inevitable, he would not have gone through the excruciating charade of fighting for his life. But he used to say: "While there is a chance, I've got to take it."

I know his is not an uncommon story. Many cancer patients do not receive the consultation and sometimes the care they deserve, and Nigel's case must be relevant to the experience of numerous people.

Here is a problem, moreover, which has the potential to get worse. One in three people in the United Kingdom are expected to develop cancer at some stage in their life. Precluding dramatic advances in cancer prevention, it is estimated that this figure will rise to one in two by the year 2020.

My brother's experience struck immediate chords with the national charity Cancerlink, which exists to provide people affected by cancer with access to support. It is currently campaigning for improved communication between cancer patients and health professionals.

Its chair, Professor Jessica Corner, director of the centre for cancer and palliative care studies at the Institute of Cancer Research in London, is disturbed at the communication breakdown at Milton Keynes. She says that if Nigel's notes were mislaid, he should have had a consultation without them.

On the general subject of care, she admits that it is only relatively recently that the right to be told that you have cancer has become generally accepted. "Even now in some parts of the UK, you cannot assume that someone has been told their diagnosis, especially if the prognosis is poor." Her experience is that cancer is discussed in veiled terms. People are often informed in surgical clinics that they have a lump or growth that needs to be removed, and they are still all too often left to decipher quite what this means.

Walking through her own local hospital, a large and famous London institution, leaves her with a sense of being present in body, but having left herself, her spirit, all that is impor tant in life, at home. "Combine this with a cancer diagnosis, with all the emotional and physical trauma and upheaval it entails, and the feelings of isolation and exclusion from one's normal world must magnify exponentially."

Corner says it should be remembered that communicating to a patient that they will die is a formidable task for some doctors, and that they need to be provided with special communication skills if they do not naturally possess them. She believes that, in many hospitals, sensitivity around cancer diagnosis has greatly improved, not from within the medical profession but from research studies revealing the inadequacy of care for patients' emotional needs.

My brother's experience is a stark reminder that the future for cancer services and for the NHS is to find better methods of offering support, and to use the experience of patients to change and enhance the system. Corner argues for the fostering of a new relationship with patients, one that encompasses partnership and collaboration, so that illness becomes mutual inquiry. Nigel would surely have benefited from such an attitude. It would not have removed his pain, but it would undoubtedly have assisted him in bearing it more easily.

fields.headline: Take a deep breath
fields.standfirst: The news that Christy Turlington, left, has emphysema came as a shock to many. But it's not just a disease for the elderly.
fields.trailText: The news that Christy Turlington, left, has emphysema came as a shock to many. But it's not just a disease for the elderly.
fields.body:
Perhaps it's the impossibly long legs, the waspish waists, the perfect skin or just the fact that they dress so much better than everyone else, but supermodels seem like a different species from the rest of us. Even if they display their fallibility from time to time and are forced to chuck a sickie from the catwalk, their sniffles, we may assume, will be the ailments of the beautiful - anorexia, perhaps, or a spot of depression; a drug addiction at the very worst.

So when the Calvin Klein model Christy Turlington announced last week that she was suffering from emphysema, it was a shock akin to suggesting that Britney Spears had Alzheimer's or Prince William had developed gout. Because emphy sema is emphatically not a disease of the beautiful. Miners get emphysema, or yellow-stained, elderly, too-old-to-stop-now smokers. Not exquisitely lovely 31-year-old women.

Turlington doesn't even smoke, having given up a 20-a-day habit five years ago. The bitterest irony is that she only discovered that she had the illness, albeit at an early stage, after signing up for an anti-smoking campaign which will see her appear in adverts for the NHS this winter. The model has been an outspoken voice against cigarettes since her father died of lung cancer three years ago.

Certainly emphysema has precious little glamour about it. The disease is a chronic lung condition in which the millions of bubble- shaped alveoli that make up the spongy surface of the lungs become damaged, causing them to become floppy and less elastic. It becomes increasingly difficult to breathe. In severe cases, the alveoli trap air and are unable to expel it, meaning that the entire chest can become distended into a barrel shape.

"In essence the lungs get blown up like balloons," says Dr Mark Britton, chairman of the British Lung Foundation. "If you take a deep breath and hold it, and then imagine that you have to then breathe in and out up there, you can't actually breathe in very much. So to breathe is like running the 100 yards all the time."

Similarly, because the healthy surface area of the lung is reduced, oxygen exchange becomes less efficient, putting greater strain on the heart. People with emphysema are also more prone to bronchitis and chest infections. And while doctors can treat the symptoms and slow the progression of the disease, there is no cure. Cases of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) - the umbrella term for emphysema and chronic bronchitis - slowly worsen over time, and frequently cause early death.

The open secret about emphysema is that it is almost entirely preventable. While a very small number of sufferers have an genetic deficiency which makes them particularly susceptible, almost everyone who has emphysema has acquired it through breathing harmful chemicals - which normally means smoking.

What is less well known, and more worrying, is that emphysema appears to be increasing, particularly among young women. Between 1990 and 1997, according to a study published earlier this year, cases of COPD shot up by a quarter among men and by a terrifying 69% among women. "Women are smoking much younger, so we're probably going to see more young girls having emphysema," says Britton.

In a cruel twist, this makes Turlington a particularly apposite spokesperson for the disease. "When I started modelling I wanted to appear more grown up, and smoking easily did that for me," the model said last week. "By 16 I was on a pack a day. The frightening thing is, my smoking caused permanent damage. It seems so ironic - breathing is part of the process that sustains life; you breathe in cigarettes and they take your breath away."

Happily there is an easy way to slow the progress of the disease, and it is the boring one you expect: stop smoking. This is particularly important, stresses Britton, if anyone in your family has had lung disease.

"Lung disease is the Cinderella of health care," he says. "Everyone knows about cancer and heart disease, but we don't do terribly well talking about lung disease. But I am sure there are quite a few people out there with emphysema who don't know it. There is little doubt that there is more emphysema in younger people than we appreciate."

fields.headline: If she had only know...
fields.standfirst: Ailsa Bernard had two potentially fatal ectopic pregnancies before being diagnosed with the sexually transmitted disease chlamydia. Until then she had no idea that the two conditions were linked.
fields.trailText: Ailsa Bernard had two potentially fatal ectopic pregnancies before being diagnosed with the sexually transmitted disease chlamydia. Until then she had no idea that the two conditions were linked.
fields.body:
Ailsa Bernard has been pregnant at least 11 times. Seven pregnancies have ended in miscarriages, three have been ectopic and just one - so far - has resulted in a much-loved daughter, Jessica, now almost five.

Every loss has cut her to the quick, each one a potential life lost. But the difference between miscarriages and ectopic pregnancies is that ectopics are dangerous, difficult to diagnose and potentially disastrous.

According to the Ectopic Pregnancy Trust, there has been a dramatic increase in ectopic pregnancies in recent years. An estimated one in 80 pregnancies is now ectopic; 20,000 women are admitted to hospital every year for emergency, life-saving surgery after a pregnancy develops in a fallopian tube, rather than the womb, then ruptures it and causes massive internal haemorrhaging. Between five and eight women die every year either because they are unaware they are pregnant, have been misdiagnosed or have not made it to hospital in time.

Ailsa, a 35-year-old housing association worker, had her first ectopic pregnancy in 1988. She found herself doubled up in extreme pain while she was driving to work. She had to fight quite hard to get an appointment with her GP, who finally referred her to hospital where she was admitted instantly and told she needed surgery.

Unaware of the serious implications of an ectopic pregnancy, Ailsa told doctors she didn't want to be operated on. The hospital told her she had no choice - without surgery she would die. "I had not really grasped the enormity of it," she says.

Surgeons removed part of her right fallopian tube in what was a major operation. (Surgery for ectopic pregnancy often results in the loss of a fallopian tube, thus reducing fertility.) Everyone was concerned about her physical well-being, but little attention was paid to her emotional state. She left hospital with a urine infection and a terrible sense of desolation, having undergone major surgery and lost a baby.

After the operation she recalls being told "it might be a good idea" if she was checked for chlamydia, though not much more was explained. Chlamydia is a sexually transmitted infection which is dramatically on the increase; if untreated it can cause infertility and it is thought to be responsible for at least half of all ectopic pregnancies. Ailsa was given the details of the local genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinic, but she did not go. "I was only 23 at the time and I would have felt embarrassed and worried what other people's perceptions of me might be."

There were more miscarriages, then in 1992 she had just done a positive pregnancy test when she began to suffer stitch-like abdominal pains. "The pain became worse, but even more than the pain and the bleeding was this very, very strong instinct that something was not right."

She went to casualty where hospital staff thought it unlikely she had ectopic pregnancy, but agreed to carry out a laparoscopy because of her history. Ailsa was right. Her second ectopic pregnancy was lodged right at the opening of her right hand tube; surgeons removed it and again she was advised about the possible link between chlamydia and ectopic pregnancy, and to go to the GUM clinic. This time she went and she was indeed found to have chlamydia.

For Ailsa, it was a relief to have some explanation for why she was losing her pregnancies. She was given a course of antibiotics, and later re-tested to make sure the infection had cleared up. For others however, the revelation that they are suffering from a sexually-transmitted disease which may have wrecked their chances of having a baby opens a whole new area of uncertainty. How did they get it? Was it their current partner? Where did he get it?

According to Peter Greenhouse, consultant in sexual health medicine at Bristol Royal Infirmary, the number of diagnoses of chlamydia has doubled in the last five years; in the last year there has been a 20% increase in teenage women and 23% in teenage men. And, according to two pilot studies whose results will be published early in the New Year, 10% of people under 25 are infected.

"There is no doubt that chlamydia is the main preventable cause of ectopic pregnancy, but what proportion it causes is a matter of debate. It is certainly not less than 50%, and in young people it's probably over 90%.

"The best evidence comes from Sweden over the last 15 years where there's been a substantial campaign, with both education and screening, to reduce the prevalence of chlamydia. What they have found is that the ectopic rates reduced at the same rate as chlamydia."

Since chlamydia is easily and cheaply treated - a short course of antibiotics for both the woman and her partner - according to Greenhouse, the majority of ectopics are therefore easily preventable. "But people are not aware of chlamydia in this country," says Greenhouse. "It's a complete failure of public health education. The majority of people who have it do not have any obvious signs or symptoms which is why there's so much of it about.

"It's almost as though chlamydia has been biologically designed to cause ectopic pregnancies. It uses the body's immune system to create inflammation in the tubes. That damages the hairs that waft the eggs down the tube.

"The damage can take months or years. Eventually you get a tube that's burned out. Either the egg is unable to get down the tube, or it gets half way down and gets stuck, which is what causes an ectopic pregnancy.

"The stress of lost pregnancy is enormous. It's a bereavement in itself. Then there's the stress of having surgery if you have an ectopic. If, on the top of that, your gynaecologist has to broach the subject of chlamydial infection, which may not have been an old infection but an active infection, then you begin to get some idea of how tricky the whole thing is."

Almost five years ago, Ailsa and her husband Titus Bernard, 36, finally had the child they had hoped for. Jessica's birth was not without trauma - she was premature and Ailsa, after so much loss, found it hard to bond with her daughter because she was frightened she might lose her at any moment.

Then, two years ago, she went on to have yet another ectopic pregnancy - her third. While she was being monitored at her local hospital, she went into shock and her blood pressure plummeted. She was operated on to remove her fallopian tube. The ectopic pregnancy could have been caused by the tubal damage already done by her earlier chlamydia infection, no one is sure.

Ailsa's is a particularly harrowing story. Once chlamydia has done its terrible damage, there's little one can do to reverse that. But with better sex education to take the stigma out of chlamydia and a national screening programme for the infection, many women and their families might be saved the sort of heartache and health risks she endured.

 The Ectopic Pregnancy Trust can be contacted on 01895 238025.

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: My shoulder is frozen
fields.body:
My shoulder is frozen

Q I have a painful stiff shoulder and can't lift my arm up beyond a few degrees. I can dress, drive and go to work, but it's all an effort and I can't lie on that side so my sleep is disturbed. A friend had a steroid injection for her frozen shoulder but I'm wary. What do you advise?

A When it's working properly, the shoulder has a huge range of movement. But flexibility comes at a price. The joint is easily dislocated and damaged. A thin capsule of tissue surrounds it and small tears make it thicken and become more rigid, which restricts movement. With a frozen shoulder, there is gradual development of pain over a few months, then, as the pain settles, the shoulder stiffens and you lose power and movement of the arm for up to a year. The good news is that after that the shoulder improves. The bad news is that it takes an average of 30 months from start to finish and that treatments do little to alter the outcome. Anti-inflammatory tablets such as Brufen are good in the early stages. Physiotherapyis at least as good as a steroid injection and less likely to cause harm. An operation is probably to be avoided.

Heart disease risks

Q Several members of my family have died of heart disease in their 50s and 60s. I asked my GP what I could do to avoid following in their footsteps but was told that apart from not smoking, eating healthily, exercising regularly and having my blood pressure checked from time to time, there was nothing much. He offered to do a cholesterol blood test. Is there much point?

A There's a lot of point. If your cholesterol level is high with an unhealthily high proportion of the "bad" part of cholesterol, LDL, you will be advised to try to reduce it by adopting a low fat diet. This rarely helps much and you may be offered drug treatment with one of a group of drugs known as statins. There is some concern about using statins for more than 10 years. Your risk of developing heart disease over the next 10 years can be calculated taking into account your age, smoking, blood pressure, whether you're diabetic and your cholesterol level. If your risk is above 15%, I'd ask for a statin. Some health authorities are a bit tight with them, only giving them to those with 30% risk or more. But stand your ground if necessary or ask to be referred to the local lipid clinic for an expert opinion.

HIV and oral sex

Q I have a new partner and am being conscientious in insisting he use condoms when we have sex. Can I catch HIV from oral sex?

A Suprisingly, the answer is "yes". The risk after one-off oral sex is low but it has been shown that if you have oral sex with a man who is HIV-positive, you could be at risk.

Testing for cancer

Q I've heard there is a blood test for cancer. How can I get one? There's a lot of cancer in my family.

A The blood test is known as DR-70tm (tumour marker) and is now on sale in Canada and China and soon to find its way to the UK. Its manufacturer, AMDL, an American company, claims it can detect 13 different cancers, including common ones. It's based on the notion that cancer cells release chemicals known as proteases, which can be measured in the blood and from which the type of cancer can be identified. fields.headline: Courting the White House
fields.standfirst:
Time is running out fast. The courts have delivered a brace of body blows. Can Al Gore still hope for the White House?
Special report: the US election race
fields.trailText: In this seemingly neverending saga, there is still a flurry of legal action to come. And the most crucial case of all will be decided by a court which is solidly Democrat by background.
fields.body:
In this seemingly neverending saga, there is still a flurry of legal action to come. And the most crucial case of all will be decided by a court which is solidly Democrat by background.

All seven justices of the Florida supreme court were appointed by Democrat state governors - a reliable indication of their political leanings. And it was they who threw Al Gore a lifeline by ruling that the deadline for manual recounting of ballots could be extended.

True, the United States supreme court has questioned that ruling, and called for clarification of the legal reasoning behind it. And true, the manual recount itself seems to be sliding into the sands of psephological history, following Monday's ruling by circuit judge Sanders Sauls that it is unnecessary.

Still, the state Supreme Court is still in the frame. It will hear the inevitable Democrat appeals against the Sauls judgment on the recount. And it will do its best to justify itself to the US Supreme over the extension of the deadline for that recount.

If both cases go well for the Democrats - and who can say they won't? - then Al Gore will be back in the reckoning; still second in the race, but still running.

The problem is they keep moving the winning line. In theory, the next big deadline is December 12, the final date for selection of Florida's 25 vital voters in the national electoral college.

The state legislature has warned that if the legal wrangling is still going on, it will step in itself to certify the electors. That means the presidency will go to George W Bush, courtesy of Florida's Republican majority.

State law is clear on the matter: the legislature has a perfect right to choose the electoral college delegation, if the voters are unable to do so. But then state law is also clear on voting procedures, certification of ballots, qualifications for registration, election timing, and any number of other aspects of democracy now being picked over in the courts.

webTitle: Comment: university reputation goes up in smoke

fields.headline: University reputation goes up in smoke
fields.standfirst: Universities wouldn't exist without patronage, but the British American Tobacco deal has tarnished Nottingham's reputation, writes Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Universities wouldn't exist without patronage, but the British American Tobacco deal has tarnished Nottingham's reputation, writes Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Universities probably wouldn't exist if it were not for the support of dubious benefactors. The plundering of monasteries by King Henry VIII helped to build some of the country's most ancient academic institutions.

In today's increasingly competitive global higher education market, universities depend more on more on corporate sponsors for their research and teaching budgets. Professorial chairs, research units and entire departments now advertise the names of oil, pharmaceuticals and drinks companies.

But for each deal, universities must tread a delicate ethical path. Is academic freedom compromised by the demands of the sponsor? Is the university unwittingly lending authority and crediblity to a company that has abandoned all social responsibilities in the search for profits? In short, what is the company getting out of the deal?

By accepting £3.8m from British American Tobacco, which is under investigation over smuggling allegations, Nottingham University has made the wrong choice. The decision to allow BAT to finance a new school of "business ethics" has triggered protests from cancer charity officials, anti-smoking campaigners and MPs.

The acid test for any sponsorship deal must be whether the commercial donor is willing to remain anonymous, and sign away any rights to influence the outcomes of the work. The publicity over the Nottingham decision can only have benefitted the tobacco manufacturer, which is currently being sued in New York over allegations that it is actively involved in organised crime.

But it has damaged the reputation of the university.

webTitle: H Bauer to launch glossy women's monthly

fields.headline: H Bauer plans glossy women's monthly launch
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Woman's weekly publisher H Bauer is planning to launch a glossy women's monthly magazine for the first time. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Woman's weekly publisher H Bauer, which publishes Take a Break and TV Quick, is planning to launch a glossy women's monthly magazine for the first time.

The magazine will target women aged between 25 and 40, aiming to tap the lucrative advertising sales market. It is codenamed Project Helena, but it is thought that it will launch with the title Real next spring.

The magazine industry has seen a flurry of high profile launches for women in this age bracket after the success of IPC's Woman's Journal and Emap's Red.

But the sector is fiercely competitive and has recently seen some high profile failures including Aura launched by the former Sunday Express editor Eve Pollard, which closed at the end of the summer.

The National Magazine Company also abandoned the planned launch from Gruner + Jahr, which it acquired in the summer, Vital (codenamed Project Florence), and Sally Brampton, editor of Red, quit recently amid speculation that publishers Emap did not like the direction in which she was taking the magazine.

Louise Newton, publishing director at H Bauer, said the magazine would be "relevant to women aged between 25 and 40 who are married or co-habiting, most likely have children and are bold, confident, chic, independent, bright and passionate.

H Bauer has not yet released details of the editor of Project Helena.

fields.headline: ANC faces poll shock
fields.standfirst: Voters are expected to deliver a hammer blow to South Africa's ruling party, reports Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: Voters are expected to deliver a hammer blow to South Africa's ruling party, reports Chris McGreal in Johannesburg
fields.body:
One of the African National Congress's leading lights cut closest to the bone as the racially-tainted rhetoric grew more heated in the run-up to today's elections for control of South Africa's sprawling new "mega-cities".

S'bu Ndebele, the ANC leader in the hotly contested KwaZulu-Natal, drew a comparison between supporters of the white-oriented opposition party, the Democratic Alliance (DA), and South Africa's best-known fast-food chain. "Non-whites who support the DA are like chickens who support Nando's. They are supporting their own oppression," he said.

Mr Ndebele's remark said something about the charged racial politics that still infects South Africa a decade after Nelson Mandela was released from prison. But it said more about the ANC's fear that it may be about to suffer humiliation at the hands of an opposition party that should be little more than a shrill irritant to the government.

The DA is, after all, an amalgamation of the old white liberal Democratic party - which, in earlier incarnations, was less than enthusiastic about the prospect of one person, one vote - and the National party, which imposed full-blown apartheid on South Africa half a century ago.

It is hard to imagine the DA as the first refuge of even the most disillusioned ANC voter. Yet, if the opinion polls are right, it threatens to deny the ruling party outright control of as many as three of South Africa's four most important cities - Johannesburg, Pretoria and Durban - and may well win control itself of the fourth, Cape Town. Opinion polls consistently give the DA at least one third of the vote in all of those cities and as much as half in some cases.

This astonishing feat is in part because the DA's controversial but politically talented leader, Tony Leon, has hammered away at the one issue on which the ANC is most vulnerable - corruption.

Many black South Africans will forgive the party of their liberation its failure to deliver on many of its promises. Even as they complain, they acknowledge that there are limited resources even for such essentials as housing, education and clean water.

But they are not forgiving of graft and abuse of power by those supposedly responsible for the public welfare. By the ANC's own admission, one in five of its own councillors is corrupt or grossly incompetent, including some who have taken backhanders from builders to get away with constructing sub-standard homes for the poor.

But that has not discouraged the ANC from putting up a candidate for mayor of Durban who was dropped by a rival party for allegedly stealing council funds, and fielding another potential councillor who is on bail on a murder charge.

The election is also a test of President Thabo Mbeki's rule. His personal standing in opinion polls has fallen sharply in recent months, largely as a result of his controversial questioning of the link between HIV and Aids.

At stake is control of sprawling six new mega-cities which incorporate former whites-only cities such as Johannesburg and Cape Town into a single administration with surrounding black townships. Some will also undergo name changes. Port Elizabeth is to become Nelson Mandela metropole, and Pretoria will be called Tshwane.

There was apparently no confusion among the many illiterate voters as to how to cast their ballots, so there are unlikely to be significant legal challenges even if the results in some places are close.

But five people were shot dead at a polling station in the Mandela Park squatter camp in what appeared to be politically motivated killings.

webTitle: NTL to sponsor British Lions tour of Australia

fields.headline: NTL signs £1m sponsorship deal with British Lions
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Cable giant NTL is to sponsor the British Lions' rugby tour of Australia next year in a £1m deal, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Cable giant NTL is to sponsor next year's British Lions' rugby tour of Australia in a £1m deal that will give it behind-the-scenes access to the players.

As part of the deal NTL will be given access to the players' dressing rooms and team meetings. The broadcaster will put together eight hours of behind-the-scenes programming from the tour through its Premier TV subsidiary.

"The tour will be the highlight of the sporting calendar for millions of sports fans. NTL will add to their enjoyment by enhancing the ways they can watch the Lions, talk about the Lions and interact with the Lions," said group marketing director Mike Hounsell.

The team will play 10 matches on the tour in June and July, including three tests against Australia. The sponsorship agreement is the latest in of a series of deals for NTL, which has invested in several premier league football clubs including Aston Villa, Newcastle United and Leicester City.

fields.headline: Jones cleared of abuse charges
fields.trailText: David Jones, the former Southampton manager, walked free from court this afternoon after all 14 charges made against him of sexual abuse against boys were dropped.
fields.body:
David Jones, the former Southampton manager, walked free from court this afternoon after all 14 charges made against him of sexual abuse against boys were dropped.

The judge at Liverpool Crown Court told Jones, 44, that he would "leave this court as you entered it - a free man".

Earlier, the trial was halted and the jury instructed to return not guilty verdicts on two charges of indecent assault and two charges of causing actual bodily harm, after a witness failed to give evidence against him.

The prosecution declined to ask for a retrial, leaving Jones to walk free. Jones, a father of four, had pleaded not guilty to a total of 14 charges.

The former Everton and Coventry City defender worked at a residential home in north-west England for children with emotional and behavioural problems between 1986 and 1990. He was accused of abusing four boys at the school.

webTitle: OFT to investigate BSkyB's pay-TV deals

fields.headline: OFT to investigate BSkyB's pay-TV deals
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: The Office of Fair Trading is to investigate BSkyB's pay-TV channel supply deals with cable operators and ONdigital, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The Office of Fair Trading is to investigate BSkyB's pay-TV channel supply agreements with cable operators and ONdigital to see if they fall foul of the beefed up new Competition Act.

The six-month OFT inquiry will consider whether BSkyB's wholesale programming deals with other pay-TV operators amount to either an abuse of a dominant market position or constitute agreements that will damage competition in the UK.

An OFT spokesman confirmed that the investigation had not been triggered by a formal complaint, unlike the competition regulator's last major inquiry into BSkyB's wholesale programming business in 1996.

The OFT said "no assumption could be made at this stage that there had been an infringement".

But the spokesman added that for an investigation to be launched there had to be "reasonable grounds for suspecting that the [Competition Act] has been infringed".

BSkyB rival ONDigital said it welcomed the inquiry. "This is exactly what we have been asking for," said a spokesman.

The move follows an OFT review of the undertakings BSkyB gave following the 1996 investigation to meet the regulator's concerns about competition.

This inquiry began in January and was prompted by consolidation in the UK cable industry and the launch of digital TV.

Now the OFT, under director general John Vickers who took over from John Bridgeman in October, has decided to launch a full inquiry under the terms of the new Competition Act.

The Act came into force on March 1 and gives the OFT a beefed up role in policing competition.

A BSkyB spokesman said the company noted the transition of the OFT's current inquiry to one under the new legislation. He added: "We look forward to an early conclusion of this inquiry."

In 1996, following the OFT's last investigation of BSkyB's wholesale programming deals, the company undertook not to bundle certain channels and publish a ratecard with a discount structure agreed in advance with the regulator.

The pay-TV operator was also required to submit separate accounts for its retail and wholesale programming businesses.

Insiders at ONDigital said that BSkyB's dominant market position has seriously affected margins on the pay-TV services the operation offers.

One option would be to drop the price of premium services such as Sky's sports and movie services and boost subscriber numbers. However, ONdigital is restricted in what it does by prior agreements with Sky.

webTitle: BA loses court battle against Ryanair

fields.headline: Ryanair triumphs over BA in court battle over ad claims
fields.trailText: 2pm: Low cost airline Ryanair has won a High Court battle with British Airways over advertising claims, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Low cost airline Ryanair has won a High Court battle with British Airways over claims in its advertising that BA is "five times more expensive" than its smaller rival.

BA initiated the court action to stop national newspapers running press ads headed "Expensive BA", which went on to claim that BA was "five times" more expensive on some routes.

A two day High Court hearing ended today in defeat for BA, with Mr Justice Jacobs ruling that "in substance" the adverts were true.

"I suspect the real reason BA do not like it is precisely because it is true," he added.

Michael O'Leary, Ryanair's chief executive said: "We are amazed that BA would spend vast sums of money in the High Court just to prove what everybody else already knows, namely that British Airways are outrageously expensive and have been charging outrageously high air fares to its British and European customers, particularly those who can't stay Saturday night.

"These bully boy tactics are typical of BA and the attempt to gag Ryanair or frighten the national newspapers was doomed to failure."

fields.headline: Lineker bags £1.5m Walkers deal
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: Gary Lineker has signed a £1.5m deal with Walkers Crisps barring him from endorsing other products for five years, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Gary Lineker has signed a £1.5m deal with Walkers Crisps barring him from endorsing any other products for the next five years.

The exclusive deal, signed today, is believed to be one of the longest ever agreed.

Lineker, 40, who first appeared in ads from Abbott Mead Vickers for the crisp brand six years ago, has since appeared in more than 25 commercials.

His many guises have included dressing up as the devil, a nun, punk rocker, headmistress, baby, schoolboy and muscleman.

Lineker said: "I have almost had as long a career with Walkers as I did with football.

"They have had me doing all kinds of crazy stunts and taken the mickey out of my ears. I dread to think what they will come up with next."

Walkers first used the former England star's golden-boy image with its "No more Mr Nice Guy" campaign as he starred in a series of commercials with other big names such as Paul Gascoigne, Des Lynam, Vinnie Jones and Ulrika Jonsson.

The new deal will tie Lineker to making at least five commercials each year, and to an agreed number of personal appearances.

fields.headline: BBC in radical restructure of agency roster
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The BBC has embarked on a radical restructuring of its agency roster, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The BBC has dumped the advertising agency behind its high-profile Perfect Day campaign in a radical restructuring of its agency roster.

Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters and Fallon have all made it onto the coveted roster of agencies.

Faulds has been reappointed in Scotland.

TBWA, J Walter Thompson and Circus were kicked off the shortlist at an earlier stage of the review.

The review has reduced the number of agencies used by the BBC from 10 to four. The new roster will exist for a minimum of three years.

Media planning and buying will continue to be handled by New PHD.

webTitle: Damilola's blood found on two broken bottles

fields.headline: Damilola's blood found on two broken bottles
fields.standfirst:
More about the Damilola case
The CCTV footage
fields.trailText: Traces of blood belonging to Damilola Taylor have been found on two broken bottles close to where the 10-year-old was murdered.
fields.body:
Traces of blood belonging to Damilola Taylor have been found on two broken bottles close to where the 10-year-old was murdered.

Police cannot yet confirm that shattered glass from the bottles was used to sever an artery in the schoolboy's left leg, leaving him to bleed to death in a stairwell.

"They may have been used as a weapon and then been smashed apart and then had blood dripped on them," said detective superintendent David Dillnutt, the officer leading the inquiry.

Two new knives found in Peckham, south London, following the attack are currently undergoing DNA and forensic tests.

Two other knives, which had been recovered shortly after the murder, did not have traces of Damilola's blood on them but will be tested further.

Police have appealed for three boys, two black and one white, to come forward. They were seen just outside the stairwell where Damilola's body was found after its discovery.

"It is clear they were there at an important time and might have some vital information.

"I would urge them to come forward and assist us," said Mr Dillnutt.

He said witnesses had seen the boys attempting to enter the stairwell. They are believed to be different from a group of boys aged between 11 and 14 who were seen in the area shortly before the attack.

Superintendent Rod Jarman said he had attended a meeting of more than 100 residents from the north Peckham estate last night where there had been strong support for the investigation.

But he said many young people that police had spoken to in the area had not understood what was going on and some did not even know that an important appeal for information was happening.

"I would urge parents and teachers to encourage youngsters to come forward. It's not that they didn't want to help but that many young people didn't understand the importance of small pieces of information they could bring."

Mr Jarman said he had spoken to Damilola's father, Richard Taylor, who had been full of support for the police investigation.

Mr Taylor is to make a public appeal for information about his son's killers at a Scotland Yard press conference tomorrow.

Damilola bled to death after being attacked on his way home from Oliver Goldsmith's primary school in Peckham.

He staggered 100 yards, with blood pouring from a sliced artery in his leg, after being stabbed.

webTitle: Social services to get winter cash boost

fields.headline: Social services to get winter cash boost
fields.trailText: Social services departments will have to show that care will be maintained during peak "winter crisis" periods to earn their share of an extra £100m earmarked by health secretary Alan Milburn. By Patrick Butler
fields.body:
Social services departments will have to show that care will be maintained during peak "winter crisis" periods to earn their share of an extra £100m earmarked by health secretary Alan Milburn.

The ring-fenced grants of up to £2.6m each come with several strings attached, including a requirement that financially stretched departments cannot use the cash to hide financial problems.

The £100m grant was announced by Mr Milburn yesterday, as it emerged that an official survey had revealed more investment was needed to strengthen health and social services winter planning.

The Department of Health's Winter Plan says the "majority" of health authority areas have been classified as at "low to medium risk" of winter problems.

But it added that there was a "need for additional resources to build extra capacity in some parts of the country, particularly at the interface between health and social services". And it warned that shortages of social services staff, as well as health staff, was a problem: "The supply of staff required to deliver the NHS plan cannot be found immediately."

All social services departments have developed local plans with the NHS to maintain services at peak times during the winter and ensure elderly patients are promptly transferred from acute hospital beds to community care when clinically appropriate.

The report did not identify which areas had been assessed as "high risk" of service problems developing over the next few weeks.

The extra £100m has been added as a top-up to the Promoting Independence grants announced earlier this year and will be paid directly to those councils that can demonstrate the money will be used effectively.

A DoH letter to local authority chief executives warns that the grants, which range from £332,000 (Merton) to £2.65m (Kent) cannot be used to ease general social services budget deficits. It says councils will also have to demonstrate specific improvements in service delivery and performance, and effective joint plans with the NHS and other partners.

The government insisted that social care has sufficient resources to cope with the winter pressures, including over £100m invested in intermediate care to ensure acute hospital patients can be moved into the community. It says that early indications show there has been an increase of 2,900 intensive home care packages in the year to September 2000, and 6,700 more local authority supported places in residential and nursing homes in the 12 months to March 2000.

Although the private care homes sector cut 7,300 beds in 1999-2000, ministers insist that its investment in intermediate care will "more than offset" this reduction.

fields.headline: Could Neanderthal prove Channel 4's missing link?
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Channel 4's caveman epic, Neanderthal, attracted homo sapiens in their droves to TV screens last night, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4's heavily promoted caveman epic, drama-doc Neanderthal, attracted plenty of homo sapiens to their TV screens last night.

The 60-minute programme, which featured actors in heavy prosthetic make-up recreating the lifestyle of neanderthal tribes in the south of France 35,000 years ago, averaged 3.1m and a 13% share on Channel 4 from 9pm, according to unofficial overnights.

Neanderthal might have done even better had it not been competing with other male-oriented factual offerings on BBC2 and Channel 5 in the same slot.

Horror in the East, a BBC2 documentary about the Japanese treatment of allied prisoners during the second world war, took 2.6m; while on Channel 5 a repeated Serial Killers documentary on Richard Ramirez gathered 1.6m and a healthy 7% share.

On BBC1 last night from 9pm, new drama Thin Ice, starring Nicholas Lyndhurst as a dodgy doctor asked by the police to infiltrate a crime gang, averaged 5.3m and a 22% share.

The BBC1 drama lost out to ITV's Michelle Collins vehicle, Daylight Robbery, which drew 7.8m - a third of the audience.

Later on the BBC1 Omnibus documentary on Dudley Moore featured the musician and comedian who is dying of degenerative disease supranuclear palsy, giving what is likely to be his last TV interview.

Dudley Moore: After the Laughter took 3.3m, nearly double the average for last week's Omnibus.

fields.headline: Record payout for stressed teacher
fields.standfirst:
Union warns of work pressure dangers after retired teacher wins £254,000 for 'two year nightmare'
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A teacher who suffered a nervous breakdown and was forced to quit her job after suffering "intolerable" stress in the classroom, has won more than £250,000 in damages in a record out-of-court settlement.
fields.body:
A teacher who suffered a nervous breakdown and was forced to quit her job after suffering "intolerable" stress in the classroom, has won more than £250,000 in damages in a record out-of-court settlement.

Her union warned the government and employers that work-related stress could become "the chief killer of the 21st century". But they urged other teachers in stressful situations not to consider similar action unless they had a case with "genuine evidence".

Janice Howell, 51, was awarded £254,362 after Newport county borough council admitted liability in January this year. It was a record payout for teacher stress. The mother of three described yesterday how she endured a two year "nightmare" because of the daily demands of dealing with 11 children with special educational needs in a mainstream class of 28.

As well as teaching one seriously emotionally disturbed boy who had already been expelled from two other schools, Mrs Howell revealed how she was later told to teach English to two Ethiopian youngsters who had come from a war zone, "and who didn't even know what a book or a pencil was". Her calls for help were ignored by the headteacher. She was forced to retire four years ago - after a career spanning more than 24 years - through acute stress and after two nervous breakdowns.

Mrs Howell said she believed she had been "an extremely competent, confident teacher" and regretted that she had had to give up her chosen career in this way. "I'd like to think I could use my educational background, perhaps as some form of adviser," she said. "But at my age not many are given the chance to work again. It was a nightmare not just for me but my family too."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of School Masters Union of Women Teachers, the second largest teaching union, warned yesterday: "If work-related stress is not taken more seriously by government and employers it could become the cancer and chief killer of the 21st century.

"The case illustrates how intolerable it was to expect Jan Howell to cope with 11 special needs pupils in her mainstream school class with next to no support."

Mr de Gruchy said intense pressure from successive governments for schools to retain disruptive and violent youngsters was to blame for growing stress levels in the teaching profession, along with inadequate provision for emotionally disturbed youngsters, and "incompetent and uncaring management" in schools.

His union, he added, was, at the moment, representing 120 teachers in stress-related cases. But in a note of caution to would-be litigants in the profession, he added: "We will be flooded with calls in the next few weeks from other people saying they're under the same level of stress.

"But teachers have to realise that they can't just say that. They have to be able to provide full evidence".

In a statement, Newport council said the events occurred when the local authority was known as Gwent county council and before its local education authority existed. The school had a different management team now. The school was now well run and providing good education. The council was "committed to the health of its employees". It added: "We are aware of the importance of dealing with stress. A stress management policy agreed with unions is in place."

webTitle: Lib Dems may drop education tax pledge

fields.headline: Lib Dems may drop education tax pledge
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats yesterday unveiled an "alternative Queen's speech" programme aimed at revitalising the key public services which worry voters most.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats yesterday unveiled an "alternative Queen's speech" programme aimed at revitalising the key public services which worry voters most.

Charles Kennedy's proposed measures include a beefed-up version of John Prescott's strategic rail authority - which would supervise a non-profit version of the national air traffic control system (Nats) and London Underground - the abolition of student tuition fees, freeing up the schools curriculum from central control and cutting paperwork for teachers.

In a radio interview ahead of tomorrow's official Queen's speech, the Lib Dem leader also proposed an NHS waiting time reduction bill - all operations within six month of a specialist's assessment - and a preventative healthcare bill to make the NHS "not just an illness service."

That will cost money, as will the Lib Dem pledge to provide free nursing and personal care for the elderly. To sugar the pill Mr Kennedy hinted that tax revenues are so buoyant he may drop Paddy Ashdown's manifesto pledge to raise income tax by 1p in the pound to help fund education.

"We make the causal link between where you levy a tax and what you do with that tax. The penny on education in days gone by was the obvious one, and we remain of that view, although you wouldn't need to pursue that particular policy right now because the Treasury, as we know, is awash with money," he told Radio 4's Today programme.

The package is close enough to Labour's views not to embarrass either side, but distinctive enough to allow Mr Kennedy to campaign as an independent force - at a time when William Hague, facing a Lib-Lab squeeze in key seats, will accuse him of being in Tony Blair's back pocket.
