fields.headline: Dalai Lama and China 'in talks'
fields.standfirst: Tibetan spiritual leader says he sent his brother to a secret meeting in Beijing, after two years of no dialogue
fields.trailText: Negotiations between the Chinese government and the Dalai Lama about the future of Tibet have resumed after a two-year gap following a secret visit to Beijing last month by the Dalai Lama's elder brother, it was claimed last night.
fields.byline: Luke Harding  in Dharamsala and John Gittings in Hong Kong
fields.body:
Negotiations between the Chinese government and the Dalai Lama about the future of Tibet have resumed after a two-year gap following a secret visit to Beijing last month by the Dalai Lama's elder brother, it was claimed last night.

Speaking after celebrations to mark his 50th anniversary as temporal leader of Tibet, the Dalai Lama yesterday said his brother, Gyalo Thondup, held talks with Chinese consular officials. Mr Thondup, a former Tibetan envoy, had earlier received "indications" the Chinese wanted to see him.

Mr Thondup returned to Dharamsala, the north Indian home of Tibet's government in exile, bearing a message from the Chinese side, but the Dalai Lama last night refused to disclose its contents. "It is early days," he said.

He said he had responded to Beijing's overture by suggesting a Tibetan delegation visit China for further talks. There had not yet been a reply.

Beijing's formal position is that the door is still open to talks it broke off in 1993 if the Dalai Lama explicitly "renounces independence". Informal talks briefly resumed after President Clinton met President Jiang Zemin in China in 1998, but were terminated soon afterwards.

The Chinese government has recently preferred to ignore the Dalai Lama, arguing that after his death Tibetan nationalism would disappear.

But senior Chinese officials consistently condemn the Dalai Lama as devious, insincere and representing feudal forces. "The Dalai Lama engages in activities aimed at splitting the country under the pretext of religion," the Tibet communist party leader, Raidi, was quoted as saying in the People's Daily last week. "His cheating and hypocrisy actually go against the doctrine of Buddhism."

Beijing claims that Tibet is undergoing rapid modernisation, that average incomes are rising fast and that it will benefit even more from China's policy of speeding up development of its western regions.

The Tibet Information Network, a campaigning and research group based in London, argues that China's "Great Leap West" is designed to submerge the identity of the Tibetan people.

Moderate Chinese officials acknowledge that Tibet is a public relations disaster abroad for the Chinese government, but complain that western reporting is invariably negative.

Observers suggest that local officials in Lhasa are more hardline than Beijing, and include many who were active there during the Cultural Revolution. Serious talks between China and the Dalai Lama could undermine their grip on power. The Tibetan government has tightened restrictions on the monasteries in the last four years and portraits of the Dalai Lama are completely banned.

The Chinese insist that the Dalai Lama, who fled in 1959, must accept that Tibet is an integral part of China and must give up his "splittist" efforts.

But in recent years, the Dalai Lama has been pursuing a "middle way" and calling on the Chinese to grant Tibet meaningful autonomy, rather than independence. This would leave China in control of Tibet's foreign policy.

"Everybody knows I'm not seeking independence. My commitment to the middle way has not changed. The Chinese government need not have any suspicion of that," the Dalai Lama said yesterday. "It is very, very essential, whether we make progress or not, that we meet face to face. I think one of the obstacles is ignorance."

The Dalai Lama said his brother, who lives in New Delhi, initially had been unsure whether to take up the Chinese offer to travel to Beijing. But he had encouraged him to go so he could visit Tibet, find out what the "real situation" there was, and inform the Chinese government "accordingly".

But Chinese officials prevented him from visiting Tibet, he said. Mr Thondup, who has a Chinese wife and was educated in Nanking before the invasion of Tibet, first visited Beijing as an emissary of the Dalai Lama in 1979 and has held talks with Chinese officials on several occasions.

News of the latest development - which has prompted the Dalai Lama to postpone a visit to Taiwan - emerged following celebrations at the temple outside the Dalai Lama's chalet-style home in Dharamsala, a former Raj hill resort surrounded by snowy mountains in the foothills of the Himalayas.

The Dalai Lama was made political leader at the age of 16, soon after the Chinese began their invasion of Tibet in 1950.

Representatives from all four of Tibet's schools of Buddhism took part in the three-hour ceremony - though the 15-year-old Karmapa, who escaped from Tibet in January to the embarrassment of the Chinese authorities, was absent. The Karmapa, Urgyen Trinley Doje, is the spiritual head of the influential Kagyu sect, which rivals the Dalai Lama's.

Indian government officials are reluctant to grant the Karmapa formal asylum for fear of offending China. Last night the Dalai Lama said the boy had been unable to attend the ceremony because he had a "stomach upset".

"The Dalai Lama engages in activities aimed at splitting the country under the pretext of religion," the Tibet communist party leader, Raidi, was quoted as saying in the People's Daily last week. "His cheating and hypocrisy actually go against the doctrine of Buddhism." Beijing claims that Tibet is undergoing rapid modernisation, that average incomes are rising fast and that it will benefit even more from China's policy of speeding up development of its western regions. The Tibet Information Network, a campaigning and research group based in London, argues that China's "Great Leap West" is designed to submerge the identity of the Tibetan people. Moderate Chinese officials acknowledge that Tibet is a public relations disaster abroad for the Chinese government, but complain that western reporting is invariably negative. Observers suggest that local officials in Lhasa are more hardline than Beijing, and include many who were active there during the Cultural Revolution. Serious talks between China and the Dalai Lama could undermine their grip on power. The Tibetan government has tightened restrictions on the monasteries in the last four years and portraits of the Dalai Lama are completely banned. The Chinese insist that the Dalai Lama, who fled in 1959, must accept that Tibet is an integral part of China and must give up his "splittist" efforts. But in recent years, the Dalai Lama has been pursuing a "middle way" and calling on the Chinese to grant Tibet meaningful autonomy, rather than independence. This would leave China in control of Tibet's foreign policy. "Everybody knows I'm not seeking independence. My commitment to the middle way has not changed. The Chinese government need not have any suspicion of that," the Dalai Lama said yesterday. "It is very, very essential, whether we make progress or not, that we meet face to face. I think one of the obstacles is ignorance." The Dalai Lama said his brother, who lives in New Delhi, initially had been unsure whether to take up the Chinese offer to travel to Beijing. But he had encouraged him to go so he could visit Tibet, find out what the "real situation" there was, and inform the Chinese government "accordingly". But Chinese officials prevented him from visiting Tibet, he said. Mr Thondup, who has a Chinese wife and was educated in Nanking before the invasion of Tibet, first visited Beijing as an emissary of the Dalai Lama in 1979 and has held talks with Chinese officials on several occasions. News of the latest development - which has prompted the Dalai Lama to postpone a visit to Taiwan - emerged following celebrations at the temple outside the Dalai Lama's chalet-style home in Dharamsala, a former Raj hill resort surrounded by snowy mountains in the foothills of the Himalayas. The Dalai Lama was made political leader at the age of 16, soon after the Chinese began their invasion of Tibet in 1950. Representatives from all four of Tibet's schools of Buddhism took part in the three-hour ceremony - though the 15-year-old Karmapa, who escaped from Tibet in January to the embarrassment of the Chinese authorities, was absent. The Karmapa, Urgyen Trinley Doje, is the spiritual head of the influential Kagyu sect, which rivals the Dalai Lama's. Indian government officials are reluctant to grant the Karmapa formal asylum for fear of offending China. Last night the Dalai Lama said the boy had been unable to attend the ceremony because he had a "stomach upset".
fields.bylineHtml: Luke Harding in Dharamsala and John Gittings in Hong Kong

webTitle: In brief: Meg Ryan and Russell Crowe anger director

fields.headline: Meg Ryan and Russell Crowe anger director
fields.standfirst: Plus: Erin Brockovich re-released in the hope of Oscar success; Mykelti Williamson signs up for Muhammad ali biopic; Catherine Zeta-Jones keeps it in the family for her latest film; Hardy Boys grow up at last in action comedy
fields.trailText: Plus: Erin Brockovich re-released in the hope of Oscar success; Mykelti Williamson signs up for Muhammad ali biopic; Catherine Zeta-Jones keeps it in the family for her latest film; Hardy Boys grow up at last in action comedy
fields.body:
 The director of Proof Of Life, Taylor Hackford, has told the Canadian publication, The Calgary Sun, that he is "deeply hurt" by Meg Ryan and Russell Crowe's (both pictured) refusal to talk to certain journalists about their roles in the film. The couple's decision to only talk to radio and television journalists has meant that Hackford has had to do the majority of promotional interviews on his own. He also admitted that the couple - who were involved in a much publicised romantic liaison during the shoot - did film a love scene, but he decided to cut it out of the final edit. "This was completely my decision," he told the newspaper. 'There was no pressure from Meg or Russell - and certainly not from the studio." Proof Of Life opens in Britain in February.

 Universal Pictures have re-released Erin Brockovich in Los Angeles and New York in the hope that Academy Award judges will sit up and take notice of the critically-lauded drama which was released last spring. Chairman of Universal Pictures Stacey Snider said the move was a chance: "To remind Motion Picture Academy voters of the incredible accomplishment that was achieved by Steven Soderbergh, Julia Roberts, Albert Finney and the rest of the cast and crew." After the warm reception given to Roberts' performance, she is regarded as a strong contender to win the best actress prize.

 Mykelti Williamson, best known for his role as Bubba in the Oscar-winning Forrest Gump, is in final negotiations to star as controversial boxing promoter Don King in the forthcoming, much-trumpeted Muhammad Ali biopic. Jamie Foxx and Mario Van Peebles have already been cast as Drew "Bundini" Brown and Malcolm X, although the roles of George Foreman and Joe Frazier have yet to be filled.

 Warner Brothers have bought the rights to British mini-series Trust with a view to turning it into a vehicle for Catherine Zeta-Jones. The film, which is described as a 'sexy thriller' will feature Mrs Michael Douglas as a lawyer who discovers that her psychiatrist husband is having a torrid affair with one of his patients. Zeta-Jones brother, Lyndon Jones, who is to produce the film, told reporters, "It's a hugely commercial premise, with a great role for Catherine, as well as a terrific role for the husband and his best friend."

 Ananova reports that Twentieth Century Fox is teaming up with Ben Stiller's Red Hour Films to produce a £40m (£27.6m) action comedy about the all-American teen detectives, The Hardy Boys. In the film, the former boy sleuths, now grown-up, team up again when their father is kidnapped. A senior source close to the production, entitled Hardy Men, said: "If we can get this right there is no reason why we shouldn't see a series of Hardy movies, like Indiana Jones."

fields.headline: 365 Corporation launches new mobile phone service
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Internet and telecoms content provider 365 Corporation has unveiled a voice-activated mobile phone service, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Internet and telecoms content provider 365 Corporation is hoping to restore consumer confidence in mobile phone gadgets with a ground-breaking new service.

The company is launching a voice-activated mobile phone operation that allows customers to access betting, pizza delivery and florist services at the touch of a button.

Through a voice-recognition system customers will be able to order a variety of products via an "electronic shopping centre".

The firm has teamed up with Philips Electronics and telecoms operator Cable & Wireless to launch the service, with bookie William Hill, Domino's Pizza and Teleflorist signed up as partners.

Mobile phone users have been disappointed by the slow-moving WAP phones and 365 promises the voice portal, called Guardian Angel, will not let them down.

Nik Philpot, a director at 365, said: "I think people will get very excited about the project. Wap has made people more aware of what their mobile phones can do, but it left a lot of people dissatisfied.

"We have a service that is much easier to use and will provide something for everybody."

The service will launch in March, with access fees providing most of the revenues. In an attempt to make the service as comprehensive as possible, users will be able to send emails by voice, and have emails and faxes read to them over the phone.

Mr Philpot said 365 would sign up more partners before the launch, and was willing to licence the service to other companies.

365 runs a series of websites, including football365.com and gardening365.com, and offers information through mobile phone text messages and internet-enabled phones.

fields.headline: Fly me to the moon
fields.standfirst:
Space tourism is just around the corner, so John Crace went to Nasa's academy in Alabama to learn what it takes to be an astronaut.
Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Space tourism is just around the corner, so John Crace went to Nasa's academy in Alabama to learn what it takes to be an astronaut.
fields.body:
I'm strapped into an open chair, attached to a vertical structure. In a few moments, I will be shot 186 feet into the air in half a second.

I'm in a state of near panic. As the seat rises, my guts remain on the ground, and as we hit the top and the machine decelerates and starts falling rapidly, I keep on going up. My bum floats off the seat as my shoulders are rammed into the restraints, and I have the conviction that I'm about to be thrown to the ground. I have just experienced the thrust of a shuttle launch and had a moment's weightlessness thrown in for good measure.

I am in Huntsville, Alabama - home to the space academy at Nasa's US Space & Rocket Center, one of the few places on Earth where a civilian can get a feel of what it's like to train as an astronaut. Ever since the Apollo programme made getting to the moon appear simple, Nasa has had an ongoing funding battle with Congress, and it has launched a charm offensive. Space tourism is this year's thing, as the sign over the academy's entrance makes clear: "The men and women who come through these doors are our astronauts of tomorrow."

If anyone can be said to embody the wrong stuff, it's me. I suffer from vertigo, I'm frightened of flying, I don't believe the US is the land of the free and the home of the brave and my mum's apple pie is anything but sweet. Or home-made.

I'm issued with a set of pale blue overalls; they are short of the full spacesuit and helmet that I'd hoped for, but when I check them against the in-flight wear of the astronauts going in the orbiter (the correct name for the shuttle), they look authentic. After this, things go downhill as I'm shown to my living quarters for the weekend. A windowless cabin may give a good feel of life aboard the space station, but for a neurotic with jet-lag it's a no-go area.

We're hustled into a briefing room to be given a brief run through of the history and the technical achievements of the US space programme. The latter involves a heavy use of acronyms, such as SRBs (solid rocket boosters) and SSME (space shuttle main engine).

Thankfully, the pace picks up as we move on to the main training area where there are mock-ups and in-flight simulators of the orbiter, the space station and mission control, and we take turns to role-play key personnel in a series of missions. I start off as the launch/landing director, before moving on to command the orbiter; I am hopelessly miscast, being surrounded by banks of computer screens with buttons and switches that mean nothing to me.

We're given a script to follow, and dutifully read out commands and key sequences into the computers, without understanding what we're doing. Occasionally, if everything is ticking over smoothly, the trainers will send a glitch into the system and we scroll through a selection of profiles to try to identify the anomaly and fix it.

Mysteriously, we bring the orbiter back to earth. Which is more than can be said for those I left behind on the space station, thanks to an early deployment of the docking gear. Well, at least I'm back safe and sound. The others will just have to hang on in there until 2001.

It rapidly dawns on me that being an astronaut is actually 99 parts scientific and technical excellence, boredom and claustrophobia to one part glamour and adrenalin. But what glamour and what adrenalin. When it comes to advanced theme-park rides, Nasa leaves Alton Towers for dead.

Weightlessness is the sine qua non of the space experience, but it is almost impossible to replicate in the Earth's atmosphere. Nasa puts its real astronauts through a series of steep parabolic loops in an aircraft known as the vomit comet; luckily this is not on offer. Instead I get to experience the feeling of microgravity in the one-sixth gravity chair that was developed to train the Apollo astronauts how to walk on the moon.

Watching astronauts bounding easily over the lunar surface, I had imagined the sense of liberation that microgravity must bring. Far from it. With little gravitational resistance, my early efforts to make forward movement leave me bouncing on the spot like a marionette. With a little practice I eventually cover about 100m in a series of out-of-control bunny-hops, side-steps and slo-mo sprints, but by the end of it I'm feeling knackered. I also wonder whether zero gravity might be all it's cracked up to be. After the first few hours of revelling in the magic of weightlessness, the loss of perspective must become disorienting and tiring. Not to mention the physical effects of decalcification of the bones.

Next, we are moved along to the centrifuge. An astronaut in space might experience 7g of force or more but, despite having completed a medical check prior to entering the academy, we're kept down to several minutes of 4g, as Nasa isn't keen to pay for civilian popped eyeballs, spontaneous bleeding or heart arrhythmia. Even so, 4g is plenty; as the centrifuge hits top speed my body starts to feel heavy as I'm pinned back. My throat tightens as if I'm being strangled, and my face feels as if it is being smeared on the wall.

Pottering around in the 5DF (five degrees of freedom) and the MMU (manned manoeuvring unit), performing simulated EVAs (extra vehicular activities) is as close to the sublime space experience as I get. Strapped into a chair attached to a long arm of something that resembles a giant floating industrial floor-polisher, I swing through five axes of roll, pitch and yaw as I repair a crucial radio mast for the good of humanity.

But to get the full "where the hell am I?" experience, you have to try the multi-axis trainer. This is a chair suspended within two concrete hoops that spins rapidly through every possible axis. All I was conscious of was a series of blurred images as the walls, ceiling and floor smashed into a single vision, and a vague sense of surprise that I wasn't throwing up.

After my performance on the launch pad, I'm not expecting the call from Nasa, but even if I had excelled I don't think I would be in too much of a hurry to go. Three months is a long time in space; the trainer makes much of the fact that inflight cuisine has improved out of all recognition, but the dried peaches still taste like flavoured ceiling tiles.

OK, so there's every satellite TV station you could possibly want, but you know what? Even though you're several hundred miles removed from several billion people, you've got astronauts floating past your nose when you're trying to get to sleep. Even space is overcrowded these days.

 Inside the Space Station will be broadcast on the Discovery Channel on December 10.

fields.headline: Express handouts 'horribly divisive' says Boycott
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Express editor Rosie Boycott has branded Lord Hollick's £40,000 handouts "horribly divisive" in an email to staff, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Daily Express editor Rosie Boycott has branded Lord Hollick's £40,000 handouts "horribly divisive".

And she has announced that the staff who got the windfalls will not be getting pay rises next year.

Ms Boycott told department managers in an email: "Clive's one-off payments have been horribly divisive. They were his personal gifts and had nothing to do with me or any member of the editorial team."

The payments, worth £1m in total, were made to around 25 staff following the Labour peer's sale of the newspaper titles to OK! publisher Richard Desmond.

Ms Boycott, who is one of those to have received cheques worth at least £40,000, is furious with Lord Hollick's decision to single out certain staff for payments.

She sent the extroardinary email to staff as rumours swept Express headquarters that journalists on the paper were about to receive a second knock in the form of a pay freeze.

Ms Boycott's email distanced herself from the payments and tried to inject some calm in the stormy atmosphere that has developed at Ludgate House.

Although it is not clear who took the decision, the email makes it clear that those who got the ex gratia payments will miss out on pay rises this year.

"There were rumours on Friday that no one in editorial would be getting a pay rise in the new year. This is not true," the email continued.

"We are awarding a 3% rise across the board to everyone except those people who were beneficiaries of Clive Hollick's ex gratia bonuses. They will receive nothing. Please forward this email onto your staff.

"Rosie."

fields.headline: No way out for Al, say Texans
fields.standfirst:
As the Democrat presidential candidate suffers setbacks in two separate rulings on the Florida recount, the mood of the media is swinging the wrong way for Gore
Special report:US elections
fields.trailText:
As the Democrat presidential candidate suffers setbacks in two separate rulings on the Florida recount, the mood of the media is swinging the wrong way for Gore
Special report:US elections
fields.body:
Most editorial writers, understandably, are showing no inkling of impatience as the best running story of the decade goes on and on.

In George W Bush's home state of Texas, however, nerves are beginning to fray. The Amarillo Globe-News, for example, is in no doubt about what should happen: "More court challenges well might have to play out. However, the clock clearly is ticking, and Gore is running out of time.

"Former secretary of state Warren Christopher - the vice-president's point man in this election debate - said over the weekend that 'when the time comes', Gore would know when to concede. Mr Vice-President, the time has come."

Coming at it from another direction, the Boston Globe also clearly senses that the Democrat challenge is coming to an end: "Vice-president Al Gore is right to make one last appeal to the state supreme court, but it will take a collective profile in courage for the justices there to swim against the tide now gathering against Gore."

The paper chides the US supreme court for failing to give clear guidance, and makes a forlorn appeal for fundamental democracy: "The US supreme court seems to be as deeply divided as the country. Its weak-kneed opinion yesterday was a major disappointment.

"The path toward legitimacy for either Bush or Gore has always been for the votes to be counted as completely and fairly as possible. Surrounded above and below by courts relying on narrow technical arguments, the Florida supreme court will need courage to further that goal."

The Chattanooga Times and Free Press begs to differ, though it concedes that the supreme court has not resolved the main issue: "The supreme court of the United States has done exactly the right thing in handling its part of the complex Florida presidential election controversy.

"It has upheld the constitution of the United States and has backed away from undesirable federal intrusion in a state election. That, of course, does not solve the legal problems in Florida or settle the presidency of the United States. Many legal questions remain."

The Miami Herald, which backed Gore in the presidential race, nevertheless praises the Florida judge whose ruling went against the vice-president.

The paper asks rhetorically whether Gore should now concede and answers the question: "That would appear to be gracious, but the most important goal now is ensuring the credibility of this election.

"Whoever wins - and it appears very likely that it will be Mr Bush - will enter his presidency stronger as more Americans believe he came by it in a fair way. We believe that will happen when the Florida supreme court has spoken on this case and, possibly, the US supreme court.

"While acknowledging the need for the nation to get on with its business, the next president to get on with the transition and the country to pay attention to an economy giving signs of faltering, we think the best course of action is patience for just a while longer."

The Chattanooga Times and Free Press begs to differ, though it concedes that the supreme court has not resolved the main issue: "The supreme court of the United States has done exactly the right thing in handling its part of the complex Florida presidential election controversy. "It has upheld the constitution of the United States and has backed away from undesirable federal intrusion in a state election. That, of course, does not solve the legal problems in Florida or settle the presidency of the United States. Many legal questions remain." The Miami Herald, which backed Gore in the presidential race, nevertheless praises the Florida judge whose ruling went against the vice-president. The paper asks rhetorically whether Gore should now concede and answers the question: "That would appear to be gracious, but the most important goal now is ensuring the credibility of this election. "Whoever wins - and it appears very likely that it will be Mr Bush - will enter his presidency stronger as more Americans believe he came by it in a fair way. We believe that will happen when the Florida supreme court has spoken on this case and, possibly, the US supreme court. "While acknowledging the need for the nation to get on with its business, the next president to get on with the transition and the country to pay attention to an economy giving signs of faltering, we think the best course of action is patience for just a while longer."

fields.headline: University accepts tobacco 'blood money'
fields.standfirst: Outrage as Nottingham takes £3.8m in funding from BAT
fields.trailText: A leading British university was asked last night to scrap plans to accept £3.8m from British American Tobacco, which is under investigation over smuggling allegations, to finance a school of business ethics.
fields.body:
A leading British university was asked last night to scrap plans to accept £3.8m from British American Tobacco, which is under investigation over smuggling allegations, to finance a school of business ethics.

Nottingham University's decision triggered protests from a cancer charity and anti-smoking campaigners as the chairman of the Commons health committee called for it to be reviewed. BAT, the world's second biggest tobacco company will, over three years, help Nottingham create what is billed as the country's first international centre for corporate social responsibility - a claim disputed by Warwick University which established its Corporate Citizenship Unit in 1996 with support from BP.

Smoking is the biggest preventable cause of cancer in Britain, killing an estimated 120,000 people a year, and Nottingham University has a strict no smoking policy.

BAT is the subject of a Department of Trade and Industry inquiry into evidence that it exploited smuggling around the world.

The Cancer Research Campaign, which funds research at Nottingham, claimed the university had "sold out" while the anti-smoking group ASH branded the support "blood money". Nottingham was urged to reverse the decision by David Hinchliffe, chairman of the Commons health committee which this year issued a damning report into the activities of tobacco companies and recommended the government inquiry into BAT.

"I'm astonished in view of the current DTI investigation and the evidence put to our committee about BAT's activities that a British university has entered into such an agreement," said Mr Hinchliffe.

University officials said there had been a lot of "soul searching" as Sir Colin Campbell, Nottingham's vice-chancellor, said nationally-agreed guidelines on commercial funding had been followed.

"BAT is working hard to address the changing expectations of society and its stakeholders. It has a genuine commitment to engaging constructively, and to supporting higher education and the development of the management skills base in the countries where it operates," he said.

Sir Colin served on a Home Office inquiry into police pay in the early 1990s headed by Sir Patrick Sheehy, BAT's then chairman.

BAT is the only big donor to agree to fund the corporate social responsibility centre which will have a professorial chair or directorship as well as visiting professors from the developing world and scholarships for students from developing countries.

Discussions continue over whether the posts will be named after the firm.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, sent inspectors into BAT after the Guardian published company documents showing how it exploited and profited from smuggling in South America and Asia.

BAT, along with Philip Morris, is being sued in New York over allegations that it is actively involved in organised crime.

The companies are contesting accusations of widespread smuggling and money laundering in an anti-racketeering writ filed by a consortium of Colombian states.

Ken Clarke, the former Tory chancellor and health secretary now paid £100,000 a year as BAT deputy chairman, is a Nottinghamshire MP and supported the deal.

Nottingham's acceptance of BAT's cash has also reopened the debate over the ethics of universities accepting funding from big businesses for specific posts.

Oxford allows Rupert Murdoch to fund a chair in English and a visiting professorship in broadcast media while Cambridge has a Shell chair in chemical engineering, ICI a chair in applied thermodynamics, Glaxo a chair of molecular parasitology, Unilever a chair of molecular science, PricewaterhouseCoopers a chair of financial accounting, Marks & Spencer a chair of farm animal health and BP professorships in organic chemistry and petroleum science.

Cambridge was involved in a similar controversy four years ago when it accepted £1.5m from BAT to found a Patrick Sheehy chair of international relations to mark the retirement of the tobacco firm's chairman.

BAT denies any involvement with smuggling and Michael Prideaux, the company's director of corporate affairs, said: "Along with others, we are working hard to address both the changing expectations of multinational companies, and the issues surrounding our industry.

"We are serious about demonstrating responsible behaviour in an industry seen as controversial."

Clive Bates, director of the ASH anti-smoking campaign, said: "This kind of expenditure by BAT is a brazen attempt to buy respectability. The only thing more dispiriting than the offer is the university accepting it. Nottingham must think again."

The Cancer Research Campaign spends more on research into the disease in universities and colleges than any other charity, including £1.5m at Nottingham.

Gordon McVie, the campaign's director general, said: "As governments around the world curb tobacco advertising the manufacturers must devise new ways of influencing young people to take up the habit.

"It's very sad that Nottingham University has sold out in this way. We understand that universities are short of money but we feel accepting tainted tobacco cash is a step too far."

John Toy, the Imperial Cancer Research Fund's medical director, said: "If you accept money from the tobacco industry you are partly in cahoots with them. For me, it's a simple division of black and white. I think it's a great shame that Nottingham University has agreed to accept this money."

webTitle: Police investigate sex abuse claims at Oratory school

fields.headline: Police investigate sex abuse claims at Oratory school
fields.trailText: The inquiry centres on a former chaplain and governor at the Roman Catholic state school in Fulham, south-west London, at which Prime Minister Tony Blair's two eldest sons are pupils.
fields.body:
An investigation was under way today into allegations of child abuse at the London Oratory school.

The inquiry centres on a former chaplain and governor at the Roman Catholic state school in Fulham, south-west London, at which Prime Minister Tony Blair's two eldest sons are pupils.

Police and social services acted after pupils alleged they were abused by Father David Martin, who died of a suspected Aids-related illness two years ago.

Martin was alleged to have met at least six pupils in his rooms at the London Oratory church, to which the highly regarded school is affiliated.

Two boys were said to have expressed fears that they might have contracted the HIV virus from the 44-year-old Scots-born priest, who died in September 1998.

There is no suggestion that Mr Blair's sons are involved in the allegations or the investigation.

A Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "Allegations of abuse at a London school have been received by the Hammersmith and Fulham child protection team.

"The allegations are being investigated."

ChildLine founder and chairman Esther Rantzen confirmed that the telephone helpline had been contacted by children who made allegations of abuse at the Oratory school.

She refused to discuss the case further, but said: "As a journalist, I have received for years letters making allegations against priests working in the Roman Catholic church, so I am very aware of the problem.

"I also know that this does occur from time to time in schools and I know how difficult it is to investigate these circumstances when they occur in schools," she told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

"Children who are sexually abused are very often frightened, guilty and ashamed and take the blame on themselves.

"When this happens inside a school, they often feel that they have to protect even their own parents, who sent them there for their own good, and they don't want to hurt their parents by revealing what has happened.

"So there are a great deal of areas in which we need to reassure children in order to ensure the truth comes out."

A spokeswoman for Hammersmith and Fulham council confirmed that a child protection team investigation was under way.

As school chaplain, Martin was employed by the church, not the school, so it is not clear whether he was subject to police checks before working with pupils, she said.

Martin entered the priesthood as a novice in 1988 after a 10-year career as a stockbroker in the City of London, the Daily Mail reported.

He was ordained by the late Cardinal Basil Hume, archbishop of Westminster, in 1994.

Martin died four years later from bronchopneumonia in the hospital of St John and St Elizabeth, Westminster.

The 1,360-pupil Catholic boys' school, which admits girls in the sixth form, was founded by the Fathers of the London Oratory in 1863.

webTitle: Cutbacks hit Network of the World

fields.headline: Cutbacks hit Network of the World
fields.standfirst: Oct 25: Cutbacks loom at Network of the World
fields.trailText:
12pm: London-based interactive entertainment service Network of the World was today hit by cutbacks, writes Jason Deans.
Oct 25: Cutbacks loom at Network of the World
fields.body:
London-based interactive entertainment service Network of the World was today hit by cutbacks as its parent company scaled back its investment in online consumer ventures.

Pacific Century CyberWorks (PCCW), Richard Li's internet and telecoms company, said it was reducing spending on business-to-consumer projects by £208m a year.

Mr Li, son of Hong Kong's richest man, Li Ka-Shing, had originally planned to invest £1.036m in NOW over five years.

Today's announcement will mean almost certain redundancies at the west London operation, which employs 350 people.

The company is a joint venture between PCCW and TV and online producer Trans World International.

PCCW originally revealed in October that it would be reducing its NOW funding, following a drastic fall in its share price.

The company is scaling back its total financial commitment to NOW and other ventures from £346m to £138m annually, but declined to give further details of how much NOW's budget would be cut or how this would impact on jobs and the level of service.

Alex Arena, PCCW deputy chairman, said the company could justify spending less on NOW because competition for content had diminished in recent months as the market valuations of internet companies tumbled globally.

Mr Arena added: "The internet market as a whole is no longer moving as fast as it was in terms of the number of competitors and the amount of money that they're spending, so we can maintain our headstart without having to invest at the same rate."

NOW launched in June, offering five themed web portals and an Asian satellite TV channel based around the same mix of content.

PCCW has seen its share price drop by more than 80% since hitting a high of HK$28.50 (£2.52) in February.

webTitle: Sixty jobs to go at Express

fields.headline: Sixty jobs to go at Express
fields.standfirst: Dec 5: Boycott slams 'divisive' handouts
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Up to 60 staff are facing the axe at the Express in the second wave of cutbacks at the newspaper, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
8.15am: Boycott slams 'divisive' handouts
fields.body:
Up to 60 staff are facing the axe at the Express, in the second wave of cutbacks at the newspaper.

Last night 35 staff in the sales department were issued with letters warning them of a review designed to "cut out duplication".

And today more than 15 staff in the marketing and circulation departments will receive similar letters.

The cutbacks follow a review by Martin Ellice, the joint group managing director of Northern & Shell, which bought the Express two weeks ago.

A spokesman said: "He, along with others, have identified a number of areas where jobs appear to be duplicated and where there are excessive layers of management."

The new owners of the Express have already indicated that 40 posts are going at the websites set up by the paper.

And further cutbacks are expected in syndication.

However Northern & Shell said this was likely to be the last area for savings.

"There will be no more reviews. What we are trying to do is cut duplication and put the money saved back into the core titles," added the spokesman.

fields.headline: Testigo - bullfighting
fields.standfirst: Inside the bullring,  Vanesa Montoya  is a rare woman in a man's world
fields.trailText: Inside the bullring, Vanesa Montoya is a rare woman in a man's world
fields.body:
La magia del toreo es que juegas con la vida y la muerte. En el toreo perder es morir. El año pasado yo maté veinte novillas en la plaza. Y doy también muchas volteretas. A veces pienso en el peligro. El torero pierde el miedo cuando se viste con el traje de luces . Al salir a la plaza de toros estudias al novillo, pues no hay dos animales iguales.

Piensas en cómo torearlo. Cuando capeas es el momento más mágico. Es la lucha del conocimiento contra la fuerza. Te concentras mucho para estudiar al novillo. Todo pasa en milésimas de segundo. Se trata de pensar e improvisar al mismo tiempo. Soy supersticiosa y cuando toreo llevo conmigo una estampa del Cristo de los gitanos, pues yo soy gitana.

Desde que tenía ocho años yo quería torear. Pero mis padres no me dejaban. A los doce años entrenaba con amigos y a los quince años empecé en la escuela taurina de Sevilla. Entreno todos los días tres o cuatro horas, excepto los domingos. Hay toreros en la familia de mi padre y en la familia de mi madre. La persona de la familia que más me ayuda es el hermano de mi madre, que es novillero en América. El me ha llevado a torear en México. Ahora tengo 19 años, y mi mayor ilusión es torear en Sevilla, donde vivo, en la plaza de toros de la Maestranza.

En el toreo si llegas arriba ganas mucho dinero, aunque al principio es difícil. Como mujer vives en un mundo con muchos hombres. Y a los hombres les atrae una mujer torera.

dejar to allow

una estampa del Cristo de los gitanos card with a picture of Christ of the gypsies

el/la gitano/a a gypsy

el/la novillero/a apprentice bull fighter, not yet at "matador" level

el/la novillo/a young bull or cow

torear to bullfight (also to dodge, to sidestep or to mess around)

el/la torero/a bullfighter

el traje de luces special costume for bullfighting

una voltereta a somersault when the bull hits you

fields.headline: Toymakers accused of promoting violence
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: A parents' pressure group in the US has issued a blacklist of toymakers it accuses of marketing violence to children, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A parents' pressure group in the US has come up with a blacklist of toy manufacturers it accuses of marketing violence to children.

The Lion and Lamb Project yesterday released a "dirty dozen" of toy brands it believes are responsible for promoting violence.

The list includes a World Wrestling Federation doll called Bone Crunchin' Buddy, which makes crunching sounds when its arms and legs are twisted, but also targets less obvious culprits such as Pokemon.

Hasbro, which owns the Pokemon brand, has been slammed for its Pokemon Battle Stadium.

The parents' organisation claims that toy manufacturers are spending $1bn every year on marketing violent toys to children.

The list also features several toys that are based on hit films. The 4ft Wolverine Battlin' Bop Bag is based on the film X-Men, and encourages children as young as five to hit it on the head.

The accusations echo a recent report by the US's Federal Trade Commission, which called on the entertainment industry to tone down its aggressive marketing of violent films and video games to children.

fields.headline: Asylum rules eased for women
fields.trailText: News: The asylum claims of women who face persecution abroad because they are openly lesbian, express feminist views or have been victims of sexual abuse or domestic violence will be given full consideration by immigration judges under new anti-discrimination guidelines. By Alan Travis
fields.body:
The asylum claims of women who face persecution abroad because they are openly lesbian, express feminist views or have been victims of sexual abuse or domestic violence will be given full consideration by immigration judges under new anti-discrimination guidelines.

The new "gender guidelines" for asylum cases, to be launched today by the human rights lawyer Baroness Kennedy of the Shaws, will not mean that any woman who has been a victim of domestic violence abroad can get refugee status in Britain, but it will ensure that their cases are not dismissed at the first hurdle as they have often been.

The new rules will give protection to men as well as women and stress the difficulties that both face in giving evidence of rape and sexual abuse to the immigration authorities. Asylum rights lawyers say that many men who have been sexually assaulted while in detention find it difficult to talk about the experience.

"We are trying to move away from the idea that a refugee is only a young single male who has been involved in party politics in opposition to the gov ernment of his country," Catriona Jarvis, an immigration appeals adjudicator who co-authored the new guidelines, said yesterday. "That narrow view is being extended to include those who become the victims of forced prostitution, and those who are forced to dress in a particular way or openly express feminist opinions. The 1951 Geneva Convention on Refugees is a living instrument and must change to meet the needs of those who require international protection."

Asylum lawyers welcomed the guidelines as "a great step forward" in acknowledging that there were different types of asylum seekers and said Britain was finally catching up with America, Canada and Australia, which operate similar guidelines.

But the guidelines, which are to be issued through the Lord Chancellor's Department, may prove an embarrassment to the home secretary, Jack Straw, who last October criticised the law lords for being "over-liberal" in backing the cases of two Pakistani women who lived in fear of domestic violence. He said there was "no way it can be realistically argued that that was in contemplation when the 1951 convention was put in place". A Home Office spokeswoman confirmed it had now accepted the House of Lords ruling.

Mr Justice Collins, president of the immigration appeals tribunal, defended the new guidelines, saying they had the support of the UN as well campaigning groups such as the Refugee Women's Legal Group.

"A great deal of work has gone into producing this valuable document. The guidelines provide a useful tool to assist the immigration judiciary, asylum caseworkers, asylum applicants, and their representatives in ensuring that the gender aspects of asylum claims are fully considered."

The guidelines recognise that because the 1951 convention was drawn up in the aftermath of the second world war, the dominant image of what constitutes a refugee in law has been that of a man, and women have not been able to benefit equally from its protection. They also recognise that there are forms of persecution that apply specifically to women, including bride burning, forced sterilisation, genital mutilation, and refusal of access to contraception. In some countries a woman may be flogged for refusing to wear a veil.

fields.bodyText: The asylum claims of women who face persecution abroad because they are openly lesbian, express feminist views or have been victims of sexual abuse or domestic violence will be given full consideration by immigration judges under new anti-discrimination guidelines. The new "gender guidelines" for asylum cases, to be launched today by the human rights lawyer Baroness Kennedy of the Shaws, will not mean that any woman who has been a victim of domestic violence abroad can get refugee status in Britain, but it will ensure that their cases are not dismissed at the first hurdle as they have often been. The new rules will give protection to men as well as women and stress the difficulties that both face in giving evidence of rape and sexual abuse to the immigration authorities. Asylum rights lawyers say that many men who have been sexually assaulted while in detention find it difficult to talk about the experience. "We are trying to move away from the idea that a refugee is only a young single male who has been involved in party politics in opposition to the gov ernment of his country," Catriona Jarvis, an immigration appeals adjudicator who co-authored the new guidelines, said yesterday. "That narrow view is being extended to include those who become the victims of forced prostitution, and those who are forced to dress in a particular way or openly express feminist opinions. The 1951 Geneva Convention on Refugees is a living instrument and must change to meet the needs of those who require international protection." Asylum lawyers welcomed the guidelines as "a great step forward" in acknowledging that there were different types of asylum seekers and said Britain was finally catching up with America, Canada and Australia, which operate similar guidelines. But the guidelines, which are to be issued through the Lord Chancellor's Department, may prove an embarrassment to the home secretary, Jack Straw, who last October criticised the law lords for being "over-liberal" in backing the cases of two Pakistani women who lived in fear of domestic violence. He said there was "no way it can be realistically argued that that was in contemplation when the 1951 convention was put in place". A Home Office spokeswoman confirmed it had now accepted the House of Lords ruling. Mr Justice Collins, president of the immigration appeals tribunal, defended the new guidelines, saying they had the support of the UN as well campaigning groups such as the Refugee Women's Legal Group. "A great deal of work has gone into producing this valuable document. The guidelines provide a useful tool to assist the immigration judiciary, asylum caseworkers, asylum applicants, and their representatives in ensuring that the gender aspects of asylum claims are fully considered." The guidelines recognise that because the 1951 convention was drawn up in the aftermath of the second world war, the dominant image of what constitutes a refugee in law has been that of a man, and women have not been able to benefit equally from its protection. webTitle: 'He can't come back in two months.He'll be dead'

fields.headline: 'He can't come back in two months.He'll be dead'
fields.standfirst: Lost notes, a postponed operation, evasive doctors . . . Keith Harper on how the NHS let down his dying brother
fields.trailText: Lost notes, a postponed operation, evasive doctors . . . Keith Harper on how the NHS let down his dying brother
fields.body:
My brother has died of cancer, painfully and bravely, after an impossible and agonising 13-month fight for life during which members of the medical profession, with the notable exception of his GP, were reluctant to tell him what was happening. Perhaps they did not know.

His final indignity in this traumatic period occurred barely a month before he died. With extreme difficulty he hauled himself out of his bed to attend a regular appointment at Milton Keynes hospital. On arrival he waited two hours for the results of a blood test. They never came. He was then informed by a doctor that his notes had been lost and that he should come back in two months. Shaking with rage and shattered at the callous reaction, his poor wife blazed out: "You can't possibly see him again. In two months he'll be dead."

Several months after he finally passed away came a further example of the appalling lack of organisation and concern at Milton Keynes when his widow took a call from the hospital. "We're just checking up on Mr Harper and to see whether he needs another apppointment."

My brother Nigel had cancer of the neck. At his death, his entire body was a shell, riddled with disease. His weight had almost halved: as his illness developed, eating had become progressively more difficult. He barely picked at his food and kept himself going mainly with liquids. To help him eat, the hospital suggested that a shunt could be inserted into his stomach so that he could be fed intravenously. It is a simple operation and a proposal to which, as always, he willingly agreed, even though people who have experienced the procedure will know the results are not always straightforward and far from comfortable. The patient, usually asleep, lies in bed and slowly receives nourishment directly into the stomach over a period of hours.

Once again the hospital let him down, as he braced himself to take this next hurdle. On the day the shunt was due to be inserted, he arrived for the operation only to be told that a mistake had been made and that it could not go ahead.

I was about to take him on a final visit to some of his favourite haunts, among them the Lakes and the Beaulieu motor museum in Hampshire. "Good idea, it'll do him good," said the hospital. But the opposite was the case. We had to abandon the trip halfway up the M6. He was in so much agony and stooped in pain that we were forced to come home. The operation was eventually performed, bringing him much-needed relief, but he never went out again.

My brother bore his illness with immense courage and fortitude, never once complaining about the enormous and endless pain from which he suffered. But the doctors, either through misplaced kindness or lack of communication, could not bring themselves to tell him what was wrong and what were his chances of survival.

It was obvious to his family that his was a terminal case. Nigel was a heavy smoker, one clear reason for his cancer. But the hospital authorities, maybe fearful of being honest, jocularly suggested that he would come to no harm if he continued to smoke throughout his treatment. If he had realised death was inevitable, he would not have gone through the excruciating charade of fighting for his life. But he used to say: "While there is a chance, I've got to take it."

I know his is not an uncommon story. Many cancer patients do not receive the consultation and sometimes the care they deserve, and Nigel's case must be relevant to the experience of numerous people.

Here is a problem, moreover, which has the potential to get worse. One in three people in the United Kingdom are expected to develop cancer at some stage in their life. Precluding dramatic advances in cancer prevention, it is estimated that this figure will rise to one in two by the year 2020.

My brother's experience struck immediate chords with the national charity Cancerlink, which exists to provide people affected by cancer with access to support. It is currently campaigning for improved communication between cancer patients and health professionals.

Its chair, Professor Jessica Corner, director of the centre for cancer and palliative care studies at the Institute of Cancer Research in London, is disturbed at the communication breakdown at Milton Keynes. She says that if Nigel's notes were mislaid, he should have had a consultation without them.

On the general subject of care, she admits that it is only relatively recently that the right to be told that you have cancer has become generally accepted. "Even now in some parts of the UK, you cannot assume that someone has been told their diagnosis, especially if the prognosis is poor." Her experience is that cancer is discussed in veiled terms. People are often informed in surgical clinics that they have a lump or growth that needs to be removed, and they are still all too often left to decipher quite what this means.

Walking through her own local hospital, a large and famous London institution, leaves her with a sense of being present in body, but having left herself, her spirit, all that is impor tant in life, at home. "Combine this with a cancer diagnosis, with all the emotional and physical trauma and upheaval it entails, and the feelings of isolation and exclusion from one's normal world must magnify exponentially."

Corner says it should be remembered that communicating to a patient that they will die is a formidable task for some doctors, and that they need to be provided with special communication skills if they do not naturally possess them. She believes that, in many hospitals, sensitivity around cancer diagnosis has greatly improved, not from within the medical profession but from research studies revealing the inadequacy of care for patients' emotional needs.

My brother's experience is a stark reminder that the future for cancer services and for the NHS is to find better methods of offering support, and to use the experience of patients to change and enhance the system. Corner argues for the fostering of a new relationship with patients, one that encompasses partnership and collaboration, so that illness becomes mutual inquiry. Nigel would surely have benefited from such an attitude. It would not have removed his pain, but it would undoubtedly have assisted him in bearing it more easily.

 Keith Harper is the Guardian's transport editor.

webTitle: Julia Roberts first actress on Hollywood Reporter power list

fields.headline: Julia Roberts first actress on Hollywood Reporter power list
fields.trailText: The highest paid actress in films has been ranked as the third most powerful woman on the Hollywood Reporter's list of the 50 most influential women in the industry
fields.body:
Julia Roberts has become the first actress to make the Hollywood Reporter's list of the 50 most influential women in show business. The Erin Brockovich star, who commands $20m (£13.8m) a film, has been Hollywood's highest paid actress for a decade, but she has now been ranked the third most powerful woman in the entertainment industry.

The list, which ranks women according to their power to change the direction of their companies or affect the industry's future, is in its ninth year. The Hollywood Reporter editorial director, Paula Parisi claimed it was highly unusual to include an actress on the list. "We tend not to focus on talent because the list was first created to turn the spotlight on women who are doing a great job and go largely unnoticed, but Julia Roberts is in a class by herself," she said.

Robert's inclusion is based on her ability to turn small projects into major box office successes and her clout in securing finance for films.

The news proves that the star, aged 33, who went into a career slump soon after she shot to superstardom in Pretty Woman in 1990, is right back at the top after a string of recent hits, including My Best Friend's Wedding, Notting Hill and Runaway Bride.

Number one on the list for the second year in a row was Sherry Lansing, chairman and CEO of Paramount Pictures, followed by Stacey Snider, chairman of production for Universal Pictures. "Female executives are running nearly half of the major film studios," said Parisi. "As well as the entertainment divisions of many of the major broadcast and cable television networks."

To see the full list go to Hollywood Reporter website.

webTitle: School resources: Occhi puntati sul Grande Fratello

fields.headline: Occhi puntati sul Grande Fratello
fields.standfirst: Ten million people watch the Italian version of the TV programme, Big Brother, every night.  Mariacarla Pavoni asks why it's such a hit
fields.trailText: Ten million people watch the Italian version of the TV programme, Big Brother, every night. Mariacarla Pavoni asks why it's such a hit
fields.body:
Chi sarà il prossimo ad uscire? Pietro, Salvo, Rocco, Cristina o Antonietta? Questa la domanda che angoscia i dieci milioni di spettatori del Grande Fratello, il programma televisivo più discusso dell'anno.

Da settembre, dieci volontari, dai 22 ai 35 anni, sono autoreclusi in una confortevole "casa" televisiva, con tanto di giardinetto e piscina. La sfida è resisterci cento giorni, isolati dal resto del mondo, ma osservati da tutti. Trenta telecamere riprendono tutto ciò che succede nel bunker e lo trasmettono 24 ore su 24 su un canale televisivo criptato e su un sito Internet.

Un canale nazionale trasmette episodi selezionati un'ora il pomeriggio e la sera. Ogni quindici giorni uno dei ragazzi "esce". L'eliminazione è decisa da spettatori e navigatori in Internet, che scelgono fra due nomi proposti dagli stessi compagni di prigionia. L'uscita, con baci, abbracci, pianti e interviste avviene il giovedì sera. Ci sarà un unico vincitore, che intascherà il premio di 250 milioni.

L'inizio è stato intrigante, con un discutissimo amplesso semi-nascosto dalle tende, poi sono prevalse banalità e noia. Ora domina il nervosismo. Il pubblico comunque aumenta e anche gli scettici confessano di dare qualche sbirciatina "Quando non ho altro da fare". Ne parlano i giornali, fioccano i pareri di psicologi, intellettuali, politici, nascono le satire. Come resistere?

D: Guardi Il Grande Fratello?

Massimiliano, 15 - Lo guardo quando non ho niente di più interessante da fare. È un programma nuovo e mi piace curiosare e vedere come si comportano le persone all'interno della casa.

Giancarlo, 17 - Chi segue il Grande Fratello in famiglia è mio fratello piccolo, che ha dieci anni! Io lo guardo solo ogni tanto.

Rossella 16 - Mi serve da riempitivo quando non so cosa fare. Devo ammettere che sono curiosa di sapere cosa è successo. Non mi perdo la serata in cui esce chi è stato escluso.

Sabrina, 18 - Ho cominciato a guardarlo con entusiasmo, pensavo potesse diventare una specie di Friends casareccio . Poi ho cominciato ad annoiarmi. I ragazzi non hanno iniziativa, non sanno organizzarsi, ognuno cerca solo di rendersi simpatico con la speranza di vincere.

D: Che giudizio ne dai?

Massimiliano - È un programma senza contenuti particolari, costruito per fare audience, ma è anche l'argomento di conversazione del giorno. A scuola chi non conosce gli ultimi avvenimenti è tagliato fuori!

Giancarlo - C'è un lato simpatico, perché i protagonisti sono ragazzi, ma il lato negativo è che più che il Grande Fratello si tratta del Grande Vuoto. Mi lascia perplesso anche il metodo con cui vengono eliminati i concorrenti. Dare la possibilità di votare al pubblico implica far sentire ognuno potente, protagonista. È una scelta di popolarità e non di qualità.

Rossella - È un programma di genere nuovo, ma non spontaneo come vogliono far credere. La sensazione è che molto venga suggerito da "fuori".

D: Cosa pensi dei ragazzi all'interno della "casa?"

Massimiliano - Penso che stiano facendo un'esperienza nuova, ma anche che soffrano. È brutto non avere contatti con gli amici, la famiglia e la vita intorno a noi. Ma non mi fanno pen a, perché lo hanno deciso loro.

Giancarlo - Penso siano dei fortunati perché possono vincere un bel po' di soldi , ma mi pare anche imbarazzante essere visto da tutta Italia. È come essere davanti a una massa di "guardoni!"

Devo anche aggiungere che se questa è un'immagine dei giovani, è piuttosto deprimente. Sono persone prive di interessi e anche di vocabolario: non sanno parlare italiano, ogni due parole devono usare una parolaccia come riempitivo. Parlano come degli adolescenti, mentre sono adulti.

Rossella - Penso siano lì per farsi pubblicità con la speranza di trovare un lavoro nello spettacolo. Il premio in denaro lo avrà solo uno, ma quello che loro vogliono è apparire. Ecco perché in un certo senso recitano. Ognuno ha una parte, un ruolo: ci sono lo sciupafemmine , la fatalona , l'ingenua, il sensibile, la saggia _ Gli esclusi sono già stati invitati a tutti i talk-show televisivi, trasformati in personaggi.

D: Ti piacerebbe far parte del gruppo?

Giancarlo - Lo farei solo per i soldi e per passare un po' di tempo senza fare niente_ a riposarmi.

Rossella - No, non mi piacerebbe. Non vorrei mai rinunciare a tante cose, lontano dagli amici, isolarmi dalla vita anche solo per cento giorni.

Sabrina - Pensavo di sì. Mi sembrava una bella occasione per farsi degli amici, imparare a convivere con gli altri e a non annoiarsi, forse scoprire sé stessi, ma più passa il tempo più mi accorgo che, ancora una volta, i giochi sono combinati e non vorrei mai partecipare a questa bufala.

Grande Fratello is broadcast on Canale 5 (Channel 5) every day at 11.30 and 18.30 for an hour, on Stream TV (pay TV) 24-hours and on the web

www.grandefratello.jumpy.it

fields.standfirst: All today's rumours harbour a strange desire to give Jamie Oliver a dry slap
fields.trailText: Leeds, AC Milan and Juventus will have to offer Newcastle £20m if they want to sign Kieron Dyer.
fields.body:
Leeds, AC Milan and Juventus will have to offer Newcastle £20m if they want to sign Kieron Dyer.

Aston Villa winger David Ginola could be going back home to France. Marseille will move for the former PSG, Newcastle and Spurs player if they can afford his wages. At the moment, Ginola is hilariously adamant that he will only leave Villa Park if Manchester United or Real Madrid come in for him.

Leicester will make a £4m move for Chelsea midfielder Jody Morris if, as expected, Neil Lennon joins Celtic in a £5.75m deal today.

Celta Vigo and Real Zaragoza are ready to offer Chelsea £1m for unsettled defender Winston Bogarde.

Manchester City are the latest club to be linked with Everton striker Francis Jeffers. Paulo Wanchope could be used as a makeweight in an £8m deal, according to the Daily Star.

Arsenal are lining up Bordeaux goalkeeper Ulrich Rame as replacement for David Seaman. The Frenchman has edged ahead of Feyenoord's Jerzy Dudek on Arsene Wenger's shopping list, according to Planet Football.

Arsenal are also ready to offer Graham Rix a coaching post at Highbury, less than a week after the 43-year-old was sacked by Chelsea.

Sunderland have had a £1.5m bid for Brann striker Thorstein Helstad turned down, according to Planet Football. The Norwegian club want at least £2.25m for their prized asset.

Bolton and Wolves are locked in a battle for the £1m signature of Sunderland defender Paul Butler.

Steve Staunton has been told he is no longer required by Liverpool. Aston Villa and Crystal Palace will scrap for his signature.

Bolton are interested in Coventry midfielder Carlton Palmer.

Grimsby are on the verge of signing Danish striker David Nielsen for £450,000.

Croatian midfielder Igor Biscan will arrive on Merseyside today to sign for Liverpool in a £5,500,000 deal.

Alun Armstrong will complete an £800,000 move from Middlesbrough to Ipswich later today.

fields.headline: Owning pets
fields.trailText: I've recently become a pet owner after a break of 20 years, and, when I'm not wasting hours gazing into their little world, wondering, I have revisited a genre of books I've generally ignored in recent years - animal stories
fields.body:
I've recently become a pet owner after a break of 20 years, and, when I'm not wasting hours gazing into their little world, wondering, I have revisited a genre of books I've generally ignored in recent years - animal stories.

The sniffy notion that anthropomorphism is, in some way, suspect is widespread, but to the detriment of our understanding about why children enjoy stories. Rescue EB White's Charlotte's Web from the class set cupboard. Wilbur may be dim, but he has courage, compassion and the sense to trust the right people.

Lady Lollipop by Dick King-Smith (Walker, £8.99, 5-10 yrs)

This is a delightful fairy tale in which the ridiculousness of the aristocracy meets the good sense of rural living to create a world in which a princess learns manners, a king learns better sense, and a queen's roses grow more beautifully. A pig take centre stage and Jill Barton, clearly a pig-lover herself, provides airy, witty illustrations.

Leon Loves Bugs by Dyan Sheldon (Walker, £7.99, 6-9 yrs)

There is a definite point to this book Leon's enthusiasm for bugs is more as tormentor than champion, until a dreadful dream demonstrates the situation from the bug's perspective, which is very small and vulnerable. Leon isn't nasty, he simply hasn't thought things through, and Scoular Anderson's illustrations help make the point that to love bugs may mean that you must leave them in peace.

Giant Creepy Crawlies by Nigel Marven (Scholastic, £3.99, 8-13 yrs)

Leon might have learnt respect for bugs sooner had he been given a copy of Giant Creepy Crawlies. Part of the charm of this book is the author's delight in his work. He relates land and sea expeditions, actively seeking encounters with giant squid - an experience which makes him grin so broadly that his diving mask fills with water - and the extraordinary ancient reptile, the tuatara. Don't expect glossaries or indexes. This is non- fiction to be read from cover to cover.

Big Tom by Jean Ure (Collins, £3.99, 8-11 yrs)

Ure is an author so prolific and reliable that we take her for granted. Read Big Tom to be reminded what a talented writer she is. Bobbie is thrilled by the outbreak of war, unlike the rest of his family. But gradually we realise that he too is fearful. He invests his affections in Big Tom, a huge cat, and this relationship eventually bring home the less exciting side of conflict.

The Journal of Watkin Stench by Meredith Hooper (Hodder, £3.99, 9-13 years)

Rats have a reputation for their ability to colonise territory at remarkable speed. This book tells the story of their colonisation of Australia, transported there on 11 English ships. This is historically and environmentally fascinating, all couched in an action-packed adventure story. Ideal for those awaiting the next in Brian Jacques' excellent Redwall series.

The Amber Spyglass by Philip Pullman (David Fickling Books £15.99, 9 + yrs)

Animals are central to the parallel worlds of Philip Pullman's His Dark Materials trilogy. The daemons, a fabulous invention, remain etched in the memory, and in this, the third acclaimed volume, we are reintroduced to the hugely attractive but terrifying Iorek Byrnison. The Bears are magnificent creatures and they deserve the best parts.

fields.headline: McQueen move fuels fashion feud
fields.standfirst: Controversial British designer angers bosses at Givenchy by signing own-label deal with their bitterest rivals, Gucci
fields.trailText: He made his name by splattering the catwalk with blood, insects, skulls and human hair and Alexander McQueen yesterday once again shocked the world of high fashion by joining the home of the luxury handbag, Gucci.
fields.body:
He made his name by splattering the catwalk with blood, insects, skulls and human hair and Alexander McQueen yesterday once again shocked the world of high fashion by joining the home of the luxury handbag, Gucci.

After months of rows with his bosses at Givenchy, McQueen has signed a partnership deal with their bitter rivals - leaving the French fashion house, where he remains head designer, reeling.

Yesterday Gucci said the deal would develop the small, independent Alexander McQueen label - in which it will hold a 51% stake - into the the Italian group's third major brand after the house label and Yves St-Laurent.

McQueen, who comes from the East End of London, entered fashion as a tailors' apprentice at the age of 16, becoming king of the catwalk in the nineties. He is known for combining shock tactics with consummate tailoring skill.

He invented the "bumster" trousers, named an early collection Highland Rape and used the model Aimee Mullins, who has a prosthetic leg.

But alongside the controversy, he has produced increasingly wearable clothes. His signature is the strong-shouldered suit, a look honed and refined over the years. His clothes have found favour with stars such as Kate Moss, Kate Winslet and Gwyneth Paltrow.

Many saw his decision to join Givenchy in 1996 as the creation of a "dream team" but it has proved otherwise. Industry insiders are already speculating on his future at the fashion house, where he reportedly feels creatively constrained by the parent company, Louis Vuitton Moet Hennessy, and its charismatic boss, Bernard Arnault. The avant garde designer has long been at odds with Givenchy's penchant for traditional elegance.

Last month, McQueen told Arena magazine that he felt there were "too many cooks" at the French house, adding that LVMH had refused him permission either to leave or to take charge as he wished.

Directing his comments at Givenchy senior executives, he said: "I'm here and stay here till the end of my contract but I'm taking control of it from now on. Otherwise fire me! Because that's what I wanted anyway."

LVMH, which is already embroiled in an unrelated bitter legal wrangle with Gucci, has been put in an impossible position, industry sources said last night.

At the very least, Givenchy is banking on McQueen to unveil its couture collection in six weeks. He is also contracted to produce another couture and two ready-to-wear collections before his contract officially expires in October next year.

Some have suggested that the provocative move could be designed to shake McQueen from his contractual obligations to LVMH, leaving him free to take a central role at the Gucci label itself.

The man behind the Italian group's look, Tom Ford, is said to be taking an increasingly strategic position and is working to regenerate Yves St-Laurent.

In a joint statement yesterday, the designer and Gucci announced that the new Alexander McQueen label would be 51% owned by the Italian group, with McQueen holding the balance.

One City analyst said that Gucci's stake in the label, which last year had turnover of $5m, was likely to be worth less than $10m.

"The future of Alexander McQueen is incredibly important to me and I believe that this partnership will prove a success," McQueen said of his label.

Rubbing salt into LVMH wounds, the Gucci president and chief executive, Domenico De Sole, revealed that his company had been in talks with McQueen for "several months".

Speaking later from New York, De Sole said: "Alexander will enjoy full and complete freedom. There is no alternative to that. We will respect his creative talents and help him develop the business side."

He also promised to fund shops in New York, Paris, Milan and Tokyo to add to McQueen's existing outlet in London's West End.

This pledge will delight those following the ongoing spat between De Sole and Arnault who are battling in the courts for control of Gucci after LVMH failed in its takeover bid for the Italian group in 1999. Both sides are suing each other for defamation as a result of the battle.

De Sole is determined to keep control of Gucci, whichhe steered from financial and critical ruin to become one of the biggest fashion houses.

But if Gucci falls to Arnault, McQueen could find himself working once more for LVMH, the company he has been so desperate to leave.

webTitle: Army plans regional advertising to boost recruits

fields.headline: Army plans regional advertising to boost recruits
fields.trailText: 11.15am: The army is looking to boost its marketing and PR activity in a concerted bid to sign up more recruits. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The army is seeking to boost its marketing and public relations activity in a concerted bid to sign up more recruits.

Saatchi & Saatchi has handled its £4m mainstream recruitment advertising drive for the past six years but a greater degree of regional support is now thought to be necessary.

Mark Bainbridge, head of recruitment advertising at the army, confirmed that he was now approaching potential partners with a view to having a regional network up and running by April 1 2001.

"What we are looking for is a regional sub-structure to support the national advertising that Saatchi's is producing," said Mr Bainbridge.

"We need a full-service marketing and public relations partner that can co-ordinate our activity nationally. Our structure has changed substantially over the years and there is still a need to recruit more candidates."

In September, the army launched three 30-second ads that featured young people showing potential for military trade skills but in civilian situations. The new strapline was, "If you've got what it takes - take it further".

The campaign was a radically different approach for the army. It was reaching out to ordinary civilians, not just the stereotypical tough guy, the traditional target for army recruitment drives.

The award-winning "Job for life" campaign from Saatchi's has run for six years, and army recruitment has doubled over that period, according to the agency.
