fields.headline: Five minutes with Naomi Klein
fields.standfirst:
Naomi Klein spoke to us on the phone from Toronto about No Logo, her analysis of brand imperialism that has inspired a movement. Find out about the new activism and listen to audio clips of the interview (you will need RealAudio, download it here for free)

Guardian First Book Award special report
fields.trailText: What's No Logo about?
fields.body:
What's No Logo about?

The book is about the birth of a new activism that isn't entirely new but has found some new targets. It's essentially about a moment in time when there was a shift from campaigners going after government targets to going after corporate targets.

 Audio clip

How did you first get involved in this new type of activism?

I got involved with politics when I was at university, I had gotten over my mall phase before I started writing No Logo. I became interested in branding because the politics I was involved in when I was at university basically became advertising fodder while I was still involved in them. I was very actively involved in issues of representation of women and people of colour - the politics that came to be known as political correctness. However, this seemed to become a kind of threatening type of politics and suddenly we were providing content for Benetton ads and ABC sitcoms. So I became interested in how marketing culture fed off so-called radical political ideas.

 Audio clip

Would you describe yourself as a writer or an activist or both?

Definitely as a writer, a journalist and activist. I was an activist first at university and the first articles I wrote were for the student newspaper about the campaigns that I was involved in but I was always interested in writing. I think my strongest writing is always about issues that I care about politically, so the two are entwined in my life. I've always believed that writing is part of activism. The analysis and argument and research are all fodder for activism and what changes people's minds is argument and experience.That's always been my own political experience.

 Audio clip

How do you think Britain compares with the States in terms of branding?

I actually think Britain, in terms of consciousness about branding, is ahead of the US. The US is home of the brand but there isn't really a public discourse around the idea of branding. I think if you talk to most people in the US, even people who have a fairly sophisticated understanding of corporate culture, they won't really see a difference between advertising and branding. Whereas in Britain I think there are a few things that have put the discussion around the difference between branding and advertising into the public discourse. One of those things has been the branding of Britain - the whole idea of very consciously building an identity around a country. I also think that having Richard Branson as a kind of rock star CEO (he's basically the most well known CEO in Britain) has taught people in Britain a lot about what branding means. Here you have a company that is all brand, that is all about extending into new areas, about building these branded temples. It is really about selling an idea, selling a persona as opposed to selling products and that's something that's quite difficult to grasp. That's why I think the discourse around branding is a lot more advanced in Britain than anywhere else.

 Audio clip

What will you be working on next?

I've spent the last year kind of living No Logo, which is a brilliant thing to happen to a non-fiction author; I wrote a book about a movement and then the movement exploded. I've been able to spend the past year being part of it and going to activist events and to universities where students are throwing ads off their campuses and having No Logo days and things like that. I've really been enjoying the process of being part of this movement after spending four years in isolation, writing the book. So in terms of what I'm going to do next I think it's going to be related to the themes of where this movement is going, where the anti-corporate movement is going next. But beyond that I don't know.

 Audio clip:

Are there any first books that you have read this year that have really stood out for you?

I loved Zadie Smith's White Teeth and Dave Eggers's A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius. I'm so honoured to be in this category with them.

One of those things has been the branding of Britain - the whole idea of very consciously building an identity around a country. I also think that having Richard Branson as a kind of rock star CEO (he's basically the most well known CEO in Britain) has taught people in Britain a lot about what branding means. Here you have a company that is all brand, that is all about extending into new areas, about building these branded temples. It is really about selling an idea, selling a persona as opposed to selling products and that's something that's quite difficult to grasp. That's why I think the discourse around branding is a lot more advanced in Britain than anywhere else.  Audio clip What will you be working on next? I've spent the last year kind of living No Logo, which is a brilliant thing to happen to a non-fiction author; I wrote a book about a movement and then the movement exploded. I've been able to spend the past year being part of it and going to activist events and to universities where students are throwing ads off their campuses and having No Logo days and things like that. I've really been enjoying the process of being part of this movement after spending four years in isolation, writing the book. So in terms of what I'm going to do next I think it's going to be related to the themes of where this movement is going, where the anti-corporate movement is going next. But beyond that I don't know.  Audio clip: Are there any first books that you have read this year that have really stood out for you? I loved Zadie Smith's White Teeth and Dave Eggers's A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius. I'm so honoured to be in this category with them.  Audio clip:

webTitle: What the public sector can expect in the Queen's speech

fields.headline: What the public sector can expect in the Queen's speech
fields.trailText: The government will tomorrow unveil its fourth Queen's speech - promising a full legislative programme with the fight against crime at its heart.
fields.body:
The government will tomorrow unveil its fourth Queen's speech - promising a full legislative programme with the fight against crime at its heart.

There will be measures on "the priority areas" that the government believes matter to the people of Britain - crime, health, education and welfare reform.

Much of the attention will be on the Prime Minister's attempt to tackle youth crime and take forward the responsibility agenda. Most attention has so far centred on expected powers for police to impose curfews on youngsters as young as 10.

Other will be included in a new Police and Criminal Justice Bill, while health measures will centre on implementing the NHS Plan, unveiled earlier this year - with extra resources targeted at the government's priorities.

Also likely to be included is a Bill to require house sellers to prepare a special pack costing around £600 to include a search and survey - usually the responsibility of buyers. The aim is to streamline England's cumbersome and sometimes costly house purchasing system.

Anti-hunting pressure groups will be eagerly awaiting details of a Hunting Bill, expected to outline a series of options to tackle the issue.

The Queen's speech tomorrow will effectively mark the last session of parliament and will be the last chance for Labour to push ahead its modernisation programme under this current parliament.

The key legislative announcements for the public and voluntary sectors are likely to be as follows:

Social care

&#149Align Adoption Act with Children's Act to ensure child's welfare is at the forefront
&#149Promoting adoption for looked-after children
&#149Increase in post adoption support by making clear legal duties for Local Authorities

Health

&#149Legislation to enact the NHS plan including the creation of care trusts
&#149Measures to give local authorities formal powers of scrutiny over local health services

Local government

&#149New duties on education authorities to support children with special educational needs
&#149Measures to give local authorities formal powers of scrutiny over local health services

Housing

&#149Councils to have a general duty to rehouse homeless people as a result of the repeal of the homelessness legislation introduced in 1996

fields.headline: Carlton braced for advertising slump
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Carlton Communications is bracing itself for a downturn in advertising revenue despite reporting a rise in profits, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications is bracing itself for a downturn in advertising revenue, despite reporting a rise in profits.

The ITV giant said ad revenue had fallen since a disastrous October, and admitted that "the television advertising market is currently subdued."

Arch-rival Granada Media has also suffered from an advertising slump, and both companies have received a drubbing on the stock market as fears mount of a continued downturn in revenue.

However, Carlton's full-year results showed a rise in pre-tax profits from £317m to £342m on turnover of just over £2bn, up from last year's £1.97bn.

Gerry Murphy, chief executive of Carlton, said the company was "making progress on all fronts", including its ONdigital joint venture with Granada Media, which has nearly reached 1m subscribers.

He said: "A successful media business requires a combination of talent, creativity and a rigorous assessment of the risks and rewards of investing in new ventures.

"I am determined to make sure that we attract, retain and back the people and businesses that will make Carlton as successful in the next decade as it has been in the last."

Despite the worries over advertising growth, which is predicted to slow from around 5% to 3.5% next year, Carlton said advertising revenue from its ITV franchises had risen by 8.8% to £692m.

ONdigital continues to be a heavy investment for both Carlton and Granada, with Carlton reporting a loss of £143.2m on the joint venture.

A much-touted flotation was effectively shelved last week when Granada boss Charles Allen said an IPO would reduce the value of the company.

Carlton, which owns the HTV, TSW, Westcountry, Carlton and Central ITV licences, is also set for a £1bn windfall through the sale of its Technicolor filmprint operation.

Carlton confirmed it was in talks to sell the lucrative business, which had a turnover of £1bn.

Michael Green, the Carlton chairman, said: "If these talks lead to a successful outcome for Carlton's shareholders, we aim to conclude a deal in the coming weeks."

&#149: There were unconfirmed reports this morning that Carlton had talked to Mirror editor Piers Morgan about a bid for the Express newspaper titles before they were snapped up by Richard Desmond.

webTitle: Vieira faces new ban as Arsenal seek old scoring touch in Europe

fields.headline: Vieira faces new ban as Arsenal seek old scoring touch in Europe
fields.trailText: Patrick Vieira will go into Arsenal's Champions League match with Bayern Munich facing another domestic ban
fields.body:
Patrick Vieira will go into Arsenal's Champions League match with Bayern Munich at Highbury tonight facing another domestic ban. The Football Association has charged him with misconduct following the physical Premiership game at Leeds nine days ago.

Vieira, who has served a five-match suspension this season after two sendings-off had brought his red cards at Arsenal to six, was charged after the FA's video advisory panel had studied incidents with two Leeds players, Eirik Bakke and Olivier Dacourt. If found guilty he could be suspended for three more games.

His manager Arsène Wenger said: "We have 14 days to respond to this charge. We will ask for a personal hearing and we will defend Patrick vigorously. I cannot accept the FA's stance."

Vieira was not among the seven Arsenal players shown yellow cards by Dermot Gallagher but the referee has since admitted failing to spot the confrontations on which the FA has acted. While Dacourt has insisted that his fellow Frenchman did not mean to kick him in the throat Bakke has told a Norwegian newspaper that "the head-butting was not the only thing Vieira did to me in that game".

Wenger, who himself is appealing against a 12-match touchline ban imposed for an alleged shove on the fourth official at Sunderland on the opening day, said: "I do not believe the Football Association has made the right decision. I am very surprised that they have said the referee saw neither incident as it is evident that he was well positioned in each case. I also note that the FA has acted on advice from the video panel and not the referee. I would be very interested to know what Dermot Gallagher's recommendations on the incidents are."

Wenger did not believe Vieira would be affected against Bayern as Arsenal look to repair the damage to their Champions League prospects after losing 4-1 to Moscow Spartak. "This game is too big for that," he said.

Vieira, moreover, can take heart from the familiar obstacle to English ambitions that will tonight stand between Ars-enal and a win. At 32 Stefan Effenberg, once the most mixed- up midfielder in the German game, is playing some of the best football of his career.

Like Arsenal, Bayern had not won for five matches before Saturday's 2-0 victory over Bayer Leverkusen, the German league leaders. Arsenal, however, were less convincing in beating Southampton with Vieira's late header and no recognised striker has scored in open play since the 5-0 defeat of Manchester City five weeks ago.

Whether this is about to change may depend on Dennis Bergkamp's sore hamstring when he has a fitness test today along with four other casualties. Tony Adams (toe), Vieira (ankle) and Grimandi (ankle) will probably play but the calf injury Silvinho suffered at the weekend may bring in Ashley Cole at left-back. Ray Parlour is suspended.

Arsenal (probable, 4-4-2) : Manninger; Luzhny, Keown, Adams, Cole; Ljungberg, Grimandi, Vieira, Pires; Bergkamp, Henry.

Bayern Munich (probable, 3-4-1-2) : Kahn; Kuffour, Sforza, Linke; Fink, Effenberg, Tarnat, Jeremies; Scholl; Elber, Zickler.

fields.headline: Venables the six-month saviour
fields.standfirst: Dominic Fifield reports as Boro look for the quick fix without ditching Robson
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough, after a fortnight of farce, yesterday came up with a suitably bizarre compromise to lure Terry Venables back into football at 57 after 23 months out of the game.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough, after a fortnight of farce, yesterday came up with a suitably bizarre compromise to lure Terry Venables back into football at 57 after 23 months out of the game.

Venables was unveiled on Teesside as Boro's first-team coach, working under the current manager Bryan Robson. Yet, true to form, nothing is that simple when it comes to El Tel or Middlesbrough. Venables, not Robson, will take training, select the side and earmark potential targets in the transfer market, making him manager in everything but name.

"If I hadn't come here, Bryan would have continued as manager," he said. "He's the future of the club but I'm going to help with the coaching and Bryan will remain in the same situation as he is now. I've just blown the cobwebs off my tracksuit. I hope it's still going to fit."

Venables, who returned to London last night, has signed a six-month contract. The former England coach, who has never previously worked further north than Tottenham Hotspur, intends to move to the North-east and will take his first training session on Friday once his midweek commitments with ITV's Champions League coverage have concluded.

He will select his first team, albeit technically under Robson's management, for the derby trip to Sunderland on Saturday before coming up against two of his former clubs, Chelsea and Tottenham.

"It's going to be a tough job ahead for everyone," he added. "It's a big challenge, maybe the biggest I've ever faced, and it's one we've got to get stuck in to. I am going to coach the team but there's no one person that's going to solve this problem. It's about us all working together. Everyone's got to play his part because it's going to be tough. It will take me a good four to six weeks to assess the players and I will have to lean heavily on Bryan."

Time is not on Boro's side. Languishing in 19th place in the Premiership, with a single point from their last eight games, the club's U-turn after talks had been broken off last Friday was indicative of a desperate need for tactical inspiration.

As flashbulbs popped all round, Venables, Robson and the Boro chairman Steve Gibson posed arm in arm in a collective show of unity, yet the scene smacked of the surreal. With the former England coach effectively running the football side of the club, it is hard not to view the appointment as an admission of defeat. Robson's job title remains but his role has been downgraded to that of apprentice.

"Terry will mainly be selecting the team but he can bounce things off me," said Robson. "Hopefully his expertise will help me - after all, there's no one better to learn from in this game than Terry. We need him to come in with a few fresh ideas; he commands a lot of respect from the players and they will respond to him. We'd sooner have Terry for six months than nothing at all. I just hope this gives the staff, players and fans of Middlesbrough a big lift. If we get a good reaction, we'll be successful. I can chat to Terry about football for 24 hours a day, bouncing things off him and learning."

Whether successful or not in staving off the threat of relegation, Venables will leave Teesside in May to take up his role as chief pundit on ITV's new Saturday night Premiership highlights programme to be launched next season. "Last week we were looking at a longer-term arrangement but it became evident that that was going to be difficult," he explained. "But if I can help Bryan and Middlesbrough Football Club short-term, I don't think there's any downside to that. We must work very closely together; I will make recommendations but, with me being in the post for a short length of time, it would not be right for Bryan not to have the final word."

Gibson, who yesterday sold the striker Alun Armstrong to Ipswich for £800,000, confirmed there would be funds available for new players and was satisfied with the arrangement. "I'm delighted," he said. "Terry's reputation as a coach is well-known and I think he brings something to the club we have not had in the immediate past.

"I know Bryan and I trust his judgment. He's had six tremendous years at this football club but I think it's time for him to catch his breath, take a step back, learn from Terry and then come back in the summer refreshed. There's never been a question in my mind that Bryan's future was anywhere other than with Middlesbrough but now we're not looking any further than the next six months. We have got to secure this club in the Premiership."

webTitle: BBC board of governors criticised by Bishop of Liverpool

fields.headline: Bishop of Liverpool lambasts BBC governors
fields.standfirst: Dec 4: Head of BBC religious unit quits
fields.trailText:
10am: The BBC board of governors have been lambasted by one of Britain's most senior clerics. By Jessica Hodgson.

Dec 4: Head of BBC religious unit quits
fields.body:
The BBC board of governors have been lambasted by one of Britain's most senior clerics the day after the resignation of Ernest Rea, head of religion and ethics.

James Jones, the Bishop of Liverpool, has branded the board, led by Sir Christopher Bland, as "prejudiced".

And he calls Rev Rea's departure as "a disaster for religious broadcasting and a triumph for philistines".

In a stinging attack in the Daily Telegraph, the bishop accused the BBC governors of "prejudice" in "dismembering, dismantling and devaluing... religion in public service broadcasting".

Bishop Jones accused broadcasters of deviously scheduling religious programmes later and later, reducing audience ratings and marginalising religion as a whole.

The BBC's Heart of the Matter, which was being broadcast at 11.30pm before it was axed, was a case in point, he said.

The bishop added that the BBC's plans to switch religious programming on to BBC2 would not necessarily result in failure, but added that "the track record does not inspire confidence".

He noted that the "contrast between BBC radio and television could not be greater".

In a pointed attack on the marginalisation of religion within the BBC power structure, he said the success of religion on radio was "a result of the positive and enlightened attitude of the controller to scheduling and budgeting; the ability of the producers; and the interest of a popular audience in the breadth of religious issues."

The bishop's attack comes months after the BBC's religious TV was branded as "trite" by church leaders.

Rev Rea, who resigned yesterday, attacked both Greg Dyke and BBC2 controller Jane Root for failing to commission and promote religious programming.

webTitle: Eriksson forced into a long March

fields.headline: Eriksson forced into a long March
fields.standfirst: English press divert Lazio's coach, reports  Paddy Agnew  in Rome
fields.trailText: The English press are diverting Lazio's coach. Paddy Agnew reports from Rome
fields.body:
The jacket says Lazio but the questions say England. When Sven-Goran Eriksson sits down in front of a row of microphones these days, it is to talk about Lazio. Yet, try as he might, the questions come round to England, especially if the English press corps is in attendance, as it was yesterday.

Even though the future England coach was at pains to point out that tonight's Group D game against Leeds was "the most important of the season so far for us", British reporters here seemed more concerned about the game's implications for his future employer, the Football Association, than about its impact on the Italian champions or indeed on Leeds.

Asked if he thought the FA would be glad to see Lazio lose tonight, the implication being that the club might sack him, thereby making him available for England, Eriksson said: "The English FA should, of course, hope that Leeds win, but not for the reasons that you mean. The FA should hope for Leeds to win because they are an English club."

While the Italian journalists were concerned about the match fitness of Juan Veron, Sinisa Mihajlovic and Angelo Peruzzi, their English counterparts were much more interested in what Eriksson had had to say to the England caretaker coach Peter Taylor after Leicester City had beaten Leeds 3-1 on Saturday.

"I spoke to Peter Taylor after his win against Leeds but only for a couple of minutes," Eriksson said. "You see, we sent my assistant Luciano Spinosi to watch the Leicester-Leeds game and I spoke much more to him than to Peter Taylor about Leeds but not, of course, because Spinosi knows more about Leeds than Taylor."

Taylor had dealt more abruptly with a similar line of questioning. "Nothing was said about Leeds," Leicester's manager told a reporter at the weekend. "It is an understatement to say that I am annoyed about what has been suggested."

The Leeds manager David O'Leary was also subjected to questions about the England job but he dealt with them swiftly. "I'm not interested in England, in David O'Leary putting one over the England manager or any of that rubbish," he told reporters.

"If you come into a job like this you get big games all the time. If he wins it's great for him. If he loses he's in trouble: he has to go to the England manager's job."

Eriksson also tried to keep his interlocutors concentrated on tonight's business but the questions kept looking forward to the new year.

Was it true that Lazio and the FA had reached an agreement to free him for England's March World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania? "No, that's not true. I haven't discussed this question yet. That is for February."

Has it been difficult combining his current and future roles? "No. I'm lucky. I have sent my right-hand man, Tord Grip, to England to take over for me. Tord is doing the job for me and that leaves me free to concentrate totally on Lazio."

Then, in response to yet another question about his future should Lazio lose tonight, Eriksson replied: "That is such a negative question. I don't think about losing. If I lose, maybe I'll think about it the day after. Anyway I am the Lazio manager whatever happens tomorrow."

Whatever happens, England will probably have to wait until next July. Two factors have banished the storm clouds that only a week ago appeared to be gathering over the genial Swede's head.

First, Lazio have picked up important Italian Cup and league wins against Udinese and Reggina in the past week. Secondly, the Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti has made it abundantly clear that he expects Eriksson to see out his contract.

The Argentine playmaker Veron seems likely to play, despite a four-week-old hairline fracture in his left shin, but the Yugoslav central defender Mihajlovic and the goalkeeper Peruzzi face fitness tests and the noises were not optimistic.

fields.headline: Phillips recovers golden touch
fields.trailText: This Premiership season remains no blind respecter of reputation. As well as Leicester and Ipswich, the name of Sunderland can be added today to an unlikely top six. But, if this pack is unfamiliar, one recognised name is on the way back. Kevin Phillips is on the goal trail again.
fields.byline: David Hopps  at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
This Premiership season remains no blind respecter of reputation. As well as Leicester and Ipswich, the name of Sunderland can be added today to an unlikely top six. But, if this pack is unfamiliar, one recognised name is on the way back. Kevin Phillips is on the goal trail again.

Phillips' enhanced general play might receive polite notices these days but it is goals he craves. Everton satisfied that craving after 64 minutes - an instantaneous completion of a random opportunity - and he struck a post for good measure. Sunderland will believe a revitalised Phillips will maintain their surge.

Their manager Peter Reid appears to share it, saying: "He's playing better than last season when he couldn't stop scoring. But he's got his goal now and it'll make him happy."

Thirty goals for Phillips last season were enough to convince much of Wearside that his failure to be anointed as England's No1 striker was best attributed to anti-Northern bias. Phillips became disheartened by his limited opportunities and lately had not even kept the home fires burning, with no goals from open play in Sunderland's last 10 matches.

Phillips' fate was settled in one lurching minute. One moment he was ruing a spurned opportunity; the next he had put Sunderland two up.

First Niall Quinn controlled well with his chest and Phillips timed his dash on to the through-pass to perfection, skipped round Thomas Sorensen but shot against the post from a comfortable angle.

The goal abruptly ended Phillips' morbid reflections. It was a messy build-up, Quinn this time contesting a cross and Julio Arca scuffing his shot. But it fell to Phillips, unmarked, left side, nine yards out. Surely his reputation had not collapsed so much that he could be left alone with impunity? He could not: the kill was swift.

Phillips also had a marvellous earlier chance to redeem him self. A long ball to the ever-threatening Quinn drew wondrous skill from the gangling Irishman as he controlled on his chest and then lobbed a volley against the bar. For the onrushing Phillips the rebound eluded him where a year ago it would surely have fallen into his path.

Everton had already won at Newcastle and Middlesbrough. But the Stadium of Light provides arguably the most strenuous test in any north-eastern treble, especially when the nights are at their darkest and Sunderland, with their high-voltage approach, seem to be plugged into the National Grid.

But Sunderland were outmanoeuvred for long periods. Kevin Campbell, the lone Everton striker ahead of a five-man midfield, snatched at one chance and found Sorensen equal to another. The best opportunity, though, fell to the Israeli Idan Tal, who collapsed under the weight of expecta tion and was soon substituted.

For Everton to fall behind, in the last minute of the first half, was rough justice. Sorensen punted 60 yards, Quinn again provided the target and, with Phillips harried out of it, Alex Rae provided a stinging finish from the edge of the area. Sunderland pros pered after half-time, no one more than Phillips. After this he might take some stopping.

fields.headline: Bruce favourite for Norwich job
fields.trailText: Steve Bruce may make a rapid return to management by takling the road back to Norwich, who are now looking for their sixth manager in five years after Bryan Hamilton resigned from the struggling First Division club yesterday.
fields.body:
Steve Bruce may make a rapid return to management by takling the road back to Norwich, who are now looking for their sixth manager in five years after Bryan Hamilton resigned from the struggling First Division club yesterday.

Bruce, despite his prestige suffering with his sacking by Huddersfield two months ago, would be a popular choice at Carrow Road, where he captained the League Cup winners of 1985 before leaving for Manchester United.

The chance of two former Norwich stalwarts returning cannot be ruled out. If Bruce takes charge he could well go back to Huddersfield with an invitation to John Deehan to become his No2.

Deehan, who filled that role in Bruce's tenure at the McAlpine stadium, is still there but working with Joe Jordan under Lou Macari. The former Carrow Road striker has already managed Norwich, in 1994-95, but may be happy to take the No2 job there after the shake-up at Huddersfield.

Another manager under review by Norwich is Steve Cotterill, who has quickly made a reputation with Cheltenham, steering them into the Nationwide League and then close to the Third Division play-offs last season.

Hamilton, the former Northern Ireland manager, took charge of Norwich only nine months ago, when Bruce Rioch departed. But the experienced Ulsterman could not turn things around and his side slumped to a fifth successive defeat at Portsmouth on Saturday. Friction between Hamilton and several senior players hardly helped a club now only four places off the bottom, where Huddersfield languish.

Norwich's chairman Bob Cooper described Hamilton's decision as "honourable" and said: "Despite all his hard work, results just haven't gone his way. He needed time to bring about the necessary changes to the playing side... Throughout the season the press and other commentators have increased the pressure in a job that was difficult enough to do."

Hamilton's No2, Nigel Worthington, takes charge for Saturday's home match against Gillingham but is not a serious contender for the permanent job.

webTitle: Celtic go for Camara but Leicester stall on Lennon

fields.headline: Celtic go for Camara but Leicester stall on Lennon
fields.trailText: Liverpool's reserve forward Titi Camara is the latest player to be targeted by the Celtic manager Martin O'Neill as he strives to ensure his first season in charge of the Glasgow club ends in fairy-tale fashion.
fields.body:
Liverpool's reserve forward Titi Camara is the latest player to be targeted by the Celtic manager Martin O'Neill as he strives to ensure his first season in charge of the Glasgow club ends in fairy-tale fashion.

O'Neill is attempting to arrange an extended loan deal which would see the gifted if inconsistent Guinea international spend the next three months at Celtic, seven points clear at the top of the Scottish Premier League.

O'Neill was at Morecambe last night to watch Camara play in Liverpool's reserve-team fixture against Blackburn Rovers and is expected to have talks with the Merseyside club this morning. If Celtic agree to pick up the £3m-rated player's £20,000-a-week wage, Camara may well be a member of their squad before the weekend.

Camara, despite being Liverpool's second-top scorer behind Michael Owen last season, is surplus to requirements after a series of disagreements with the manager Gérard Houllier. He joined Liverpool from Marseille for £2.75m 18 months ago.

This morning O'Neill is also expected to increase his £5m bid for Leicester City's midfielder Neil Lennon.

City's manager Peter Taylor, O'Neill's successor at Filbert Street, yesterday insisted that he would abandon transfer talks at 5pm today unless he receives an offer of £5.75m which would cover the 15% sell-on clause agreed with Lennon's former club Crewe.

As Camara readies himself to leave Liverpool, the Croatia midfielder Igor Biscan is ready to move in after many weeks of speculation.

Biscan, 22, is expected to complete a £5m move from Dynamo Zagreb this afternoon after rejecting opportunities to join Juventus and Valencia.

"He will be ready to go straight into our first team if required as he has just completed a full season with Dynamo," said Houllier. "He is talented and highly versatile."

Liverpool's 31-year-old defender Steve Staunton is expected to complete his free transfer to Crystal Palace before the weekend. "My love of Liverpool is well known but clearly the manager has decided that he no longer wants me," the Republic of Ireland international said.

webTitle: Weary US voters turn to St Chad

fields.headline: Weary US voters turn to St Chad
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the US elections
St Chad's website
fields.trailText: The website of the parish church of St Chad's in Lichfield has increased its hits from four to more than 300 a day as US voters type the word chad into search engines and click on anything that might explain the bizarre nature of their election.
fields.body:
The website of the parish church of St Chad's in Lichfield has increased its hits from four to more than 300 a day as US voters type the word chad into search engines and click on anything that might explain the bizarre nature of their election.

US polling officials have pored over thousands of ballot papers trying to detect voter intention in the tiny punched squares, categorising them as hanging chads (largely detached from the ballot paper), swinging chads (half detached), dimpled chads (indented) and pregnant chads (bulging). Officials have walked the length of counting rooms, scooping up fallen chads with the gum from post-it notes.

But when the Washington Times quipped at the weekend that St Chad might be the patron saint of disputed elections, the website of the small Lichfield church suddenly appeared on political news groups, despite bearing no reference to the US election, just a list of church services, articles of local interest and a welcome note to pilgrims from Guildford.

Northern Ilinois University now has a link to the parish website on its Whitehouse 2000 election page.

In St Chad's online guestbook, Chad Walker, from Georgia, wrote: "Being named Chad and well aware of the importance of bits of paper called chads I have been embarassed by it all. Your website has restored some dignity to my name for me."

St Chad humbly stood down as bishop of the Northumbrians in 667 after a dispute over who should be appointed. Visiting the British church's website, Sean Fitzpatrick from Upper Darby, Pennsylvania, wrote: "The story of St Chad is a delicious coincidence. Al Gore would have said 'ONE Roman bishop!?! There were THREE! I want a recount.' Then he would have claimed to have been the model for Beowulf." Another visitor from the US, Tracy, said: "The fact that there is a St Chad, and that he is revered because of his humility when he stepped down as bishop of York, is seen as delicious irony here. If only our own candidates would follow St Chad's example!"

Jill Warren, rector of St Chad's 16,000 souls, said: "We are delighted at the number of hits. Surfers, scraping the barrel for stories on chads, have hit our site and this is a new way of reaching out to people."

Stephen Smith, the volunteer who created and runs the site, has put in extra hours to respond to US messages in the guestbook. "Normally, we get one message every six weeks, about the history of the saints or related issues. We have just had nine chad messages in one weekend."

He said he did not expect to attract chad-generated advertising revenue.

"Once the election has been sorted out, our traffic will go back to normal," he said.

fields.headline: Telegraph subeditor jailed
fields.standfirst: Original story in New Nation
fields.trailText:
A subeditor who has worked on the Daily Telegraph has been jailed for abusive and racist behaviour, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Original story in New Nation
fields.body:
A subeditor who has worked on the Daily Telegraph has been jailed after being found guilty of abusive and racist behaviour.

Dominic Swords was sentenced to 28 days at the magistrates court in the City of London.

Police said he was arrested on October 3 at Tower Bridge and charged under Section 4 of the public order act for "using abusive and threatening words or behaviour which was also racially aggravated".

Mr Swords, who appeared before the courts on November 13, pleaded guilty but was released on bail until today's sentencing.

The victim, who works for a local authority, was awarded £1,000 in compensation.

fields.headline: Crushing blow to Gore's hopes
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A Florida state judge last night delivered a crushing blow to Al Gore's hopes of preventing George W Bush from winning the presidential election.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington and  Julian Borger  in Tallahassee
fields.body:
A Florida state judge last night delivered a crushing blow to Al Gore's hopes of preventing George W Bush from winning the presidential election.

Judge N Sanders Sauls in Tallahassee threw out every aspect of Mr Gore's challenge to the certified results of the November 7 election in a judgment that had Mr Bush's supporters cheering and which represented one of the most serious setbacks so far to Democratic aspirations.

Judge Sauls rejected calls for recounts to be held in Palm Beach and Miami-Dade counties, and said that a third county, Nassau, had not infringed Florida law in its declaration of votes. In so doing, the judge knocked away each leg of Mr Gore's principal hope of winning judicial support for a challenge which now goes to the Florida supreme court.

Judge Sauls said Mr Gore's lawyers had failed to prove there was "a reasonable probability that the results of the election would have been different" in the event of a recount. "This court ... concludes the evidence does not establish any illegality, dishonesty, improper influence, coercion or fraud in the balloting and counting processes."

The seven justices of the Florida supreme court now find themselves as the main actors in what could be the decisive legal phase of the election drama. They stand at the intersection between the state appeals process against Judge Sauls's ruling and yesterday's other main development, this time in the federal courts.

This came when the US supreme court refused to impose a solution to the presidential election dispute and instead passed the parcel back to the Florida supreme court in Tallahassee. The nation's highest court in Washington issued a judgment which unanimously set aside last month's ruling by the Florida supreme court that gave counties an extra week to allow hand recounts, and told the state judges to reconsider their legal reasoning.

But the judgment fell short of providing the much-vaunted "closure" which some had prophesied it would bring to the four-week old battle.

However, the seven-page ruling marginally strengthened Mr Bush's grip on the Florida result by reinstating the 930-vote lead that he enjoyed before the latest recounts.

The Bush legal team was jubilant. Ben Ginsberg, the campaign's chief legal strategist, said: "We think that the facts and the law have triumphed here today and we are pleased with the outcome." In Austin, Mr Bush said he thought he had won the election and said Mr Gore was "going to have to make the decisions that he thinks are necessary".

David Boies, the head of Mr Gore's legal team, shrugged off the Florida county court defeat, saying that both sides had always assumed the case would end up in the Florida supreme court. He argued that Florida's statute only required the Democrats to show that the number of disputed ballots would "change or place in doubt the result of the election".

"The ballots were the best evidence of the intents of the voters," Mr Boies said, pointing out that the judge had not looked at them. "This was the first court in an election contest where the court has refused to look at the ballots."

The US supreme court and Florida county court reverses are the latest in a string of defeats for the vice-president, but he seemed ready last night to stagger into a final round, hoping for a knockout blow in the previously sympathetic Florida supreme court.

Mr Gore is now more than ever racing against the clock in his efforts to overturn Mr Bush's narrow lead in Florida before the state chooses its members of the electoral college a week today. Unless one of the legal cases still under way in Florida comes up trumps, Mr Gore's chances of preventing Florida's votes going to Mr Bush look slim.

The Florida supreme court was reported to be studying yesterday's decision by its federal counterpart, and is expected to offer further explanations of its decision to set back a vote-count deadline to enable some counties to carry out hand recounts.

fields.headline: Ball back in Florida's court
fields.standfirst:
Battle for the White House Democrats cling to legal lifeline after Washington judges avoid final election ruling

Special report: US election race
fields.trailText: America's most senior judges yesterday handed George W Bush a limited victory in his battle for the White House, but backed away from making themselves the final arbiters of the outcome of the US presidential election.
fields.body:
America's most senior judges yesterday handed George W Bush a limited victory in his battle for the White House, but backed away from making themselves the final arbiters of the outcome of the US presidential election.

The US supreme court's ruling set aside last month's decision of the Florida supreme court to extend the recount phase of the election. But at the same time, the ruling asked the Florida justices to look again at the reasoning behind their decision, in effect offering the state court a second chance to keep the matter out of the federal court's hands.

The latest decision means that Mr Bush's lead over Al Gore in the Florida presidential election is returned to the 930-vote margin which existed before a recount in Broward county reduced it to 537 votes.

But it took no position on Mr Bush's bigger claim that the Florida court had overstepped the constitution by extending the recount phase, and it left Al Gore's legal "contest" actions against the Florida results untouched, at least until local judges had had time to digest the implications of the Washington ruling.

The ruling leaves Mr Gore and Mr Bush free to continue their sparring in the Florida courts, and suggests that the supreme court might be more concerned to preserve its own public unanimity in dealing with such a partisan issue than to venture in with a more sweeping ruling telling all the lower courts how to interpret the law.

The court in Washington issued an unsigned, and thus apparently unanimous, finding which "vacated" the Florida court's earlier ruling on the dispute. On November 21, the Florida supreme court had extended the deadline for manual recounts of the ballot for the presidency and set a new deadline of November 26.

But any hope - or fear - that the nine members of the US supreme court would cut through the tangle of cases in Florida and clear a path towards a final outcome of the disputed November 7 election disappeared yesterday with the publication of the ruling.

"As a general rule, this court defers to a state court's interpretation of a state statute," the ruling said. But, the higher court said, the Florida ruling may not have taken into account all the constitutional implications.

The Washington judges remained "unclear" about the extent to which their Florida colleagues had taken account of article 2 of the constitution and of section 5 of the 1877 United States Code on the electoral college.

In effect, the Florida court was told to think again.

"There is considerable uncertainty as to the precise grounds for the decision," the US supreme court found. "This is sufficient reason for us to decline at this time to review the federal questions asserted to be present."

"Apparently what they said, as near as we can make out, is that they can't figure out what the Florida supreme court based its decision on, whether constitutional grounds or Florida state laws," Mr Bush's lawyer, Fred Bartlit, said.

"I think that if you read what the court said today, it's pretty clear that they're saying the Florida supreme court has got to tell us whether they were engaged in statutory interpretation or whether they were interpreting the Florida constitution," said Mr Gore's lawyer, David Boies.

If the former were true, then the US supreme court would be likely to leave the Florida court's ruling alone, Mr Boies added. But, if the latter were correct, then the Washington court would want to "have a look at it".

webTitle: Doubts grow over success of Vivendi/Seagram deal

fields.headline: Doubts grow over success of Vivendi/Seagram deal
fields.trailText: 9am: The jury is still out on the £50bn merger of Vivendi and Seagram as doubts grow about the value of the deal, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The jury is still out on the £50bn merger of French media giant Vivendi and Seagram of Canada as doubts grow about the value of the deal.

Analysts are voicing concerns after Vivendi's shares halved in value since the beginning of the year. Vivendi and Seagram's shareholders meet today to approve the deal.

It will be a formidable partnership, as the new company called Vivendi Universal will combine Vivendi's internet and telecoms interests, the Canal Plus pay-TV channel and Seagram's Universal Music and Universal Film operations.

However, many observers doubt that Vivendi boss Jean-Marie Messier will be able to combine such disparate operations successfully.

Richard Webb of Chase Fleming Asset Management, said: "I am not convinced by the logic of it all. Vivendi cannot actually show where the added value can be found, and their share earnings have been diluted."

A key to investor confidence in the deal is the Vizzavi mobile internet portal, a pan-European joint venture between Vivendi and Vodafone, the world's largest mobile phone company.

The combined group's content has undoubted earning potential, but it needs a secure and diverse distribution platform to ensure a steady flow of revenues.

The blockbuster £91bn merger between AOL and Time Warner offers a more integrated base, with Warner's extensive US cable and AOL's massive subscriber numbers, though it has yet to secure approval from US watchdogs.

Analysts have also complained about the lack of progress with the portal, which was launched with great fanfare in June but has been dogged by the threat of lawsuits and the slow roll-out of next generation mobile phone services.

"Vizzavi is the area with the most question marks in valuation. It could be worth from zero to $40bn (£27.5bn), which is a huge gap," said one analyst.

BT has filed a lawsuit against Vivendi, claiming that the portal breaks a shareholder agreement between the companies.

The UK telecoms operator is a shareholder in SFR, the French mobile phone company which is controlled by Vivendi and uses Vizzavi.

Sources close to Vivendi have complained that expectations are too high for a venture that only received EU approval in May and has yet to launch its combined mobile phone and personal computer services in the UK and France.

According to user figures from Vodafone and Vivendi's internet and telecoms operations, Vizzavi has a customer base of 90m people, although the company will not release current user numbers.

Despite fervent denials from Mr Messier, speculation continues to mount that Pierre Lescure, the head of Canal Plus, is unhappy with the management structure at Vivendi Universal and is set to resign.

Questions about Mr Lescure's future are certain to be asked at the Vivendi extraordinary general meeting.

fields.headline: Kronenbourg launches £12m ad blitz
fields.trailText: 8.45am: Kronenbourg 1664 will use a Latin beauty wreaking havoc among her male admirers in its latest TV ad campaign, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
It is a variation on a very old theme - a beautiful woman selling products to men.

One of the most recognised brands in the premium beer market, Kronenbourg 1664, will use a beguiling Latin beauty to launch a national TV campaign as part of its annual £12m advertising assault.

In the advert her devastating good looks lead to a host of fatal injuries among her male admirers.

"This ad will certainly turn heads," said Robert Campbell, joint creative director at Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R. "It makes you wince and yet still manages to make you laugh. It certainly won't go unnoticed."

The ad forms part of a £12m marketing push behind the brand, which has seen it advertised consistently on national TV throughout the year.

The objective is to build on Kronenbourg's position as the UK's number two premium draught lager, after Stella.

Alistair Gronbach, marketing manager at parent company Scottish Courage, said: "Premium lagers represent the most dynamic sector of the UK beer market as consumers continue to trade up to brands that are well supported and have genuine premium values."

The ads will air nationally across ITV, Channel 4, Channel 5 and satellite TV.

fields.headline: 'Years' of winter pressures to come
fields.trailText: Tony Blair warned yesterday that patients will endure winter pressures in the NHS for several more years until increased spending produces enough trained staff to cover seasonal peaks in demand. John Carvel reports
fields.body:
Tony Blair warned yesterday that patients will endure winter pressures in the NHS for several more years until increased spending produces enough trained staff to cover seasonal peaks in demand.

As ministers put the finishing touches to legislation in the Queen's speech tomorrow to push through health service reform, the prime minister also appealed to the media for fair coverage of problems in the hospitals over the next three months, warning of a growing resentment among NHS staff that only the bad things got reported.

"Until we have delivered the increases in capacity year on year for several more years, there are bound to be pressures. And there will be cases where patients do not get the care they should," he said.

"But let us get a sense of balance. Support the NHS staff who give a wonderful service to the majority of patients and do not fall into the trap of saying that every time something goes wrong, the NHS is in crisis or on its knees. The glass is half full, not half empty."

Mr Blair was presenting the government's winter planning strategy to leaders of doctors, nurses and NHS managers at a press conference in Downing Street. They were shown the document a week ago, but attended yesterday to show solidarity.

The prime minister gave a double message to sceptical voters, trying to play up improvements in the capacity of the NHS to withstand winter pressures, but also to reduce expectations that the service can avoid running into difficulty.

He said progress over the last 12 months included 445 extra critical care beds, an increase of 18% on hospitals' capacity last winter. There were 3.2m more doses of flu vaccine, 1,350 more acute beds and more than 6,000 extra nurses - a net increase of 16,000 since the election.

Health authorities had spent £20m on contracts with independent hospitals under the recent concordat with the private sector. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said this would provide thousands of NHS patients with routine surgery over coming months.

The government yesterday distributed £100m in grants to local authorities for social services in 2001-2, allowing them to help older people leave hospital this winter without fearing the cost of looking after them during the next financial year. But Mr Blair warned: "Inevitably the NHS is not yet the service patients would like it to be. There is still a long way to go."

The government is expected to promise legislation tomorrow to speed up the pace of NHS reform. It will include powers for health authorities and local councils to form care trusts to co-ordinate hospitals, GPs and social services. The bill will abolish community health councils and create a new patient advocate service. There will be powers to provide free nursing care for the elderly.

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said: "Talking about whether the NHS glass is half full or half empty misses the point - what patients and doctors are worried about is whether their hospital's beds are full or not."

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said: "The extra nurses have to be good news, but most hospitals would tell you that they still have very real shortages of staff this winter."

webTitle: Jobless to take classes or lose benefits

fields.headline: Jobless to take classes or lose benefits
fields.trailText: The government is considering cutting unemployment benefits for claimants who have poor reading, writing and arithmetic, but who shun help offered to improve them, writes Peter Kingston.
fields.body:
The government is considering cutting unemployment benefits for claimants who have poor reading, writing and arithmetic, but who shun help offered to improve them.

The proposal is part of a national crusade to boost basic skills to be launched today by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary.

He believes radical solutions are needed because initiatives over recent years have failed to reduce illiteracy and innumeracy among adults. Last year a report by Sir Claus Moser said 7m adults had inadequate basic skills.

The government believes these weaknesses are a threat to its vision of a "skills economy".

A new cabinet committee set up to address the basic skills problem has set a target to cut the overall number of adults with weak literacy and numeracy by 750,000 by 2004.

In today's Guardian education supplement Mr Blunkett outlines Skills for Life, a consultation paper for a comprehensive national strategy for tackling poor basic skills.

The aim is "to test out whether incentives to partici pate in basic education will help these individuals get and keep jobs," Mr Blunkett said.

One way which could be explored would be to make payment of the benefit dependent on "willingness to improve basic skills", a departmental source said.

This could mean testing claimants and making those identified with inadequate literacy and numeracy enrol for appropriate programmes, with a cut in benefit for those who refuse.

Ministers believe many people's reluctance to return to study stems from dismal experiences first time around, which often accounted for their poor reading and writing skills.

They think it is unrealistic simply shunting them towards the nearest further education college and want to encourage learning in shopping centres, pubs and other community locations.

"We need to be radical and imaginative," Mr Blunkett said. "Adults want to study at times and in places that are convenient for them, so we will ensure that their learning choices are rich and varied."

webTitle: Consultants threaten to close A&E unit

fields.headline: Consultants threaten to close A&E unit
fields.trailText: Twelve senior consultants at the Manchester Royal Infirmary are insisting its "degrading" accident and emergency unit be closed three days a week to non-urgent cases referred by doctors, to ease pressure caused by the unit's shortage of beds.
fields.body:
Twelve senior consultants at the Manchester Royal Infirmary are insisting its "degrading" accident and emergency unit be closed three days a week to non-urgent cases referred by doctors, to ease pressure caused by the unit's shortage of beds.

They have written to Central Manchester healthcare trust's chief executive, David Woodyatt, saying: "We are ashamed of the conditions we are offering our patients for long periods. It is simply degrading and unpleasant for them, and indeed for us in 2000. Therefore we have to inform you that from Monday, December 11, we insist on the A&E department being closed to ambulance referrals for Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays."

However, Bob Johnson, medical director of the trust, and a consultant surgeon at the infirmary, said: "It is not up to doctors to decide whether to close departments, it is a matter for the trust - and we will not be closing the A&E." He added that the letter reflected frustration felt by consultants across the service.

Doctors at the infirmary asked for at least 25 beds to be made available to deal with the winter season, but claim only 11 had been made available because of lack of staff.

A spokeswoman for the trust said the A&E department had been under pressure since the closure of a casualty unit at Withington hospital, but a new three-storey theatre block with 112 in-patient beds would open in September and other measures had been put in place. Over the winter the hospital's intensive care unit would increase by two beds to 13 and four extra high dependency beds would open in January.

webTitle: ITV cancels Savage New Year's Eve

fields.headline: Fireworks cancellation put rocket under ITV's New Year's Eve plans
fields.trailText: 8.15am:ITV has pulled the plug on its New Year's Eve special starring Lily Savage following the cancellation of the London fireworks display, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Outrageous drag artist Paul O'Grady has become a victim of the London fireworks celebration fiasco.

An ITV New Year's Eve special, which was to have been presented by his hit character Lily Savage, has been cancelled.

ITV was planning to broadcast a live special, fronted by Ms Savage from around 11pm on New Year's Eve, with the "midnight moment" firework display being lined up by London mayor Ken Livingstone as the show's centrepiece.

But the broadcaster has been forced to pull the plug on the show, following last month's cancellation of the fireworks spectacular.

The display was dropped after London Underground announced that it was closing all but 10 of its central London stations at 4pm on December 31, raising doubts about how people would get into the capital to see the fireworks.

A spokesman for Carlton TV, the producers of the show, said: "The show hinged on there being a big hoopla around the Thames with the fireworks. Suddenly there wasn't, which rather defeated the object of doing it."

ITV is expected to announce a replacement programme later this week, when the Christmas and New Year listings are published.

fields.headline: Leagas Delaney exec blasts BBC
fields.standfirst: Dec 5: BBC revamps agency roster
fields.trailText:
11.45am: The advertising supremo behind the BBC's acclaimed Perfect Day promotion has today lashed out at the corporation after his ad agency was dumped.
Dec 5: BBC revamps agency roster
fields.body:
The advertising supremo behind the BBC's acclaimed Perfect Day promotion has today lashed out at the corporation after his ad agency was dumped.

Tim Delaney, executive creative director at Leagas Delaney, said the decision showed a serious lack of seniority at the corporation's marketing department.

Leagas Delaney has been the lead BBC agency for the past five years but was today dropped as part of a streamlining operation by the corporation.

"The whole thing is completely mystifying," said Delaney "They told us that we did the best presentation by a mile but that they couldn't work with us.

"We've been the BBC's main agency for the last five years and produced some extraordinary advertising for them. They have thrown away proven experience.

"The people there are very young. There is no real experience now that Matthew has left."

Mr Delaney was referring to former Radio 1 boss Matthew Bannister, who has been the director of marketing at the BBC for less than a year.

He recently announced he was quitting as part of a career switch. Up to now the BBC has used up to seven main agencies, which have over the last five years produced a string of memorable campaigns.

These have ranged from the recent digital TV ad starring Michelle Collins and Zoe Ball to the children's TV campaign starring schoolboy star Scott Chisholm, and the Perfect Day video starring Bono, Tammy Wynette and David Bowie.

Mr Delaney said the rationale behind the BBC's thinking was that it wanted to appoint one big agency and one smaller creative agency.

"We were told they didn't want us, and get this, because we are medium-sized," he said.

The BBC has now opted for a smaller roster of agencies including Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters and Fallon, the agency behind Radio 1's campaigns.

Mr Delaney added: "The BBC has been a mission for us, we have rarely made money on it but that's not why you work for a client like that.

"I fundamentally believe in it but when young people are allowed to do what they've just done it shows a serious lack of seniority in the decision-making - a decision that will make a material difference to their business. I'd have to put it down to a new team wanting new faces."

He believes his agency have "de-demonised" the BBC's use of outside advertising agencies. The corporation was reluctant to use outside firms before the agency's appointment.

"When we first worked with the BBC, it had by its own admission no marketing expertise. Two years later it was named brand of the year. That is in part, a testament to our work," he said.

webTitle: Maxim to launch US fashion glossy

fields.headline: Maxim to launch US fashion glossy
fields.trailText: 8am: Maxim is launching a fashion-based glossy spin-off in the US, which could reach the UK next year, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Maxim is launching a fashion-based, glossy spin-off in the US, which could form the basis for a new launch in the UK late next year.

And Dennis Publishing, headed by media maverick Felix Dennis, wants to expand the Maxim brand into a masthead TV show in the States.

Former Arena editor Greg Williams, who is currently editor-at-large of Maxim, will edit Maxim Fashion when it launches in the US next spring.

Maxim Fashion will be launched as a biannual experiment for the spring and autumn fashion seasons. If it proves successful, Dennis is likely to launch a UK version next autumn.

Observers have expressed doubt that Maxim Fashion will be able to crack the competitive US men's fashion market against competition from rivals including Details, Esquire and FHM Collections.

But Andy Semple, publisher of Maxim UK, said that the magazine's strong following in the US will give it a headstart.

Semple confirmed US reports that Dennis US was talking to cable networks Fox and ABC about creating masthead Maxim brands.

fields.headline: New PHD scoops Weetabix account
fields.trailText: 8am: New PHD has picked up £18m-worth of business by bagging the media account for Weetabix in a five-way pitch, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
New PHD has added nearly £18m-worth of business to its books this week by picking up the centralised media account for Weetabix.

It scooped the £17.3m business following a five-way pitch against Western Media, OMD UK, StarCom Motive and MediaCom TMB.

The win will secure the agency additional brands including Frutibix, Weetos and the main Weetabix brand - the most prized of the portfolio.

Western emerges as the biggest loser. It has been handling the lion's share of the Weetabix business with a slice of around £13m. It faces the loss as it prepares to merge into Initiative Media over the next few months.

fields.headline: Euro turns the corner
fields.standfirst:
US economic slowdown helps European currency deliver its most sustained recovery yet

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The euro yesterday showed signs of turning the corner with the best five-day rally since it was introduced two years ago.
fields.body:
The euro yesterday showed signs of turning the corner with the best five-day rally since it was introduced two years ago.

Europe's single currency gained more than 5% against the dollar on the back of mounting worries about the health of the US economy, breaking through $0.89. This marked its strongest performance since the Group of Seven industrialised countries banded together to support it on September 22.

The recent rises mean the G7 countries have made a profit of around $1bn between them since the intervention began, according to Nick Parsons, chief currency strategist at Commerzbank.

Mr Parsons said the euro could now look forward to parity with the dollar in the first half of next year.

"It's been a day of reckoning on the foreign exchange market. It really does look as though the euro has turned a corner."

Since the currency was first traded in January 1999 its value against the dollar has declined by around 25%. Investors have been attracted to the greenback by the relative strength of the US economy and a higher return on American assets.

But now that the hi-tech bubble has burst and US growth is beginning to slow markedly, the dollar has suffered a reversal of fortune.

Mr Parsons said that since its peak on March 10 the total market capitalisation of the Nasdaq - until last spring the symbol of US investors' rampant enthusiasm for technology stocks - had fallen by $4.1 trillion, or $15bn a day.

Analysts say the dollar is exposed to a decline in hi-tech companies because they have been the driving force of US growth.

In early trade yesterday, US stocks were mixed with the Nasdaq down more than 2.75% but the blue chip Dow Jones index up about 0.5%.

The picture of a cooling economy was reinforced by a fall in the privately run Conference Board's Index of Leading Economic Indicators, a respected gauge of the US economy, which dipped 0.2% in October to 105.5.

"This series has been signaling, and continues to point toward, a cooling of still strong economic conditions," Conference Board economist Ken Goldstein said.

Although the US labour market remains tight, falling share prices are beginning to de press consumer spending, the index suggested.

"This points not only to an economic slowdown, which has been going on, but a rising possibility of an economic downturn," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo Bank in Minneapolis.

"The probability of an economic recession is rising at a good pace, although a soft landing is still more likely today."

To prevent the possibility of the slowdown turning into a recession, economists expect the US Federal Reserve, when it holds its next meeting on Tuesday week, to abandon its bias towards raising interest rates in favour of a neutral policy stance.

However, the market is not anticipating a rate cut to bolster growth until March next year.

The US central bank has held key short-term rates steady since May, following six rate rises after June 1999, but has repeatedly warned that it considers inflation a bigger economic risk than a sharp slowdown.

In a separate report, the commerce department reported that sales of new US homes in October fell 2.6% to an annual rate of 928,000 units, compared to 953,000 in September.

webTitle: Women can bring added value to social care organisations

fields.headline: Women can bring added value to social care organisations
fields.standfirst: It is time that the expertise and life experience of all members of the workforce is seen as an important resource, argues Daphne Statham
fields.trailText: It is time that the expertise and life experience of all members of the workforce is seen as an important resource, argues Daphne Statham
fields.body:
SocietyGuardian's list of the most influential people in social care was mainly made up of women and headed by a woman. This is an appropriate recognition of the contribution women make to social care as a whole, but it is not reflected in some parts of the industry.

Women are the mainstay of the social care workforce, making up nearly 90% overall. The percentage is even higher in home care work. The National Institute for Social Work's workforce studies tracked social workers' jobs over five years and found that while more than half the men surveyed were in management positions, only one third of women had reached this level.

The main reason for this trend seems to be that women's work patterns put them at a disadvantage in their careers. Men and women tend to have different employment patterns. Women, unlike most men, usually have periods of part-time working and time out of employment. The institute's research found that, where their employment patterns followed those of their male colleagues, women did not experience this career block.

Not all women want to become managers, and we need to have enough expert practitioners to provide social care. But not moving into a managerial role should be a matter of choice as opposed to a lack of options because of responsibility for parenting, supporting family members, or different lifestyles.

There appears to be a gender-based culture in most organisations, where men usually have expectations about moving into management while women see obstacles - the glass ceiling.

For black and minority ethnic women, there are additional blocks. Just under a third of staff surveyed reported incidents of racism from colleagues and managers, with 45% reporting such behaviour from service users and their relatives. It is troubling that the attitudes of colleagues are not much different to the public's.

Against this background, and with today's greater employment options for women, there are problems recruiting and retaining social care staff. At the same time, there is an increased need for a committed workforce to deliver the new quality strategy. The research and joint reviews of social service departments show a connection between good human resource policies and high quality service provision - as well as evidence that such policies help retain staff.

People skills needed in social care jobs are also highly valued in the service industries. In the wider employment scene, some businesses are beginning to look at flexible employment policies that balance work and family life for both men and women, as a way to retain a critical mass of expertise.

Social care has done well on flexible working, with a high number of part-time jobs in the sector, but less so on removing the disadvantages attached to this pattern of work - insecure, low paid and with poor access to training. This is a problem employers need to tackle if they want to encourage commitment.

Human resource policies also have to acknowledge that about a third of all staff, including first-line managers, support an adult family member at home. While there has been some recognition of childcare needs, the true and significant number of carers among the workforce is often hidden. The impetus to get more staff qualified will have to take account of the balance that a substantial number of staff have to make between work and home life.

Recognition is also needed of the "added value" these (mainly) women, together with black and minority ethnic and disabled staff, can bring to the organisation's work. It is ironic that the expertise and experience of people using services are being seen as an important resource, yet this same resource in the workforce is to a large extent unacknowledged.

We have to get away from a view that employees' personal experience and expertise is a block to an efficiently run organisation and to good social care. This position is in conflict with the policies for involving service users and contrasts with the position taken by organisations that are run by service users, such as the National Centre for Independent Living.

These organisations have shown how people's life experiences and expertise can be used creatively to help them remain user-focused and efficient. Surely we can learn from them and develop policies, management approaches and training which values the life experiences and expertise of staff, too?

Creating a culture that appreciates and uses workers' experience may be part of the answer to providing services to which staff are committed, as well as being valued by service users.

 Daphne Statham is director of the National Institute for Social Work

 The social services workforce studies: second summary, November 2000

fields.bodyText: SocietyGuardian's list of the most influential people in social care was mainly made up of women and headed by a woman. This is an appropriate recognition of the contribution women make to social care as a whole, but it is not reflected in some parts of the industry. Women are the mainstay of the social care workforce, making up nearly 90% overall. The percentage is even higher in home care work. The National Institute for Social Work's workforce studies tracked social workers' jobs over five years and found that while more than half the men surveyed were in management positions, only one third of women had reached this level. The main reason for this trend seems to be that women's work patterns put them at a disadvantage in their careers. Men and women tend to have different employment patterns. Women, unlike most men, usually have periods of part-time working and time out of employment. The institute's research found that, where their employment patterns followed those of their male colleagues, women did not experience this career block. Not all women want to become managers, and we need to have enough expert practitioners to provide social care. But not moving into a managerial role should be a matter of choice as opposed to a lack of options because of responsibility for parenting, supporting family members, or different lifestyles. There appears to be a gender-based culture in most organisations, where men usually have expectations about moving into management while women see obstacles - the glass ceiling. For black and minority ethnic women, there are additional blocks. Just under a third of staff surveyed reported incidents of racism from colleagues and managers, with 45% reporting such behaviour from service users and their relatives. It is troubling that the attitudes of colleagues are not much different to the public's. Against this background, and with today's greater employment options for women, there are problems recruiting and retaining social care staff. At the same time, there is an increased need for a committed workforce to deliver the new quality strategy. The research and joint reviews of social service departments show a connection between good human resource policies and high quality service provision - as well as evidence that such policies help retain staff. People skills needed in social care jobs are also highly valued in the service industries. This is a problem employers need to tackle if they want to encourage commitment. Human resource policies also have to acknowledge that about a third of all staff, including first-line managers, support an adult family member at home. While there has been some recognition of childcare needs, the true and significant number of carers among the workforce is often hidden. The impetus to get more staff qualified will have to take account of the balance that a substantial number of staff have to make between work and home life.
