fields.headline: How life in fast lane could curb pavement rage
fields.trailText: The double pram outside the Disney Store was causing a tailback that stretched all the way to Selfridges. In Oxford Street, in the West End of London, yesterday, impatience to get past it turned the pavement into an obstacle course, in which the lucky ones were those who got an apology after the elbow in the ribs.
fields.body:
The double pram outside the Disney Store was causing a tailback that stretched all the way to Selfridges. In Oxford Street, in the West End of London, yesterday, impatience to get past it turned the pavement into an obstacle course, in which the lucky ones were those who got an apology after the elbow in the ribs.

In a vision of Oxford Street presented to Westminster city council, pedestrians on one of London's busiest shopping streets would be delivered from the scrum by sticking to one of two lanes: the fast one, with a minimum speed of 3mph, and a slow one for tourists, window shoppers and natural dawdlers.

Devised by a group of traders under the name Operation Tugboat, the idea is to reduce the potential for "pavement rage", outbursts of temper triggered by irritation at walking behind someone with a slower pace.

"In an ideal world there would not be any regulation," said Rhona Harrison, spokes woman for the team. "But there are too many people and there is too little space."

The two lane system would be marshalled by pavement cops, invested with the power to impose £10 fines on slow coaches drifting into the fast lane. In the fast lane, breaks for eating, map-reading and the use of mobile telephones would be banned.

"I'm very old - I'm 85," said Reenie Pyle from Dulwich, who was cutting a slow path through the crowds to Marks & Spencer. She is at constant risk of being mown down. "I'm a bit doddery and when I walk here with my son, he's half a mile ahead. People just give you a shove and sometimes they say sorry. But really, who's going to abide by a silly rule like lanes?"

In the bottleneck outside Top Shop, Fiona Thomas, a training officer with advanced bobbing and weaving skills, said: "As someone who walks quite fast, I'm all for it. I cope when I'm stuck behind someone slow - looking for spaces, dashing into the road to nip past them on the outside - but it can be frustrating. If this scheme got off the ground it would save a lot of time. Mind you, they'd have to create entry points so people could cross lanes and get into the shops."

"I'd be one of the map-readers in the slow lane," said Robert Owens, a tourist from Sydney carrying the sort of monster rucksack that triggers an instant fit of pavement rage in the busy Londoner. "I just go with the flow, you know? Regardless of how many rules they create, people are always going to break them, so what's the point?"

Nine million tourists visit Oxford Street each year. Mark Impleton, a T-shirt seller stationed between House of Fraser and John Lewis, said: "It annoys me when people doodle along, but the whole point is there aren't enough people in Oxford Street. It's only this busy for a couple of weeks at Christmas and even then people can get all the shops they want at Brent Cross. If Selfridges goes, it won't be worth trading here."

He said the lane system would take up valuable pave ment space and push more pedestrians on to the road. "Since they've widened the pavement the gap between the buses and the shoppers has become so small that there's an ambulance called out at least once a month. This would make it even worse."

Westminster city council said the scheme was a recipe for creating more confusion and that people should be allowed to walk at the pace they want. A spokeswoman said: "We don't want to be too mean and council-ish about this idea ... but really."

webTitle: Byers to hit out at CBI over parents' rights

fields.headline: Byers to hit out at CBI over parents' rights
fields.standfirst: SocietyGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will accuse the CBI and other business organisations of being outdated and out of touch with enlightened company practice on the rights of employed parents this week.
fields.body:
The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will accuse the CBI and other business organisations of being outdated and out of touch with enlightened company practice on the rights of employed parents this week.

A long awaited green paper on the balance between work and home life, to be published on Thursday, will claim that improved rights could save business at least £30m a year in reduced recruitment costs in the long term.

The government will propose two weeks' state-paid paternity leave for 350,000 working fathers each year. The DTI estimates that there would be a 60% take up, which will cost the state £25m a year. It recommends the rate should be set at £60.20, the same as the flat rate for maternity pay.

It will also propose that parents with disabled children should be allowed to take extended parental leave at any point up to the child's 18th birthday. At present access to parental leave stops as soon as a child is five. The DTI will also propose a range of extended maternity rights, but offer no fixed proposals.

Mr Byers is to take on both the British Chambers of Commerce and the CBI by ridiculing their claim that his proposals will be a burden on business. He will draw on a DTI survey showing massive support for the reforms to press his case.

The industry secretary likens the coming battle to the struggle to persuade business to accept the statutory minimum wage and will argue that the ideas in the green paper mark a key dividing line between Labour and the Tories as the election approaches.

The green paper will argue that if, as a result of its proposals, only 10% of mothers change their mind and return to work following the birth of their child, employers would save £30m in recruitment costs. The average cost of recruiting each individual worker is estimated at £3,500.

For example, the NHS loses an investment of £200,000 if a doctor leaves, and £34,000 if a nurse quits the profession.

Mr Byers also hopes to draw the sting of CBI resistance by pointing out that businesses that employ fewer than ten people are likely to have a pregnant member of staff only once every 10 years. Any company with workforce of less than 25 staff is likely to have a pregnant worker once every five years.

Drawing on unpublished DTI data, Mr Byers will cite polls showing that 94% of parents think fathers should have paternity leave and that a majority of new mothers say they are more likely to return to work if the husband has been paid leave.

At present, just 38% of fathers are given specific paternity leave by their employers, a further 33% take annual leave and 31% take time off with the discretion of their manager.

Mr Byers will suggest that the government's proposals are simply enlightened business practice as 24% of organisations with more than 250 employees already top up maternity pay.

Figures from the Department of Social Security, also to be published on Thursday, will also show that only 7% of companies need to pay statutory maternity pay each year, and that 44% of these are entitled to recover 105% of what they pay out from the state.

A separate Department of Employment survey will show that more than half of all employers think that everyone should be able to balance their work and and home life, provided this does not jeopardise the needs of business.

Mr Byers will also cite surveys showing that half of employers will allow some movement from full-time to part-time work and three-quarters of those would make this available to women returning from maternity leave.

The green paper, which has been the subject of extensive discussion, contends that many of the proposed new rights are not enforceable without improved child care provision.

fields.headline: Claimants face cuts for shunning 3Rs
fields.trailText: The government is considering cutting unemployment benefits for claimants who have poor reading, writing and arithmetic, but who shun help offered to improve them.
fields.body:
The government is considering cutting unemployment benefits for claimants who have poor reading, writing and arithmetic, but who shun help offered to improve them.

The proposal is part of a national crusade to boost basic skills to be launched today by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary.

He believes radical solutions are needed because initiatives over recent years have failed to reduce illiteracy and innumeracy among adults. Last year a report by Sir Claus Moser said 7m adults had inadequate basic skills.

The government believes these weaknesses are a threat to its vision of a "skills economy".

A new cabinet committee set up to address the basic skills problem has set a target to cut the overall number of adults with weak literacy and numeracy by 750,000 by 2004.

In today's Guardian education supplement Mr Blunkett outlines Skills for Life, a consultation paper for a comprehensive national strategy for tackling poor basic skills.

The aim is "to test out whether incentives to partici pate in basic education will help these individuals get and keep jobs," Mr Blunkett said.

One way which could be explored would be to make payment of the benefit dependent on "willingness to improve basic skills", a departmental source said.

This could mean testing claimants and making those identified with inadequate literacy and numeracy enrol for appropriate programmes, with a cut in benefit for those who refuse.

Ministers believe many people's reluctance to return to study stems from dismal experiences first time around, which often accounted for their poor reading and writing skills.

They think it is unrealistic simply shunting them towards the nearest further education college and want to encourage learning in shopping centres, pubs and other community locations.

"We need to be radical and imaginative," Mr Blunkett said. "Adults want to study at times and in places that are convenient for them, so we will ensure that their learning choices are rich and varied."

webTitle: Tories urge Hague to accept poll on euro

fields.headline: Tories urge Hague to accept poll on euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: A Tory alliance of Eurosceptics and pro-Europeans is pressing William Hague to reunite the party to head off Labour's expected election attack by accepting the need for a referendum on the single currency.
fields.body:
A Tory alliance of Eurosceptics and pro-Europeans is pressing William Hague to reunite the party to head off Labour's expected election attack by accepting the need for a referendum on the single currency.

The concession would have the benefit of neutralising pro-European Conservatives ahead of polling day, and might even persuade the former chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, to rejoin the shadow cabinet.

The move has the tacit support of key figures in Business for Sterling, the most effective of the Eurosceptic lobbies. Lord Owen's New Europe campaign is also not opposed to a referendum in principle.

The crucial gain for Mr Hague, as he slumps in the polls despite his seemingly popular stance against Europe, is that it would prevent Tony Blair from saying that only Labour is offering voters a choice if the cabinet decides to recommend British membership of the euro during the next parliament.

Mr Hague is being told that the polls are so much in his favour on the single currency that he has nothing to lose and a lot to gain by offering voters a similar choice.

Labour's private polling suggests that voters prefer having at least the option to join, rather than just Mr Hague's policy of keeping the pound for the next parliament - a line that fails to satisfy even his own hardliners.

Late changes to the referendums act, passed last week, have given the proposed electoral commission - to be chaired by Sam Younger - the power to express an opinion on the fairness and intelligibility of the issue.

Support for the idea of a referendum has come from the former shadow foreign secretary, John Maples, as well as the former education secretary, Gillian Shephard, and arch sceptics Sir Michael Spicer and Edward Leigh.

Mr Hague, whose chief aides are Eurosceptics, may be reluctant to change course so late in the parliament, but he will be urged to on the basis of it being a vital tactical shift rather than a strategic retreat. The idea has also been put to Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, but he is thought to be reluctant to support another u-turn.

fields.headline: Is there life on Mars?
fields.standfirst:
Pictures raise scientists' hopes
Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Scientists hope they may yet discover life on Mars, as the latest pictures from a spacecraft orbiting the planet suggest it was once covered with seas and lakes that could have supported organisms.
fields.body:
Scientists hope they may yet discover life on Mars, as the latest pictures from a spacecraft orbiting the planet suggest it was once covered with seas and lakes that could have supported organisms.

Nasa's Mars Global Surveyor probe has found evidence of lakes dating from between 4.3bn and 3.5bn years ago, with photographs showing layered geological outcrops thought to be sedimentary rock.

The pictures are the best indication so far that traces of life may be found on the red planet. Lake beds are thought to be the most likely source of fossils.

The pictures, taken by the Mars orbital camera on the Global Surveyor and analysed at Malin Space Science Systems in San Diego, California, are reported in the journal Science.

Kenneth Edgett, one of the team, said: "This makes Mars more complicated and more exciting. This record is going to tell us a lot about what early Mars was like, and maybe the early Earth as well, since we don't have a lot of rocks on our own planet from this time period."

fields.headline: Passport control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town and why
fields.body:
You're a big man, but you're out of shape... And so, with the release of last year's bovine millennial thriller End Of Days, the cry went up among the world's movie-goers: is Arnold Schwarzenegger (pictured), staunch Republican and professional Teuton, still a relevant force in modern cinema? And then, from a million voices, came the answer: no. Not that anyone appears to have told the ageing he-man about the transient nature of popular culture, as he pitches up in the UK to promote the release of The Sixth Day, yet another vehicle for his rapier wit and out-size triceps, this time involving the novel Maguffin of human cloning (think Twins, but without Danny De Vito and set in the future ). Which, aside from the fact it's written by a couple called Wibberley - something I found inexplicably funny - is pretty much all there is to say about it. The cumbersome Austrian will be entertaining the media with his noted repertoire of piquant one-liners ("I'll be back"/"Hasta La Vista"/"Did you know my coronary bypass involved being fitted with a pig's heart valve?"), before waving to the paparazzi at the film's Leicester Square premiere this Thursday evening.

Like grunge never died... Meanwhile, whatever the collective noun is for thirtysomething US hairies who make their living providing a soundtrack for pubescent boys to grapple with each other while developing tinnitus, there'll be a (insert noun here) of them scratching themselves at customs this week en route to the sticky floors of Britain's concert venues. To wit, Dave Grohl's Foo Fighters are due over to begin a UK tour tomorrow night at the Manchester Apollo; the profitably snotty Green Day turn up for a short stint in support of their LP, Warning; and, last but not least, J Mascis, one-time frontman of the seminal Dinosaur Jr, drops in on Sunday to plug his album More Light. And that, deafeningly enough, is that.

webTitle: Five guilty in GM crop damage case

fields.headline: Five guilty in GM crop damage case
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Five people were found guilty of criminal damage yesterday after destroying genetically modified crops. But a judge in Liverpool said he accepted that they honestly believed they had a "positive purpose".
fields.body:
Five people were found guilty of criminal damage yesterday after destroying genetically modified crops. But a judge in Liverpool said he accepted that they honestly believed they had a "positive purpose".

A hearing in Darlington last month heard that the five pulled up and bagged £2,000 worth of oilseed rape, planted for research at a farm in Hutton Magna, Co Durham, by AgrEvo UK in October last year.

Stephen Gordon, 26, Hugh Baker, 26, and Zoey Exley, 23, all of Manchester, Miss Exley's mother, Lorraine, 51, of Poole, Dorset, and Emma Henry, 22, of York, admitted destroying the crops but denied causing criminal damage.

They said removing the plants was necessary to prevent gene pollution which could damage crops, farmland, the environment and public health.

Yesterday district judge Paul Firth, who had heard the case at Darlington and reserved judgment to the Liverpool hearing , conditionally discharged the five for 12 months and ordered them to pay a total of £1,500 in costs. But he stopped short of ordering them to pay compensation to AgrEvo, now known as Aventis, or to George Richardson, the farmer whose land was involved.

Mr Firth said: "I am accustomed to dealing with many defendants who damage property belonging to others. Almost without exception the damage caused is wilful, disruptive and negative.

"I say almost because this is the exception _ I accept the honesty of [these defendants'] motives insofar as they believed they were doing this for a positive purpose."

The five, who are not affiliated to any group, said they took action after trying to lobby the Labour party conference last year on the GM crops issue and becoming "disillusioned with the democratic process".

Ms Exley senior, a writer, said she was relieved they were not being made to compensate AgrEvo UK; she would have gone to prison to avoid doing so.

webTitle: Agatha Christie's books to be filmed

fields.headline: Murder most foul
fields.standfirst: A terrible crime is about to be committed: Agatha Christie's books are to be filmed - with their setting changed to the present day. Somehow, Hercule Poirot with a mobile phone doesn't quite do it for Lindsay Duguid.
fields.trailText: A terrible crime is about to be committed: Agatha Christie's books are to be filmed - with their setting changed to the present day.
fields.body:
Agatha Christie's status as the queen of crime may be due to her ingenious plots, but her continuing popularity these days - especially with television producers - has more to do with something else: the decor. Written between 1920 and 1968, Christie's novels are fixed in our imagination in an era which is 20s, or perhaps 30s - but definitely "period". There is a charm in their set-pieces - the locked library, the French windows through which the maid overhears a quarrel, the footsteps on the gravel drive - and they are populated mostly by straightforward people, summed up by their creator with the sort of snap judgment which may contain an important clue. "Annie is the house parlourmaid. A nice girl but an inveterate talker"; "He was well-groomed, with a cheerful, somewhat vacuous face. Not a type that I admire."

Then there is the dialogue, only distantly related to natural speech. "Sorry. I - I didn't mean to startle you. I didn't know there was anyone here"; "Father, I'm going up to town in the Hispano. I can't stand the monotony down here any longer." On television, the gleaming cars, the cigarette holders, the backless frocks and the Marcel waves became part of the ritual; they allowed us to watch the unrolling of events a point or two above dozing.

Now this vision of Christie is under threat, from what she might have called a brash young American. Chorion Intellectual Properties, the holder of the Christie copyright, plans to bring some of her books up to date by setting them in "the microchip age", in the belief that "a modern setting will bring in a younger demographic".

Chorion also plans to "develop a licensing programme based on Christie's works and associated characters for the gift and collectable markets". But any upgrading of the technology would upset Christie's elaborate use of mechanical alibis, those intricate plots built up from chance overhearings and deceptions about time. Seven digital clock radios would not do the same job as the ticking alarm clocks used in the Seven Dials Mystery. The internet would provide Superintendent Battle of Scotland Yard with all the information he needed on subversive secret societies and all those letters - lost, hidden, delayed, read secretly - would have been replaced by email.

The very possibility of a mobile phone destroys the set-up for the telephone alibi - a Christie favourite. The phone call from an accomplice could not have been used to help the murderer in Lord Edgware Dies, and, if Lord Edgware had had a burglar alarm installed at his Regent's Park house instead of a bolted door, many red herrings would have been avoided.

The staple plot device of the locked room needs old-fashioned things: locks, a library, maids. Just as the important motives of scandal, blackmail and secret pasts need a society with an agreed code of behaviour. And there is, of course, a long list of supporting plot elements that simply no longer exist, from impassive butlers to steel millionaires to railways that stick to a timetable. Chorion's gifts and collectables will also be full of difficulties. Unlike the characters in the Sherlock Holmes stories, who come with a range of accessories, the only Christie character with distinctive features (pear shape, bowler hat, moustache, spats) is Poirot.

Apart from that, any franchising company would surely want those elaborate props - the oriental dagger, the box of poisoned chocolates, the clock that had been tampered with - that had been done away with in their updating.

If Christie is seen as ripe for commodification in the US, in Europe she is being deconstructed in an elegant but rigorous manner. Pierre Bayard, a psychoanalyst and a professor of literature at the University of Paris, has written a book, Who Killed Roger Ackroyd? (Fourth Estate), which casts doubt on whether Dr Sheppard really did murder the local squire. The Murder Of Roger Ackroyd (1926) is famous for having a narrator who turns out to be the murderer, having withheld vital information in his account of the happenings at the great house - a piece of narrative sleight of hand which has long fascinated the critics. "If the narrator of every novel is suspect then we can no longer rely on any part of the text," concludes Bayard, perhaps with slight exaggeration. Christie's original solution is not only unlikely, he argues, it has no proper motive. Bayard is interested in why Christie should have made this "error"; he also finds a relationship between the detective story and the deeper mysteries of the human mind: "Solutions to plots mask real answers."

Christie was a tireless producer of material for the imagination. Her novels are so sparely written that the reader rushes to fill in the gaps, and one of the reasons she has had such a successful afterlife is that later generations of readers can interpret her books to their liking. There have already been several academic examinations of her work. Like Chorion's plans to drag the novels into the 21st century, they are just another example of the fun to be had with icons of popular culture.

fields.headline: Asylum rules eased for women
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The asylum claims of women who face persecution abroad because they are openly lesbian, express feminist views or have been victims of sexual abuse or domestic violence will be given full consideration by  immigration judges under new anti-discrimination guidelines.
fields.body:
The asylum claims of women who face persecution abroad because they are openly lesbian, express feminist views or have been victims of sexual abuse or domestic violence will be given full consideration by immigration judges under new anti-discrimination guidelines.

The new "gender guidelines" for asylum cases, to be launched today by the human rights lawyer Baroness Kennedy of the Shaws, will not mean that any woman who has been a victim of domestic violence abroad can get refugee status in Britain, but it will ensure that their cases are not dismissed at the first hurdle as they have often been.

The new rules will give protection to men as well as women and stress the difficulties that both face in giving evidence of rape and sexual abuse to the immigration authorities. Asylum rights lawyers say that many men who have been sexually assaulted while in detention find it difficult to talk about the experience.

"We are trying to move away from the idea that a refugee is only a young single male who has been involved in party politics in opposition to the gov ernment of his country," Catriona Jarvis, an immigration appeals adjudicator who co-authored the new guidelines, said yesterday. "That narrow view is being extended to include those who become the victims of forced prostitution, and those who are forced to dress in a particular way or openly express feminist opinions. The 1951 Geneva Convention on Refugees is a living instrument and must change to meet the needs of those who require international protection."

Asylum lawyers welcomed the guidelines as "a great step forward" in acknowledging that there were different types of asylum seekers and said Britain was finally catching up with America, Canada and Australia, which operate similar guidelines.

But the guidelines, which are to be issued through the Lord Chancellor's Department, may prove an embarrassment to the home secretary, Jack Straw, who last October criticised the law lords for being "over-liberal" in backing the cases of two Pakistani women who lived in fear of domestic violence. He said there was "no way it can be realistically argued that that was in contemplation when the 1951 convention was put in place". A Home Office spokeswoman confirmed it had now accepted the House of Lords ruling.

Mr Justice Collins, president of the immigration appeals tribunal, defended the new guidelines, saying they had the support of the UN as well campaigning groups such as the Refugee Women's Legal Group.

"A great deal of work has gone into producing this valuable document. The guidelines provide a useful tool to assist the immigration judiciary, asylum caseworkers, asylum applicants, and their representatives in ensuring that the gender aspects of asylum claims are fully considered."

The guidelines recognise that because the 1951 convention was drawn up in the aftermath of the second world war, the dominant image of what constitutes a refugee in law has been that of a man, and women have not been able to benefit equally from its protection. They also recognise that there are forms of persecution that apply specifically to women, including bride burning, forced sterilisation, genital mutilation, and refusal of access to contraception. In some countries a woman may be flogged for refusing to wear a veil.

Alison Stanley of the solicitors Bindman's, and a member of the Refugee Women's Legal Group, said the guidelines acknowledged that simple acts such as washing up, passing messages, or providing food and shelter might be regarded as political acts by some regimes if those who were helped were freedom fighters.

fields.headline: Labour now 10 points ahead
fields.standfirst:
ICM poll shows boost to Tories from petrol crisis has disappeared
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour has bounced back into the "comfort zone" with a 10 point lead over the Conservatives, according to results of the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.
fields.body:
Labour has bounced back into the "comfort zone" with a 10 point lead over the Conservatives, according to results of the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.

Labour is back on 44%, up four points, where it stood in August before the government's political nerve was tested by the petrol crisis. The Tories remain unchanged on the month on 34%, while the Liberal Democrats are down four points to 16%. Labour has increased its lead from six points in November to 10 points - more than enough to guarantee a majority of more than 100 if there were a general election now.

The Guardian/ICM survey is the second major opinion poll in a week to give Labour a lead in double digits. Last week's Times/MORI poll, which usually gives Labour a larger share of the vote, gave Tony Blair a clear 15 point lead over the Conservatives. Both polls will fuel speculation that a general election even earlier than the Westminster conventional wisdom of early May could be on the cards. April 5 has already been named as a possible alternative.

The ICM survey underlines that the lift given the Tories during September's petrol crisis has long since disappeared. It suggests that their continuing internal feuding has proved damaging, and that opposition attacks over the train crisis and the floods have failed to stick.

William Hague's party has spent the last three months "flatlining" around 34% on the monthly ICM poll. This loss of political "touch" by the Conservatives was illustrated by the row over the European rapid reaction force. The Tories and the Eurosceptic press were convinced that it was a Brussels scare story that would play among the marginal voters but when public opinion was put to the test it was found that a majority of the public thought it a good idea.

The poll would also seem to support claims that voters are acutely aware of the Conservative legacy when it comes to issues such as rail privatisation and food safety.

The surprise gainers of Labour's autumn wobble proved to be the Liberal Democrats. Their drop this month follows three months in which they managed a 22% share of the vote - their highest since January 1995.

Charles Kennedy and his troops have had a relatively good late autumn with high profile battles over the environment, rail privatisation, and the freedom of information bill, as the party leader has begun to find his feet.

The annual averages for each party published this month with the December ICM give a clear picture of what has happened since the May 1997 election. Labour's average poll share in 1997 stood at 53%, the Tories' at 28%, the Liberal Democrats' at 14%, and "others" at 4%. The annual averages for 2000 show Labour down 11 points to 42%, the Tories up five points to 33%, and the Liberal Democrats up four points to 18%.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,003 adults aged over 18 by telephone from December 1-3. Interviews were conducted across the country and results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Greek snub to British Museum over marbles
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Elgin marbles
fields.trailText: The Greek ambassador has snubbed the opening of the British Museum's new £100m Great Court by the Queen tomorrow because of a decision by the governors to hold a royal dinner in the galleries that house the Elgin marbles.
fields.body:
The Greek ambassador has snubbed the opening of the British Museum's new £100m Great Court by the Queen tomorrow because of a decision by the governors to hold a royal dinner in the galleries that house the Elgin marbles.

Alexandros Sandis, the new ambassador, has declined an invitation to the opening and dinner, after pleading with the museum not to use the Duveen galleries which house the marbles for corporate entertaining. Greece wants the marbles, which it knows as the Parthenon sculptures, returned.

The diplomatic dispute is the latest problem to mar the opening of Norman Foster's refurbishment of the Great Court following a row with English Heritage over the use of cheaper French instead of Portland stone to replace the demolished portico.

A spokesman for the Greek embassy said: "We are upset and astonished that the British Museum has decided to use the Duveen galleries for this event. We think it is really insensitive of the museum, coming straight after revelations about the holding of corporate dinners there and a buffet lunch during a conference on the Parthenon sculptures last year. The ambassador has decided not to attend either the opening and the supper, as it would be discourteous to the Queen to arrive but leave before the supper took place."

A British Museum spokesman confirmed it had received "a polite letter" from the ambassador declining the invitation.

Some 1,500 dignitaries and VIPs will attend the opening of the new Great Court, which is now enclosed by a stylish glass roof over the historic British Museum Reading Room. After the opening 600 guests will sit down to dinner in three rooms, including the Duveen galleries.

The opening is being attended by the Queen, the Duke of Edinburgh, Princess Margaret, and the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester. The duke, who is a trustee of the museum, will be the main royal guest at the supper. Buckingham Palace said that the Queen, who is travelling by train to Newcastle upon Tyne the following day, would not stay for the supper. The palace has had to allow extra time for the rail journey because of speed restrictions.

The ambassador took the unusual step of writing to Buckingham Palace to explain why he could not attend. The Greek government is said to have been concerned that the Queen should not think this a personal snub.

It is said also to have taken the opportunity to explain the dispute over the marbles and its concern about the sculptures being used as a centrepiece for dinner parties.

A spokesman for the palace said it could not comment on private correspondence with other governments.

webTitle: Business: Lastminute says patience will pay dividends

fields.headline: Lastminute says patience will pay dividends
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com, the beleaguered internet retailer, yesterday delivered better than expected full year results and a plea for investors nursing paper losses to stick with it.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com, the beleaguered internet retailer, yesterday delivered better than expected full year results and a plea for investors nursing paper losses to stick with it.

Non-executive chairman Allan Leighton said the company continued to exceed its own revenue projections despite seeing its share price savaged by the stock market .

He asked shareholders to remain patient. "This is a calm ship in a raging sea. There is a lot left for us to do but the business is performing ahead of plan. There is so much hype and noise around this company and this sector that all we can do is continue to produce the numbers and let people make up their own minds."

In the 12 months to September 30 losses widened from £4.5m to £35.7m as total transaction value climbed from £2.64m to £34.2m. Had Lastminute's recent acquisition of French firm Degriftour been included in the figures transaction value would have been £90.5m.

Unusually for a business valued at £127.5m, Lastminute's balance sheet for the past three months shows it generated more income from interest payments on cash it has in the bank than from gross profits on its commercial activities.

"It's an oddity but one that most e-commerce businesses would like to have," Mr Leighton said. "We've got cash and many of them haven't."

The figures were slightly better than analysts had forecast and enabled the sector's highest profile stock to rise 4.9% to 75p.

Lastminute shares were issued at 380p at the height of the craze for internet stocks and touched a high of 555p shortly afterwards.

Analysts welcomed the figures, which they said showed strong growth and included no unpleasant surprises. Several analysts are bullish about Lastminute's long-term prospects but say the company still has work to do. They say the shares are likely to remain depressed in a market where technology companies are out of favour. Since its inception a little over two years ago the late-bookings specialist has attracted nearly 3m subscribers but only 156,196 have bought through its website.

Mr Leighton, the former boss of supermarket chain Asda, was recruited to Lastminute by the company's founders, Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane-Fox, to bring retail expertise and "a wise head". He said one of the priorities is to make the experience of booking flights and tickets through Lastminute easier. An updated website was introduced last week and a voice-recognition service that aims to allow customers to "speak" their orders through their mobile phones will start trials soon.

"When you have a great consumer-focused idea like Lastminute you have to make it as easy as possible for people to use. We're in contact with 3m people every week and, if we make it easier for them to buy, conversion rates and then revenue rates will increase."

fields.headline: Lamont gets Pinochet medal
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: The former chancellor of the exchequer Norman Lamont yesterday became the first foreigner to be awarded the "Star of Honour and Merit" by the Augusto Pinochet Foundation in Chile, for "his extraordinary and valiant attitude in defending Senator Pinochet".
fields.body:
The former chancellor of the exchequer Norman Lamont yesterday became the first foreigner to be awarded the "Star of Honour and Merit" by the Augusto Pinochet Foundation in Chile, for "his extraordinary and valiant attitude in defending Senator Pinochet".

The former dictator's son, ex-military colleagues and associates gathered in front of television cameras in Santiago to pay homage to Mr Lamont.

The president of the foundation, Hernan Briones, said: "In the last century the English Conservative party gave to humanity such distin guished people for universal history as Sir Winston Churchill and Lady Margaret Thatcher. Today we have with us Lord Norman Lamont, the prominent Englishman to whom we owe so much."

Lord Lamont - who did not flinch as he was repeatedly called Lord Lament by his Spanish-speaking hosts - was presented with a medal on a red ribbon. "This visit had been planned for some time. I am only sad that it coincides with such unfortunate and controversial events," he said.

On Friday, a Chilean judge ordered Gen Pinochet to be placed under house arrest after he was indicted for his role in a series of crimes under his 17-year rule, including kidnapping, murder and torture.

Lord Lamont said he could not comment on the judicial case in Chile, "but I would just like to say the arguments that have gone on in the UK have been arguments about history. Sometimes people forget that there was a cold war.

"It is easy and a mistake to judge yesterday by today's climate and today's standards." Gen Pinochet was a "friend and ally" of Britain who had been badly treated after coming to the UK in good faith, Lord Lamont said.

webTitle: Durex faces market sheathed in tradition

fields.headline: Durex faces market sheathed in tradition
fields.standfirst: British brand stages seduction of a country which knows it only for Marigold gloves
fields.trailText: British brand stages seduction of a country which knows it only for Marigold gloves
fields.body:
On Omotesando, a prime shopping street in Tokyo, is a Condomania, a rather startling shop featuring a three-metre picture of a dancing yellow prophylactic over the door. The store is an Aladdin's cave of contraceptive sheaths. All tastes (literally) are catered for - there is even a sushi-flavoured condom. Sizes vary from "big boy" to the tactfully named "wee willie". Christmas shoppers can pick up a gift pack containing two condoms, a chocolate, a little Father Christmas and a toy fir tree.

Hundreds of brands are on sale in Condomania, including the market leader Benetton, made under licence by Japan's top manufacturer, Okamoto. The notable absence is Durex - a household name in Europe, America and south-east Asia but yet to penetrate Japan.

That is about to change - Durex's owner, Cheshire-based SSL International, is planning to seduce the land of the rising sun. The British company can no longer afford to ignore the biggest, wealthiest condom market in the world.

Ted Miyake, president of SSL Japan, is masterminding the assault from a small office down a back street in Shibuya, Tokyo's entertainment district. He hopes to snatch 5% to 7% of the Japanese condom market within a year, which would put Durex a shade ahead of Benetton.

That would involve selling between 12m and 17m condoms. To do so, Mr Miyake needs to make a very big splash, and he knows it. He says: "Until now, Japanese condom advertising has been mild and conservative. We're going to change that."

Mr Miyake intends to blitz Japan with condom promotions of a kind the country has never seen. Advertisments will run on television and in newspapers, some of which will have the country's conservatives spluttering over their early-morning pickles and rice.

"There are likely to be those who argue against our campaign," Mr Miyake admits. "But I'm not afraid of scandal."

The company is still waiting for a licence from Japan's healthcare authorities, which classify condoms as closely regulated "medical devices". Approval is expected in March or April, with launch shortly afterwards.

Mr Miyake then intends to educate the population in the advantages of polyurethane over traditional rubber sheaths, which will require Durex to take a huge step away from the Japanese condom industry's usual arty shots of couples walking into the sunset.

It is remarkable that it has taken Durex so long to enter the market. Japan's 126m people buy 250m condoms a year, behind only India and China. Prophylactics are favoured by 80% of Japanese couples; they have had little choice.

Until recently, the contraceptive pill was unavailable - initially because of a stigma about uncleanliness, but more recently because of government concerns about side effects (which concerns many believe have been actively encouraged by local condom makers).

The Japanese are only just beginning to relax a taboo on discussing contraception. Mr Miyake says: "Younger people buy their condoms from convenience stores. They don't care what the cashier thinks. In the past, though, people have wrapped them in newspapers to conceal them. People were ashamed."

The Condomania store is, as yet, an exception, and whether the country is quite ready for Durex's blitz remains to be seen. Mr Miyake says the recent arrival of western pharmacy chains has helped the Japanese to loosen up over condoms.

Boots the Chemist now has shops in Japan, and supermarket chains such as France's Carrefour sell a huge range of health and beauty products. These have pushed condoms from dusty corners to prime shelf space, and widened the range of products available.

The industry has been relatively unimaginative up to now because of the dominant presence of one player - Okamoto. The company claims to have 65% of the market, although it operates through a diverse range of brands.

It was Okamoto's near monopoly which for many years deterred Durex's parent company, London International, which chose instead to forge a joint venture allowing the Japanese firm to distribute its Marigold rubber gloves.

London International's merger last year with healthcare company Seton Scholl to form SSL International has added firepower. Durex is key to SSL's expansion in the country. The company already sells gloves, shoes and footcare products such as corn pads and hygiene sprays. It wants to increase its sales from ¥3.5bn (£23m) to ¥6bn within three years by selling condoms and by introducing Seton products, such as catheters and drainage bags, for hospitals.

There are some issues yet to be finalised for Durex. The company has been consolidating much of its manufacturing in low-wage facilities in Thailand, at the expense of factories in Europe. It wants to use its Thai factories to supply Japan, but the market may have some special requirements. Mr Miyake says: "Many people believe foreign condoms are too thick, or even too big for Japan."

A conclusive answer will be available soon. He is conducting laboratory tests on relative "length, diameter and stretch" to find out. Then a company from Britain, long regarded as one of the world's most buttoned-up nations, will begin teaching the Japanese how to talk about sex.

Facts of life

 Durex is short for "durability, reliability and excellence"

 The company has 22% of the global condom market

 Originally the London Rubber Company, Durex was established by a barbers' supplier in 1915

 The first pub vending machine was installed in 1968

 Durex was recently introduced to the US and Australia

 Worth £270m a year, the Japanese condom market is the most valuable in the world

webTitle: Business: Sentiment costs 45 jobs after Nettec profits hit

fields.headline: Sentiment costs 45 jobs after Nettec profits hit
fields.trailText: Nettec, the quoted e-business solutions company, yesterday followed last month's profit warning with plans to axe 45 jobs and to sell or close its online advertising business.
fields.body:
Nettec, the quoted e-business solutions company, yesterday followed last month's profit warning with plans to axe 45 jobs and to sell or close its online advertising business.

Chief executive Brian Gunn said advertising performance had been disappointing, with both existing and new customers spending less than expected.

The business, which employs about 10 people, would close if a planned management buyout was not completed by the end of the year.

Nettec, which floated at 240p a share in April, has been hurt by the changing attitude towards technology stocks.

More than £49m was wiped off its stock market value last month when it warned that doubts about a number of contracts and a downturn in advertising revenue would cut operating profits by £3.5m.

Yesterday Mr Gunn said the group was on target to move into pretax profitability by the end of 2002 as forecast in the prospectus.

The bulk of the job cuts would be among support staff, where there was duplication after the acquisition of businesses in France.

webTitle: Fierce battle in heart of Bethlehem

fields.headline: Fierce battle in heart of Bethlehem
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli forces and Palestinian gunmen fought a three-hour gun battle near a holy shrine in Bethlehem in the early hours of yesterday morning, shattering hopes that more than nine weeks of fighting might be coming to an end.
fields.body:
Israeli forces and Palestinian gunmen fought a three-hour gun battle near a holy shrine in Bethlehem in the early hours of yesterday morning, shattering hopes that more than nine weeks of fighting might be coming to an end.

The Israeli military said it unleashed its tanks and combat helicopters after midnight to halt an attempt to storm Rachel's Tomb, a Jewish pilgrimage site and a flashpoint in the violence that has killed almost 300 people.

But local people said Israeli gunners had opened fire hours earlier, hurling tank shells into shops, while an attack helicopter rocketed a seven-storey building overlooking the al-Aza refugee camp.

The latest fighting brought the violence into the heart of Bethlehem, as well as two refugee camps straddling the town's main road.

"From 8pm and 2.30 in the morning, helicopters, machine guns, tanks - I could not believe it," said Ayed al-Kassi, whose grocery shop in Aza camp was hit by at least two rockets.

"My wife, my mother, my daughter and I hid for six hours under the stairs. The children were crying, and we prayed to God."

For Bethlehem, where the authorities have already cancelled official Christmas celebrations, the attack was another blow to hopes for peace.

"They have killed everything, there will be no Christmas this year in Bethlehem," said Jiries Freij, the deputy governor of Bethlehem.

"It is going to be very, very sad. The whole world now should understand that if they keep silent, this is going to go on and on, and we will only be left with war."

After a relatively quiet weekend, the first signs of trouble came with a confrontation between Jewish settlers and Palestinians in the village of Husan, near Bethlehem.

Palestinians say the clashes began when shots were fired from a white pick-up truck at the village mosque, where worshippers were gathering for evening prayers.

The Israeli army said its soldiers moved in when villagers stoned a car driven by a Jewish woman travelling to the settlement.

Two dozen people were injured by Israeli fire, two seriously. "This is a deliberate and planned escalation," the Palestinian authority said in a statement. "We appeal to the whole world to secure protection for our people from attacks by settlers and soldiers, and we hold the Israeli government fully responsible for this ugly crime in Husan."

webTitle: Business: Glimmer of hi-tech hope from two fallen stars

fields.headline: Glimmer of hi-tech hope from two fallen stars
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Two of the hi-tech boom's fallen stars yesterday offered a glimmer of hope for dozens of other companies in the same position by reporting better than expected results and seeing their share prices climb away from previous lows.
fields.body:
Two of the hi-tech boom's fallen stars yesterday offered a glimmer of hope for dozens of other companies in the same position by reporting better than expected results and seeing their share prices climb away from previous lows.

Affinity Internet, provider of branded internet access to companies like Egg and Powergen, and Orchestream, a specialist supplier of software for internet networks, have seen their stock values battered amid growing investor nervousness surrounding technology company valuations.

Affinity's shares had slumped from almost £85 to barely 500p, while Orchestream had fallen from a 700p high to trade below its first day trading level of 313p. Affinity yesterday unveiled pretax losses widening from £7m to £10.8m for the nine months to September 30, but increased revenues and user numbers helped the company to an 8% rise in its shares to 587.5p.

Shares in Orchestream meanwhile climbed 5% or 12p from recent lows to 252p after it announced that revenues for the nine months to September 30 had beaten expectations at £1.63m.

House broker UBS Warburg had been looking for revenues of around £1m. Losses grew from £3.72m to £8.6m on a year on year basis.

Official brokers to both companies argue that they are undervalued and two positive research notes are expected to be published on Affinity over the next few days.

Stockbrokers say they are still having trouble persuading clients to buy into the hi-tech sector while values remain so volatile and economic uncertainty remains in the US.

Affinity's broker, Charles Stanley, is forecasting revenues of £40m on a loss of £13m for the year to 2001, with the company moving into profit the following year.

It believes that a billing system that Affinity has devised in partnership with Powergen - to enable customers to receive their gas, electricity and telephone bills on a single sheet - will be a significant source of future income.

Orchestream said that contract wins from Energis and Siemens had been key drivers of revenue growth.

The chief executive, Ashley Ward, said the group had also signed several other materially significant contracts. For legal reasons, he added that he could not yet divulge the names of the companies involved.

fields.headline: At this price?  Exel
fields.trailText: Transport group Exel's acquisition of the Total Logistics Company yesterday is not likely to have taken much out of the firm's £1bn acquisition budget. But it is a sign of things to come.
fields.body:
Transport group Exel's acquisition of the Total Logistics Company yesterday is not likely to have taken much out of the firm's £1bn acquisition budget. But it is a sign of things to come.

TLC is a bolt on acquisition thought to have cost about £12m. It will help beef up Exel's operations in an area where it needs a stronger presence - Australia and New Zealand - and in a sector where it sees growth - medical products. It will also help Exel to expand in the Asia-Pacific region.

TLC, set up in 1986, provides supply chain management services for 30 of the world's leading pharmaceutical and health care companies, using purpose built facilities.

Exel, the result of the merger earlier this year of the former National Freight and Ocean Transport & Trading, is planning a series of deals similar to TLC. It is already the world's second largest logistics business.

Logistics is a business which is in transition. Born out of old fashioned haulage and freight forwarding, it is expanding to take over many activities traditionally carried out by manufacturers.

John Allan, Exel's chief executive, expects to spend most of the company's acquisition war chest on small or medium sized com panies which plug gaps in the present business.

The group is already involved in talks on a number of deals. The biggest gap in Exel's portfolio is Germany, where it needs a sizeable deal to give it the scope it needs. It is up against tough competition there, including the recently floated Deutsche Post.

It is also buying in a sellers' market. Many of the former or still state-owned post offices, including Britain's Post Office, are seeking to become major players in the logistics market through acquisition.

Exel should continue to prosper as world trade grows. The downside is that it might have to pay generously for acquisitions.

Though its shares closed 15p higher at 1068.5p yesterday, it might be quite a long haul before they deliver significant gains.

fields.headline: Billiton digs up compliments
fields.trailText: Forget a satisfying lunch at the Savoy. The real way to a City analyst's heart is to put an exotic stamp on his passport.
fields.body:
Forget a satisfying lunch at the Savoy. The real way to a City analyst's heart is to put an exotic stamp on his passport.

Take mining outfit Billiton. Yesterday its stock topped the blue chip leaderboard - up 14.5p to 242.5p - after the City's top mining brains returned from a five day "research trip" to its operations in Chile and Peru.

Officially the trip was a first and at least for some time the last chance for analysts to see the copper assets of Rio Algom, the international mining group Billiton acquired earlier this year for $1.2bn (£826m). Billiton goes into its two month silent period ahead of interim figures in February next week.

However, traders suggested there might have been a hidden subtext - to convince the doubters that its strategy of increasing its exposure to copper is a good idea.

By all accounts the trip, which started last Monday, got off to a good start. There were no shortage of analysts willing to go, something that might have been helped by Billiton's generous offer to pay the £4,000 air fare. It seems the offer was taken up by one or two City analysts who have exceeded their travel budgets.

If that offer was generous so too was the feedback. While some analysts, namely those at Deutsche Bank, still think Billiton still paid too much for Rio Algom, all were in agreement about the quality of the assets and management. The analysts visited two sites, which represented more than half the total value of Algom. One was said to be operating well and the other on track to enter operation ahead of schedule.

While the Billiton tale might have provided an interesting diversion on an otherwise drab Monday, there was no doubting the hot topic of debate in City dealing rooms - the future of Abbey National , up 41.5p to £11.45.

Various theories were advanced through the session. One that gained support early in the day was that Lloyds TSB, down 9p 665p, would wait until Abbey National and Bank of Scotland, up 16p at 696p, announced details of a nil premium merger before launching a near £13 a share offer.

But late in the day this tale had been replaced by a more straight forward one - a bid for Abbey in the morning from Lloyds. Once again the magical figure of £13 was being mentioned. But the sceptics noted the only thing this story had in its favour was the heavy - 14m - turnover in Abbey shares.

Such excitement was in marked contrast to events in the wider market. The FTSE 100 index closed down 11.7 points at 6,158.7, as buyers stayed and sellers stayed on the sidelines waiting for fresh direction from Nasdaq.

When debutant Bradford & Bingley and market heavyweight Vodafone were stripped out of the equation, market turnover just topped 1bn shares.

Elsewhere, the FTSE Techmark 100 index eased 17.95 points to 2,576.78 and the FTSE Mid 250 slipped 25.5 points to 6,437.6.

Shire Pharmaceuticals provided some colour to the session with a rise 36p to £11.10. Merrill Lynch reckons recent weakness in its share price on fears about generic competition for Adderall, its top selling drug for attention deficit disorder, has been overdone. Merrill's sizeable salesforce was yesterday telling its clients the recent weakness is an excellent buying opportunity.

Going the other way was Granada Media, off 11p at 388p after analysts at Deutsche Bank cut the stock from "buy" to "market perform". Despite last weeks decent figures, Deutsche analyst Paul Reynolds does not think Granada is in any position to achieve its revenue targets and has downgraded his current year profits forecast - 33% - accordingly.

In the mid cap market, favourable movements in the currency markets and a UBS Warburg upgrade helped steel maker Corus advance 7.75p to 69.75p, while Infobank rose 12.5p to 325p ahead of institutional presentations today.

Aberdeen Asset Managers rose 11.5p to 550p. Word has it that today's full-year figures will be much better than anticipated.

webTitle: Chrysler losses draining German partner's funds

fields.headline: Chrysler losses draining German partner's funds
fields.trailText: Losses at Chrysler are reported to be reducing DaimlerChrysler's cash reserves to dangerously low levels.
fields.body:
Losses at Chrysler are reported to be reducing DaimlerChrysler's cash reserves to dangerously low levels.

The US magazine Newsweek said that the group's cash reserves could fall to about $2bn by the end of the year - a 78% decline on the level two years ago.

Rivals Ford and General Motors have cash reserves of more than $13m which they believe will be essential if they are to survive a downturn forecast in car sales.

Jurgen Schrempp, DaimlerChrysler's chairman, told the magazine that the merger between Daimler Benz and Chrysler had been fair and transparent, contrary to the claims made in a lawsuit brought by the company's third largest shareholder Kirk Kerkorian. The latter's Tracinda company is claiming that the merger was presented as one of equals when in practice it was a takeover by the German company of the American one. It had thus been deprived a a takeover premium for its shares.

Analysts are forecasting that the Chrysler operation will run up a fourth quarter loss of about $1bn. Moody's, the credit rating agency, downgraded DaimlerChrysler's debt rating on Friday and Standard & Poor's is expected to follow suit.

Mr Schrempp is due to write to DaimlerChrysler shareholders soon outlining what is being done to improve the position at Chrysler and stressing how well other parts of the group are doing.

fields.headline: Kirch pumps $550m into EM.TV
fields.trailText: Television magnate Leo Kirch yesterday paid out $550m to support beleaguered EM.TV, the German media group whose recent spending spree gave it rights to Formula One motor racing and the Muppet Show but helped push its debts up to 2.2bn marks (£700m).
fields.body:
Television magnate Leo Kirch yesterday paid out $550m to support beleaguered EM.TV, the German media group whose recent spending spree gave it rights to Formula One motor racing and the Muppet Show but helped push its debts up to 2.2bn marks (£700m).

The news failed to arrest EM.TV's share price slump, which has sent tremors through the whole of Germany's Neuer Markt.

The deal involves Kirch Gruppe buying half of EM.TV's 50% stake in SLEC, the holding company for Formula One, from EM.TV. The other 50% is owned by promoter Bernie Ecclestone.

An EM.TV spokesman confirmed that talks had also taken place about the possibility of selling some of the SLEC shares to car manufacturers and Formula One teams. DaimlerChrysler, which has financial troubles of its own, is thought to be one of the companies involved in the talks though the EM.TV spokesman declined to provide names.

Kirch will also exchange its share in the two companies' existing joint venture, a programme library of children's and family entertainment, for around 16.7% of EM.TV. Kirch will also get voting rights to just over 8% of EM.TV shares held by the company's chief executive, Thomas Haffa.

That will give Mr Kirch just over 25%, amounting to a potential blocking stake in the music-based company.

EM.TV also said that Sesame Workshop, the non-profit company that has produced the Sesame Street children's series since 1969, had acquired the rights to the programme.

Despite the flurry of activity, EM.TV's shares fell 40% to just over €9 yesterday in the wake of Friday's profits warning. The group admitted that earnings before interest and tax for the full year would total DM50m, compared to the "planned" DM525m. The group also said it would undershoot its sales target by a modest margin.

Among those affected by the plummeting EM.TV share price is Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, part of Deutsche Bank asset management, which sold a stake in SLEC earlier this year to EM.TV in exchange for EM.TV shares.

Last night Deutsche Bank declined to comment on the fall in value of the EM.TV holding, which was given a price tag of around $450m when the deal was done, against the $275m Morgan Grenfell Private Equity paid for the SLEC holding.

Deutsche Bank also refused to comment on exactly how many shares Morgan Grenfell Private Equity had acquired or the price per share it paid.

One report suggests, however, that it could be sitting on paper losses of as much as $270m.

Yesterday, alongside its nine-month figures, EM.TV detailed the financial performance of both the Jim Henson Company - the Muppet business which it bought at the beginning of April - and Formula One.

According to EM.TV, the Henson business made a loss of DM40.5m in the six months from April 1 while Formula One - in which EM.TV acquired its stake in May - made a profit of DM283.6m in the first nine months of the current calendar year.

webTitle: Britain and France clash over defence

fields.headline: Britain and France clash over defence
fields.standfirst:
Cook fights plan to let groups of countries mount own initiatives
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Britain is locked in a new dispute with France over a call for groups of European Union members to be allowed to mount their own defence initiatives, warning that this approach could undermine Nato.
fields.body:
Britain is locked in a new dispute with France over a call for groups of European Union members to be allowed to mount their own defence initiatives, warning that this approach could undermine Nato.

With three days to go before the Nice summit, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, insisted last night he was opposed to arrangements that might duplicate the alliance's work.

The disagreement over the French idea on defence adds another contentious item to the agenda at the summit - billed as the most important since Maastricht - which must agree vital reforms in order to allow the EU to accept new members.

Three big issues - reweighting the votes of member states, the future size of the European commission and majority voting - appear deadlocked, according to diplomats.

But Hubert Vedrine, the French foreign minister, expressed confidence that negotiations would end in success. "It looks very difficult, but we will reach an agreement because every country wants to get that agreement," he said. The French, who currently hold the EU's rotating presidency, are leading calls for the principle of "enhanced cooperation" - where countries move together on certain policies without the rest - to defence matters. They say this would improve EU capabilities at crisis management.

Speaking in Brussels, Mr Cook said the French idea could upset plans for the EU's rapid reaction force, unveiled amid controversy last month. Britain is insisting that defence must be kept out of the treaty. Neutral Sweden and Ireland agree, fearing that they will be bullied by EU members of Nato.

"We are not going to agree to any arrangements where there are parallel structures where we don't know what that might lead us to," Mr Cook said. "We strongly believe that we should focus on the project we have started and not set out on a totally different path. We have always made clear that we want to complement Nato, not to compete with it."

The Nice summit will approve a document stating explicitly that the 60,000-strong rapid reaction force "does not constitute a European army", precisely the charge thrown at the government by the Tories and the Eurosceptic media. "I look forward to the Conservative party endorsing these proposals and dropping their narrow, party-based concerns that, if elected, they would cancel the UK's participation - which would weaken European crisis management, make the continent less safe and damage Britain's credibility," Mr Cook said.

His comments came as the US defence secretary, William Cohen, warned that Nato and US security ties with Europe will be eroded if the EU insists on separate operational planning for the European force.

Speaking on the eve of a Nato defence ministers' meeting in Brussels, Mr Cohen said the EU force should not have a separate planning operation but should rely on Nato's expertise in that field.

He stressed that Washington supported the EU's move to shore up its own defences with the force, which is to be ready in 2003. But he added: "If they try to set up a separate operational planning capability - separate and distinct from that of Nato itself - then that is going to weaken the ties between the US and Nato and Nato and the EU."

There was one victory for the summiteers yesterday when foreign ministers managed to settle a potentially damaging row with Turkey, the 13th and most difficult of the candidates queueing up to join an enlarged EU.

Turkey would not have been able to attend the Nice summit if the row over its accession partnership agreement had not been settled. Ankara has yet to begin detailed discussions with Brussels because of concern over its human rights record, the Cyprus issue and territorial spats with Greece.

Greece had threatened to block financial aid to Turkey if accession partnership terms did not include mention of a Cyprus settlement. The final text called on Turkey to "resolve any outstanding border disputes and other related issues" - a clear reference to the disputed island.

"It's a historical day for European Union relations with Turkey," the Greek foreign minister, George Papandreou, said. "I would hope Turkey truly sees this as a partnership."

webTitle: Job fears grow at ING Barings as top two walk out

fields.headline: Job fears grow at ING Barings as top two walk out
fields.trailText: The omens worsened for the 2,000 City employees of the Dutch-owned former Barings bank yesterday after its two senior executives walked out.
fields.body:
The omens worsened for the 2,000 City employees of the Dutch-owned former Barings bank yesterday after its two senior executives walked out.

David Robins, the chief executive of ING Barings, and his deputy, Malcolm Le May, left immediately. Many banking sources had expected the two to stay while ING, which bought Barings in 1995, completed its continuing strategic review of its investment banking arm.

However, their decision to depart just two weeks after the surprise review was initiated was regarded as an indication of the determination of ING to end its investment banking business. ING has already appointed Goldman Sachs to review the options for its US business.

ING is yet to confirm how many jobs will go from its operation in the City, where it employs 2,000 traders, ana lysts and investment bankers but has pledged to announce the outcome of its strategic review early in the new year at the latest.

ING, which bought Barings after it was bankrupted by Singapore-based Nick Leeson, had made it clear that the asset management operation is not included in the review.

As the City continued to fear for ING Barings, another major employer in the Square Mile, Deutsche Bank, announced reorganisation plans.

Deutsche Bank intends to split its operation into two, one unit that will unite its investment banking and corporate banking businesses, and another to marry its retail banking and asset management divisions.

The bank refused to give any indication as to whether the change in structure would affect jobs. The reorganisation comes after a turbulent year in which it failed to merge with its closest rival, Dresdner.

fields.headline: Leeds boss given £850,000 share options
fields.trailText: Leeds United manager David O'Leary is believed to have become the first top flight football manager to be awarded share options by his employers.
fields.body:
Leeds United manager David O'Leary is believed to have become the first top flight football manager to be awarded share options by his employers.

Leeds Sporting, the Yorkshire club's stock market listed parent company, said Mr O'Leary had been granted options on over £850,000 worth of shares.

A football manager's job is notoriously unstable but Mr O'Leary has signed a new six-year contract with the club. If he is still with Leeds in December 2003 he will potentially be able to cash in directly on his side's performance at any time over a four-year period. Mr O'Leary has been awarded 5.8m shares at 14.5p each which would cost him £850,000 to buy. He would only make a profit if the shares trade above 14.5p and he is still at the club in 2003.

Several clubs have looked at awarding share options to players and managers as a way of countering wage demands, which can be as high as £50,000 per week, and encouraging long-term loyalty. Sunderland manager Peter Reid owns shares in his club but is not thought to have any options.

Leeds shares started trading at 17p after they were floated in October 1998 but have failed to take off. Chairman Peter Ridsdale believes that they are undervalued with the club flying high in the Premiership and ambitious to develop. Last night the shares closed unchanged at 14.5p.

webTitle: Business: ARM tightens grip on mobile market

fields.headline: ARM tightens grip on mobile market
fields.trailText: ARM Holdings yesterday moved a step closer to becoming the world's dominant designer of microchips for devices such as mobile phones and electronic organisers by announcing a wide-ranging agreement with Motorola.
fields.body:
ARM Holdings yesterday moved a step closer to becoming the world's dominant designer of microchips for devices such as mobile phones and electronic organisers by announcing a wide-ranging agreement with Motorola.

The US firm, the world's sixth-largest manufacturer of microchips, said its customers had requested that ARM-designed "cores" be included in its chips that power devices including mobile phones, set-top boxes and in-car electronics.

Customers will be able to chose between Motorola and ARM cores. The role played by a core in a microchip has been likened to that of an engine in a car.

Motorola already uses some ARM designs in its mobile phones but this deal "deepens and strengthens" their relationship

"This is the biggest piece of news from the company this year," said an analyst at ARM's stockbroker, Morgan Stanley. ARM chief executive Robin Saxby likened the deal to a similar agreement with chip group Intel struck last year.

Neither party gave financial details but the firms said the deal would focus initially on handheld devices then expand into other areas. ARM expects first revenues from the deal to filter through about a year from now.

ARM designs are found in around 80% of the world's mobile phones and the Cambridge-based firm has been looking to build its presence in fields such as set-top boxes, in-car electronics and games consoles.

The City responded positively to the deal, ARM shares climbing 6.5p to 521.5p in an otherwise drab market for technology stocks.

The US firm, the world's sixth-largest manufacturer of microchips, said its customers had requested that ARM-designed "cores" be included in its chips that power devices including mobile phones, set-top boxes and in-car electronics. Customers will be able to chose between Motorola and ARM cores. The role played by a core in a microchip has been likened to that of an engine in a car. Motorola already uses some ARM designs in its mobile phones but this deal "deepens and strengthens" their relationship "This is the biggest piece of news from the company this year," said an analyst at ARM's stockbroker, Morgan Stanley. ARM chief executive Robin Saxby likened the deal to a similar agreement with chip group Intel struck last year. Neither party gave financial details but the firms said the deal would focus initially on handheld devices then expand into other areas. ARM expects first revenues from the deal to filter through about a year from now. ARM designs are found in around 80% of the world's mobile phones and the Cambridge-based firm has been looking to build its presence in fields such as set-top boxes, in-car electronics and games consoles. fields.headline: Sema stock slumps further
fields.standfirst: Software group defers meetings to investigate dealing scandal
fields.trailText: Relations between Sema and the City plunged to a new low yesterday when the troubled software services group postponed until January a series of meetings with analysts and fund managers.
fields.body:
Relations between Sema and the City plunged to a new low yesterday when the troubled software services group postponed until January a series of meetings with analysts and fund managers.

Shares fell a further 29p to 271p as Sema explained it was forming a committee to investigate events leading up to the disclosure on October 27 of a share-dealing scandal.

Sema said last week it would brief institutions this Thursday and Friday on the timing of share dealings by Hartmut Lademacher, one of its directors, and also a trading statement issued by the company on 24 November.

Mr Lademacher, who sold his LHS software company to Sema earlier this year, was forced to leave the company last week for selling up to £24m worth of stock in a closed period ahead of financial results. Legal action is being considered against him by the company.

Sema justified its decision to postpone the briefing till January on the basis it "will be able to give the market a fuller update on trading in the fourth quarter of 2000 and a better picture of the outlook for 2001."

Analysts said they were disappointed given the desperate need for rebuilding confidence. One added: "They must have feared that the presentations this week would have turned into a lynch mob for [chief executive Pierre] Bonelli. They are clearly hop ing that the season of goodwill over Christmas makes people more sympathetic or maybe they hope memories will slip."

Meanwhile the company reiterated that the overall trading position is profitable and said that second half profits would be in line with last year. At a weekend board meeting Sema took a decision to establish a committee made up of non-executive directors Sir Julian Oswald and Harry Fryer plus Mr Bonelli and company secretary Nick Deeming.
