webTitle: Lloyds is looking too close to home

fields.headline: Lloyds is looking too close to home
fields.standfirst: Abbey bid would offer few benefits
fields.trailText: Emergency board meetings, followed by stony silence - it is enough to frustrate even the most ardent followers of high City finance. Lloyds TSB's determination to refuse to admit it held a board meeting on Sunday night to consider bidding for Abbey National, and then its avoidance of revealing to the City what it decided, only served to add to an already frenzied rumour mill yesterday.
fields.body:
Emergency board meetings, followed by stony silence - it is enough to frustrate even the most ardent followers of high City finance. Lloyds TSB's determination to refuse to admit it held a board meeting on Sunday night to consider bidding for Abbey National, and then its avoidance of revealing to the City what it decided, only served to add to an already frenzied rumour mill yesterday.

It seems that trying to sweet-talk the management team at Abbey, already under siege from the Bank of Scotland, is a likely option. But, it might be the one that Lloyds TSB, which has held unfruitful talks with Abbey over the last three years, should avoid, particularly if talk of a huge £13-a-share bid is true.

While Peter Ellwood, the Lloyds TSB chief executive, is under pressure from investors to prove his credentials, taking over Abbey may not satisfy their demands.

For a start, a takeover would be risky on the competition front. Combined with Abbey, Lloyds TSB would control more than 30% of the current accounts in the country, one aspect of the business which caused much excitement during the controversial Don Cruickshank investigation into financial services earlier this year.

Moreover, Abbey is regarded as one of the potential competitors for Lloyds in this market. It is a brave corporate finance executive who would advise that such a factor would pass by even the newly depoliticised competition authorities.

While Lloyds might placate the authorities with pledges to run two separate brands - the Royal Bank of Scotland/NatWest route - this would dampen its ability to strip out costs in every aspect of the combined business. There is also the little matter of a bid for Abbey amounting to a scrapping of the preferred acquisition strategy - a European takeover, that is - which Lloyds has been presenting to the City for a good 18 months now.

That strategy still makes more sense than acting defensively at home.

Alarm bells

Wow! That Greg Dyke is ringing the changes round at the BBC, making commercial bits of the corporation sweat.

Last week BBC Worldwide, the corpo ration's business division which is dedicated to exploiting the profitability of BBC programmes, announced a Canadian joint venture to launch digital TV over there.

Yesterday, we got another deal - a "multi million pound deal", at that - to license the BBC for Business catalogue of training videos and CD-Roms to Knowledge Chase, "a private equity-backed investment company" focused on education.

The idea is that Knowledge Chase, an American concern, develops BBC for Business as a global brand, digitising the BBC's training products for use on everything from DVD to the internet. Aside from top titles like 20 Steps to Better Management and Empowering Appraisal, Knowledge Chase will also have a first-look option over future BBC programming suitable for business training.

The BBC, meanwhile, will also get an equity kicker in the form of a 5% stake.

This is all forward-looking sounding stuff. But hang on, who exactly is Knowledge Chase?

According to yesterday's blurb, it is a new company founded by its current chairman and chief executive, Ed Guinan, which is "seeking to capitalise on the estimated two trillion dollar global eductation market".

The name Guinan should ring a cracked bell or two on this side of the Atlantic. He was chairman of Jellyworks, the internet investment firm.

Working with Jonathan Rowland, the 24-year old son of Monaco-based financier David "Spotty" Rowland, the venture was billed as a billion pound company in the making and one that would emulate Richard Branson's success with the Virgin brand.

Launched into the net investment feist of last Christmas at 5p a share, the market hit hypershift and sent the price to 541p - valuing a hotch-potch of options and stakes in internet businesses at almost £100m.

It almost goes without saying that the proverbial rocket came down like a stick, leaving Jellyworks to be bought out as a listed "shell" company at 25p-a-share.

Mr Guinan, however, lasted just two months at the company - his resignation proving all the more mysterious since he gave up stock options then worth a cool £20m.

He is an entrepreneur and makes no secret of the fact that several of his past enterprises have failed dismally. The BBC also know this but is satisfied that Knowledge Chase is a suitable partner.

All the same, it is difficult to avoid speculating that this is a business disaster training video in the making.

webTitle: Tanzanian toads hit road to escape extinction

fields.headline: Tanzanian toads hit road to escape extinction
fields.trailText: A chronic power shortage in Tanzania is threatening to wipe out a rare species of toad which shares its only known habitat, a 200-metre stretch of riverbank in the southern highlands, with a new hydro-electric power station.
fields.byline: James Astill  in Dar es Salaam
fields.body:
A chronic power shortage in Tanzania is threatening to wipe out a rare species of toad which shares its only known habitat, a 200-metre stretch of riverbank in the southern highlands, with a new hydro-electric power station.

The power plant is currently running below capacity as water is diverted to the inch-long spray toads, which live in a cloud of vapour beneath the Kihansi waterfall.

But since the introduction of power rationing last week, the Tanzania Electric Company (Tanesco) has come under mounting pressure to turn the turbine taps on full. Should that happen, the 10-12,000 toads will dry out and die.

Last week the World Bank paid for 500 of the toads to be flown to US universities, to see whether a new habitat could be artifically created.

To sustain spray toads in their natural state, the waterfall must have a constant flow of eight cubic metres per second, cutting potential electricity generation by almost a third. At present an artificial sprayer sprinkles the toads with two cubic metres of water per second.

But Tanzania is producing less than half the electricity it needs. Two cubic metres of water could power a rural area the size of southern England.

Environmentalists say the toad species - only discovered in 1996, two years after work began on the £189m hydropower project - is unique in that the toads give birth to fully-formed tadpoles instead of spawning.

But Tanzanians care little that the toad might be wiped out. One Dar es Salaam resident said yesterday: "We are not worth the bloody toad. How do we benefit from its rarity?"

webTitle: Caught on camera: The last journey of Damilola Taylor

fields.headline: Caught on camera: The last journey of Damilola Taylor
fields.standfirst:
More about the Damilola Taylor case
Gallery: the CCTV shots
fields.trailText: Damilola Taylor leaps across a set of decorative stones outside a sports centre in Peckham, south London, leaning heavily to one side to keep his balance, his arms splayed.
fields.body:
Damilola Taylor leaps across a set of decorative stones outside a sports centre in Peckham, south London, leaning heavily to one side to keep his balance, his arms splayed.

Moments later, he is filmed running deliberately along the marked lines of a nearby square.

He seems lost in his own world, playing a private game that has its own set of rules and challenges.

By the time he reaches Peckham library, the 10-year-old is walking - concentrating, perhaps, on the computer class ahead.

The final picture shows him waiting in a lift. He is on his own and appears to be smiling.

These images of Damilola, which were recovered from closed circuit television security cameras, span just a few minutes at the end of his life.

But they show that at 3.45 on Monday afternoon last week, about an hour before he died from a stab wound to his leg, he was in high spirits. Although he had complained of being bullied at Oliver Goldsmith primary school, it did not seem to be preying on his mind. At this point, he was not being followed.

Detectives are still trying to piece together what happened to him in the interval between 4.25pm, when he left the library to walk home, and the discovery of his body in a stairwell of the nearby North Peckham estate 21 minutes later.

They hope the cctv pictures will jog memories and encourage witnesses to come forward. Detective Superintendent David Dillnutt, who is supervising the inquiry, said: "I ask children and adults, did they see Damilola? Did they see him talk to anyone? Did they see anyone attacking him? However irrelevant you might think the information may be, please come forward."

Mr Dillnutt said the inquiry, Operation Seale, was not facing any wall of silence in the community: many children had given statements, although the 70-strong murder squad had had to treat the children with caution because of their age.

The boy had arrived in London four month ago from Nigeria, but yesterday leaders of the African community in London sought to dispel fears of tensions between Africans and Afro-Caribbeans during a meeting held in Peckham.

Kabineh Koroma, of the Confederation of African Community Organisations, said: "Any attempt to focus on community tensions is going to divert our limited energies and resources. Let us concentrate on catching whoever committed this crime. Damilola could have been a Turkish boy or an English boy, and the perpetrators could also be any members of our society."

Southwark council yesterday released figures showing that on five Peckham estates with a violent reputation, including the one where Damilola was murdered, crime had fallen in the last year - there being 182 attacks on people in the year to September 30, compared with 213 the previous year.

webTitle: Anger at greetings from killers' regiment

fields.headline: Anger at greetings from killers' regiment
fields.standfirst: Supporters of man shot by army sickened by 'peace' card
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence has been asked to investigate why soldiers sent a Christmas card to a civil rights group that is protesting bitterly at the decision to allow two men to stay in the army after they killed an unarmed Catholic teenager.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence has been asked to investigate why soldiers sent a Christmas card to a civil rights group that is protesting bitterly at the decision to allow two men to stay in the army after they killed an unarmed Catholic teenager.

The card from the Scots Guards, with the handwritten message "From all ranks, 1st Battalion Scots Guards, Nanyuki, Kenya" was sent last week to the Pat Finucane Centre in Derry. Two Scots guardsmen - James Fisher and Mark Wright - are staying in the army despite killing the civilian.

The official British army card has a picture of a guardsman with a group of laughing Kenyans and reads: "The army wishes you a happy Christmas and a peaceful new year." It was enclosed in an official UN envelope. An army spokesman said last night: "It is either tactless or malicious and is deeply to be regretted".

The spokesman confirmed the Scots Guards were training in Kenya under UN auspices.

The Pat Finucane Centre last month strongly condemned the decision by the ministry to allow the Scots guardsmen to remain in the army. The two soldiers shot Peter McBride in the back after he was stopped and searched by an army patrol in north Belfast in 1992. They were tried in 1995 and given a life sentence for murder but were freed under licence in 1998.

The MoD said that Queen's regulations allowed convicted soldiers to remain in the army under "exceptional circumstances", but refused to elaborate on what these might be.

The card was received by the centre last week on the anniversary of Mr McBride's birthday.

The Labour MP, Kevin McNamara, yesterday called on Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary ,to order an immediate investigation into the incident. "If those responsible were Scots Guards it further demonstrates the folly of allowing the guardsmen, Fisher and Wright, to resume their military careers with impunity," he said.

He said public confidence demanded that "rogue units" were dealt with swiftly and "without prevarication".

Paul O'Connor, spokesman for the Pat Finucane Centre, last night described the card as an insult to the McBride family. In the context of the army board's decision, he said it was not surprising that a "gloating and offensive card is sent signed on behalf of the 1st battalion, the Scots Guards". He said it was pitiful.

The MoD yesterday denied reports that a decision had been taken to court martial three British paratroopers after the killing last year of two Albanians, thought to be members of the Kosovo Liberation Army. The soldiers, from the 1st battalion of the Parachute Regiment, were alleged to have shot the men, Fahri Bici, 20, and Avni Dudi, 24, in Pristina on July 3.

"Army legal services are undertaking a preliminary examination of the evidence," said an MoD spokesman. The soldiers, based at Folkestone, Kent, will stay in service during the inquiry.

Official reports on the incident said that the soldiers' patrol had opened fire on a vehicle because they feared lives were at risk from a man firing shots outside a building full of Serbs whom the paras had been ordered to protect. One of the wounded civilians was hit six times.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Ernst & Young bonus bonanza
fields.body:
Ernst & Young bonus bonanza

Four hundred partners at Ernst & Young, the big five firm of accountants, took home average pay and bonuses last year of more than £800,000.

The firm said strong revenue growth pushed profits per partner ahead 16% to £424,000.

The successful disposal of its management consulting arm to French rival Cap Gemini resulted in bonuses of £390,000 for each partner and an undisclosed number of shares in the new business -Cap Gemini Ernst & Young.

British Alcan cuts 220 jobs

British Alcan Aluminium said yesterday it would cut 220 jobs in Wales, following the closure of one of its plants in the region by the end of June next year.

The company, which is a unit of Canadian firm Alcan Aluminium, cited severe market conditions and the strength of the pound against European currencies as reasons for the closure of its Foil plant in Rogerstone, Newport, south Wales.

Airline hints at bid approach

British Regional Air Lines yesterday announced a possible bid approach which lifted its share price but left analysts puzzled about the identity of the possible bidder.

BRAL, a franchise operator of British Airways domestic flights, was spun off from British Midland in 1998 at 150p a share. But its shares have languished near the 60p level until yesterday's statement.

Any deal would need the support of BA and the backing of BRAL's chairman, Sir Michael Bishop, who owns about 26% of the company.

Short circuit at ScottishPower

ScottishPower faces a $180m (£124m) hit after its 430-megawatt power plant in Hunter, Utah, suffered a short circuit which could keep it out of action for up to six months.

The net impact will be $1m a day, including the cost of buying in electricity to fuel its customers through the winter.

The problem occurred on November 24 and is thought to have been caused by an insulation breakdown.

The timing is bad from a financial point of view because power prices are now high in California and the western US.

Shops feel seasonal chill

The Christmas shopping season got off to a slow start last month, with sales of top high street stores rising just 2% from one year ago, according to the British Retail Consortium's monthly survey published today.

"Disruption to transport and rain throughout November appears to have dampened people's enthusiasm for shopping," said Bill Moyes, director general of the BRC.

Bridget Rosewell, chief economic adviser to the BRC, said shoppers could well be waiting for discounts before doing their Christmas shopping.

BRAL, a franchise operator of British Airways domestic flights, was spun off from British Midland in 1998 at 150p a share. Any deal would need the support of BA and the backing of BRAL's chairman, Sir Michael Bishop, who owns about 26% of the company. webTitle: TI finance chief in line for £2.3m farewell

fields.headline: TI finance chief in line for £2.3m farewell
fields.trailText: Martin Angle, former finance director of TI Group, is in line for a pay-off of at least £2.3m after abruptly deciding yesterday not to join the main board of Smiths Group.
fields.body:
Martin Angle, former finance director of TI Group, is in line for a pay-off of at least £2.3m after abruptly deciding yesterday not to join the main board of Smiths Group.

His decision emerged as trading began in shares in the engineering combine created by the £4.5bn merger between Smith and TI.

Mr Angle, due to become executive director of strategy at Smiths, made his decision as the group prepares to enter the FTSE 100 and raise up to £1.2bn through the sale of the old TI automotive division to venture capitalists.

It is understood that Mr Angle, a former investment banker, prefers to continue his career in the financial field rather than switch to corporate strategy. He is already pursuing a number of options.

He is following the lead of Sir Christopher Lewinton, former TI chairman and chief executive, who turned down the offer of a year's contract as Smiths chairman and received a £2.37m cash severance package, with a number of share options to be realised.

Two TI executives, John Langston and David Lillycrop, join the main Smiths board while three non-executive directors, Sir Colin Chandler, John Hignett and Sir Nigel Bloomfield, are also switching over to the enlarged group.

Mr Angle's two-year contract entitles him to twice his salary of £400,000 and he stands to pick up a further £575,000 from a TI bonus scheme. A range of other benefits bring the total package to £1.6m.

Under a share incentive scheme he can convert 190,000 TI shares into 87,000 Smiths shares, worth around £700,000 at last night's close of 817.5p. But analysts expect Smiths stock to rise in value once it enters the FTSE on December 18.

The new group will have four divisions: aerospace, medical, sealings and industrial.

fields.headline: Tories face a beating
fields.standfirst:
Even with sophisticated opinion polling, it is hard to predict the outcome of the election. But the signs are not good for the Conservatives

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The latest whisper says it is April and politicians, journalists and party strategists are going to be scrutinising the polls, including the Guardian/ICM result today, with ever-increasing attention. Their focus is mostly the "horse-race" aspect of the polls, how far Labour leads the Tories and whether their lead can be overturned before polling day.
fields.body:
The latest whisper says it is April and politicians, journalists and party strategists are going to be scrutinising the polls, including the Guardian/ICM result today, with ever-increasing attention. Their focus is mostly the "horse-race" aspect of the polls, how far Labour leads the Tories and whether their lead can be overturned before polling day.

But the party voters say they might vote for in polls is only half the story. What matters is how such votes get translated into the seats held by the respective parties in the House of Commons. Ultimately it is the tally of constituencies won that decides the outcome of a general election; but, typically, little attention is given to this fact when polls are reported. That may be because the business of translating votes cast for parties into seats held in the Commons is thought to be very difficult.

It is not as complicated as some people think. In the 1950s, when Labour and the Tories dominated the Commons, the device for translating vote shares into seat shares was known as the "cube rule". This formula stated that the ratio of Tory to Labour seats in the Commons was the same not as the straightforward ratio of one party's vote to the other's but as the ratio between the cube of the Tory vote-share and the cube of the Labour vote-share.

The rule is not as involved as it may at first appear. Take the 1955 general election, when Anthony Eden's Tories faced a Labour party led by an ageing Clement Attlee. The Tories won 49.7% of votes cast for MPs and Labour 46.4%. If we cube these percentages we get a figure of 122,763 for the Tories and 99,897 for Labour. That makes the Tory share just over 55% of the combined total. So their predicted share of seats in the Commons should also be 55%. Thus in 1955 the cube rule predicted 347 Tory seats and 283 Labour seats. The seats actually won by the parties were 344 for the Tories and 295 for Labour. The rule was not completely accurate but it did come pretty close.

Two-party rule was broken when the Liberals (as they then were) and the Scottish and Welsh nationalists started to win seats, and by the 1970s the cube rule had become quite inaccurate. The February 1974 election called by Ted Heath was a turning point. The Liberals took 19% - a three-horse race. If we apply the cube rule to the 1997 general election, it predicts 485 Labour seats, when they actually won 418. So the rule is not very accurate in the context of multi-party politics.

But there are alternative models for predicting how Commons seats fall out. One method is to give each party a baseline number of seats and then add extra seats for every additional percent of the vote won by that party while subtracting seats for the share of the vote won by its main rival. If we retrospectively apply this model to the 1997 election, it performs quite well, giving a result only five seats out for Labour and nine out for the Tories.

The model does less well with the Liberal Democrats, forecasting 33 seats for them when they actually won 46 seats. The problem with calculating Liberal Democrat seats is that they are rivals to the Tories in many more seats than they are in close competition with Labour, so the scale of Tory support has a big influence on their success. Another factor is that the Liberal Democrat seat tally is influenced by the effectiveness of their local constituency campaigns. While targeted campaigns are important for Labour, they are really important for the Liberal Democrats and the model does not take this into account.

September's Gallup poll - the survey was conducted just after the petrol crisis - said 44% intended to vote Labour, 35% Tory and 17% for the Liberal Democrats. If we apply the forecasting model to these figures it predicts 377 seats for labour, 219 for the Tories and 26 for the Liberal Democrat. However, the same Gallup poll - testing the idea that Labour supporters might be less likely to turn out and vote than supporters of the other parties - asked respondents to indicate the strength of their intention to vote in the next general election. Respondents who said they were very likely to vote made up 72% of the sample, which is fairly close to the actual turnout in the last general election. We get a more accurate picture of actual voting behaviour by concentrating on this group.

The voting intentions of this group were 42% for Labour, 36% for the Tories and 17% for the Liberal Democrats. So the bias caused by lower turnouts among Labour supporters appears to be worth about 2%. Translated into seats gained by the parties, this would give Labour 358, the Tories 240 and the Liberal Democrats 24. The last figure is a bit of a problem: as before, the Liberal Democrat prediction is likely to be less accurate than for the other two parties. Other research shows that if Liberal Democrat party members can campaign as effectively at the local level as they did in 1997, they could do significantly better than this figure suggests.

So what happens when we apply this reasoning to the latest evidence of people's voting intentions? The November MORI poll published recently in the Times gave Labour 48%, the Tories 33% and the Liberal Democrats 13%. If we factor in a 2% adjustment to the Labour and Tory shares to reflect differences in turnout, then the model predicts 397 seats for Labour, 199 Tory and 26 Liberal Democrats - Labour's winning margin is 172. Labour has clearly bounced back from the petrol crisis.

A necessary caveat is that things may be upset again. But if not, the Tories look set to take a real beating at the next election, enough to make William Hague vulnerable as their leader. You might conclude that Michael Portillo picked a bad time to express reluctance to stand for the Tory leadership, since it is looking increasingly likely that the job will become vacant when votes are counted after the next election.

Paul Whiteley is professor of politics at the University of Sheffield.

fields.headline: Pepsi's $13bn wins Quaker sports drink
fields.trailText: A drink created for thirsty college football players in Florida was at the centre of a $13.4bn (£9.2bn) deal yesterday when PepsiCo agreed to buy Quaker Oats, owner of the Gatorade sports drink.
fields.body:
A drink created for thirsty college football players in Florida was at the centre of a $13.4bn (£9.2bn) deal yesterday when PepsiCo agreed to buy Quaker Oats, owner of the Gatorade sports drink.

Shares in Pepsi and Quaker rose as investors welcomed the conclusion of a takeover battle which started more than a month ago.

The acquisition will put Pepsi ahead of rival Coca-Cola in the fast growing market for "non-carbonated" drinks.

Gatorade, which was developed in 1965 to stop the University of Florida Gators from dehydrating, is America's top-selling sports drink with 83% of the market.

Roger Enrico, chairman and chief executive of Pepsi, said non-carbonated drinks were expected to grow three times as fast as carbonated ones in the next few years. The company is likely to use its distribution network to increase overseas sales.

Gatorade, available in varying flavours according to country of sale, contributes about 40% of Quaker's sales and profits. Sales increased 15% last year. Pepsi sales rose 4%.

Mr Enrico, who will step down as chairman once the deal is completed next year, also expected Quaker's snack food business to grow rapidly. "More and more people are getting their nutritional and calorific intake through on-the-go meals," he said. Quaker owns a range of cereal and fruit bars as well as the eponymous porridge oats.

Under the terms of the all-share deal, Pepsi will offer 2.3 of its own shares to Quaker shareholders. Based on Friday's closing price of $42.38, this values the Chicago-based food business at $97.50 a share, an 18% premium to its price in early November when reports of takeover talks first emerged.

Shares in Quaker rose $2.50 to $91.06 yesterday morning. At midday, shares in Pepsi were also up almost $2, valuing each Quaker share at $101.6 and the deal at $13.8bn before the assumption of $750m in debt. Yesterday's agreement included a provision for Quaker to walk away from the deal if its value falls below $92 a share.

John Macmillan, food analyst at Prudential Securities, said the deal was good for both sides. "If colas are not growing, you have got to expand your hand," he said.

Shareholders in Quaker Oats were disappointed two weeks ago when Coca-Cola withdrew from a proposed $15bn bid.

Quaker Oats, which dates back more than 100 years, has been revitalised by the popularity of Gatorade, which it bought in 1983. The former miller adopted the Quaker Man as a logo in 1901, much to the annoyance of the Society of Friends (the Quakers) with which it has no connection.

Pepsi said that it expected restructuring costs of $400m from a deal which would be earnings enhancing within 12 months of completion. It also expected $65m savings on costs within five years but declined to say where these would fall.

webTitle: Old tyres to fuel cement works

fields.headline: Old tyres to fuel cement works
fields.trailText: Urban landscapes disfigured by mountains of tyres could become a thing of the past under plans by Blue Circle Industries to use rubber to fuel its cement kilns.
fields.body:
Urban landscapes disfigured by mountains of tyres could become a thing of the past under plans by Blue Circle Industries to use rubber to fuel its cement kilns.

Blue Circle admits it might face opposition from local communities but claims tyre burning is environmentally friendly because the kilns are so hot they produce almost no emissions or smells.

The cement group, which has seen its fuel bills soar recently, hopes to cut £6m a year off operating costs through a joint venture with French tyre manufacturer Michelin.

The landfill disposal of tyres will be outlawed under European commission rules in 2003. By then the joint venture, Sapphire Energy Recovery, expects to be burning 200,000 tons of tyres a year. It could dispose of half of the 39.5m tyres scrapped in Britain every year.

Rob Davies, operations director at Blue Circle Cement UK, said he could use the knowledge of Michelin to "help provide the tyre industry with cost-effective solutions for environmentally sound scrap tyre disposal while also reducing energy bills in the cement-making process".

Blue Circle has started trials at its Hope plant in the Peak District and Dunbar works in Scotland, under agreements with environmental agencies and local communities.

A BCI spokeswoman said no tyre burning was undertaken at its seven sites in Britain without first going through lengthy consultations with residents. Many local people were fearful when approached but were won over when they heard details.

BCI pointed out that other unusual fuel sources had been used in plants including recycled liquid fuel which could contain the remnants of anything from paint stripper to petrol station leftovers. BCI even burns pieces of carpet at its plant in Atlanta, Georgia.

BCI's global fuel bill per year is £300m, but the potential saving from tyres equates to the increase this year in UK fuel costs.

fields.headline: Airport faces pay cuts disruption
fields.trailText: One of Britain's busiest airports is likely to be hit by strike action in the run-up to Christmas. Porters, cleaners, security guards and other staff at Luton airport are threatening industrial action in protest at salary cuts.
fields.body:
One of Britain's busiest airports is likely to be hit by strike action in the run-up to Christmas. Porters, cleaners, security guards and other staff at Luton airport are threatening industrial action in protest at salary cuts.

Members of the Transport and General Workers union claim that some staff will have their pay slashed by 50% because of cost cutting plans.

The union, which is expected to announce a strike date within a few days, warned the airport could be closed by the action. Luton, the country's seventh busiest airport, is used by 6m passengers a year and is the base of the cut price carrier EasyJet.

The union said the private consortium running the airport was trying to cut costs, even though passenger numbers were up and air travel was booming. Some security guards claimed their pay will be cut from £21,000 a year to £14,000 a year, under the proposals.

George Ryde, the union's national officer, said: "We have proposed a pragmatic maximum limit on pay cuts within the existing cost base but the airport management refused to agree an acceptable compromise.

"The strength of feeling among workers is clear to see. They will not accept the slashing of their pay when their hard work is making the airport such a success. Any financial problems at the airport are entirely of the company's own making."

A spokeswoman for the airport, which was run by the local council until 1998, said changes were planned because staff were working on different terms and conditions. Some staff would have their pay cut but others would receive an increase, she said.

Meetings have been held between the two sides at the conciliation service, Acas, and she hoped the dispute could be resolved by negotiation. The spokeswoman admitted that the airport would be affected by a strike but added that contingency measures were being drawn up.

webTitle: Flagship show's quiz proves weakest link

fields.headline: Flagship show's quiz proves weakest link
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: It may be the BBC's flagship news programme, but Today's first foray into light entertainment has proved a flop.
fields.body:
It may be the BBC's flagship news programme, but Today's first foray into light entertainment has proved a flop.

Programme makers have been forced to admit that a news quiz running on Today's corner of the Radio Four website is failing after eight people attempted it last week.

The dismal take-up may have something to do with the prizes which this week include a signed Charlie Dimmock calendar, a guide to pre-menstrual syndrome, the new Rolf Harris single and a re-issued King Crimson CD.

Listeners who log on to the quiz must rack their sleep-fuddled memories to recollect the "strange, ludicrous, mendacious or plain stupid" things people have said or done on the previous week's Today programmes.

A fairly typical question comments waspishly on Tory MP Sir Peter Tapsell, who "prior to putting the phone down on our producer ... told him that Today only ever called him about silly things and that if we wanted him on the programme we should talk to him about economics or monetary policy".

The quiz asks: "As a listener to Today, with what degree of urgency do YOU think we should take up Sir Peter's suggestion?" The suggested answers range from "very great urgency" to "a fairly relaxed degree of urgency."

As an on-screen message admits: "We are all, in a sense, the weakest link. Goodbye."

fields.body:
The Financial Services Authority yesterday told mortgage companies to cut back on big loans for first-time buyers and warned that prices in the London area may be in the "danger zone".

It revealed that in recent months more and more mortgages have breached the traditional affordability test of three times a borrower's income.

FSA chairman Howard Davies told a council of mortgage lenders meeting of the government's concern about irresponsible lending at a time when the number of personal loans for cars and holidays is leading to widespread over-indebtedness.

He told them to take more account of potential affordability problems and ordered closer monitoring of high income multiple lending.

Most at risk are home buyers taking out big loans for expensive London homes, he said. "The gap between average London house prices and average prices in the rest of the country is now as large in percentage terms as it was at its peak in the late 1980s."

In 1988 London prices peaked at 1.75 times the national average, but then fell to 1.22 times by 1993.

"I am not in the prediction business ... but clearly one cannot exclude the possibility of a fall in London house prices, which could put very high loan-to-value loans into the danger zone," said Mr Davies.

Halifax said yesterday that its income multiples have stayed relatively stable, and that while prices in London are high, low interest rates make big loans more affordable. A spokesman said: "In the late 1980s Londoners were paying 40% of their salary into a mortgage, but today the figure is 25% as interest rates have come down from 15.4% to 7.74%."

webTitle: Bones point to man's oldest relative

fields.headline: Bones point to man's oldest relative
fields.trailText: French and Kenyan scientists claimed yesterday to have found fossils of a human ancestor from 6m years ago. The find of bones and teeth from at least five individuals, in the Tugen Hills of Kenya's Bariongo district, pushes human ancestry back another 1.5m years, according to the team.
fields.body:
French and Kenyan scientists claimed yesterday to have found fossils of a human ancestor from 6m years ago. The find of bones and teeth from at least five individuals, in the Tugen Hills of Kenya's Bariongo district, pushes human ancestry back another 1.5m years, according to the team.

The new hominid - nicknamed Millennium Man - had strong hind legs which enabled it to walk upright, and the upper arm of a tree-climbing creature - although it was probably not strong enough to hang from branches or swing through the forest.

Its teeth - small canines and full molars covered with thick enamel - and jaw structure mark it most obviously as part of the lineage of modern humans.

"Thickened enamel in the molars is a feature which does distinguish our lineage, and it is something we don't see in the Pongidae , which include the chimpanzee and the gorilla," said Robert Kruszynski of the Natural History Museum in London last night.

The bones were found in rock strata which had already been shown to be 6m years old or more. This makes the Millennium Man far older than any previous find, and a candidate ancestor of the Australopithecines of South Africa, the forerunners of species such as Homo erectus, who stalked the planet a million years ago.

Hominids and great apes are thought to have descended separately from a common ancestor which lived perhaps 7m years ago.

"Not only is this find older than any else previously known, it is also in a more advanced stage of evolution," Martin Pickford, one of the discoverers, said in Nairobi.

One of the team, Brigitte Senut of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, said: "We have found fossils of trees, fossils of rhino, antelope ... many things. They would not be what you would recognise today, but earlier ancestors of them."

fields.headline: Fonteyn admirers horrified by sale of costumes and letters at auction
fields.trailText: Admirers of Dame Margot Fonteyn, the greatest British dancer of the 20th century, are fighting a behind the scenes campaign to stop treasured relics of her career vanishing abroad into private collections.
fields.body:
Admirers of Dame Margot Fonteyn, the greatest British dancer of the 20th century, are fighting a behind the scenes campaign to stop treasured relics of her career vanishing abroad into private collections.

One is understood to have written to the Queen, pleading for support in raising funds to buy the prima ballerina assoluta's costumes and letters for the nation when they come up for auction at Christie's in London next Tuesday.

Their spokesman, the distinguished ballet director Sir Peter Wright, said last night: "It breaks my heart to think that these things may be hidden away in some collection in the US or south America.

"The prospect is horrifying. It is a tragedy that we seem to have lost our national pride. We as a nation will be the poorer."

The collection of 150 items includes the tutu for the Sleeping Beauty in the production which brought Fonteyn to sudden and enduring international fame in 1946. There are also costumes in which she danced alongside Rudolf Nureyev in Swan Lake, as well as her lifelong correspondence with her mentor, Ninette de Valois. Fonteyn died in 1991 after a career spanning more than 40 years.

The collection is understood to have been put on the mar ket by the family of her late brother, Felix. It is expected to raise well over £100,000 - though ballet dresses and headdresses are priced at relatively low figures, from £600 to £5,000.

Sir Peter, 74, director laureate of Birmingham (formerly Sadler's Wells) Royal Ballet, danced with Fonteyn in the late 1940s and directed her in many productions until the early 1980s. He said one leading campaigner had delivered a letter to Buckingham Palace appealing for help from the Queen, who has been patron to the Royal Ballet.

Sir Peter said: "There is anguish about this in the ballet world. It is a tragedy that we seem to be losing the legacy of the greatest and most wonderful stars like Fonteyn, Frederick Ashton, and Nureyev. This extensive collection seems to be being auctioned off in a hurry. But, since there are no funds, it is understandable the family wishes to sell it."

Both the National Art Collections Fund and the Royal Opera House were unable to help. "I hope many people with influence - and hopefully money - will go and buy some of these things and donate them to the Royal Opera House, where they can be collated and displayed."

Sir Peter added that Dame Ninette, aged 102, was not well enough to be told of the sale: "I know it would break her heart."

The costume from Fonteyn's 1946 Sleeping Beauty recalled for him the "night of nights" when he saw it as a young dancer. "It was exquisitely danced, with the greatest interpretative artistry as she moved from the innocence of a young girl into becoming a young woman. It was thrilling. She was unmatched as an interpreter of a role."

In their work together, "she was quite a hard taskmaster. She pushed me into getting the best she possibly could. She was the most amazing and selfless artist I have ever seen."

After speaking to the Fonteyn family last night, Christie's said: "The vendors believe that offering this collection at auction is the most appropriate way of giving all of Fonteyn's many fans, as well as other interested parties, an opportunity to acquire individual items on the open market."

 Born Margaret Hookham in Reigate, Surrey on May 18 1919. Spent much of her childhood in China and returned to live in England aged 14.

 Made her debut in 1934 for the then Vic-Wells ballet as a snowflake in Nutcracker.

 By 1940 she was prima ballerina of the Royal Ballet. Her performance as Aurora at the re-opening of the Opera House, Covent Garden, in 1946 is considered one of her most memorable. This Ashton-Messel production catapulted Fonteyn and British ballet to international fame.

 In 1956 she married Roberto de Arias, a Panama nian diplomat.

 Close to retirement in the early 60s she formed a partnership with the Russian dancer Rudolf Nureyev, who was 20 years her junior. The acclaimed partnership was to last into the 1970s.

 In 1954 she became president of the Royal Academy of Dancing and in 1956 she was made a Dame of the British Empire.

 In 1979 the Royal Ballet granted Fonteyn the rare title prima ballerina assoluta.

 Fonteyn gave her last performance in the early 70s, and retired to Panama to live with her husband. She died of cancer in 1991.

webTitle: Leader: If only Blair could temper privatisation

fields.headline: Wish list for the next term
fields.standfirst:
If only Blair could temper privatisation
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats gave theirs yesterday, the Tories will give theirs today - but the one that counts will come tomorrow. Putative Queen's speeches, like shadow budgets, are all very well but the one that matters is the one Her Majesty delivers. And that will be written by Labour.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats gave theirs yesterday, the Tories will give theirs today - but the one that counts will come tomorrow. Putative Queen's speeches, like shadow budgets, are all very well but the one that matters is the one Her Majesty delivers. And that will be written by Labour. What it contains will be read not only as a programme for the remainder of the government's first term, but as a wish list for its second. For that reason a Queen's speech written for an administration that is three and a half years old is more than an agenda for government: it is an argument for a renewed mandate, a glimpse of the manifesto to come.

So what will be in tomorrow's address - and what should be? Purists would doubtless like Labour to use its last spurt of legislative time to fulfil all those pledges made in 1997 which are yet to be honoured. In this category, some would dearly wish for, say, a referendum on electoral reform for the House of Commons - that was on Charles Kennedy's list yesterday - while others dream of full government sponsorship of a bill to ban foxhunting. But those hopes are unrealistic and also a little unfair: Labour's 1997 manifesto was sufficiently vague on those topics for the party to insist with justification that there were no real commitments to be broken. Lawyers speak of the promised independent judicial appointments commission which has failed to appear - but Labour can point to the new advisory body it set up to assist the lord chancellor in filling the senior benches, and say that the government has at least addressed the issue.

The result is that only one key promise is unambiguously unfulfilled - and that is the implementation of the Scott report's recommendations following the arms-for-Iraq affair. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, made his name on that episode - and Labour in opposition exploited the issue very effectively. And yet they have failed to act; the arms trade remains untamed.

Labour should not face the electorate next spring with a promise so blatantly unkept. Happily, the signals are that it will not: it seems the Queen will trail tomorrow at least a first step towards the realisation of Scott, in the form of consultation or draft legislation to be completed in a second Labour term. That is welcome. Still, Labour made another promise in 1997: it said it would wean weapons manufacturers off their trade and help them adapt to making other products. Only the most optimistic would look for action on so-called defence diversification tomorrow - even though the Ministry of Defence has spent nearly four years dragging its feet.

Besides that gesture towards the promises of 1997, the rest of tomorrow's address will focus on what has become the chief mission of this government: repairing Britain's public services. Look for legislation implementing this year's national health plan and helping the police fight crime. There might also be action on transport, preparing the legal ground for changes on rail safety for example, and some new, if modest plans for education: after five large bills in that area, Labour is unlikely to do anything major.

Will that be enough? For those stranded on the railways, struggling on the London Underground or worried about safety in the skies it may not be: they would rather see New Labour recant its faith in partial privatisations and apply a more public approach to the big services - while still spending plenty of money. That kind of change of tack is unlikely tomorrow, but if the speech works - and Labour wins its second term - the pressure to make it can only intensify.

fields.headline: Animal feed ban as Europe acts on BSE
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The controversial practice of feeding ground animal remains to pigs and poultry is to be outlawed across the European Union from January
fields.body:
The controversial practice of feeding ground animal remains to pigs and poultry is to be outlawed across the European Union from January as part of a continent-wide effort to stamp out a rising wave of consumer panic over mad cow disease.

In a move which brings the rest of Europe more into line with anti-BSE measures already taken in Britain, EU agriculture ministers yesterday agreed to ban the use of meat and bonemeal from animal feed, initially for six months only, from January 1.

Britain has outlawed the practice since 1996 but other countries have continued to feed meat and bonemeal to pigs and poultry believing it to be safe.

Late last night ministers were poised to adopt Europe's most drastic package of anti-BSE measures to date, including the effective banning of 7m older cattle from all food products from the same date.

Under the scheme cattle carcasses more than 30 months old which have not been tested for BSE will not be allowed to enter the food chain.

Countries such as Sweden and Finland - which are still able to boast BSE-free cattle herds - were, however, showing some signs of opposition to the deal, mainly because of the high costs involved. It could cost £3.4bn to implement.

But most countries were eager to clinch an agreement to avoid the issue spilling over into the crunch EU summit in Nice later this week.

Momentum for action over BSE has been building in recent weeks after the first cases of mad cow disease were discovered in Germany and Spain.

A rise in BSE incidence in France has also piled on the pressure and sales of beef have plunged around Europe as consumers have rushed to switch to chicken and pork.

Although there is scant scientific evidence to prove that feeding meat and bonemeal to pigs and poultry poses a risk to human health, the European commission suspects that many European farmers are illegally giving the feed to cattle, a practice known to be dangerous.

Spokeswoman Beate Gminder said: "We have serious doubts about whether the separation of feed is being done properly. The commission is very satisfied that this went through because it will give us a period of time to review our controls."

By taking meat-based feed out of the foodchain altogether the EU aims to choke off supplies so that unscrupu lous farmers are not tempted to give the feed to their cows.

Germany and Finland opposed the ban. Germany thought the measures were not strict enough while Finland considered it was being unfairly forced to act in the light of the fact that its herds are supposedly BSE-free.

The entire package was supported by Nick Brown, Britain's agriculture minister, who argued that an EU-wide approach to the problem was the only option.

He is keen to discourage individual member states from taking unilateral action because he believes a continent-wide response to the disease increases Britain's chances of getting France to lift its own illegal ban on British beef.

"I think the French were wrong on their ban against British beef... they were wrong on science and they are wrong in law," Mr Brown told BBC radio.

"For the rest of the EU to replicate that would be a mistake. There aren't national solutions to this. The prion itself that causes the condition in cattle knows no boundaries."

Tim Yeo, the shadow agriculture minister, yesterday reiterated his call for a ban on French beef, accusing Mr Brown of being afraid to act for fear of offending the European commission.

fields.headline: Clearing the air
fields.standfirst:
Global agreements can work
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Not all international climate conferences are gloom and doom. Just before the Hague meeting last month, scientists met in Buenos Aires under the world climate research programme and came to a surprisingly optimistic conclusion.
fields.body:
Not all international climate conferences are gloom and doom. Just before the Hague meeting last month, scientists met in Buenos Aires under the world climate research programme and came to a surprisingly optimistic conclusion. They are part of the worldwide effort being made to measure changes in concentrations of ozone in the upper atmosphere - the stratosphere. At the same time they are modelling the process by which a pollutant near the earth's surface becomes humankind's salvation higher up. Nothing dramatic: the hole is still there, 11m square miles of it according to readings taken in September, along with signs of smaller holes over the Arctic. But there are also convincing signs that the volume of the chlorine compounds or CFCs, agents in the destruction of high-atmosphere ozone, may now be stabilising. If - and all ifs in international climate politics are very big ifs - the terms of the Montreal protocol of 1987 are stuck to, there is even a chance that ozone depletion may eventually be reversed and the machine that protects the planet against ultraviolet light be repaired.

Compared with controlling emissions of other greenhouse gases, notably carbon, the attack on CFCs is straightforward. Fridge and appliance makers had other chemicals to turn to. There were no great transition costs involved; it was easy for countries such as Japan to score brownie points by the scale of the reduction in CFC production they have achieved. That is not to minimise the achievement - the European Union countries, the US and Russia have made huge cuts, even if China's emissions have risen since Montreal by at least 75%.

What is worth celebrating is the scientific effort made to keep the Montreal signatories honest: the world already has a "civil society" and it publishes in peer-reviewed journals. A note of national pride is forgivable since British contributions have been important and the Natural Environment Research Council has recently come through with substantial additional support for climate work. Alan O'Neill of Reading University says the prospect of reversing ozone depletion vindicates efforts to find global solutions through the apparatus of conferences and negotiation. He is right. For all the tears and tantrums at the Hague, treaties painstakingly put together on the basis of scientific consensus are the only way environmental degradation will be stopped.

fields.headline: Meet the Flintstones
fields.trailText: Neanderthal / Thin Ice
fields.body:
Courtship in the south of France 35,000 years ago was nasty, brutish and short. The boys would go out in groups of three and track an unsuspecting girl across the rolling Provençal landscape; then, when she was happily playing with a couple of old flints they would pounce. Chat up lines were rudimentary (Him: "Nargo!" Her: "Hama!" Him: "Yeda!") but effective. After a while, however, the hunter got captured by the game: intrigued by her matted hair and eyebrows, the butchest caveman got quite affectionate, and even parted with a juicy hunk of marrowbone.

This romantic vignette was one of many revelations in Channel 4's Neanderthal , an everyday tale of stone-age folk. Actors laboured under prosthetics and ratty wigs to give a convincing impression of what Cro-Magnon man actually looked like - large of nose, heavy of brow, like Michael Portillo deprived of grooming products. Yet, while they were strangers to soap and tweezers, the Neanderthals had mastered other essential skills. Fossil remains suggest that their vocal cords could sustain speech, and that they cooked their meat. Brains were massive, as were noses - a big nose helped to warm up freezing ice-age air and prevent internal damage. They consumed up to 7,000 calories a day in winter and never got fat. They also sidestepped the problem of care for the elderly: 80 per cent never reached their 40th birthday.

While many historical documentaries are forced to rely on talking heads, laboratory sequences and endless shots of fossils, Neanderthal took the bold step of dramatic reconstruction. Nine times out of ten this goes badly wrong, but for once we could forget that these were actors with M&S thermals under the furs and enter wholeheartedly into an imagined world. The make-up created a convincing halfway stage between primitive homo erectus and modern homo sapiens, although one was forced to the conclusion that some of one's friends may have a more ancient lineage than they're letting on.

Towards the end of the show, our Neanderthal pal came face to face with his new neighbour, a recent immigrant from Asia, a tall, refined homo sapien who shaved his head and went a bit heavy on the blue eye shadow - a prehistoric Leigh Bowery prototype. They stared at each other, the brute male and the dandyfied newcomer, in mingled attraction and hostility, thus setting the blueprint for similar encounters in the millennia to come. To find out how they got on, don't miss next week's concluding episode.

All the Neanderthal clan members looked strangely similar, rather like that family in the WH Smith advert so cunningly portrayed by Nicholas Lyndhurst. The man himself appeared without wig and, mercifully, without lipstick in Thin Ice , a refreshingly black comedy on BBC1. Lyndhurst usually plays thoroughly nice young men; it was good for once to see him as an utter shit, and getting away with it. Self-styled doctor Graham Moss (Lyndhurst) handed out sleeping pills and sick notes to his grateful patients, one of whom turned out to be a police officer. Stripped of his bogus credentials, Moss promptly fell among thieves when a former patient involved him in an unlikely heist. For the rest of the hour Moss dithered between a life of crime and a career as an informer. The former had manifold attractions, not least a suitcase full of notes, and boasted the glorious sight of Geraldine McEwan as a gun-wielding Godmother. The latter's claims were pressed by smooth Det Insp Glover (Tim Dantay), who kept persecuting the slippery Moss in restaurants and car parks. The dirty Doc, however, had other ideas, and betrayed all and sundry by doing a moonlight flit with £250,000 towards starting a new life.

Thin Ice trod a fine line between mainstream drama and minority satire - just the sort of show that the controllers used fondly to call "BBC One-and-a-Half" back in the 90s. There were touches of House Of Cards - a villain you could cheer on, and some cold, calculating to-camera confessions. Lyndhurst seemed to enjoy the twist on his Goodnight, Sweetheart persona; this time he was leading a double life not because he wanted to avoid hurting anyone, but because he was a callous, self-seeking bastard. The only complaint was that Geraldine McEwan didn't have enough to do. Some of us would watch TV 24 hours a day if Miss McEwan was on.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 Poor Peter Hain becomes ever more confused about the Iraqi sanctions. For weeks, the ambitious Foreign Office minister has been saying in briefings that Britain wants them to end, but that the hawkish Americans are insisting they remain. How this tallies with the story of a plane chartered by the Moroccan lawyers' association to take humanitarian supplies (mainly medical) and 55 lawyers to Baghdad is a mystery. The plane was grounded at Casablanca for three days while our government, as a member of the UN 661 sanctions committee, kept demanding more details. Eventually, the Moroccan ambassador to the UK called George Galloway, the Commons' leading opponent of sanctions, to say that publicity was causing "widespread anti-British feeling" in Morocco. George wrote to Peter and soon after the flight finally left. What may embarrass Peter, given his line that only US intransigence is prolonging sanctions, is that the Americans on UN 661 raised no objection to the flight. Nor did anyone else but the British. Peter may have to play his little games rather more cleverly if he is to crawl into the cabinet next year.

 Thoughts of Peter bring us to an appeal. Is there a tailor or seamstress out there prepared to make a red coat which can be turned inside out to reveal a bright yellow lining? This will be first prize for the winner of a readers' poll, to be held between now and the day Mr Tony calls the election, for "New Labour Turncoat of Turncoats". Full runners and riders tomorrow, along with the fee for making the coat.

 The latest journalist to hail Mary Kenny's resignation from the Daily Express (because of porn baron Richard Desmond's takeover) is Richard Ingrams, who in the Observer follows several others in applauding this heroic self-sacrifice. Quite right too. Mary, who recently told Radio 5 listeners that her own private research suggests "almost all incest takes place within the family", is a woman of high principle. The fact that her resignation coincided with the end of a brief stint filling in until columnist Carol Sarler arrived, and that she could not have known of Mr Desmond's takeover when she finished her last piece and that she had no job to resign from or further work for the Express not to do, is not the point.

 Syd and Norma Davis write from Somerset to report committing a faux pas in the Weston-super-Mare Tesco when, after unloading their stuff, they tried to push the trolley through the checkout corridor. How gauche. As the assistant informed them, "that trolley is for use only on the last checkout, No 24." The goods were unloaded and the trolley wheeled through checkout 24 and then delivered back to them on the exit side of No 15, where they refilled it and headed for the car. Bespoke trolleys - not for nothing did Tesco supplant Sainsbury's as our leading supermarket chain.

I am captivated by a report from my so-called rival Nigel Dempster about a new member of the Taki-George family. Mandolyna Taki-George has thrown a glass of water over some ex-girlfriend of her wine waiter father, reports Nigel, in New York. The 25-year-old, who works at the National Theatre, was apparently upset at this woman's attempt to break up Taki's "happy marriage" to a minor European royal. Weirder than this, I think, is news that Taki-George himself is currently in New York. What happened to the US blanket refusal to let in anyone with a drugs conviction, however minor, let alone one for smuggling Class A substances into Britain?

 An embarras de richesses delays selection of the new Book of the Month. The two candidates are Monday Morning Blues, a selection of Express columns by Peter Hitchens; and He Never Said (Discover the Real Message of Jesus) by Diary vicar the Rev Steve Chalke. An agonising choice you will agree, but with God's help we will decide by tomorrow.

webTitle: No trial for police who shot painter

fields.headline: No trial for police who shot painter
fields.trailText: The family of a man shot dead by Metropolitan police marksmen as he walked home from a pub to watch a football match are considering seeking a judicial review of a decision yesterday not to prosecute the officers involved.
fields.body:
The family of a man shot dead by Metropolitan police marksmen as he walked home from a pub to watch a football match are considering seeking a judicial review of a decision yesterday not to prosecute the officers involved.

Harry Stanley, 46, was shot 100 yards from his home in London's east end last September. He was carrying a plastic bag containing a wooden table leg his brother had repaired. Two armed police officers responded to a tip from somebody in the Alexandra pub in Hackney who had dialled 999 and said Mr Stanley was an Irish terrorist carrying a sawn-off shotgun.

The officers challenged Mr Stanley, a painter and decorator who was originally from Glasgow, before shooting him in the head and the hand. To the fury of justice campaigners and the man's family, the CPS said yesterday that following a review the two officers would not face criminal charges.

"It is an established principle of English law that when a man honestly believes he is facing an immediate risk of suffering serious injury, even if that belief is mistaken, he is entitled to use such force as is reasonably necessary to defend himself," the CPS said in a statement, adding that close consideration was given to whether a conviction was likely should the officers face trial on charges of murder or manslaughter by gross negligence.

Mr Stanley's family have been infuriated by the treatment they have received. It took officers 18 hours to inform them of his death, despite the fact he was killed less than 100 yards from his front door and had been carrying a passport.

Yesterday Mr Stanley's son, Jason, said: "I am extremely angry and upset. It proves that nobody is safe on the streets. If this can happen to my dad, it can happened to anyone. When will somebody be held accountable for these actions?"

Daniel Machover, the family solicitor, said the family was considering a judicial review of this "remarkable" decision.

Deborah Coles, coordinator of pressure group Inquest, said: "This decision follows a pattern of cases where police officers whose conduct has led to death have not been subjected to proper scrutiny and shows that the rule of law does not apply to police officers.

"How can we accept that the shooting dead of an unarmed man does not result in a trial where a jury decides whether the actions were unlawful?"

fields.headline: Digital art
fields.trailText: Stuart Jeffries (It's not all over till the fat lady zaps, G2, November 30) argues that premium television channels such as Artsworld will find it hard to succeed because they "must court the viewers who have subscribed to Sky to see more movies and football".
fields.body:
Stuart Jeffries (It's not all over till the fat lady zaps, G2, November 30) argues that premium television channels such as Artsworld will find it hard to succeed because they "must court the viewers who have subscribed to Sky to see more movies and football".

This is an outdated caricature of Sky viewers. Sky's digital service attracts far greater numbers and varieties of households than its analogue offering did precisely because it offers a wide range of programming across all genres.

It has never been the intention of Artsworld to cater for mass audiences, just arts lovers. Thankfully, not all at Farringdon Road share Mr Jeffries's gloomy prognosis. With BSkyB, Artsworld's other major corporate shareholder is, of course, the Guardian Media Group.
Richard Freudenstein
Chief operating officer, BSkyB

fields.headline: Queen's press secretary quits for PR job
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Crawford, the Queen's press secretary, confirmed yesterday that he is leaving Buckingham Palace to become a public relations executive in his native Australia.
fields.body:
Geoffrey Crawford, the Queen's press secretary, confirmed yesterday that he is leaving Buckingham Palace to become a public relations executive in his native Australia.

Mr Crawford, an urbane and genial former diplomat, helped to steer the Queen through the crisis after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales in 1997 and was at her side on her recent official visit to Italy.

His decision comes only 18 months before the royal golden jubilee, but suggestions in the Sunday Times that the Queen was annoyed by his leaving - rumoured for some time - were dismissed last night as utter rubbish by a palace spokesman.

In a statement the palace said: "The Queen is saddened by Mr Crawford's departure but entirely understands the reasons for it."

Mr Crawford, 50, was seconded to become an assistant press secretary to the Queen in 1988 and was made press secretary to the Princess of Wales in 1993, at the time of her separation from the Prince of Wales.

He resigned from that post after the princess failed to tell him in advance about her notorious Panorama interview in 1995 in which she admitted adultery.

He was taken up by the palace again to become first deputy press secretary and then, from early 1997, press secretary to the Queen in succession to Charles Anson, another former diplomat who went into corporate public relations.

Mr Crawford has also represented the Duke of York, the Earl of Wessex, Princess Margaret and Princess Alexandra during his period at the palace. One of his most difficult mo ments came when he was identified as the official source who rubbished the Duchess of York in an off-the-record briefing to the BBC in 1992.

Mr Crawford's deputy, Penny Russell-Smith, 44, a former government press officer who has worked at the palace for seven years, is to succeed him.

Her promotion means that the Queen and Prince Charles will each have a woman and former civil servant as their chief spokesperson. The prince appointed Colleen Harris, a former trade department press officer, as his spokeswoman in the summer.

fields.headline: Back in the USSR
fields.trailText: During an ABC special, The Beatles Revolution, aired on November 17, I spoke of the influence the Beatles had had on Soviet youth. In the same show, the director Milos Forman observed that the Beatles were partly responsible for the fall of communism.
fields.body:
During an ABC special, The Beatles Revolution, aired on November 17, I spoke of the influence the Beatles had had on Soviet youth. In the same show, the director Milos Forman observed that the Beatles were partly responsible for the fall of communism.

On November 18, you published an article (For Lenin read Lennon) expressing doubts about my words, as well as those of Milos Forman, spoken during the show. The fact is that for many generations of Russians, The Beatles were one of the few means of escaping the drudgery of everyday life. What we said is not so hard to believe. More and more people are beginning to share Mr Forman's theory.

It is an interesting coincidence that, although I am not personally acquainted with Mr Forman, the same idea appears in my book, Strings For a Beatle Bass, which deals with the Beatles generation in the USSR.

Should you still have any doubts, you could easily step outside and question a Russian walking the streets of London, which is not so rare a sight as it used to be. Or simply answer the following question: what marked the end of the day in August 1991 that saw the collapse of communism in the USSR? A parade on Red Square, or a huge, open-air rock concert in Moscow, organised by the defenders of the White House?

Should there be any difficulties in answering this question, Keith Richards can provide a hint: "After those billions of dollars and living under the threat of doom, what brought it down? Blue jeans and rock'n'roll."
Dr Yury Pelyushonok
Ontario, Canada

fields.headline: Private challenge to absentee votes is Gore's last hope
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Harry Jacobs, a fast-talking lawyer from New Jersey who may prove to be Al Gore's last legal lifeline, will go to court today to back the vice-president's claim that Republicans tampered illegally with thousands of ballots in Florida's Seminole county.
fields.body:
Harry Jacobs, a fast-talking lawyer from New Jersey who may prove to be Al Gore's last legal lifeline, will go to court today to back the vice-president's claim that Republicans tampered illegally with thousands of ballots in Florida's Seminole county.

Mr Jacobs is suing the elections supervisor, Sandra Goard, and calling for all 15,000 of the absentee ballots cast across the county to be thrown out. As George W Bush won the absentee vote in Seminole by a clear majority, the rejection of the ballots would overwhelm the Texas governor's 537-vote lead in Florida and hand Mr Gore victory in the state, and therefore the presidency.

Mr Bush's supporters have portrayed Mr Jacobs as a Democratic pawn who is simply doing the bidding of the Gore campaign, and Republican lawyers are due in court in Tallahassee today to try to have his case thrown out as without merit, before a full hearing tomorrow.

Mr Jacobs insists that he is acting out of outrage after overhearing a remark by a Seminole county election official. The official said the local Republican elections supervisor had allowed Republican officials to fill in voter identification numbers on incomplete absentee ballot forms being sent out to their supporters.

Republicans say the controversy has been confected from a simple printing error. Before the elections, both parties send absentee ballot applications to their supporters living abroad or out of their home state. More than 2,000 Republican forms, however, came out of the printer without the any voter identification number.

In response to a Republican request to have the forms completed, Ms Goard allowed two party workers to fill in the missing numbers in her office.

Local Democrats are suing Martin county, just north of Miami, where another Republican elections supervisor, Peggy Robbins, allowed Republican officials to remove faulty ballot application forms from her office, fill in missing information and return them to her a few days later. That case is also due to be heard in Tallahassee tomorrow.

The Gore campaign has distanced itself from the Jacobs case, almost certainly because, if successful, it would lead to the invalidation of absentee votes from members of the armed services posted abroad, a controversial move. But the case may prove to be the vice-president's last hope if he loses his formal contest of the Florida election result.

Republican officials point to the fact that Mr Jacobs has contributed to the Gore campaign and that he has admitted that he had sought advice about his lawsuit from a colleague, Mitchell Berger, who is also a Gore fundraiser in Florida. The conversation, Republicans argue, proves Mr Jacobs is surreptitiously taking instructions from the Gore campaign.

Mr Jacobs' lawyer, Gerald Richman, rejected the claims. "They're absolutely, totally false," Mr Richman said yesterday. "He just called a lawyer he knew to seek advice. The Republicans just want to avoid the merits of the case."

Lawyers for the Bush campaign have tried to oblige Mr Gore to appear as a witness. They have also called on the judge hearing the case, Nikki Clark, to withdraw, on the grounds that she has a vested interest. She was recently overlooked by Florida's governor, Jeb Bush (George W's brother) for a job in the state appellate court.
