Mr Jacobs insists that he is acting out of outrage after overhearing a remark by a Seminole county election official. The official said the local Republican elections supervisor had allowed Republican officials to fill in voter identification numbers on incomplete absentee ballot forms being sent out to their supporters. Republicans say the controversy has been confected from a simple printing error. Before the elections, both parties send absentee ballot applications to their supporters living abroad or out of their home state. More than 2,000 Republican forms, however, came out of the printer without the any voter identification number. In response to a Republican request to have the forms completed, Ms Goard allowed two party workers to fill in the missing numbers in her office. Local Democrats are suing Martin county, just north of Miami, where another Republican elections supervisor, Peggy Robbins, allowed Republican officials to remove faulty ballot application forms from her office, fill in missing information and return them to her a few days later. That case is also due to be heard in Tallahassee tomorrow. The Gore campaign has distanced itself from the Jacobs case, almost certainly because, if successful, it would lead to the invalidation of absentee votes from members of the armed services posted abroad, a controversial move. But the case may prove to be the vice-president's last hope if he loses his formal contest of the Florida election result. Republican officials point to the fact that Mr Jacobs has contributed to the Gore campaign and that he has admitted that he had sought advice about his lawsuit from a colleague, Mitchell Berger, who is also a Gore fundraiser in Florida. The conversation, Republicans argue, proves Mr Jacobs is surreptitiously taking instructions from the Gore campaign. Mr Jacobs' lawyer, Gerald Richman, rejected the claims. "They're absolutely, totally false," Mr Richman said yesterday. "He just called a lawyer he knew to seek advice. The Republicans just want to avoid the merits of the case." Lawyers for the Bush campaign have tried to oblige Mr Gore to appear as a witness. They have also called on the judge hearing the case, Nikki Clark, to withdraw, on the grounds that she has a vested interest. She was recently overlooked by Florida's governor, Jeb Bush (George W's brother) for a job in the state appellate court.

webTitle: Mandelson a disaster says Sinn Fein

fields.headline: Mandelson a disaster says Sinn Fein
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's education minister, yesterday launched a scathing attack on Peter Mandelson, describing him as a "peace wrecker" who was ill-equipped to resolve the deadlock in the peace process.
fields.body:
Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's education minister, yesterday launched a scathing attack on Peter Mandelson, describing him as a "peace wrecker" who was ill-equipped to resolve the deadlock in the peace process.

In his most outspoken attack on the Blair government, Mr McGuinness denounced the Northern Ireland secretary as a "political disaster" who had spent his time in Belfast courting unionism.

Speaking in Australia, Mr McGuinness said: "We have a peace wrecker rather than a peace maker. If the present crisis is to be resolved I very much doubt whether Peter Mandelson has the integrity to recognise this, much less acknowledge it. In short [he] is a political disaster."

Mr McGuinness rounded on Mr Mandelson for watering down the Patten report on policing and for failing to reduce security measures in Northern Ireland. His remarks underlined the tensions between republicans and the government which were exacerbated in October when David Trimble imposed a ban on Sinn Fein attending meetings of a special cross-border ministerial council.

Although Mr Mandelson criticised Mr Trimble's action, Sinn Fein is angry with the government for stepping up pressure on the IRA to negotiate with the international disarmament body. Sinn Fein says it is wrong to demand that the IRA should "engage" with the commission when the government has allegedly failed to live up to its commitments to scale down security measures, particularly in border areas.

Sinn Fein is also threatening to boycott the new police board unless the government introduces fundamental concessions in a special plan which will implement the Police Act. Sinn Fein wants a commitment that the police board will have greater independence and an assurance that Chris Patten's recommendation for a neutral badge will be implemented. Mr Mandelson will rule on the badge if the police board cannot reach agreement.

The government yesterday dismissed Mr McGuinness's criticism. A Northern Ireland Office spokesman said: "Since Peter Mandelson came to Northern Ireland we have achieved devolution and the power-sharing executive."

One source suggested that Mr McGuinness's remarks demonstrated Sinn Fein's frustration after Mr Patten called on nationalists to end their campaign against the Police Act and to join the new force.

There are signs the SDLP might heed Mr Patten's advice and take its three seats on the police board. Tony Blair is said to have held a productive meeting last week with Seamus Mallon, the party's deputy leader, who outlined a seven-point plan which would allow the SDLP to join the board.

His demands included independent judicial reviews into the controversial killings of three Roman Catholics, including that of the Belfast solicitor Pat Finucane, and a commitment to implement the Patten recommendations on merging the RUC's anti-terrorist special branch with its CID division.

A government source said ministers were relaxed about Mr Mallon's demands. It is understood Mr Mallon was told the government would keep open the option of judicial inquiries into the killings once a series of investigations had been completed. Sir Ronnie Flanagan, the RUC chief constable, is also expected to outline a timetable for the merging of special branch and CID within the next few weeks.

The political atmosphere in Northern Ireland is intensifying ahead of next week's visit to the province by President Clinton. There are hopes that the SDLP will make a decision on taking its seats on the police board to coincide with the president's visit.

The row between Sinn Fein and the government came as John Hume, the leader of the SDLP, formally resigned his seat in the Northern Ireland assembly yesterday. His decision, announced in August, will allow him to concentrate on his work as MP for Foyle and as an MEP .

fields.headline: Publishing's dirty secrets
fields.trailText: Small publishers do not come much smaller than us (four local-interest titles, one-man company). We do not aim to get rich from Waterstone's, but have supplied books when they order from us (Bookshop discounts 'threat to publishing', December 2).
fields.body:
Small publishers do not come much smaller than us (four local-interest titles, one-man company). We do not aim to get rich from Waterstone's, but have supplied books when they order from us (Bookshop discounts 'threat to publishing', December 2). The first invoice went unpaid for over a year, despite reminders and phone calls. We sued through the small claims court and they paid immediately plus costs.

Our second order is now coming up to 12 months overdue and we are about to sue again. Waterstone's sponsor the Essex Book Awards for which one of our books was short-listed. We didn't win but enjoyed a good awards ceremony: especially the bit where the Waterstone's representative had to tell the prize-winner he had been unable to get a cheque to pay the £200 prize. It seems Waterstone's want 100% not just 50% from really small publishers.
David Corke
Lopinga Books Lopinga@aol.com

 The news that 635 publishers are demanding an inquiry into Waterstone's request for improved terms may cause amusement among booksellers, but the publishers concerned should be ashamed. The UK publishing industry is chronically resentful of being required to function by the rules of the market. Booksellers, whom nobody proposes to subsidise, cannot afford such scruples.

The real threat to publishing comes from publishers themselves. There are too many of them. Some are so amateurish in the conduct of their business, that they appear to have contempt for everyone else in the supply chain, not excepting the customer. Yet in their naked greed they persist in throwing new titles of dubious quality at an oversaturated market like mud at a wall.

As a former Waterstone's bookseller, I remember struggling to extract single copies of a book from publishers who routinely lost or misdirected orders, and were unable to process an order within 28 days. If the book arrived, it would often be found to bear a "single copy surcharge", which obliterated the bookseller's margin.

David Kneale's real crime lies in exposing to public scrutiny one of publishing's dirty secrets: that incompetent publishers have long relied on the buffer of unrealistically large subscription orders and a slow and complex returns procedure to disguise low sales. No wonder the industry objected when BookTrack began to release accurate weekly sales figures to the media. Compared with publishing, bookselling is a model of transparency.
Paul Bowes
Llandinam, Powys PBowes9116@aol.com

 You recently mentioned Borders bookshop and its US owner's attempts to discourage its workers from joining or forming trade union branches (Working lives, November 1). Why then, are the Guardian and the Observer including Borders' publicity material and competition offers in its recent editions?
S Hawkesworth
Lancaster

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In yesterday's front-page report, Rural group gives in on fox-hunting, Richard Burge, the chief executive of the Countryside Alliance, became Sturge at several points in the article. The deputy chief executive of the organisation is Alex (not Alan) Armstrong. Apologies.
fields.body:
In yesterday's front-page report, Rural group gives in on fox-hunting, Richard Burge, the chief executive of the Countryside Alliance, became Sturge at several points in the article. The deputy chief executive of the organisation is Alex (not Alan) Armstrong. Apologies.

Sylvia Ayling, who contributed a note about Caroline Benn, page 24 (Obituaries), November 29, points out that the memorial plaque unveiled by Ms Benn did not commemorate Keir Hardie. It remembered the East London Federation of Suffragettes.

Contrary to what we said in an article headed Berlin's chips off the old bloc, page 7, Sport, December 2, Hansa Rostock is not the only football team from the former GDR in the Bundesliga. Energie Cottbus is in the Bundesliga too.

In a review of Robert Skidelsky's biography of John Maynard Keynes, page 9, Saturday Review (Books), December 2, we appeared to attribute to Jeremy Bentham the description of economics as "the dismal science". It was, in fact, Thomas Carlyle who applied the term (Latter-Day Pamphlets, 1850). Source: The Oxford Dictionary of Quotations.

Homophone corner, from the Notebook (Finance), page 31, December 2: "...the boardroom in Railtrack's Euston bunker must have echoed with cries of 'here, here' in response to [her] accusation".

webTitle: Letter: Our fox is not shot

fields.headline: Our fox is not shot
fields.trailText: I am a Labour party member with a lifelong involvement in Labour and trade union politics, as well as a former master of fox-hounds and a present board member of the Countryside Alliance. Moreover, unlike your correspondent, I was one of those who actually took part in last week's small, private dinner between the alliance and eight Labour MPs, which you misrepresented so badly in your front-page article (Rural group gives in on fox-hunting, December 4).
fields.body:
I am a Labour party member with a lifelong involvement in Labour and trade union politics, as well as a former master of fox-hounds and a present board member of the Countryside Alliance. Moreover, unlike your correspondent, I was one of those who actually took part in last week's small, private dinner between the alliance and eight Labour MPs, which you misrepresented so badly in your front-page article (Rural group gives in on fox-hunting, December 4). I can authoritatively refute the article's preposterous assertion that the alliance might "roll over" on hunting in return for government concessions on rural policy.

Our discussions hardly touched on hunting - not surprisingly since the purpose of the dinner was to discuss the rural white paper. Moreover our robust, non-negotiable position on hunting is well-known to Labour MPs. However, at this dinner we made clear two points: first, that our fight against the imposition of a hunting ban would continue via all legal means, including, if necessary, an appeal under human rights legislation; and second, that we would continue to fight strictly within the law.

This avowal has been sadly twisted in your piece - whether unintentionally or through some malign intent we leave your readers to conclude. But it is strange that in writing this piece your correspondent did not attempt to contact any of us present for the alliance at the meeting to ask what we actually said.
Maurice Askew
Countryside Alliance

fields.headline: Rewriting the script (again)
fields.trailText: Lord Harris says the Liberal Democrat peers' deal with the government on the freedom of information bill was justified because the Conservatives would not have stood firm in pressing more fundamental amendments (Letters, December 2).
fields.body:
Lord Harris says the Liberal Democrat peers' deal with the government on the freedom of information bill was justified because the Conservatives would not have stood firm in pressing more fundamental amendments (Letters, December 2). He cites their decision to abandon efforts to block air traffic privatisation as evidence of Tory unreliability.

But Tory peers supported Lib Dem and Labour rebels in forcing government concessions to protect the pension fund of air traffic staff from being raided by future owners - a significant improvement.

The government was on the point of being defeated on the FoI bill by a similar coalition. This would have led to more substantial concessions than the amendments obtained under the Lib Dem deal.

Even the home office minister, Mike O'Brien, agreed these were not as decisive as Lib Dem peers have claimed. As he told MPs on November 27, the peers "may well have felt a need to overstate their case a little in order to justify what they had decided to do".
Maurice Frankel
Campaign for Freedom of Information

 What a boost to the technology revolution the new databank proposals are likely to be (Spies seek access, December 4). How many, like me, are contemplating abandoning email, making only minimal use of the telephone and reverting to the ancient art of letter-writing? That way, at least, some poor human will have to wade through the script to extract information.
VC Tomkinson
Ringmer, E Sussex

webTitle: The end of the digital dream?

fields.headline: Waiting for the revolution
fields.standfirst:
The net was going to change our lives for ever. Books, films, shopping - everything would 'go virtual'. But first dot.com firms started falling like flies, and now there are reports of millions of disillusioned users logging off. So, asks Oliver Burkeman , is it the end of the digital dream?

Net news
fields.trailText: The net was going to change our lives for ever. Books, films, shopping - everything would 'go virtual'. But first dot.com firms started falling like flies, and now there are reports of millions of disillusioned users logging off.
fields.body:
Sober nations have all at once become desperate gamblers, and risked almost their existence upon the turn of a piece of paper," wrote the journalist Charles MacKay in his book Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds. "Men, it has been well said, think in herds; it will be seen that they go mad in herds, while they only recover their senses slowly, and one by one."

The year was 1841, and the mass hysterias MacKay had in mind were the tulip-buying mania of 17th-century Antwerp and the frenzied buying of shares in the South Sea Company in 18th-century London. But, sipping a latte in one of Silicon Valley's numerous identikit coffee shops in recent years, listening to the talk of business plans drawn up and deals done, of millions of dollars poured into businesses with no particular plans to turn a profit any time soon, he might have made similar observations. And we may be about to recover our senses sooner than we thought.

According to a new survey, once-enthusiastic internet users are logging off in droves: 28 million people in the United States, and perhaps two million in the UK, now fall into the category of "former internet users". Even worse, it is teenagers - the very age group on whom the future of the medium supposedly depends - who are disconnecting in the greatest numbers. "They were energised by what you can do on the net," said Professor Steve Woolgar of the Virtual Society? research programme, which carried out the survey with sponsorship from the Economic and Social Research Council, "but they have been through all that and realised there is more to life in the real world."

If Woolgar is to be believed, we really do want books with spines that crack; movies in popcorn-strewn cinemas; sex with real people. Add to that the recent string of downbeat dispatches from cyberspace - from the collapse of Boo.com and Clickmango to the commercial failure of Stephen King's online novel The Plant to the plunge in tech shares on the world's stock markets - and pessimistic minds begin to see a pattern emerging.

"There's a genuine belief that this technology is transformative for the better," says Sally Wyatt, another researcher on the Virtual Society? project, "but the evidence is really pretty slim. History is littered with technologies which promised radical change and it didn't happen."

The internet boom is not tulipomania: it has already wrought far too much social change for that. But it might, Wyatt speculates, end up looking in hindsight a lot like CB radio: initially a cult among specialists; a sudden, skyrocketing surge in popularity, and then, well . . . not much, really. Mentioning one's email address at the better sort of party, it seems, might one day be as déclassé as loudly informing the assembled gathering of one's CB call sign.

Like any technological revolution - farming or factories, trains or televisions - the internet has long attracted its fair share of evangelists, and at first we believed them. "The first wave of hype was: everything is going virtual," says the US media critic and author Jon Katz. "Everything - all movies, all books - would go online. It was a classic moral panic, a hysteria." But then, in 1995, two Americans, James Katz and Philip Aspden, noticed something strange. The two academics had been preparing a survey on internet use. They only included the category of "former internet user" for conceptual clarity: logically, such a being could exist, but they didn't expect that any actually would. And so they were taken aback when their survey revealed that 8% of their sample had peered into the infinite depths of cyberspace - and decided they didn't like what they saw.

What is it that these early rejecters - and the many more identified in the Virtual Society? survey - didn't like? One seductive argument is the ubiquitous claim that the internet just isn't human, that it isn't part of Woolgar's "real world" - that we simply won't be "fooled" by a virtual, and therefore somehow inferior, version of life. But the explanations often turn out to be rather different.

For one thing, researchers report, it's expensive: there are pieces of hardware to buy, internet service providers to subscribe to, telephone bills to pay - and then more, better hardware to buy, and so on. (Most free providers still can't match the level of service of the paid-for ones, and unmetered access, finally on the horizon, still costs money.) More crucially, though, the promise that it would simplify our lives didn't seem anywhere close to being realised. The Virtual Society? researchers confirmed most office workers' suspicions with their finding that email is adding to, not solving, the problem of information overload. We fret over writing them, because we know they can be stored and used against us, and then we hold meetings to discuss those emails. "Email has increased, rather than reduced, the number of face-to-face meetings," write Dr Steven Brown and Dr Geoff Lightfoot in the report, "since meetings are now held to resolve disputes arising from electronic communication."

And above all the internet is simply too slow. Advances in technology had prompted vast increases in the amount and speed of information that could be transmitted on the net - but the volume of information has grown even faster: elaborate web pages, data-heavy movies and music. To disinter the oldest of internet metaphors, we kept adding new lanes to the information superhighway and - just as on the M25 - new cars arrived from nowhere.

"We're going through a healthy process of discovering that the internet is good for some things and bad for others," says Jon Katz. "There was too much money being thrown at too many companies for too many dubious reasons." But he doesn't share the doom-mongers' view that this means the cyber-revolution is drawing to a close. "People are confusing this new air of reality with the idea that the internet is over."

But something is changing. Deep beneath the highways and the seabeds of the industrialised world, telecommunications companies are laying thousands of miles of fibre-optic cables that will carry communications on the internet at the speed of light - and herald, so the enthusiasts say, an era that will reduce the net of the 1990s to a similar status to that held today by the ZX Spectrum and Betamax video recorder.

"We are now entering a new era," writes the breathless George Gilder, the leading prophet of this "bandwidth revolution", in his new book Telecosm. "A new form of PC will be dominant. It may not do Windows, but it will do doors. Tetherlessly transcending most of the limitations of the current PC era, the most com mon PC will be a digital cellular phone. And, oh yes, it will unlock your front door or car door, open your garage door, or even play Jim Morrison songs."

The instant, infinite internet - whose working title, among the techies currently beavering away on its more arcane elements, is the "evernet" - will eliminate many of the internet's biggest turn-offs at a stroke, rendering once-grainy movies at cinema quality and music to rival the sounds of a concert hall. Meanwhile, at the MIT Media Lab in Cambridge, Massachusetts, a new invention, "electronic paper", promises soon to remove the discomfort of reading books on a computer monitor.

"It's like Evel Knievel jumping the Grand Canyon," says Mike Butcher, news editor of the Industry Standard Europe, the new economy bible, demonstrating a panache for metaphor typical of those who struggle to communicate these changes to a lay audience that is enthusiastic but out of its depth. "There is a chasm between internet access now and access whenever you want it, wherever you want it: via your TV, your mobile phone. Right now, we're mid-jump."

You have to be young to understand this, Jon Katz argues - and he means young . "If you're not 13, it's almost impossible to keep up with the culture. The internet empowers and liberates young people by giving them access to so much information that it creates an enormous chasm between the young and the old," he says. "But just as it was a mistake to assume that the internet was ever going to change everything, it's a bigger mistake to conclude that it is ever going to go away."

In any case, "using the internet" is becoming an ever vaguer concept. Not only are we presented with the prospect of net connections in our fridges and earrings; we are already, even the greatest Luddites among us, using the internet at one remove when we do business with any of the thousands of major companies that deal with each other via electronic markets or organise their distribution and payments systems over the web. At least some of the teenagers who are logging off in their hordes are turning to text messaging on their mobile phones - a technology that doesn't currently use the internet but will soon, as fully internet-connected mobile phones come to market.

fields.bodyText: Sober nations have all at once become desperate gamblers, and risked almost their existence upon the turn of a piece of paper," wrote the journalist Charles MacKay in his book Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds. "Men, it has been well said, think in herds; it will be seen that they go mad in herds, while they only recover their senses slowly, and one by one." The year was 1841, and the mass hysterias MacKay had in mind were the tulip-buying mania of 17th-century Antwerp and the frenzied buying of shares in the South Sea Company in 18th-century London. But, sipping a latte in one of Silicon Valley's numerous identikit coffee shops in recent years, listening to the talk of business plans drawn up and deals done, of millions of dollars poured into businesses with no particular plans to turn a profit any time soon, he might have made similar observations. And we may be about to recover our senses sooner than we thought. According to a new survey, once-enthusiastic internet users are logging off in droves: 28 million people in the United States, and perhaps two million in the UK, now fall into the category of "former internet users". Even worse, it is teenagers - the very age group on whom the future of the medium supposedly depends - who are disconnecting in the greatest numbers. "They were energised by what you can do on the net," said Professor Steve Woolgar of the Virtual Society? research programme, which carried out the survey with sponsorship from the Economic and Social Research Council, "but they have been through all that and realised there is more to life in the real world." If Woolgar is to be believed, we really do want books with spines that crack; movies in popcorn-strewn cinemas; sex with real people. Add to that the recent string of downbeat dispatches from cyberspace - from the collapse of Boo.com and Clickmango to the commercial failure of Stephen King's online novel The Plant to the plunge in tech shares on the world's stock markets - and pessimistic minds begin to see a pattern emerging. "There's a genuine belief that this technology is transformative for the better," says Sally Wyatt, another researcher on the Virtual Society? project, "but the evidence is really pretty slim. History is littered with technologies which promised radical change and it didn't happen." The internet boom is not tulipomania: it has already wrought far too much social change for that. But it might, Wyatt speculates, end up looking in hindsight a lot like CB radio: initially a cult among specialists; a sudden, skyrocketing surge in popularity, and then, well . . . not much, really. Mentioning one's email address at the better sort of party, it seems, might one day be as déclassé as loudly informing the assembled gathering of one's CB call sign. Like any technological revolution - farming or factories, trains or televisions - the internet has long attracted its fair share of evangelists, and at first we believed them. "The first wave of hype was: everything is going virtual," says the US media critic and author Jon Katz. "Everything - all movies, all books - would go online. It was a classic moral panic, a hysteria." But then, in 1995, two Americans, James Katz and Philip Aspden, noticed something strange. The two academics had been preparing a survey on internet use. They only included the category of "former internet user" for conceptual clarity: logically, such a being could exist, but they didn't expect that any actually would. And so they were taken aback when their survey revealed that 8% of their sample had peered into the infinite depths of cyberspace - and decided they didn't like what they saw. What is it that these early rejecters - and the many more identified in the Virtual Society? survey - didn't like? One seductive argument is the ubiquitous claim that the internet just isn't human, that it isn't part of Woolgar's "real world" - that we simply won't be "fooled" by a virtual, and therefore somehow inferior, version of life. But the explanations often turn out to be rather different. For one thing, researchers report, it's expensive: there are pieces of hardware to buy, internet service providers to subscribe to, telephone bills to pay - and then more, better hardware to buy, and so on. (Most free providers still can't match the level of service of the paid-for ones, and unmetered access, finally on the horizon, still costs money.) More crucially, though, the promise that it would simplify our lives didn't seem anywhere close to being realised. The Virtual Society? researchers confirmed most office workers' suspicions with their finding that email is adding to, not solving, the problem of information overload. We fret over writing them, because we know they can be stored and used against us, and then we hold meetings to discuss those emails. "Email has increased, rather than reduced, the number of face-to-face meetings," write Dr Steven Brown and Dr Geoff Lightfoot in the report, "since meetings are now held to resolve disputes arising from electronic communication." And above all the internet is simply too slow. Advances in technology had prompted vast increases in the amount and speed of information that could be transmitted on the net - but the volume of information has grown even faster: elaborate web pages, data-heavy movies and music. To disinter the oldest of internet metaphors, we kept adding new lanes to the information superhighway and - just as on the M25 - new cars arrived from nowhere. "We're going through a healthy process of discovering that the internet is good for some things and bad for others," says Jon Katz. "There was too much money being thrown at too many companies for too many dubious reasons." But he doesn't share the doom-mongers' view that this means the cyber-revolution is drawing to a close. "People are confusing this new air of reality with the idea that the internet is over." But something is changing. Deep beneath the highways and the seabeds of the industrialised world, telecommunications companies are laying thousands of miles of fibre-optic cables that will carry communications on the internet at the speed of light - and herald, so the enthusiasts say, an era that will reduce the net of the 1990s to a similar status to that held today by the ZX Spectrum and Betamax video recorder. "We are now entering a new era," writes the breathless George Gilder, the leading prophet of this "bandwidth revolution", in his new book Telecosm. "A new form of PC will be dominant. It may not do Windows, but it will do doors. Tetherlessly transcending most of the limitations of the current PC era, the most com mon PC will be a digital cellular phone. And, oh yes, it will unlock your front door or car door, open your garage door, or even play Jim Morrison songs." The instant, infinite internet - whose working title, among the techies currently beavering away on its more arcane elements, is the "evernet" - will eliminate many of the internet's biggest turn-offs at a stroke, rendering once-grainy movies at cinema quality and music to rival the sounds of a concert hall. "There is a chasm between internet access now and access whenever you want it, wherever you want it: via your TV, your mobile phone. Right now, we're mid-jump." webTitle: Leader: South Africa's rulers face a voter revolt

fields.headline: Rainbow blues
fields.standfirst: South Africa's rulers face a voter revolt
fields.trailText: South Africa's 19m voters have an opportunity today to give the ruling African National Congress a well-deserved kick up the backside. It is to be hoped that they will do so. On the issues that most concern voters - unemployment (30%), record crime, housing, education, the HIV-Aids epidemic, endemic corruption - the ANC's record is at best uneven, at worst deeply unimpressive.
fields.body:
South Africa's 19m voters have an opportunity today to give the ruling African National Congress a well-deserved kick up the backside. It is to be hoped that they will do so. On the issues that most concern voters - unemployment (30%), record crime, housing, education, the HIV-Aids epidemic, endemic corruption - the ANC's record is at best uneven, at worst deeply unimpressive. It is simply not good enough to continue heaping all the blame on apartheid's legacy, as President Thabo Mbeki is wont to do, six years after white minority rule ended. There is an echo here of Robert Mugabe attempting to pin Zimbabwe's woes on Britain rather than his own misrule. It is disappointing, too, to hear Nelson Mandela, founding father of the Rainbow Nation, adopting the language of racial division in describing the opposition Democratic Alliance as a white people's party supported by "a few black stooges".

While the ANC's overall political dominance is not under threat, its evident alarm is well-founded. The DA is expected to increase its share of the vote in the nationwide municipal elections, especially in the big new metropolitan areas. Young black township voters, who have no memory of the apartheid struggle and who wonder why it is only now that the ANC is offering free electricity and water, may join with mixed-race and white voters in backing the opposition. ANC dissidents running as independents may also weaken the ruling party's grip.

Such developments would be welcome in terms of bridging the racial divide and maintaining a pluralist democracy. And they would serve as a timely reminder that all governments, whatever the past context, have a present-day duty to deliver. A low turnout may yet spare some ANC blushes. But for Mr Mbeki, whose personal ratings have plunged since he took office 18 months ago and whose performance on Aids and the Zimbabwe crisis has been particularly criticised, there is a message here: must do much better.

fields.headline: Roy Judge
fields.standfirst: Exposing the myths of morris dancing and Merrie England
fields.trailText: Roy Judge, who has died aged 71, did more than anyone else to demythologise the early days of the 20th-century folk revival and the origins of May Day folk customs.
fields.body:
Roy Judge, who has died aged 71, did more than anyone else to demythologise the early days of the 20th-century folk revival and the origins of May Day folk customs.

In a series of carefully researched studies, he examined such subjects as the work of Cecil Sharp, morris dancing in the theatre, Merrie England and maypole dancing. He overturned preconceptions, recognised the contribution of those who had been overlooked in previous histories, and examined the provenance of ancient folk customs.

Judge was born in Hastings, went to the local grammar school and read history at Oxford University between 1947 and 1950. After national service, he taught for 10 years at secondary schools in Peckham, south London, and Erith, in Kent, before becoming a lecturer in religious studies at Furzedown college of education.

By the mid-1970s, such colleges were seeking to expand their range of courses and, under the guise of pursuing research into social anthropology, Roy obtained a sabbatical to study folklore at the University of Leeds folklife studies institute.

His dissertation was published as The Jack-In-The-Green (1979), which set new standards of meticulous research in a discipline that has frequently attracted shoddy and fanciful scholarship (a second edition has recently been published). He then turned to Changing Attitudes To May Day: 1844- 1914, the title of his doctoral thesis. He took early retirement in 1980, and, significantly, much of his work was therefore completed purely for enjoyment rather than for career advancement.

Roy's interest in folklore was first stimulated by folk dancing as an undergraduate, when he took part in the May morning celebrations in Oxford. He later published his research into the origins of the singing on Magdalen College tower and the festivities below, commenting, in particular, on the Merrie England image as illustrated by the painting of the scene by Holman Hunt.

Merrie England became a recurrent theme in Roy's writing, and he used his first address as president of the Folklore Society in 1991 to illustrate its importance in the development of May Day customs. His other studies of May Day customs looked at the origins of plaited maypole dancing, May queens and the Helston furry dance. His dis coveries showed that many of the customs we regard as old are, in fact, quite modern, although often they had older, different forms. One of his papers contrasted the images of May Day in Tennyson's The May Queen and Flora Thompson's Lark Rise.

In 1959, Roy joined the London Pride Morris Men, and later the Ancient Men, comprising past and present members of the Oxford University morris team. Although fascinated by the south midlands, village-based morris dances of the rural working-classes that formed the basis for the 20th-century morris dance revival, Roy was also drawn to the other contexts for morris dancing in the 19th century, contexts which the folk revival preferred to ignore. These included morris dancing as part of the Merrie England movement, morris dancing on the stage and the pageants of showmen such as the pageant master, D'Arcy Ferris.

I n his studies of the early days of the folk-music revival, Roy examined the controversies that surrounded Cecil Sharp's work on folk dance, a topic that led him to a major re-assessment of the work of Mary Neal, an early colleague, and later critic, of Sharp. Always even-handed, Roy's study allowed both parties to emerge from the events with credit.

The study of the morris dances from Lichfield, Staff- ordshire, required even more sensitivity. There was no notation for these dances until they were sent (anony mously) in the 1950s to key folk dance enthusiasts, who performed them as genuine. It was often suspected that one of the enthusiasts had invented the dances, and passed them off as traditional - and Roy's research indicated this to be the case.

Although hesitant and cautious in conversation, he was a powerful speaker in public, with a dramatic presence and a strong sense of humour. He was always conscious of his readership, a mixture of academics and practitioners of folk music and dance, and he managed to present his arguments with academic rigour in an accessible style.

In addition to his presidency of the Folklore Society (1990-93), Roy also served as vice-president, and was awarded the society's Coote Lake research medal. He was an assistant editor of the English Folk Dance and Song Society's folk music journal, and a strong supporter of that society's Vaughan Williams memorial library, where much of his research took place.

Everyone who came in contact with Roy was touched by his generosity, humanity and ability to see good in everybody and everything. He was always willing to help younger researchers and was an inspiration to many.

He is survived by his wife Betty, daughter Elisabeth, and sons Peter and Derek.

 Roy Edmund Judge, folklorist, born July 24 1929; died November 17 2000

webTitle: Omagh bombing cited by agencies demanding access to all phone calls

fields.headline: Omagh bombing cited by agencies demanding access to all phone calls
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The security and intelligence agencies are using difficulties in pursuing the perpetrators of the Omagh bombing in August 1998 in their demand for access to records of every phone call made in Britain.
fields.body:
The security and intelligence agencies are using difficulties in pursuing the perpetrators of the Omagh bombing in August 1998 in their demand for access to records of every phone call made in Britain.

The full classified report written by Roger Gaspar, deputy director general of the national criminal intelligence service (NCIS), has been posted on the internet. It says the agencies should have the right to access all telephone calls, emails, and internet connections. Though individuals suspected of involvement in the Omagh bombing, which killed 29 people, have been named in the media, none has been charged.

"The only evidence currently available to link suspects is that provided by data from the use of their mobile phones," Mr Gaspar says. "This places them within the proximity of the incident."

He adds: "Recent advances in location-based customer services have reached the stage where more precise data can now pinpoint the whereabouts of the user of a mobile phone at a specific time. In the absence of any other evidence (particularly from witnesses who are likely to be intimidated) communications data will be the only means of securing a prosecution. Deletion of data would seriously damage the ability of the agencies to reactively investigate acts of terrorism."

Mr Gaspar, who says he wrote his report to the Home Office on behalf of MI5, MI6, GCHQ, and Customs, as well as the Association of Chief Police Officers, wants all communications service providers to retain their records for seven years. Some now delete their records after 24 hours.

"It is not just the current communications data that is needed," says Mr Gaspar. "Identification of users (particularly with anonymous pre-paid mobiles) is invariably dependent upon research through older data and analysis of links with other callers and locations. This kind of research is used so frequently that at least two major software programmes exist for the analysis of this data. All law enforcement agencies use these programmes."

In a revealing insight into the activities of the security and intelligence agencies, Mr Gaspar says it is difficult to overstate the value of communications data as an intelligence tool.

"The intelligence officer's toolbox of techniques comprise informants, eavesdropping, interception, observation, surveillance and analysis of latent data," he says. "Latent data is both open and closed source material which is created by our everyday human activity and can range from the Electoral Role [sic] and DVLA [the vehicle licence agency] to that retained in bespoke intelligence databases.

"Major criminal conspiracies," he adds, "utilise the same business techniques as legitimate business and consequently communications between criminal associates is a crucial component.

"Whereas the Kray brothers had to rely on a physical location to run and control their criminal structure... the more common structure of organised criminality today has far wider geography."

The proposals, which would require legislation, conflict with the right to privacy enshrined in the data protection and human rights acts, civil rights groups say.

"It is clear the police want the ability to track every citizen as they go about their business," said John Wadham, director of Liberty.

fields.headline: Bernard Vorhaus
fields.standfirst:
Film director who found refuge in Britain from America's anti-communist witch-hunt
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The New York-born film-maker Bernard Vorhaus, who has died aged 95, struggled in the 1930s and 1940s, often successfully, to elevate low-budget pictures with artistry, intelligence and human values. The handful of films he made in this country, rescued from obscurity after more than half a century, provide an unusually bright patch in British cinema of the period.
fields.body:
The New York-born film-maker Bernard Vorhaus, who has died aged 95, struggled in the 1930s and 1940s, often successfully, to elevate low-budget pictures with artistry, intelligence and human values. The handful of films he made in this country, rescued from obscurity after more than half a century, provide an unusually bright patch in British cinema of the period.

But in the United States, with his Welsh-born wife Esther (always known as Hetty), he became a target for the red-baiting witchhunts of the House UnAmer-ican Activities Committee (Huac). While Vorhaus was directing Pardon My French (1951) in France, the directors Edward Dmytryk and Frank Tuttle namedhim as a communist to Huac. Finding themselves also persona non grata in France and Italy - where Bernard had made Fanciulle di lusso (Luxury Girls, 1952) - Vorhaus and his wife settled in Britain.

The son of a lawyer, Vorhaus became hooked on films before the first world war, when, as a small boy, he would accompany his sister Amy, 12 years his senior and a script- writer, to the local film studios in Fort Lee, New Jersey. There, he picked up scraps of film to edit and show on his toy projector at home. After Harvard, he resisted pressure to join the family law firm, and, through connections with the mogul Harry Cohn, found work as a film writer.

His debut as director was an independently-produced, silent two-reeler, Sunlight (1928), which was a casualty of the talking picture revolution. Vorhaus consoled himself with a trip to Britain, and stayed. He found work making dirt-cheap "quota quickies", films churned out to take advantage of the quota imposed on cinemas in order to protect domestic production.

His luck was to find himself at Twickenham film studios, founded and run by the former actor Julius Hagen, who had the rare merit among British tycoons in that he loved movies (although he was as tough as the rest in his financial control). Vorhaus marvelled at the quality of the Twickenham technicians, dedicated to making the best films they could under the circumstances.

Good at spotting talent, he took on a young British Movietone newsreel cutter, David Lean, to work on two of his first British features. The best of his hour-long melodramas, thrillers and comedies - The Ghost Camera (1933), which debuted Ida Lupino, Crime On The Hill (1933), Dusty Ermine (1936), Cotton Queen (1937) - are distinguished by their intelligence, imagina tive camerawork and, whenever possible, use of locations rather than cramped studio sets. His most impressive work, The Last Journey (1936), is the story of a train driver who, in despair at losing his job and - he wrongly believes - his wife, recklessly drives the packed London-to-Manchester express with suicidal intent. It is exemplary in dramatic structure, suspense and characterisation.

Vorhaus had married Hetty, then working in a telephone exchange, in 1932. A gifted pianist and, later, portraitist, she was also a tireless campaigner for radical and humanitarian causes, from the 1926 general strike to Greenham Common in the 1980s. Her young husband wanted her "to learn about films so that we could share our life", and she rapidly became a talented film editor and dialogue director on his and other directors' films.

In 1937, Vorhaus accepted a Hollywood contract with Republic Pictures, whose chief, Herbert J Yates, was impressed by his ability to work within the low budgets that were the studio's speciality. Vorhaus's 16 Hollywood films are mostly forgotten, though they seem to have maintained much of the same qualities as his British films. He was often associated with leftwing writers, such as Samuel J Ornitz and Ring Lardner Jr, and gave his first Hollywood work to the Hungarian cinematographer John Alton, who went on to photograph An American In Paris and Teahouse Of The August Moon.

During the second world war, Vorhaus rose to the rank of major and worked for the US Army Air Force motion picture unit alongside the (then liberal) Ronald Reagan. fields.headline: Elma Mitchell
fields.standfirst: A poet linking the great and small issues of life
fields.trailText: The poet Elma Mitchell, who has died aged 81, first came to public attention in middle life, when her devastatingly original poem, Thoughts After Ruskin, appeared in the 1967 PEN anthology.
fields.body:
The poet Elma Mitchell, who has died aged 81, first came to public attention in middle life, when her devastatingly original poem, Thoughts After Ruskin, appeared in the 1967 PEN anthology.

Two years later, the same poem was included in a group submitted anonymously to the 1969 Camden festival poetry book prize under the title of Seasons And Enquiries. The judges - the then poet laureate Cecil Day Lewis, Edward Lucie-Smith and Anthony Thwaite - chose it as the winner.

The poem presents a quirkily original view of the nature of women, and, as in all Elma Mitchell's work, links the apparently trivial minutiae of domestic existence with the most urgent human concerns:

Women reminded him of lilies and roses.

Me they remind rather of blood and soap,

Armed with a warm rag, assaulting noses,

Ears, neck, mouth and all the secret places.

The poem goes on to detail "all the terrible chemistry of their kitchens" and a whole list of customary household activities, delivered with great gusto:

Their distant husbands lean across mahogany

And delicately manipulate the market,

While safe at home, the tender and the gentle

Are killing tiny mice, dead snap by the neck,

Asphyxiating flies, evicting spiders,

Scrubbing, scouring aloud, disturbing cupboards,

Committing things to dust- bins, twisting, wringing,

Wrists red and knuckles white and fingers puckered,

Pulpy, tepid.

The poem modulates to a deliberately ambivalent ending:

And when all's over, off with overalls,

Quickly consulting clocks, they go upstairs,

Sit and sigh a little, brush- ing hair,

And somehow find, in mir- rors, colours, odours,

Their essences of lilies and roses.

While this poem has been deservedly much anthologised, it has served to deflect attention from the quality of Mitchell's whole oeuvre of heart-rending, compassionate, compelling and rhythmically skilful verse.

Her first volume of poetry was The Poor Man In The Flesh (1976); the second was The Human Cage (1979). Both sold out, but the best poems from both collections, together with 18 new poems, are still available in People Etcetera: Poems New & Selected (1987). All were published by Peterloo Poets, as was a separate collection, Furnished Rooms (1983), with a splendid nude painting by Leonard McComb on the front cover.

It, too, is out of print, but several of the poems in this volume can be found in the revived Penguin Modern Poets series No 6, which Mitchell shared with UA Fanthorpe and Charles Causley.

Elma Mitchell was born in Airdrie, Lanarkshire. She won a scholarship to Somerville College, Oxford, where she took a first in English in 1941. She went on to take a diploma in librarianship at University College London, and spent her earlier working life as a librarian and information officer for the BBC (1941-43) and for the British Employers' Confederation.

Along the way, she became fluent in several languages, including Russian, and moved to the Somerset village of Buckland St Mary, where she worked as a freelance writer and translator from a thatched barn library and workplace that harboured an endangered spieces of bat.

Mitchell did not give many public readings, but when she did so the effect on her audiences was electrifying. In 1993, I chaperoned her at the splendid Aldeburgh poetry festival. She was then in failing health, though when she stepped onto the platform to read in her Airdrie accent she was like a tigress.

I remember, especially, her rendering of what, in essence, was a very clever woman's mission statement about how poetry may be produced by the intellect but only works by releasing the emotions. This Poem - in its entirety - goes:

This poem is dangerous: it should not be left

Within the reach of the children, or even by adults

Who might swallow it whole, with possibly

Undesirable side-effects. If you come across

An unattended, unident- ifiable poem

In a public place, do not attempt to tackle it

Yourself. Send (preferably in a sealed container)

To the nearest centre of learning, where it will be rendered

Harmless by experts. Even the simplest poem

May destroy your immunity to human emotions.

All poems must carry a government warning. Words

Can seriously affect your heart.

 Elma Mitchell, poet, born November 19 1919; died November 23 2000

fields.headline: Loopholes for torturers
fields.standfirst:
Pinochet has been indicted at last in Chile. But what about Britain's own new law against dictators?

Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: One hundred and fifteen nations have now committed themselves to establishing an international criminal court, and Britain has been a prime mover in a project which belatedly brings to fruition one of the chief original objectives of the UN: to provide effective machinery to outlaw war crimes and crimes against humanity.
fields.body:
One hundred and fifteen nations have now committed themselves to establishing an international criminal court, and Britain has been a prime mover in a project which belatedly brings to fruition one of the chief original objectives of the UN: to provide effective machinery to outlaw war crimes and crimes against humanity.

The new court will be based at the Hague and will extend worldwide the jurisdiction of the tribunals set up by the UN for Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia.

Each state party must ensure that its commitment is translated into its own domestic law and, following public consultation on a draft bill, the government will shortly introduce it in parliament.

Crimes against humanity are those which international law puts beyond the pale of legality wherever they are committed. In the context of a widespread or systematic attack on any civilian population, they include murder, torture, rape and enforced disappearance. The promoters of the new court, among whom Robin Cook has taken a leading role, are well aware that so huge a task cannot be performed by the court on its own. There are far too many cases.

Not only must the participating states assist and support the work of the court, they must also be prepared to put perpetrators on trial themselves. The preamble to the Rome statute of 1998, which established the court, reminds us that it is the duty of every state to exercise its jurisdiction over international crimes. The bill which the government proposes fails to carry out this duty. While it properly ensures that the crimes outlawed by the Rome statute are also crimes in UK law, it limits prosecutions in this country to crimes committed here and to crimes committed abroad by UK nationals.

Laws passed to comply with other international obligations, such as the United Nations convention against torture, are not limited in this way. General Pinochet could have been tried here for torture but under the bill a future Pinochet could not be tried for mass murder or enforced disappearance.

A Briton serving in Kosovo could be tried here for a war crime but not a Serb admitted as an asylum seeker. Should Britain be a haven for such people? If the risk of prosecution causes them to stay at home, then so much the better. We can surely do without the brutal dictators who come here to meet their friends and shop in Knightsbridge.

We played host for two years to Colonel Muvunyi, the Rwandan who was recently handed over to the war crimes tribunal in Tanzania on charges of killing thousands of his fellow citizens. Valentine Strasser, who led a military coup in Sierra Leone, may still be in Britain, after coming to this country to study at Warwick University.

A coalition of non-governmental organisations, supported by the eminent international lawyer Professor Sir Nigel Rodley, has been pressing the government to remove this anomaly. Peter Hain, the foreign office minister in charge of the bill, argues against trying foreigners for foreign crimes in Britain because the evidence is difficult to investigate.

Of course, without the evidence there can be no prosecution but that is no argument for excluding cases where the evidence is readily available. Sometimes, as in the case of Pinochet and in the case of Colonel Muvunyi, there is a positive avalanche of evidence, which the victims and their families could not be more eager to provide.

The Rome statute advances the principle of universal jurisdiction: there can be no hiding place for those who commit international crimes. But that must also mean that there are no exemptions or immunities. Again the government's bill falls short. The Rome statute applies to all per sons without distinction based on official capacity, but the British bill preserves all existing immunities.

Pinochet failed in his claim to immunity as a former head of state, for example, but he could have succeeded if he had still been president of Chile at the time of his arrest. Mass murderers entering Britain under cover of diplomatic status could also claim immunity.

We accepted the principle of universal jurisdiction in Rome. We cannot decently reject it at home. Fortunately, the government has time to reflect and put right these defects in a measure which otherwise calls for loud applause.

Geoffrey Bindman is a solicitor specialising in human rights

g.bindman@ucl.ac.uk

webTitle: Criminal past of man from paradise islands

fields.headline: Criminal past of man from paradise islands
fields.standfirst: Concerned government questions the character of Vanuatu's honorary consul in Britain after revelations about his history
fields.trailText: With a lovely home in London's West End, designer clothes and a portfolio of successful businesses, Peter Chen appears to be every inch the respectable entrepreneur.
fields.body:
With a lovely home in London's West End, designer clothes and a portfolio of successful businesses, Peter Chen appears to be every inch the respectable entrepreneur.

His appointment this year to the post of honorary consul in Britain for the republic of Vanuatu, a group of tropical islands proud to be known as the South Pacific's "premier tax haven", added to his prestige.

Visitors from the republic to Dr Chen's office in north London can relax on the sofas, sip tea and flick through magazines about their islands.

But life is not so easy for Vanuatu's man in London. Murky allegations about his past have surfaced, prompting the British government to demand that he be removed from his post.

Though the Foreign Office has denied that the episode will cause a diplomatic row, there is no doubt that it has the potential to dent relations with Vanuatu, which is growing in prominence because of its tax haven status and has military significance because of its position. It is also causing concern that officials did not discover Dr Chen's past until months after his appointment.

Dr Chen took up his posting in the spring. His CV is that of an upstanding businessman. Born in Hong Kong in 1951, he boasts degrees and a doctorate in social sciences, politics and law from various Far Eastern institutions. He claims a close involvement in charity work. He has founded an educational foundation to help Chinese students study abroad and takes an active interest in making sure impoverished citizens of Hong Kong can access proper medical care. In Britain he is a director of the UK Chinese Community Association.

Dr Chen, who is married with a son, has been involved in the running of profitable finance and property companies in Britain and in the Far East. The British end of his empire is run from bases on the Edgware Road in north London - now shared with his consulate - and in London's Chinatown. He forged links with the Vanuatu government through his timber concerns there.

His business interests in Vanuatu, which was governed jointly by the British and the French until its independence in 1980, led to his appointment as honorary consul earlier this year. The role does not entitle him to full diplomatic privileges but the Consular Relations Act does give certain rights not afforded to the ordinary citizen - for example, easier access to residents of the country represented.

But then the British government learned that Dr Chen's CV had not revealed his whole past. An inquiry was held and a Foreign Office spokesman confirmed it was no longer satisfied that Dr Chen fulfilled the "good character criteria" his posting required. The British government, the spokesman added, was "in discussions" with the Vanuatu government over Dr Chen and expected the matter to be resolved within the next few weeks. He said: "We would prefer it if the Vanuatu government took action but if it does not we will do so."

Sources say there are "serious" concerns about Dr Chen's criminal past. The inquiry into his activities centred on a criminal record outside Britain.

Before flying to the South Pacific last week, Dr Chen admitted he had a criminal record. He said he had been imprisoned while in his 20s in Hong Kong for handling stolen goods. Sources say that the inquiry into Dr Chen examined more recent alleged involvement in criminal activity.

Dr Chen said that he had studied in jail and went on to become a businessman. He claims that he visits China-town talking to youths to persuade them against joining gangs such as the triads. He denies any involvement with such organisations.

He said he had offered to resign but had been told by the Vanuatu government not to. Though the Vanuatu government has maintained a diplomatic silence, relations between it and Dr Chen seem to remain warm. In October Dr Chen was pictured in its Trading Post newspaper with prime minister Barak Tame Sope Maautamate Sope.

Claiming puzzlement at why his past has been raked up, Dr Chen said: "I became honorary consul to try to help Vanuatu. I do not get anything out of it. I have tried to make something of my life but what I did in the past has caught up with me."

Why the revelations have emerged is a puzzle, though some suggest that Dr Chen's position as an adviser to the Vanuatu government on relations with Taiwan might have attracted Chinese interest.

He said: "We would prefer it if the Vanuatu government took action but if it does not we will do so." Sources say there are "serious" concerns about Dr Chen's criminal past. The inquiry into his activities centred on a criminal record outside Britain. Before flying to the South Pacific last week, Dr Chen admitted he had a criminal record. He said he had been imprisoned while in his 20s in Hong Kong for handling stolen goods. Sources say that the inquiry into Dr Chen examined more recent alleged involvement in criminal activity. Dr Chen said that he had studied in jail and went on to become a businessman. He claims that he visits China-town talking to youths to persuade them against joining gangs such as the triads. He denies any involvement with such organisations. He said he had offered to resign but had been told by the Vanuatu government not to. Though the Vanuatu government has maintained a diplomatic silence, relations between it and Dr Chen seem to remain warm. In October Dr Chen was pictured in its Trading Post newspaper with prime minister Barak Tame Sope Maautamate Sope. Claiming puzzlement at why his past has been raked up, Dr Chen said: "I became honorary consul to try to help Vanuatu. I do not get anything out of it. I have tried to make something of my life but what I did in the past has caught up with me." Why the revelations have emerged is a puzzle, though some suggest that Dr Chen's position as an adviser to the Vanuatu government on relations with Taiwan might have attracted Chinese interest.

webTitle: Police question man over Lamplugh case

fields.headline: Police question man over Lamplugh case
fields.trailText: A 46-year-old man was brought to London last night to face questions over the disappearance of the estate agent Suzy Lamplugh 14 years ago.
fields.body:
A 46-year-old man was brought to London last night to face questions over the disappearance of the estate agent Suzy Lamplugh 14 years ago.

Scotland Yard said John Cannan had been detained at Full Sutton prison near York. Cannan was driven to a police station in London and could remain in custody until Friday.

He became a suspect when the Metropolitan police serious crime group reopened the investigation seven months ago following a case review.

Officers led by Detective Superintendent Shaun Sawyer re-interviewed witnesses and retired police officers.

Cannan has been questioned before about Miss Lamplugh, who has not been seen since she left her office to show a client, "Mr Kipper", a house in Fulham, west London. Cannan has always denied being involved.

Scotland Yard said the questioning of Cannan was an element of the fresh inquiry that could lead to him being eliminated as a suspect.

Miss Lamplugh's body has never been found, but detectives are planning "highly focused searches" in areas where it is thought she may have been buried. Specialists have already conducted initial examinations of potential sites. One is thought to be an army barracks in Norton, Worcestershire.

Miss Lamplugh, who was 25 when she vanished, was officially declared dead in 1994.

fields.headline: Pass notes
fields.standfirst: No: 1775 Tom Parker-Bowles
fields.trailText: Who he? You remember - the ruddy-faced one-time film industry PR and son of Camilla.
fields.body:
Who he? You remember - the ruddy-faced one-time film industry PR and son of Camilla.

Ah, yah! Bloody nice chap. Rah! Excuse me?

Rah! Rah! Oh, I see. The standard greeting of London's well-bred young gadabouts.

Yah. Rah! So, what's the blighter up to? He's launching Quintessentially, a "bespoke concierge service" for the creme de la creme of London society. If you're lucky to be granted membership, you call them and they'll find you anything from a plumber to "the best shirt-maker in Naples" .Tom's gone into the business with some chums including his cousin, the bar owner

Ben Elliott . . . Benjy-poos!

Lucia van der Post . . . Lucy doo-dahs!

Santa Sebag-Montefiore . . . Santy-pants!

And Annabel Heseltine. Bella-boo-boos!

Oh, rah, rah, rah! So, the object of the enterprise is to help all those who believe "life is too precious to bother with the mundane", the mundane presumably meaning anything beyond knocking back champers on yachts.

Steady on! Tom's only trying to make a new start after that hairy business with the you-know-what. Oh yes, last year's shocking confession that, as a member of the aristocracy involved in both public relations and the movie business, he had taken cocaine.

And now he just wants to do something worthwhile with his time. Nothing to get sniffy about. Sniffy?

You know what I mean. So, be a good chap and stop bringing up the Charlie Chan, OK? Fine. I'll just tell you about some more of Quintessentially's services: apparently, they can deliver you "something as simple as a bar of triple-milled soap . . . or as extravagant as a brand new Cessna airplane"

Beezer! I've been short of a Cessna ever since Tiggy downed the bugger over Mustique. You poor chap.

Don't say: You look just like your mum.

Do say : Rah! Rah! Rah, rah, rah!

webTitle: Kremlin's arms salesmen target US foes

fields.headline: Kremlin's arms salesmen target US foes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russia is trying to revive its declining arms industry and military sales by exploiting market openings among America's enemies as part of President Vladimir Putin's policy of pursuing a more assertive foreign policy and restoring a sense of power among his people.
fields.body:
Russia is trying to revive its declining arms industry and military sales by exploiting market openings among America's enemies as part of President Vladimir Putin's policy of pursuing a more assertive foreign policy and restoring a sense of power among his people.

In the past couple of weeks, senior officials have pledged to kickstart military cooperation with North Korea, and the defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, is expected to visit Tehran in the next few weeks - a move that could signal the ditching of a clandestine agreement with the White House to phase out arms supplies to Iran.

The Russians are shopping for military orders in Libya, Mr Putin is about to visit Cuba, and last week the Iraqi foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, made two visits to Moscow.

And despite US, British and French opposition, the Russians last week called for the end of a United Nations arms embargo on Yugoslavia.

But, according to Jane's Defence Weekly, Moscow's biggest arms customer to date is China, which will shell out up to $15bn (£10bn) in the next five years on Russian military equipment that could neutralise any US attempt to defend Taiwan.

Where Washington sees a rogue state, Moscow is increasingly seeing a market niche. "As far as public opinion is concerned, the west is no longer seen as a reliable partner," said Konstantin Kosachev, a former senior diplomat and deputy head of the parliamentary foreign affairs committee. "There's a big shift in foreign policy taking place. It's about looking after our own national and economic interests."

Iran is currently Russia's biggest bone of contention with the US. In the secret 1995 agreement, Moscow bowed to US pressure and assented to halting arms sales to Tehran by last year. It failed to redeem the pledge and now says it is no longer bound by the deal.

The armed forces newspaper, Krasnaya Zvezda, said that new contracts with Iran could be worth up to $8bn. This is probably an inflated estimate but indicates that the potential profits outweigh any possible penalties imposed by the Americans, who have the Iranian state blacklisted as a "sponsor of terrorism".

"The decision on Iran was taken a long time ago, last year during the Kosovo war," said Alexander Pikayev, a military analyst at Moscow's Carnegie Centre. "But it was not made public to avoid trouble."

Russian and American experts are to discuss the row this week, with the US state department's spokesman, Richard Boucher, warning: "We have made clear to the Russian government that there would be consequences if Moscow withdrew from such a commitment and that certain kinds of arms sales could lead to sanctions."

According to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (Sipri), Russia was a distant second to the US in the world arms sales league table last year, fuelling Russian complaints that the US consistently sought to keep Russia out of the arms market in the 90s.

While the jury is out on whether the once-mighty Russian arms sector will be able to deliver on its sales pitches, the president moved last month to streamline his arms sales department by sacking the managers of the two main export organisations, merging them into a single new agency and putting a former KGB colleague in charge.

"The US was supposed to compensate for our losses in halting sales to Iran by helping to promote Russian weaponry in other markets, including Nato countries," said Krasnaya Zvezda. "Not only did this not happen, but Washington tried to put spokes in the wheels anywhere Russia had a chance to do profitable deals."

Mr Kosachev said such behaviour was "the west's great strategic mistake. The western market was closed to Russian arms. The only markets left are where there is no serious western competition."

Under US pressure earlier this year, the Israelis retreated from a deal to supply China with sophisticated electronics for Russian-made A-50E planes. These are the Russian equivalent of the Awacs early warning aircraft.

Following a recent visit to Beijing by Mikhail Kasyanov, the prime minister, Moscow is now to provide the avionics as well as the planes. China has ordered four A-50Es at a cost of $800m.

The impact of projected Russian sales to China of submarines, fighter aircraft, naval missile systems and the A-50Es has the US, Japan, Taiwan and India worried that such armaments could secure mastery for Beijing of Taiwanese airspace and the waters of the Taiwan Straits.

Further signs of a resumption of the old superpower rivalries surfaced last week when the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe was unable to issue a declaration aimed at resolving the conflict in Chechnya after it was blocked by Igor Ivanov, the Russian foreign minister.

For the first time since the end of the cold war, meanwhile, the defence ministry sent five "Bear" strategic bombers on training exercises in the Arctic, where they are expected to probe US air defences. This type of plane has nuclear capability.

"Putin's power has been dependent on the military and security structures," said Mr Pikayev. "The arms trade is important to them. The military is gearing up for exports."

2 Russia $3,125m

3 France $1,701m

4 Germany $1,334m

5 Britain $1,078m

6 Italy $533m

7 Ukraine $429m

8 Australia $298m

9 Canada $168m

10 Sweden $157m

 Ranked by arms sales for 1999.

Source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (Sipri).

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Cheshire
fields.trailText: The dominant tree in the valley woodlands is the beech, its shallow roots thriving in fertile, humus-rich soils to produce many fine mature specimens. From May to late October every year each one is an expert at trapping all the available sunlight - its massive dome of leaves creates a thick canopy overhead and casts a dense shade below, stifling the growth of most other plants beneath it. The Victorian landowner of the estate solved this problem thanks to his lifelong hobby of cultivating rhododendrons.
fields.body:
The dominant tree in the valley woodlands is the beech, its shallow roots thriving in fertile, humus-rich soils to produce many fine mature specimens. From May to late October every year each one is an expert at trapping all the available sunlight - its massive dome of leaves creates a thick canopy overhead and casts a dense shade below, stifling the growth of most other plants beneath it. The Victorian landowner of the estate solved this problem thanks to his lifelong hobby of cultivating rhododendrons.

This evergreen shrub from Asia will adapt to all types of soils and situations, even the heavy shade of a beech wood, so now in areas of both the northern and western woods there are impenetrable layers of rhododendrons under the trees. Our Victorian landlord left a list of what he had planted, but unfortunately not where, so present-day attempts to identify the many cultivars have proved difficult.

Like many other estates in England of the same period, an assortment of exotic trees was also introduced, and none is more impressive here than the giant sequoia, or "wellingtonia". It grows on the edge of the western woods, and now that all the broad-leaved trees are mostly bare, its rufous bark shines like a beacon across the broad sloping pasture. The tree was unknown to Western naturalists until the early 19th century, when it was first seen by European eyes as a result of the 1849 California gold rush. It was introduced to England in 1857 on the Duke of Wellington's estate in Hampshire - hence "wellingtonia". Unfortunately, the "Iron Duke" had died five years earlier, so he never saw it.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: Have you ever been gripped by an overwhelming desire to express your disapproval in an arresting manner?
fields.body:
 Have you ever been gripped by an overwhelming desire to express your disapproval in an arresting manner? Have you ever felt that mere words fail you in their ability to convey the extent of your angst? You might be well served taking instruction from a group of women in Swaziland, who last week bared their buttocks in protest at the seizure of land by the king's brother. Following the eviction of more than 200 people from their land, 50 women removed their underwear and walked for three hours to protest outside the prince's new home.

 Not that our birling social whirl has been devoid of bum-baring recently. Last Thursday night saw Sidelines enjoying a Night of Sex as we graced the opening of the biggest ever Ann Summers store, in London's Oxford Street, then flounced on to the launch of Agent Provocateur's own label perfume (top notes: rose; dress: "provocative"). But our initial assumption that we would be venturing from the ridiculous to the sublime was not borne out. Ann Summers, while not entirely wholesome, was real in all its stretchy, rubbery, buzzy glory, and at least was talking about something men and women do to each other rather than at each other. The AP do was packed with alarming women, all corseted mini-waists, shelf-like bosoms and nobody-home eyes. Sidelines kept its jumper on (though you should have seen what we were wearing underneath). While visually exhausting, it had the sexual frisson of a badly-lit porn set and had a similarly emptying effect on the soul.

 Apparently we "missed Madonna". Which is a shame because obviously if we'd met up we'd have chat-chat-chatted and become really great pals immediately. Still, something cosmic must have happened, since Sidelines now appears to be inhabited by the spirit of Tara Palmer-Tomkinson.

 Finally, for those who consider open access to phone, email and internet links by the intelligence services insufficient intrusion, Labour may soon be counting your calories for you. The appointment of a national diet coordinator has been mooted in Scotland, following a recent study that found "astonishingly high levels of obesity" north of the border. Doesn't the government realise that it's cold up there? An extra layer of lard saves on woollens bills. And after the Fat Tsar, can we have a Tsars' Tsar to help us keep track?
