fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Apt Pupil / Blood Simple / Single White Female / Pi
fields.body:
Apt Pupil

(Bryan Singer, 1997)

10pm, Sky Premier

This adaptation of a Stephen King story by the director of The Usual Suspects and X-Men is a sobering portrayal of moral corruption and the lure of fascism. Brad Renfro plays the bright young Californian teenager who, obsessed by the Holocaust, encounters one of its perpetrators - Ian McKellen's Kurt Dussander. In exchange for not exposing him, the former SS man recounts the horrors of his past. The pair's twisted relationship makes for fascinating, but disturbing viewing.

Blood Simple

(Joel Coen, 1984)

10pm, FilmFour

A savage but worthy descendant of classic 40s film noir. The plot is a foul brew of lust, vengeance, greed and treachery, winding through a series of vicious twists with malignant humour, Barry (Men In Black) Sonnenfield's rich photography belying the paltry $1.5m budget. The cast has a ball too: Dan Hedaya the Texas bar owner reaping the whirlwind when he hires sleazy private eye M Emmett Walsh to murder his wife, Frances McDormand, and her lover, John Getz.

Single White Female

(Barbet Schroeder, 1992)

10.05pm, 3.25am, Sky Cinema

Bridget Fonda's Allie, who has just evicted her slimy philandering boyfriend, takes a flatmate. But compared to Jennifer Jason Leigh's lodger from hell he was a pussycat: "Allie's new roommate is about to borrow a few things without asking. Her clothes. Her boyfriend. Her life", went the blurb. A low-rent thriller that raises few shivers.

Pi

(Darren Aronofsky, 1997)

1.15am, FilmFour

In a strangely disturbing, black-and-white version of reality, Sean Gullette's wacky Max sits in his Chinatown apartment trying to unravel the mysteries of the universe - in the form of the mathematical formula that, he believes, governs the world stock market. Is he really a visionary embarked on a modern version of the alchemist's quest to turn base metal into gold?

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Solitude / File On 4
fields.body:
Father Michael Holleran, after 22 years in hermetic isolation as a Carthusian monk, decided that Solitude (11.0am, Radio 4) wasn't all it's cracked up to be. He now runs a parish church in Greenwich Village and tells Peter France that he found few happy or balanced people in his order (a judgment vigorously disputed by the abbot). Carraigh Thompson, on the other hand, revels in being solitary on the Greek island of Patmos. Two hours playing Bach's keyboard music gives him all the daily satisfaction he needs.

The increasing pressure on job applicants to allow prospective employers to check their past against police records gives Gerry Northam (pictured) pause in File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). He learns that various studies down the years have repeatedly shown criminal records to be seriously flawed. Some have listed a conviction where the defendant was, in reality, acquitted. Others have included raw police intelligence which has never been properly investigated or confirmed.

He now runs a parish church in Greenwich Village and tells Peter France that he found few happy or balanced people in his order (a judgment vigorously disputed by the abbot). Carraigh Thompson, on the other hand, revels in being solitary on the Greek island of Patmos. Two hours playing Bach's keyboard music gives him all the daily satisfaction he needs. The increasing pressure on job applicants to allow prospective employers to check their past against police records gives Gerry Northam (pictured) pause in File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). He learns that various studies down the years have repeatedly shown criminal records to be seriously flawed. Some have listed a conviction where the defendant was, in reality, acquitted. Others have included raw police intelligence which has never been properly investigated or confirmed.

fields.headline: Body count
fields.standfirst: The first exhibition in the revamped galleries of the British Museum brings together innumerable and beautiful images of humans from Congolese masks to Yemeni grave markers to Mayan maize gods. But why? Adrian Searle is nonplussed.
fields.trailText: The first exhibition in the revamped galleries of the British Museum brings together innumerable and beautiful images of humans from Congolese masks to Yemeni grave markers to Mayan maize gods.
fields.body:
The dust is settling in Norman Foster's new, glass-roofed Great Court at the British Museum, a space that, in life, looks even more like a computer simulation than computer simulations make it look. The great courtyard is difficult to take in. How many Tate Turbine Halls would fill it? Is its circumference greater than the London Eye? They could put Stonehenge in here, and half of Wiltshire with it.

Will it be possible, ever, to sit in the Reading Room, a book in your hand, lost in words? Or will you only ever be an actor here - less than an actor, an extra? I want to drag things back to human scale, to the whisper, to the enigma of its presence, the unfathomable confrontation with a singular object.

Human Image - the resonant title of the opening show at the museum's Joseph Hotung Great Court Gallery - is perhaps an attempt to bring us down to earth again, to reduce things to manageable proportions. The temporary exhibition gallery, reached via the broad stone stairs that curve around the cylinder containing the Reading Room, is a difficult arc of space. It also appears too small, a bit mean, for even the 100 objects and images from the museum's collection that make up the exhibition.

This show brings together a heterogeneous selection of major and minor things in an almost perverse display, even though every one is a representation of the human form. Banners hang from the ceiling, marking the zones of the exhibition: Creation, Devotion, Inscription, Perfection, Others, Power, Drapery, Guardians, Portraits, Abstraction. What a curious, meaningless list. Where does a Greek Nereid belong? This ruined, archaic sea-nymph is under the sign of Drapery, in front of a Matisse drawing, all charcoal flounces and flourishes. Nearby rests a carving by a 19th-century chief from the north-west coast of America, a dead shaman prepared for burial. No drapery here, but a carved corpse wearing a dead man's grin.

Things rear up at you, look down on you, are spied accidentally in the multiple reflections and refractions of the Perspex display cabinets. Anything can happen and frequently does. Here's a statue of Mrs Anne Seymour Damer, standing in for the muse of sculpture, brave soul, looking across at a great Ibibio figure from Nigeria, a huge man, body-painted and scarified, with filed teeth. She is all white neoclassical marble; he is a painted tree-trunk. The categories collapse, the banners fall. I cannot deal with this.

Each of these sections could be a show. The section called Others (with its Chinese madonnas, a Japanese Diogenes, a Roman oil lamp decorated with African heads) is a fascinating glimpse of how we view one another across cultures or invent versions of ourselves and others across time and space. A tattoed Pictish warrior, by 16th-century artist and traveller John White, conflates his encounters with native North Americans and a fantasy of a Scottish dark age. Like White, we are all a bit lost.

I could go on like this all day. It is so difficult to home in on the singular. It is impossible to see things as they are, for what they are. It is all surmise and conjecture. The exhibition raises big questions. Who are we? Where do we belong? Carping over categories is this year's game, whether it is at the British Museum, in the Hayward Gallery's Spectacular Bodies show, in the movement-mangling displays at Tate Modern and Tate Britain. Mistrust of fixed values, and of closed contexts have led us here. The question is, where are we going? Nobody knows. Might as well make it up as you go along.

A mass-produced porcelain figure of Chairman Mao, hand raised in salutation or blessing, stands in Portraits. Mao has become a kind of talisman, a sort of guardian of the home, office or car - a sort of Chinese St Christopher, then. Move him here, move him there, you can put the chairman anywhere. Here he is, near a beautiful drawing by Roger van der Weyden, and close to a Graeco-Roman-Egyptian encaustic portrait from a mummy's tomb. Surely, though, he's a guardian, or a votive presence. Hang it, you say to yourself, it doesn't matter. But maybe it does.

This exhibition has been curated by Jonathan King, an enthusiastic anthropologist at the Museum, made giddy by the chance to make wild juxtapositions. If we are all postmodernists, maybe we can all be curators, and if curators, why not artists? After all, Picasso didn't give a jot how early Iberian sculpture, a Congolese mask, a cardboard guitar and the head of an old man from a Pyrenean village might come together in his work. All became grist to his mill. But watching British Museum curators style-mixing and sampling is like watching your dad dance to hardcore.

The museum, a repository of stories as much as of objects, re-inters what it preserves. In the section called Abstraction, felt-penned walruses by a native Canadian called Penn rub shoulders with a Jacob Epstein drawing of so-called "Primitive Figures" with huge sex organs. Primitive, maybe; daft certainly. Hereabouts, too, a Yemeni grave marker, a simplified, honey-coloured alabaster head, which even the catalogue recognises as an attempt to "catch the essence of an individual, emphasising the salient features of the human face". The rubric Abstraction means little more than that these things look a bit like modern art.

I shuttle back and forth, making my own connections. But I know, too, that once the exhibition is open, sheer numbers of visitors are likely to defeat an attempt to play this game. And game it is, to reshuffle these poor objects again and again. I come away from The Human Image knowing that I have seen some great objects and images but unable to make any meaningful sense of their collisions. Look, I want to say, there are fabulous things here: an Alaskan wooden figure with fox's teeth; a Mayan maize god with a beautiful head; a real human skull, from Jericho, from the 8th millennium BC, a skull somehow re-animated with plaster, giving the form of flesh, with shells for eyes; a Gustave Courbet self-portrait- the young artist smug and sly and self-regarding; a tiny Egyptian ivory figure of a girl, with lapis lazuli eyes, her hands folded across her belly, pin-pricked nipples. How anyone can make any kind of sense at all of these conjunctions without losing their way is beyond me. Here are deities, jokes, ritual objects, symbols. We can only surmise their original meanings, the intentions of the hands that made them. All we know is that the human image endures, even in the museum, and that a thing no bigger than your fist can be as resonant and compelling as all that space, all that architecture. You can't avoid the categories, or all that historifying, and you might even get a hint of all the stories these objects have to tell if you resist the temptation to try to see too much.

 Human Image is at the Joseph Hotung Great Court Gallery at the British Museum, London WC1, until February 11. Box office: 020-7323 8599.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Two die in Ivory Coast protests
fields.body:
Two die in Ivory Coast protests

At least two people died during unrest in Ivory Coast's main city, Abidjan, as supporters of ex-prime minister Alassane Ouattara defied a ban to take to the streets yesterday.

The interior minister, Emile Boga Doudou, told state television that two Ouattara supporters had been killed in the protests .

Protesters, angry at Mr Ouattara's exclusion from an election on Sunday on nationality grounds, paralysed the city, building barricades of burning tyres and stopping people going to work.
Reuters, Abidjan

Moscow seeks tycoon's arrest

Russia has asked Interpol to put the media magnate Vladimir Gusinksy on an international wanted list on fraud charges.

Mr Gusinsky, who called the charges an attempt to put political pressure on the media, is accused of having misrepresented assets in the Media-Most group when he accepted loans of more than £200m.

A spokesman said Mr Gusinsky was dividing his time between Israel, Britain, Gibraltar and Spain.
Amelia Gentleman, Moscow

Three killed in Kashmir

Three people died in attacks in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir yesterday, police said.

The violence came as the prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, said India's ceasefire in Kashmir could continue after Ramadan if Pakistan created the right conditions, the Press Trust of India reported.

An Indian army convoy hit a landmine laid by separatists in Baramula, killing two people. And police said a militant died when a suicide squad stormed a security camp in Anantnag district.
Reuters, Srinagar

10,000 flee Congo fighting

Fighting in southern Congo has driven more than 10,000 refugees into Zambia in less than two days, a UN official said yesterday.

The refugees were fleeing a battle between government troops and rebels for Pweto town, said Martin Bucumi, of the UN high commissioner for refugees in Lusaka.
AP, Nairobi

fields.headline: Why snobs can keep their dreaming spires
fields.standfirst:
On the Oxbridge myth

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A rich father wants his son to go to Oxford. No surprise there. Except that the son apparently is not quite qualified enough to get in on his own merits and daddy, who is used to getting just what he wants (even though some claim that he is now down to his last £10bn), is keen to secure the coveted place by using his contacts.
fields.body:
A rich father wants his son to go to Oxford. No surprise there. Except that the son apparently is not quite qualified enough to get in on his own merits and daddy, who is used to getting just what he wants (even though some claim that he is now down to his last £10bn), is keen to secure the coveted place by using his contacts.

This, surely, is exactly the problem with both Oxford and Cambridge Universities. Whether it is relevant that the father in question is the Sultan of Brunei (once the richest man in the world but now, tragically, down to third) or not, the oddly familiar scenario does make you wonder. Why is it that the sultan wants his offspring to go to Oxbridge at all? Especially if he is going to struggle academically.

Magdalen college, which has had its fair share of publicity this year, is the place fortunate enough to have been chosen by the sultan as fitting the bill for his son, Prince Azim.

Magdalen, of course, is the college that turned down Laura Spence (the middle-class girl held up to epitomise the working-class struggle to break the Oxbridge elite, who had the foresight to apply to Harvard just in case). Which makes the story even juicier. But perhaps it is time to move away from the issue of elitism and query why everyone is so keen to go to Oxbridge in the first place.

The prime minister and his opposite number were both educated at Oxbridge. Although there may be fewer of these people in government than in the past, Oxford and Cambridge continue to revel in their traditional role as the only places to educate the elite (that is, the intellectual rather than moneyed elite, although there has been rather a crossover). In the past, the two universities were undeniably head and shoulders above the opposition. But that is no longer true.

During the Laura Spence saga, I longed to ask her why she had wanted to study medicine at Oxford. My curiosity increased when, after telling the world that she was desperate to be a doctor, Laura chose instead to take a Harvard scholarship to study biochemistry.

The reason, I am pretty sure, is that Miss Spence is a bit of a snob herself. After all, if you are looking for a university with cachet and Oxford won't take you, Harvard is clearly a delightful option. Far better, if that is what you are after, than other British medical schools. Even though, as the recent teaching assessments for medicine show, Oxford comes below Manchester, Liverpool, Newcastle, Southampton, Leicester and St George's, to name just a few.

Now they have become paying consumers, surely A-level students should look harder at which universities offer the best teaching when they apply. It is fine to consider whether a location offers a good nightlife, is far away enough from home and is not too expensive. But it isn't - or shouldn't be - fine to apply to a university because it has a good "name" or for its historical legacy.

When I was at school, "bright" students were encouraged to apply to Oxbridge as a matter of course. It didn't matter if Imperial College was better for science, the LSE for economics or Bristol for history; Oxbridge was what counted. And that was before league tables.

My school wasn't alone. Across the country, children grow up with the idea that, when it comes to higher education, Oxbridge is the pinnacle. True, they may also think that it is for an elite, for people such as young Freddie Windsor (currently studying at - where else? - Magdalen college, Oxford), or those who dream of punting along rivers and going to May balls. They may decide it is not for them, that they would have more fun in a bigger city or in a more modern setting. But it would be a rare pupil who would dismiss these two universities on the basis of their teaching.

The Sultan of Brunei may be doing us all a favour. It is time to start a debate that is not just about why certain students from certain types of school proliferate at Oxford and Cambridge.

Let's forget about trying to "open up" the colleges to people from different backgrounds. If one of the richest men in the world wants to send his son to Oxford, fine. Leave our oldest universities to those who care about snob value. Students should apply to the best university they can for what they want to study.

Oxford and Cambridge - which are better funded than all our other universities - should offer the best courses in every subject or lose their exalted position in our national psyche.

fields.headline: Another fine mess . . .
fields.standfirst: It's almost a year since the South Bank Centre's grand masterplan was unveiled. So why does no one seem to be doing anything? Stephen Moss finds out.
fields.trailText: It's almost a year since the South Bank Centre's grand masterplan was unveiled. So why does no one seem to be doing anything? Stephen Moss finds out.
fields.body:
Karsten Witt, chief executive of London's South Bank Centre, has done it. He has negotiated the hurdles of Britain's complicated planning regulations and seen his building plan through to fruition. After 18 months living out of a suitcase, he has completed his new flat in Spitalfields. Now all that remains is to do the same thing on the South Bank, the largest dedicated arts space in Europe, where for the best part of a decade, arguments have raged over its reconstruction.

But can he do it in time? The former president of Deutsche Grammophon has been in the job for less than two years, but already the vultures are circling. Chief vulture Norman Lebrecht has pronounced the South Bank a disaster: the Royal Festival Hall is seedy, and the proposed medium-sized concert hall an economic non-starter. "It seems almost unimaginable that stagnancy still prevails at our premier arts centre," the author and critic thundered recently in the Daily Telegraph.

Despite cosmetic improvements in recent months, the South Bank does, indeed, remain a tip. The car parks are pot-holed; the empty spaces beneath the Queen Elizabeth Hall are still colonised by skateboarders; Hungerford Bridge retains its post-apocalyptic look; the National Film Theatre is outmoded; the Museum of the Moving Image is still awaiting reconstruction; the Festival Hall has been condemned by performers and audiences; the Hayward Gallery is as hard to locate as ever.

It's a mess, and the South Bank Centre's board admits as much. In February it unveiled a complete remodelling by "masterplanner" Rick Mather. We just had to be patient. Patience, however, is running thin.

Over the past year, the management has been consumed by a vast consultation exercise. Mather's scheme has been fleshed out, and the South Bank is now willing to give a timetable for rebuilding. But there remain two great bugbears - planning consent and money - that could scupper the whole scheme.

It had been predicted that the Festival Hall, which is to have a £50m overhaul, would close for refurbishment in 2002/3. The resident orchestras, the London Philharmonic and the Philharmonia, had assumed they would be homeless for that period and made alternative arrangements, but they have now been told there will be no closure until 2005/6 at the earliest. Much of the work needed to improve the hall's acoustics will be delayed until then.

Critics say the delay in refurbishing the Festival Hall is at best an embarrassment. The management has admitted that the acoustic is unsatisfactory (Simon Rattle said playing there sapped his will to live), yet now audiences are stuck with it for at least another five years.

Witt is putting a brave face on the delay. He says he never publicly committed himself to closing in 2002/3 and that phasing the changes will be less disruptive. "Instead of rushing into a closure period, which would have the advantage that we could do everything at the same time, we will take an incremental approach, which will allow us to be more flexible," he says. "But that doesn't mean we will postpone everything. My hope is that at the end we will need a shorter closure period."

The South Bank has about half of the £50m it needs to complete the refurbishment of the Festival Hall and is embarking on a fund-raising drive to coincide with next May's 50th anniversary of its opening. Reg ular concertgoers are being solicited for contributions, and a gala concert on May 3 will inaugurate a month of celebratory events.

Instead of pressing on with major structural changes to the grade I-listed Festival Hall as originally envisaged, Witt hopes to start work at the Hungerford Bridge end of the site. The car park will be grassed over and the area landscaped to form sloping gardens. Beneath this newly created green space, which London mayor Ken Livingstone is apparently keen to open while still in office, will be a new film centre (incorporating a five-screen National Film Theatre, the revamped Museum of the Moving Image and the British Film Institute's headquarters), along with the 1,350-seat concert hall, and, perhaps, a smaller hall to replace the Purcell Room.

Witt is passionate about the idea of a new medium-sized venue. "What in other places is regarded as the basis of the music business doesn't exist in this city," he says. "You don't have any place where you can properly perform a Mozart symphony. I want a hall which offers the intimacy of a chamber-music hall but has the space for Mozart symphonies, early music, choir music and spatial music." Once the new venue is built, the Queen Elizabeth Hall would lose its chamber music function and specialise in amplified music, performance and dance.

Serge Dorny, chief executive of the London Philharmonic, is worried about the focus on the new hall "A new hall is clearly attractive to funders," he says, "but the danger is that if the new hall is built before the Festival Hall gets done, the latter will be forgotten about."

A competition has been launched to find an architect for the Hungerford Bridge site, which will include a mixed-use "gateway" building and retail units. Work on the site will cost around £80m, and commercial development will be crucial in raising the capital. Witt has been loath to be tied to a figure for the entire South Bank redevelopment but it will be at least £200m, with 25% likely to come from lottery funds, 25% from donations and the rest from retail and office development. After the Dome disasters, transparency - that governmental buzzword - is everything. The South Bank's public need to be told when their suffering will cease: we can put up with the pain of the journey, even enjoy the collective sense of getting somewhere, if the destination is made clear. Otherwise, the predictions of failure will become self-fulfilling, and the vultures will have their feast.

fields.headline: Nowt as queer as Gillen
fields.standfirst: He brought gay life to mainstream TV, he is about to play Ariel at the Almeida and he stars in a film released next month. So why on earth is Aidan Gillen so worried about life, asks Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: He brought gay life to mainstream TV, he is about to play Ariel at the Almeida and he stars in a film released next month. So why on earth is Aidan Gillen so worried about life, asks Lyn Gardner.
fields.body:
Tell actor Aidan Gillen that you think that he is on the cusp of being big, really big, and he recoils as if you've bitten him. "No I'm not that kind of person. I'll only fuck it up. I'm not good enough," he protests. But whether he likes it or not, Gillen is staring major success in the face. Already well-known for his role as the arrogant, good-time Stuart in Queer as Folk - the drama that brought gay life and love to mainstream TV - Gillen's Shakespearean debut as Ariel in Jonathan Kent's production of The Tempest at the Almeida later this week will bring two years of non-stop work to a climax.

Over Christmas he will be seen as Carver Doone in the BBC's production of Lorna Doone; and in January there will almost certainly be more attention with the release of Jamie Thraves's original and smart debut feature film The Low Down, in which Gillen stars as Frank, a confused man about to hit 30, who can't make up his mind whether to go for the mortgage and commitment or to stay a waster. This performance won Gillen the best newcomer award at this year's Edinburgh film festival.

In the circumstances it's no surprise that 32-year-old Gillen ("I look younger and feel older - much older") is looking weary. The arrival of his second child six weeks ago, combined with rehearsals for The Tempest, are also taking their toll. "Every couple of years - no, that's every couple of weeks - I think I'm going to give up acting. I heat myself up over the fact that I am never going to be as good as I want to be. I hate it when people tell you you're good when you know that you're not."

Gillen has been acting since his early teens, when he joined his local Dublin youth theatre as a way to meet girls and get invited to parties. "To start, I wasn't really interested in acting at all and I didn't make much impact. The first play I was in was on for five nights and I didn't show up for two of them and nobody noticed. But I stayed because that's where my friends were, and after a while I found myself wanting to inhabit other people's worlds and lives. I discovered that I enjoyed acting - although you can't deny that it's also about showing off and wanting people's approval."

At 18 he auditioned for a role in Billy Roche's A Handful of Stars at the Bush, got it, came to London, felt lonely and has barely been out of work since, although he had a bare patch just before Queer as Folk. He still claims that his career feels like an accident - but his CV reeks of quality, with stints in Mojo at the Royal Court, the Playboy of the Western World at the Almeida and Juno and the Paycock at the National.

While he clearly gets offered good stuff, he is canny enough to skim off the real cream. He spotted the quality of Russell T Davies's scripts for Queer as Folk as soon as he saw them and was keen to play Stuart, not least because the self-confident gay man who was always the centre of attention was a million miles away from his own persona.

"I felt I needed to confound people's perceptions of what they thought I was," says Gillen. He points out that the series has done his career nothing but good, though he was unprepared for the amount of attention - not all of it welcome - it brought him. He groans when I tell him that I've taken a tour of sites on the internet on which female and male admirers drool over him.

One of the pleasures of Gillen's performance in The Low Down is the way in which he suggests that there is part of the hapless, personable, slightly comic Frank that is hidden, wild and totally unknowable. It is what gives the film its emotional ballast.

Jonathan Kent, who is directing Gillen in The Tempest, recognises that quality in him too, describing it as "a hinterland...There is a darkness in him that is fascinating," says Kent. He originally hadn't thought of casting Gillen, who had no Shakespearean experience and no drama-school training. He just happened to be having a drink with Gillen one day when the rightness of the casting hit him. "I was sitting staring at him and I suddenly thought, 'I've been mad not to think of him. He is Ariel. Ariel is so elusive and so is Aidan.' "

"Jonathan had to talk me into it. I was a bit worried because I've been used to doing a lot of muttering and mumbling as an actor," says Gillen. "But I've discovered that once you know what you're talking about and you believe in it, the Shakespearean language comes naturally.

"What I've really found interesting is the antagonistic relationship between Prospero and Ariel, and the way they are tied together, like body and soul. It is as if Ariel represents the dying of Prospero's imagination."

Gillen starts laughing at himself. He is a little over-analytical - a natural-born worrier. "The reason I get in a tortured state about acting is because sometimes I don't think I feel enough anguish about it," he says. "I want to care. I don't want to be apathetic. I want to move people. I'm not good at smiling. I'm not saying that I'm not interested in being famous but I'm more interested in being good, and I never feel that I am good enough."

He gets up to leave and smiles. "On the cusp, you say? The cusp. Yes, I'd say being on the cusp is a quite interesting place to be."

webTitle: Rio favourite to host southern branch of Guggenheim

fields.headline: Rio favourite to host southern branch of Guggenheim
fields.trailText: Rio de Janeiro seems to be the front-runner in a contest between four Brazilian cities to house the first branch of the Guggenheim museum in the southern hemisphere.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Rio de Janeiro seems to be the front-runner in a contest between four Brazilian cities to house the first branch of the Guggenheim museum in the southern hemisphere.

The museum is likely to be a big architectural attraction and the chosen city can expect a surge in tourism. The Guggenheim's director in New York, Thomas Krens, said that since the foundation's spectacular museum opened in Bilbao in 1997, he had received requests from more than 60 cities around the world to open new outposts.

He seems to be plumping for a site in Brazil and recently completed a tour of potential locations together with the architect of the Bilbao museum, Frank Gehry. Describing the chances of Rio winning the museum, Gehry said: "It's kind of some place between a kind of done deal and a scouting expedition."

The museum's most likely site is understood to be by Praca Maua, in Rio's rundown dock area. A dramatic outcrop of rocks between the Copaca bana and Ipanema beaches was initially touted but then discarded, as the Guggenheim wants such projects to regenerate urban areas. Other venues inspected were in the colonial cities of Recife and Salvador in the north-east, and Curitiba, a model of modern urban planning, in the south.

"The cultural centre of Latin America will shift to Rio with this museum," argued Edemar Cid Ferreira, president of the Brazil-US Council which will help to raise funds for the £200m project. "The major cultural route has always included Paris, London, New York and Tokyo. Now it will go south of the equator for the first time."

Dedicated to contemporary art, the Guggenheim has already expanded beyond New York to Berlin and Venice, as well as Bilbao. This week it announced a new museum for the waterfront in lower Manhattan. Gehry is the designer.

Mr Krens is reported to have become increasingly interested in Brazil during the planning for an exhibition - called Brazil: Body and Soul - which will be hosted by the New York Guggenheim next autumn. "The cultural story here is unbelievably rich," Mr Krens said. "It is time to have a cultural trade that runs north and south, not just east and west."

But financial bidding is also a crucial part of the Guggenheim equation: according to press reports, Rio's mayor-elect has offered Mr Krens $100m (£71m) for the project. The governor of Parana state, which includes Curitiba, has offered a public building, and the vice-president of Brazil, Marco Maciel, has said he hopes that Recife is chosen by the Guggenheim.

The "courting" period between the Guggenheim and Brazil's cities is expected to last six months before a final decision.

webTitle: A hated Soviet symbol lingers in Warsaw

fields.headline: Poles have yet to shed shadow of big brother
fields.standfirst: While Warsaw modernises, a hated Soviet symbol lingers
fields.trailText: While Warsaw modernises, a hated Soviet symbol lingers.
fields.body:
It dwarfs everything around it. In its shadow lies the old city, reconstructed brick by brick as a monument to the 1944 Warsaw uprising, and the Marriott hotel.

But it is neither a monument to Polish heroism against the Nazi occupiers, nor an icon to Poland's western future. It is the Palace of Culture and Science - all 30 floors, 3,000 rooms, 817,000 cubic metres of it.

This building is Poland's Eiffel Tower, with a spire 231 metres high. While Minsk, Kiev, even Baku, got a metro system from Big Brother in Moscow, Warsaw drew the short straw and commuters to this day curse as they clunk around Uncle Joe's Christmas cake in trams.

Poles suffer from an attack of collective amnesia when it comes to speaking Russian. "I studied for nine years in school and not a word seems to have stuck," says a 26-year-old, whose English is fluent. So what does Poland now do with the most prominent symbol of its former occupier?

Coca-Cola has its local office there, for one thing, and there is also a casino. For one woman, perched on the 15th floor, the building's present cultural predicament presents a special irony. Hanna Szczubelek has worked as the palace's official chronicler for 40 years.

She accompanied the Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin to the viewing tower on the 30th floor. "He was nice and had a sense of humour, not like the others," she remembers. "He leaned over and said: 'How far to the Earth it is from here'."

It was mostly Ms Szczubelek's hand that recorded the list of official greetings in the leather bound book. In it, Josef Cyronkiewicz, wrote as prime minister in July 1955: "The Polish nation with happiness receives today this beautiful and noble gift from our brother nation of Russian workers ... a high symbol of untouched friendship between our two nations."

Other correspondence is vaguely addressed to "the cordial government", or "Eduard Gerek", Poland's former communist leader. To children, the palace was the imagined home of Father Christmas. Workers thought it was where Gerek lived. Everyone believed it was the ultimate seat of power, which made the book a place to lodge pleas for official help.

"Dear government", wrote a farmer from Ostrowka, a village south of Warsaw, "I can't live any more. My neighbour Cyril took my land. When I was building my house, he and his wife put salt and sugar in my wet concrete. I don't have any money for the courts and I don't know how to fight for my rights, and he does it because my sheep ate a little of his grass. What can I do?"

The building radiated more than just power. One supplicant complained: "I live on the eastern side of the palace of culture and every night I get this electric feeling caused by radiation from the television antenna [on top of the palace]. This worries me very much. I have a request for the technical department to cover this antenna."

Another child wrote simply: "Dear palace of culture, get my dad out of jail."

The building was luxury on show to a proletariat to whom colonnaded corridors, candelabra and window sills made of real oak were the stuff of Hollywood. "You could see the beautiful corridors and stairs. You could indulge yourself in luxury and go quietly without any hurry and always find something new," wrote one woman admirer.

Ms Szczubelek leans over conspiratorially: "There are 25 cats living officially in the second level of the basement. Every one has a name. There is even a budget for their food. You know, they are fed livers." One of the cats, Ozi, is not satisfied. He crosses the six-lane highway every day to the kitchen of the Holiday Inn.

On the building's roofs and turrets, the academy of sciences found 117 species of plants growing, including apple trees and tomato plants. Rare grasses are trapped in its concrete cracks.

The mayor is putting a millennium clock atop the building to reclaim it for modern Poland. But Hanna Szczubelek cannot forget the early days.

A park is named after her father, who died fighting the Nazis while the Russians waited across the Vistula in 1944 for the Nazis to finish off his ilk. "What do you think? I always hated the Soviets," she says.

This worries me very much. I have a request for the technical department to cover this antenna." Another child wrote simply: "Dear palace of culture, get my dad out of jail." The building was luxury on show to a proletariat to whom colonnaded corridors, candelabra and window sills made of real oak were the stuff of Hollywood. "You could see the beautiful corridors and stairs. You could indulge yourself in luxury and go quietly without any hurry and always find something new," wrote one woman admirer. Ms Szczubelek leans over conspiratorially: "There are 25 cats living officially in the second level of the basement. Every one has a name. There is even a budget for their food. You know, they are fed livers." One of the cats, Ozi, is not satisfied. He crosses the six-lane highway every day to the kitchen of the Holiday Inn. On the building's roofs and turrets, the academy of sciences found 117 species of plants growing, including apple trees and tomato plants. Rare grasses are trapped in its concrete cracks. The mayor is putting a millennium clock atop the building to reclaim it for modern Poland. But Hanna Szczubelek cannot forget the early days. A park is named after her father, who died fighting the Nazis while the Russians waited across the Vistula in 1944 for the Nazis to finish off his ilk. "What do you think? I always hated the Soviets," she says.

fields.headline: Officials send school's unisex toilets down the pan
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A headteacher is to ask education officials to reconsider their veto on unisex toilets in his comprehensive school.
fields.body:
A headteacher is to ask education officials to reconsider their veto on unisex toilets in his comprehensive school.

The toilets, 19 cubicles with brick dividing walls and floor-to-ceiling doors, have been installed at a cost of £35,000 at Bramhall high school in Stockport, Greater Manchester.

But they are used only by girls because the Department for Education and Employment says they violate the regulation that pupils aged over eight must not wash their hands together.

"The time is not right for the introduction of unisex toilets in schools," said a letter from the DfEE to the head, John Peckham. "Concerns have been raised on religious grounds. Also many children welcome privacy when using toilets and washing facilities."

Mr Peckham said yesterday that he was disappointed by the department's response to a scheme designed in part to beat bullying.

"The school has asked the DfEE to operate the toilets for six months as an experiment," he added. "Parents' and pupils' reactions would be recorded, along with any incidents of bullying or vandalism. The school felt the results would be of interest to other schools facing similar problems."

Bramhall decided on its experiment after Ofsted inspectors commented on the poor quality of the toilets. Pupils were consulted, and it was felt that a mix of girls and boys would help to lessen aggression and vandalism.

The toilets could be patrolled by one teacher, male or female, and security cameras would be trained on the wash basin zone. Other single sex toilets would remain in use.

Pupils using single sex lavatories had complained of being locked in cubicles, made to smoke and having their heads forced under running taps.

"Youngsters look on traditional toilets in schools as places where they can go and be 'gangy'," Mr Peckham told the BBC. In a mixed space "there's not the opportunity".

He dismissed fears of sex sessions, suggesting that pupils would seek somewhere more comfortable.

webTitle: Flames of scandal close in on silent Chirac

fields.headline: Flames of scandal close in on silent Chirac
fields.trailText: An increasingly isolated Jacques Chirac came under fierce pressure yesterday to explain himself both to the French people and to investigators looking into allegations of corruption at Paris town hall while he was the city's mayor.
fields.body:
An increasingly isolated Jacques Chirac came under fierce pressure yesterday to explain himself both to the French people and to investigators looking into allegations of corruption at Paris town hall while he was the city's mayor.

Days before the start of the Nice summit meant to crown France's six-month presidency of the European Union, the French head of state was deemed to be in the deepest trouble of his career: even his closest allies were demanding that he respond to the accusations of graft being levelled against his RPR party.

"This affair is exceptionally serious," said a leading RPR heavyweight, Philippe Séguin, the party's former chairman and its candidate for Paris mayor at next year's local elections. "Public trust in our democracy has hit rock bottom. We need explanations."

François Bayrou, the head of the conservative UDF party that has traditionally fought municipal and national elections on the same ticket as the RPR, said the country was in "a moral and political crisis without precedent", hit by "a shockwave of which we know the origin - but not where it will finish up".

Mr Chirac's former right-hand man in the early 1990s, Michel Roussin, was placed under formal investigation on Friday night and thrown into jail after refusing to answer accusations that he helped run an illicit funding scheme based on kickbacks from building companies.

Investigators say they have firm evidence that the RPR's coffers were swollen with huge bribes paid by the companies in exchange for construction and maintenance contracts worth some £2.8bn for hospitals, schools and council housing in the Paris area.

Businessmen and local politicians under investigation in the case have told magistrates that building firms paid some £60m in bribes between 1989 and 1996 - the year after Mr Chirac's 18-year tenure at city hall ended. Some 70% allegedly went to his RPR party, and the remainder to the Socialists and Communists.

President Chirac, who denies any wrongdoing, is refusing to comment on the scandal before the Nice summit, and is in any event immune from prosecution as long as he remains France's head of state.

But media and public opinion is starting to turn against the Elysée palace's controversial policy, reiterated again yesterday by a Chirac aide, of "no apology, no explanation".

The popular daily Le Parisien said the president had never appeared so isolated or enfeebled. "Things seem to falling apart around the Elysée and its occupant," it said. "Chirac can no longer wall himself in silence." The left-leaning daily Libération captioned a front-page portrait of the president with the words: "Prime witness".

The latest accusations follow a claim by the RPR's unofficial treasurer, Louise-Yvonne Cassetta, that Mr Chirac, while he was mayor of Paris and president of the RPR, was personally informed of all "gifts" donated to the party by construction and engineering companies.

They also appear to confirm the extraordinary beyond-the-grave accusations levelled by a former property developer and senior RPR official, Jean-Claude Méry, that were made public in September.

Mr Méry, who died of cancer last year, accused Mr Chirac in a video-taped confession of setting up the covert fundraising system. He said he personally helped companies win city hall contracts in return for huge bribes, usually about 1.5% of a contract's value.

"We worked only on orders from Mr Chirac," he said during the hour-long tape-recording, the transcript of which was published by Le Monde.

Describing how he personally handed over some £500,000 to Mr Roussin in the presence of Mr Chirac, Mr Méry added that the total cash payments to the RPR reached "£3.5m to £4m every year for more than seven years, under my direction".

Mr Chirac dismissed the posthumous video tape as "an abracadabra tale", and has since refused to speak on the matter. His aides have counter-attacked, accusing the president's political opponents of manipulation and character assassination aimed at undermining his bid for a second presidential term in 2002.

But as evidence of wrongdoing mounts, opinion polls show the French public wants an explanation: some 76% in a recent survey said they felt the president should at the very least address the nation, while 70% would like him to volunteer for questioning.

Some more outspoken MPs from the ruling Socialist party, which was itself rocked by a financing scandals in the early 1990s, have demanded Mr Chirac's head.

"He should get himself a good lawyer," said one young deputy, Arnaud Montebourg, who is trying to gather MPs' signatures for what would amount to Mr Chirac's impeachment.

"To ensure any semblance of justice, the investigators must at least question the president as a witness."

The players

Jacques Chirac French president, mayor of Paris 1977-1995 and founder of the neo-Gaullist RPR party. Name has appeared on the margins of a multitude of investigations into the funding of the RPR, including an alleged kickback scam and a fictitious jobs scandal. Has persistently denounced all such rumours and allegations as malicious and unfounded nonsense.

Jean-Claude Méry Now-deceased multimillionaire property developer, RPR official and close ally of Chirac; ran a consultancy that specialised in helping companies win lucrative Paris city hall contracts. Did time in prison; recorded a video cassette three years ago to 'put the record straight'. Released in September, Méry's detailed allegations sent a shock wave through the entire French political establishment.

Michel Roussin Chirac's chief aide at city hall from 1989-1993, a former cooperation minister, commander of the French secret service and senior gendarme. Accused of 'complicity in, and receipt of the proceeds of, corruption', Roussin is seen as one of the kingpins of Chirac's alleged illicit funding system.

Louise-Yvonne Cassetta Known as 'La Cassette' (the purse), Ms Cassetta allegedly was for many years the RPR party's unofficial treasurer, collecting and distributing illegal kickbacks paid by construction and maintenance companies. She was released for lack of sufficient evidence last week but was rearrested the following day.

webTitle: Blair warns NHS patients of more winter problems

fields.headline: Blair warns NHS patients of more winter problems
fields.trailText: Tony Blair warned yesterday that patients will endure winter pressures in the NHS for several more years until increased spending produces enough trained staff to cover seasonal peaks in demand.
fields.body:
Tony Blair warned yesterday that patients will endure winter pressures in the NHS for several more years until increased spending produces enough trained staff to cover seasonal peaks in demand.

As ministers put the finishing touches to legislation in the Queen's speech tomorrow to push through health service reform, the prime minister also appealed to the media for fair coverage of problems in the hospitals over the next three months, warning of a growing resentment among NHS staff that only the bad things got reported.

"Until we have delivered the increases in capacity year on year for several more years, there are bound to be pressures. And there will be cases where patients do not get the care they should," he said.

"But let us get a sense of balance. Support the NHS staff who give a wonderful service to the majority of patients and do not fall into the trap of saying that every time something goes wrong, the NHS is in crisis or on its knees. The glass is half full, not half empty."

Mr Blair was presenting the government's winter planning strategy to leaders of doctors, nurses and NHS managers at a press conference in Downing Street. They were shown the document a week ago, but attended yesterday to show solidarity.

The prime minister gave a double message to sceptical voters, trying to play up improvements in the capacity of the NHS to withstand winter pressures, but also to reduce expectations that the service can avoid running into difficulty.

He said progress over the last 12 months included 445 extra critical care beds, an increase of 18% on hospitals' capacity last winter. There were 3.2m more doses of flu vaccine, 1,350 more acute beds and more than 6,000 extra nurses - a net increase of 16,000 since the election.

Health authorities had spent £20m on contracts with independent hospitals under the recent concordat with the private sector. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said this would provide thousands of NHS patients with routine surgery over coming months.

The government yesterday distributed £100m in grants to local authorities for social services in 2001-2, allowing them to help older people leave hospital this winter without fearing the cost of looking after them during the next financial year. But Mr Blair warned: "Inevitably the NHS is not yet the service patients would like it to be. There is still a long way to go."

The government is expected to promise legislation tomorrow to speed up the pace of NHS reform. It will include powers for health authorities and local councils to form care trusts to co-ordinate hospitals, GPs and social services. The bill will abolish community health councils and create a new patient advocate service. There will be powers to provide free nursing care for the elderly.

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said: "Talking about whether the NHS glass is half full or half empty misses the point - what patients and doctors are worried about is whether their hospital's beds are full or not."

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said: "The extra nurses have to be good news, but most hospitals would tell you that they still have very real shortages of staff this winter."

fields.headline: Independent MP eyes new seat
fields.trailText: Martin Bell, the white-suited Independent MP for Tatton, heightened speculation that he will stand for Parliament again last night after announcing a press conference to discuss his plans in a Tory-held constitutency later this week.
fields.body:
Martin Bell, the white-suited Independent MP for Tatton, heightened speculation that he will stand for Parliament again last night after announcing a press conference to discuss his plans in a Tory-held constitutency later this week.

The former BBC war correspondent is to meet journalists on Friday at a hotel in Brentwood and Ongar, an Essex constituency that is one of the Tories' safest seats.

The move comes after local Conservatives approached him expressing concern that some 200 members of an evangelical church had flooded the local constituency and voted their members into key posts.

Mr Bell, who defeated Neil Hamilton, the former Tory minister at the centre of the cash-for-questions scandal, at the last election, promised in 1997 that he would not seek re-election in his existing constituency. But the 62-year-old has been looking for a new seat after admitting that being an MP was "very agreeable, working in this wonderful palace, with the illusion of being at the centre of things".

Brentwood and Ongar, which had a Tory majority of 9,690 in 1997, was investigated by Central Office after claims that the local Peniel Pentecostal Church had conducted a campaign of "entryism" in order to win control of its Conservative association. The investigation found no proof of malpractice and Eric Pickles, the sitting MP, has denied the group has undue influence.

fields.headline: Heseltine enters deselection row
fields.trailText: Michael Heseltine issued a stern warning to William Hague yesterday that the Tories would make themselves unelectable if pro-European MPs are deselected ahead of the general election.
fields.body:
Michael Heseltine issued a stern warning to William Hague yesterday that the Tories would make themselves unelectable if pro-European MPs are deselected ahead of the general election.

Speaking as Tories in Esher prepared to vote on whether to deselect their long-serving MP, the former deputy prime minister said that the leadership needed such votes "like a hole in the head".

Mr Heseltine said it would be deeply regrettable if Ian Taylor, a former minister who has served as MP for Esher and Walton since 1987, were deselected.

"What William needs like a hole in the head, to be honest, is that one of his more talented backbenchers is put under a deselection process," Mr Heseltine told BBC's The World at One.

The former deputy prime minister said that Mr Taylor, a vociferous opponent of Mr Hague's decision to rule out membership of the euro for the next parliament, had not broken party rules. "The fact is that William Hague has made it clear that backbench members of the House of Commons are free to express their views on Europe," Mr Heseltine said. His support for Mr Taylor came hours before Tories in Esher voted on whether to reverse their decision to allow Mr Taylor to stand as their candidate at the next general election. His opponents managed to force an extraordinary general meeting of the local association because of Mr Taylor's "repeated rejection of Conservative party policy on Europe".

The Tory leadership, which has been exasperated by Mr Taylor's regular attacks on its European policies, has urged Tories in Esher to stand by their MP.

In a firmly worded letter last week to the constituency chairman, John Burns, the Tory chairman Michael Ancram said that challenging the position of a MP because of his opinions had "never been a part of our tradition".

Mr Ancram's letter did not signal a thaw in relations with Mr Taylor who regularly lambasts the Tory leadership in press releases issued by the Britain in Europe group. Tory Central Office highlighted its anger with Mr Taylor yesterday when a spokesman said that Mr Hague would not offer personal support for the beleaguered MP ahead of the vote.

fields.headline: Plight of whales worsens
fields.standfirst: Action plan to save cetaceans in UK waters
fields.trailText: Conservationists yesterday set up an action plan to save the whales and dolphins which frequent European waters and which are being poisoned, killed in nets, and deliberately harassed by people in fast boats. Despite international agreements, cetacean numbers are continuing to fall and threats to them are growing.
fields.body:
Conservationists yesterday set up an action plan to save the whales and dolphins which frequent European waters and which are being poisoned, killed in nets, and deliberately harassed by people in fast boats. Despite international agreements, cetacean numbers are continuing to fall and threats to them are growing.

The action plan is focused on getting modifications to fishing nets so that whales, dolphins and porpoises can avoid entanglement and drowning. It also aims to stop the oil industry using explosions and seismic echoes in cetaceans' home waters, and to ban the chemicals that accumulate in cetacean body fat causing illness and infertility.

At the launch of the campaign yesterday by the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society and Dive magazine, the periodical of the British Sub Aqua Club, Mark Simmonds, WDCS director of science, said: "Chemical pollution, fishing nets, offshore oil and gas industry, are all substantive threats to the marine wildlife."

There are 24 species of dolphins and whales remaining around Britain's coasts, but since the first WDCS review of these mammals in UK waters, in 1997, their plight has worsened. This year's report notes that young people on jet skis and power boats have been herding and even killing dolphins in Torquay, Devon. Under the Countryside Act a new offence of "reckless harassment" is coming into force.

Whales and dolphins are also disturbed by low frequency sounds emitted by ships to detect submarines and for communication purposes. The noise disrupts their ability to navigate and their "conversations", and can drive them away from their home territory.

Manufactured chemicals such as PCBs which stay in body fat, preventing reproduction and causing disease, are now recognised as a serious threat, too. The International Whaling Commission has been investigating the problem. Dead porpoises washed up on beaches show a clear link between body fat pollution and disease. One population of dolphins on the Moray Firth, Scotland, is affected by pollution and expected to die out in the next 50 years.

About 2,000 of the once common harbour porpoise are also killed each year in nets. The WDCS wants conservation areas established in Cardigan Bay and Bardsey Island, in Wales, for the mammal, which is now listed as endangered.

Helen Brinton, Labour MP for Peterborough, has criticised the Countryside Act for doing little for marine life.

Yesterday Graeme Gourlay, Dive magazine's editor, added that real protection was needed "for the fabulous diversity of cetaceans" or "we'll be the last generation to enjoy such a natural wonder".

At the launch of the campaign yesterday by the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society and Dive magazine, the periodical of the British Sub Aqua Club, Mark Simmonds, WDCS director of science, said: "Chemical pollution, fishing nets, offshore oil and gas industry, are all substantive threats to the marine wildlife." There are 24 species of dolphins and whales remaining around Britain's coasts, but since the first WDCS review of these mammals in UK waters, in 1997, their plight has worsened. This year's report notes that young people on jet skis and power boats have been herding and even killing dolphins in Torquay, Devon. Under the Countryside Act a new offence of "reckless harassment" is coming into force. Whales and dolphins are also disturbed by low frequency sounds emitted by ships to detect submarines and for communication purposes. The noise disrupts their ability to navigate and their "conversations", and can drive them away from their home territory. Manufactured chemicals such as PCBs which stay in body fat, preventing reproduction and causing disease, are now recognised as a serious threat, too. The International Whaling Commission has been investigating the problem. Dead porpoises washed up on beaches show a clear link between body fat pollution and disease. One population of dolphins on the Moray Firth, Scotland, is affected by pollution and expected to die out in the next 50 years. About 2,000 of the once common harbour porpoise are also killed each year in nets. The WDCS wants conservation areas established in Cardigan Bay and Bardsey Island, in Wales, for the mammal, which is now listed as endangered. Helen Brinton, Labour MP for Peterborough, has criticised the Countryside Act for doing little for marine life. Yesterday Graeme Gourlay, Dive magazine's editor, added that real protection was needed "for the fabulous diversity of cetaceans" or "we'll be the last generation to enjoy such a natural wonder".

webTitle: Computers in schools 'a boon to poorer pupils'

fields.headline: Computers in schools 'a boon to poorer pupils'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pupils from poor backgrounds are more enthusiastic about using computers to learn in school than affluent children, research for the government shows.
fields.body:
Pupils from poor backgrounds are more enthusiastic about using computers to learn in school than affluent children, research for the government shows.

Some 60% of pupils in social group E and 47% in social group D - those from families of unskilled and partly skilled workers - felt they learned more using a computer in the classroom, compared with 26% of those from groups A and B, from families of senior managers and professionals.

Around 80% of pupils from groups D and E stated that they preferred learning from a computer in school, 17% more than ABs. And 87% of pupils of those from group E felt they would like to spend more time learning from a computer in the classroom, compared with 70% of ABs.

Students from richer families are much more likely to have computers at home. Nine out of 10 ABs, three out of four C1 and C2s (children from skilled workers), but about half of Ds and Es have a computer at home.

In the study 68% of 7-14 year olds in group E felt that using computers in school helped improve their concentration compared with 48% of ABs.

According to the survey, 40% of the sample who had home computers felt that they would do less school work at home if they did not have a computer. This was true of 58% in group E.

The survey of 750 pupils by polling company Access showed that 91% of 10-year-old pupils used computers in school, mostly in English and information technology lessons. But nearly half said they never used computers for maths, or science. Two-thirds never used a computer in modern languages lessons and only a quarter used it for history.

webTitle: Telegraph Hill's journey from 'fresh start' to full stop

fields.headline: School's out, forever
fields.standfirst: Will Woodward traces Telegraph Hill's journey from 'fresh start' to full stop
fields.trailText: Will Woodward traces Telegraph Hill's journey from 'fresh start' to full stop
fields.body:
It sounded familiar: an idealistic headteacher takes over one of the government's "fresh start" schools, and it all goes very wrong very quickly. Without a proper timetable, with building works making the school a daily nightmare, the head loses the confidence of the council, and he resigns with dream in tatters.

But this wasn't the Islington Arts and Media School, whose drama was etched in the skulls of every hard-working teacher and anxious parent who watched the BBC2 documentary series Head on the Block. And the head wasnot Torsten Freidag. But on the other side of London, the teachers at Telegraph Hill, Lewisham, saw the series and thought: this is what happened to us, too. The comparisons aren't exact. For instance, it's said that Mike Davies, the headteacher at Telegraph Hill, formerly Hatcham Wood, kept the support of staff much longer than Mr Freidag had. And whereas Mr Freidag had been a glutton for publicity, it was only last week that the blanket of silence about this school began to be removed.

The Islington school is now approaching the future with a certain degree of hard-headed optimism, under the headship of Richard Ewen, who as it happens was last year a consultant to Telegraph Hill. But Telegraph Hill is on the way out. The council's decision to close it, uncovered by the Guardian last Thursday, was formally revealed to parents on Friday. And now 500 pupils are looking frantically for a new school to take them next September.

Althea Efunshile, director for education and culture at Lewisham council, told parents in a letter: "It is my judgment that despite the tremendous commitment of staff and governors, the school faces an enormous and impossible task if it is to offer a satisfactory education to pupils within a reasonable timescale . . . I believe they will be better served by being educated in other schools."

The apology asked for from the council by the National Union of Teachers did not come. "I don't feel I should apologise to the union. I regret that fresh start didn't work - but it was worth trying," Efunshile told the Guardian. Though the school was improving, she now felt that rather than being turned around in two or three years, it would be more like six to nine.

Martin Powell-Davies, Lewisham secretary of the NUT, said: "The failure of the fresh start contains in a nutshell everything that is wrong with government policy - the blaming and sacking of good staff while ignoring the real problems facing a school with the greatest needs in the borough. Disgracefully, the local education authority has managed to go full circle back to the situation that first faced Hatcham Wood when Ofsted criticised it in 1998."

Last Friday, after sending letters to parents, Efunshile met local headteachers to ask them to take on Telegraph Hill's children. Few parents made the school their first choice. About a third live in Southwark but come to Telegraph Hill because they can't get into Southwark schools. For the remainder, other than Malory school in Downham, which itself has a poor academic record, and the Catford Girls' school, it is difficult to see where these pupils will go.

Parents have to be consulted on the council's plan, which will go to councillors on December 13. But though there may be protests, there seems little appetite for keeping the school open. What became Telegraph Hill, but was once Hatcham Wood, was never going to be an easy school. In a difficult part of town, there were plenty of other educational attractions. The blazers of the wealthy Haberdashers' Aske's Hatcham College, a city technology college 100 yards down the road where pupils are taken on interview, sucked most of the brightest pupils away. Two thirds of Hatcham Wood's pupils were on free school meals, two thirds were speaking English as an additional language, and almost as many had special educational needs. Nearby Deptford Green school also took a lot of the middle-class children away.

Hatcham Wood had serious truancy problems - the council took a mother to court after her child turned up for school on 11 out of 66 days. Four out of five students had very poor basic skills. Staff recruitment was becoming all but impossible. Exam results bumped around - 17% one year, 14% in 1998. In January of that year, with 12 agency teachers drafted in and 12 existing members of staff "acting up" to more senior posts, the school was put into special measures by Ofsted. But some parents remained loyal to the school, which they felt was doing its best in difficult circumstances.

In May 1998, parents were consulted on the future of the school. Closure was ruled out because there were too many children to accommodate; a merger with Haberdashers' was floated but opposed by many of the CTC's parents, and by other secondary heads in the borough who were worried that the enlarged school would drain even more students away from local comprehensives. Though the council was proud of its record in turning around other failing schools, it opted instead for fresh start - untried, unproved, but fashionable. The government's flagship scheme for turning around failing schools promised a high profile, a new beginning and more money.

So the previous head, Jill Jordan, took early retirement, and in stepped Mike Davies, previously a head in Stranraer, Scotland, and once head teacher of Stantonbury school, a liberal comprehensive in Milton Keynes. The school closed as Hatcham Wood in July 1999 and reopened as Telegraph Hill in September. Just 11 of the 42 Hatcham Wood staff kept their jobs.

The new staff met just four days before it opened. They spent most of those moving equipment around to get the school working. The key post of special needs co-ordinator remained unfilled. According to Davies, speaking at a Royal Society of Arts conference last week, new pupils entered the school with a reading age of eight or below.

Davies introduced a transformed curriculum, partly based on an RSA scheme, which involved teaching by faculty. Science, maths and technology were to be taught together within the same lessons. But the building wasn't up to it: classrooms for those subjects were in different parts of the school. According to three of its teachers, the school never had a fully working timetable. Despite extensive building works, this did little more than patch up the site. The school opened without computers, photocopiers or a working telephone system. Teachers communicated on mobiles. Painting carried on, the canteen did cold meals only, and the school administration was done in the gym.

The pupils didn't know the new staff, and the new staff didn't know the school. Pupils ran around and discipline collapsed. The school ran up a deficit of £200,000. In the summer, Ofsted visited the school and placed it in special measures. Davies resigned. According to some staff, council officials had lost faith in Mr Davies earlier but they had been resisted by the governing body, chaired by Labour councillor Madeleine Long. When the GCSE results came out, just 3% of students got five A*-Cs at GCSE, making it the joint worst school in England. Down the road at the CTC, 76% did. But then just 3.7% of students at the college had special needs, compared with 40.2% at Telegraph Hill.

On Friday Estelle Morris, the schools standards minister, may effectively have signed the death knell for the policy by telling councils to close schools rather than fresh start them. There are 25 fresh start schools - 24 if Telegraph Hill closes - and well-placed departmental sources were suggesting there may never be another one.

But that's no consolation for the staff and pupils of Telegraph Hill. "It's been the worst teaching year of my life," said one teacher. "We made a terrible mistake when we decided not to do any publicity because it means we have colluded with the horror that we have had to cope with."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Firm supplied unfit tap water
fields.body:
Firm supplied unfit tap water

Yorkshire Water yesterday admitted 17 counts of supplying water unfit for human consumption two years ago at locations in West and North Yorkshire. A sentencing hearing will take place at Leeds crown court on Friday.

Russian mafia threat to caviar

The Russian mafia's control of caviar, the most expensive food in the world, is so threatening the sturgeon fish that some species may be extinct within a few years, the environment group WWF said yesterday. Russian anti-poaching officials and border guards have seized more than 70 tonnes of caviar this year, estimated to be a fraction of the illegal catch in the Caspian basin.

Soccer noise equal to jet

A Premiership soccer crowd screams as loud as a jet engine when celebrating a goal, tests published yesterday showed. Monitoring by environmental health officers at Ipswich Town's ground on Saturday revealed a noise of 118 decibels at one point - the level of a Harrier jet taking off.

University staff in pay protest

University staff from six unions will today begin industrial action in protest at pay and working conditions. The 100,000 staff will work to contract and boycott examinations. David Blunkett, the education secretary, last week told universities to reach a fair settlement with staff.

Veronica Guerin murder denied

John Gilligan appeared in a Dublin court yesterday and pleaded not guilty to the murder of journalist Veronica Guerin in June 1996.

Gilligan, 48, also denied 15 separate drugs and firearms offences allegedly committed between 1994 and 1996. He was extradited from Britain last year to stand trial in Ireland following a three-and-a-half-year legal battle.

Hours threaten women's health

Women workers believe their health and home lives are being hit by the country's long hours culture, a survey showed yesterday. A poll of 100 women for the London Chamber of Commerce also found that excessive working was affecting relationships.

Man faces tree cutting charge

A 25-year-old man was due to appear at Melton magistrates court today charged with criminal damage. It follows an incident in which a chainsaw was used to cut down a 20ft Christmas tree in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire.

Warning on bunk beds

Children under six should not be allowed to sleep in top bunks because of the risk of falls, researchers said yesterday. The warning was issued after a study at Royal Aberdeen children's hospital revealed that over five months 85 out of 8,000 children had fallen out of bunk beds.

Families rarely eat together

Most families dine together once a week or even less often, according to a survey of 1,000 people published by the Food Foundation. Only one in four said they made a family meal a regular event. The foundation said the analysis showed further evidence of the break-up of family life.

webTitle: Father fights adoption of secret son

fields.headline: Father fights adoption of secret son
fields.trailText: A 20-year-old airline flight attendant is challenging his 16-month-old son's adoption on the grounds that he was unaware of the child's existence.
fields.body:
A 20-year-old airline flight attendant is challenging his 16-month-old son's adoption on the grounds that he was unaware of the child's existence.

Juan Campoverde, who lives in Harlem, New York, says he was not told about the birth of Shiloh Morabito. "I just want my son. How can this adoption be legal if my son's birth was kept a secret from me?"

He says in papers filed with a family court that he tried to keep in touch with Sabrina Morabito, 26, after their 10-month relationship ended, but that he was always turned away. "Her mother always answered the phone and always had a reason why Sabrina was not available or didn't want to speak with me," he said. "I was always rushed off the line."

The couple went their separate ways two years ago and it was not until August that Ms Morabito's mother told him that he was a father.

By then, the 13-month-old Shiloh had been adopted. Court documents in the father's case say that Ms Morabito threatened never again to talk to her mother, a teacher, if she told him of the pregnancy.

The child is now said to be in the care of a couple in Poughkeepsie, New York, after a previous adoption attempt failed when the private agency concerned said that the father should be notified.

Sari Friedman, general counsel for the Fathers' Rights Association of New York, said: "This is the first case of its kind in that it addresses a situation where a father came around but the mother refused to tell him. Fathers should be notified and given the first right of adoption."

Unmarried fathers however are rarely successful in opposing adoptions because New York state law says that they do not need to be told of the proceedings.

"My client's case is different because he was calling for a year and was never told of the pregnancy or the birth," Susan Chana Lask, Mr Campoverde's lawyer, said. "It was only after the child was given away that the grandmother developed a conscience and revealed the secret."

webTitle: The price of healthy canteen food

fields.headline: Healthier meals come at a price in company canteens
fields.trailText: Pies, chips and beans are giving way to stuffed peppers, nut cutlets and fresh salads as company canteens catch up with healthy living.
fields.body:
Pies, chips and beans are giving way to stuffed peppers, nut cutlets and fresh salads as company canteens catch up with healthy living.

Nine in every 10 now offer a daily vegetarian option compared with only six out of 10 five years ago, according to a survey published today by the union funded Labour Research Department.

Two-thirds also use genetically modified-free ingredients wherever possible and a quarter cater for religious or cultural requirements such as beef or pork-free dishes. A significant minority have even started using organic products as a rule.

The downside is that staff are paying 29% more than five years ago as employers have pushed up prices by double inflation, reducing or withdrawing subsidies and in some cases even shutting canteens.

The average price of tea in the 273 workplaces surveyed was 27p a cup with coffee 31p, a can of soft drink 43p, a snack £1.15, main meal £1.94 and dessert 60p. Smoking is banned in four out of five canteens but in more than a dozen cases employers broke the law by not protecting non-smokers from tobacco smoke.

Segregation whereby managers and the shopfloor were served in separate rooms has virtually disappeared as Japanese-style "one for all" restaurants take over. Public sector workers are being charged more - 17p for a cup of tea - than employees in the private sector who enjoy bigger subsidies. A majority of canteens are contracted out with the Granada Group, including its Compass and Sutcliffe subsidiaries, and Sodexho Alliance, which owns Gardner Merchant, dominating the market.

The Labour Research Department found most staff happy with the quality of food and hygienic standards, if not prices, at work, with a few notable exceptions.

A union official at the driver and vehicle licensing authority in Swansea said a complaint was made to management after it had been "feeding vegetarians meat products in error".
