fields.headline: A vicious circle
fields.standfirst: Jerome Monahan  explains why many think the world's poorest countries should not have to repay their debts
fields.trailText: Jerome Monahan explains why many think the world's poorest countries should not have to repay their debts
fields.body:
On Saturday, thousands marched in London to mark the end of Jubilee 2000. So ended one of the most successful international protest movements ever known, which united hundreds of organisations in a four-year battle to get the debts owed by the world's poorest countries to the richest cancelled.

What is the problem?

Loans to Third World countries amount to over two trillion dollars. Fifty-two of the world's poorest nations owe about £254 billion. The money borrowed by African countries is equal to every person on the continent having a debt of £255 - far more than most Africans earn in a year.

These poor countries have to pay an extra charge called interest on the money they have borrowed. As they cannot hope to pay off the original debts, the interest payments go on and on. So instead of governments having this money to spend on their people, it flows away to rich nations and big organisations such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank.

Jubilee 2000 campaigners claim that if these countries could channel the money they spend on debt repayments back into medical care, for example, the lives of 13 children a minute could be saved. In Tanzania, where four in ten people die before they are 35, debt repayments are six times greater than the annual health budget.

Can't these countries refuse to make their loan payments?

Mexico almost did this in 1982. The response of lenders to borrowing countries in difficulty has been to offer them more loans or let them spread out repayments. So the debts do not go away. What is worse, to get the extra money or time, borrowing countries have to carry out Structural Adjustment Programmes (SAPs). These can involve reducing government spending on state services (health, education) and cutting the money spent keeping food prices down. So life for poor people gets tougher.

Why should these countries escape their debts?

Much of the money lent in the past was wasted or stolen by corrupt leaders or dictators building up their armies. Billions went on crazy development schemes such as a nuclear power station in the Philippines built on an earthquake fault line. Campaigners ask why the poor should go on suffering for the errors of the past. They say countries need a break from crippling repayments to solve other problems.

Does this debt have an impact on our lives in the West?

Yes. When an economy is focused only on generating money to pay off debts, the result is often deforestation, over-fishing and soil overuse. Such environmental damage affects everyone on the planet.

Poor nations cannot afford to import goods from abroad. Debt is bad for world trade. Also, the main drug-producing countries are among the world's biggest debtors - poor farmers grow drugs because nothing else pays as much.

Has Jubilee 2000 achieved what it set out to do?

Huge Jubilee 2000 demonstrations and a petition with 24m signatures have forced world leaders to act. Recently, the top seven (G7) nations promised to forget the money owed them by 41 heavily indebted poor countries (HIPCs), but so far only 13 have had some debt relief and only $12bn has been shaved off the $110bn the creditors offered to forget. Jubilee 2000 points out that there are some desperately poor nations not on the G7 list, such as Bangladesh, which are excluded because their debts are not large enough to make them a HIPC.

One plus is that to qualify for debt relief, poor countries must now set out how they will use the saved cash to reduce poverty. But, says Jubilee 2000, the requirement that countries stick to strict economic controls over several years before they can get their debt relief is delaying things terribly. They say it is like asking a sick patient to run a marathon before they can have an operation.

What next?

As Jubilee 2000 ends so the Drop The Debt Campaign begins. Its focus will be on the next meeting of the world's richest nations in Genoa, Italy, next year.

Meanwhile, the countries that have received some debt relief are using it well. Uganda is offering its children free primary school places, while Mozambique has increased its spending on health and education.

More information:

www.jubilee2000uk.org

www.worldbank.org

www.dropthedebt.org

www.ecgd.gov.uk

See the New Internationalist site at: www.oneworld.org/ni/

fields.headline: On the web
fields.standfirst: Natural disasters
fields.trailText: Natural disasters
fields.body:
Met Office Education

****

Suitable for KS2-4

Not only does the Met Office offer resources for pupils, it also includes an excellently-illustrated teacher training centre on weather-related topics. You can also order posters and packs and research events such as the 1987 hurricane and the London smog of 1952, in which at least 4,000 people died.

Volcano Activity Update

****

Suitable for KS3-5

A fantastic source of volcanic case studies, the Update gives details of the most recent eruptions (mainly in Indonesia just now) and sometimes includes questions for pupils. It links to Volcano World, where you interrogate a vulcanologist and watch videos of famous eruptions.

Outbreak

***

Suitable for KS4-5

Readers of thriller novels and pupils alike will find Outbreak - a study of the spread and control of epidemics and pandemics - a source of fascinating detail. Particularly interesting is the link betwen El Niño and an outbreak of cholera.

Global Warming

***

Suitable for KS2-4

Global warming is brought about by man, but the weather changes it brings about are usually regarded as natural disasters. The department of the environment's teaching resources are written with the National Curriculum in mind and range from eco-snakes and ladders at KS2 to extended data analysis at KS3.

Snow and Ice Data

****

Suitable for KS3 onwards

Why and how avalanches happen, the definitive guide to snow on the web and a useful case study on the 1996 blizzards in the eastern parts of North America.

Asteroid Impact

**

Suitable for KS4 onwards

The dangers of NearEarth Objects and what the US is doing about them. Essential reading for Armageddon fans. neo.jpl.nasa.gov offers a slightly more readable introduction.

The Disaster Finder ltp

****

Suitable for teachers

A directory of disaster and crisis management sites with a US bias. Topics include tsunami (giant waves), earthquakes, flooding and famine.

Earthquake Hazards

****

Suitable for KS4 onwards

Click on General Earthquake Information for explanations of plate tectonics, magnitude and faults, or research one of the many case studies of quakes and tsunamis.

El Niño

***

Suitable for teachers

A directory of educational sites dealing with the El Niño phenomenon and its effects.

Bizarre Stuff to Make

****

Suitable for KS4 onwards and teachers

Construct a hurricane machine, micrometeorites, a seismograph or an erupting volcano. Not all these can be created using kitchen utensils.

Correction: last week's Constitutions site address can be found at www.uni-wuerzburg.de/law/home.html

You can find more sites on natural disasters at www.educationunlimited.co.uk/netclass or contact Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com

Next week: Shakespeare

webTitle: So you want to be... a veterinary nurse

fields.headline: So you want to be...
fields.standfirst: A veterinary nurse
fields.trailText: A veterinary nurse
fields.body:
Wow! What's up? I'd never dare do that. Do what?

Pick Tiddles up like that. You mean like this?

Yikes! She'd bite my thumb off if I tried it. Nonsense. It's the best way.

It may be for you. It really is the safest way for anybody to pick up a mongoose.

How dare you! Tiddles is a prize Burmese cat. Oops. Beg pardon. I haven't got my specs on.

Surely that's a bit dicey in your job. Yes, but they got broken this morning and my spare pair's at home.

Oh dear, was it a large animal? I wouldn't call the vet large exactly.

The vet? He sat on them.

He will be careful with Tiddles ? I'll make sure he is.

So what does your job entail? Veterinary nurses assist vets with the treatment of animals, generally small domestic beasts - cats, dogs, rabbits etc, plus more exotic animals, for example, reptiles. They may also deal with farm animals, even wild animals if there's a zoo on the books.

A nurse holds animals during routine examinations and also assists the vet during surgery, preparing animals and monitoring equipment and anaesthesia.

The job can often involve dirty and unpleasant tasks. And it can be difficult when animals die and you have to deal with grieving owners.

What skills and interests do you need? Obviously a veterinary nurse must have a keen interest in animals, and must be able to deal with all kinds. It is also useful for anyone thinking of entering this profession to get a reasonable level of knowledge of a science subject such as biology.

You must love animals, too? Yes, but it's no good being over-sentimental, as the job often means having to carry out tasks that are quite unpleasant. Animal patients need very careful handling, possibly far more than humans, as often they are very frightened and it is much more difficult to calm an animal as they do not really understand that what is happening to them is for their own good! Nurses need to be quite adept at being able to perform several tasks at once. It is important that they are good at dealing with people both face to face and over the telephone. And they need administrative skills for handling and organising patient records.

What entry requirements are there? To get on the Royal College of Nursing Veterinary Training Scheme, you need five GCSEs including English language, maths and a science. Applicants must be 17 or over, but need parental consent under 18. Training must be at an approved training centre, usually a veterinary practice, and the training period usually lasts approximately two years, which includes practical work within the surgery and day release to college where exams have to be undertaken in order to qualify.

webTitle: If you ask me...about attending college from abroad

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: I live and work in Thailand. My two children have Thai and British citizenship. How does the fees system work? I would like them to attend a university in Britain, but will they be treated as overseas students when fees are determined?
fields.trailText: I live and work in Thailand. My two children have Thai and British citizenship. How does the fees system work? I would like them to attend a university in Britain, but will they be treated as overseas students when fees are determined?
fields.body:
England and Wales

Universities and colleges class students as either "home" or "overseas" for tuition fee purposes. Overseas students, mainly those from outside the European Union, pay the full cost of their tuition fees. These vary between institutions and courses, but are generally higher than for home students - in the region of £6,000-£8,000 pa for an undergraduate course.

However, institutions may offer an overseas student a reduced tuition fee, or no fee at all, according to their circumstances. Refugees and students with recognised asylum status are charged home fee rates.

UK or other EU students are liable for the home tuition fee rate, provided they have no restriction on how long they remain in the UK, and have been ordinarily resident in the UK or another European economic area country for the preceding three years - provided none of this time was just to receive full time education.

Home students' tuition fees are assessed according to their income and that of their family. As a rough guide, the maximum tuition fee contribution expected from students in 2000/1 is £1,050.

Students on a full- or part-time course of initial teacher training (other than first degree course) receive free tuition regardless of income.

Non-repayable help is targeted at: students with disabilities and dependents; those entering HE from care; and, from 2001/2, those entering HE from low income families in inner city areas. Help is also available from universities and colleges for students who get into financial difficulties.

Scotland

From this academic year, students will no longer pay up-front fees at any Scottish higher education institution, if they are a) normally domicile in Scotland, or b) members of the European Union ("normally domicile" refers to anyone considered a resident of Scotland for tax purposes).

English and Welsh Europhobes may be cheered to learn that they are not considered members of the European Union - at least, not in terms of paying fees in Scotland. English and Welsh domiciles are subject to fees as under the English and Welsh system.

If a student has been residing in Scotland for more than one year prior to taking up their studies, he/she is considered to be Scottish for the purposes of assessing fees, etc.

However, if a parent is working on a full-time, permanent contract outside of the UK and EU, and/or has been living outside the UK and EU for more than three years, they are deemed to be an overseas student.

Next academic year, Scottish and EU students will be eligible for bursaries and mature student bursaries for students living and studying away from home. This depends on family income - from the full £2,000 bursary, plus a student and additional loan (of £500) for those whose income falls within £10,000-£15,000 pa to the maximum parental income of £45,000 and a minimum bursary of £750.

Scottish and EU students who begin their academic studies in 2001 will be expected to contribute to the graduate endowment scheme (this will be in 2004/5 when they graduate). This is equivalent to 9% of salary once in full time employment.

Northern Ireland

As in the case of England, Wales and Scotland, determining whether a student will be treated as a home or an overseas student depends on residency of at least three years within the UK or EU. Like England and Wales, there are tuition fees for higher education and a similar system is followed.

The level of fees for overseas students is, however, decided by the two universities in northern Ireland - Queens University, Belfast, and the University of Ulster. In both cases, overseas students' fees may be slightly less than the median across the HE sector, in order to encourage more people to study in the province. Students from China and India are particularly welcome. Where a large group of students from one country apply it may result in a generally-reduced rate.

Like other HE institutions, universities in Northern Ireland are keen to expand and develop overseas links in order to meet government targets for UK universities to attract a quarter of the world's share of international students by 2005.

webTitle: Furthermore: Like a whirlpool, it never ends

fields.headline: Like a whirlpool, it never ends
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock finds himself caught in a revolving problem
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock finds himself caught in a revolving problem
fields.body:
I should have known better than to tempt fate and dash into college through the newly installed revolving doors. These are part of a major improvement of the reception area, designed to make the college look like a bank. The whole project, involving beech veneer, bent chrome and purple, wedge-shaped sofas aims to be modern and forward-looking. All a bit Bradford and Bingley meets BUPA if you ask me.

Then it happened again. I was trapped in the revolving doors. Others came in past me through the adjacent sliding doors and stared. My mate Colin from maths tapped my glass cell and made goldfish faces at me.

I waved to get the attention of the receptionist. She smiled, picked up the telephone, laughed for a couple of minutes into the handset and finally came over to the door.

"My scarf is stuck and it looks like I've buggered up the mechanism," I said calmly.

"Was it you who did the same thing last week?" she asked slowly with exaggerated lip movements.

"Yes. Are they coming to rescue me?"

"The premises staff are at full stretch this morning. They have logged you as an incident and will get to you shortly."

For what seemed like a very long time I was incident number 457, left to ponder whether the previous 456 incidents had happened over the year, this month or this week. And I was getting later for my meeting with the cross-college marketing task force committee.

The fruits of this committee's regular brainstorming sessions were all around me as I stared hopefully into the foyer. There is the electronic message board with its blinking smiley face icons. After a bunch of smiley shapes have finished forming a pyramid and the word WELCOME comes up, a list of today's cancelled classes take over for the next five minutes. It's like being at a railway station.

On the purple sofas in the waiting area a group of students sat and stared in my direction. Noticing that one of them was checking his text messages, I realised that I could use my mobile phone to contact the outside world. I tapped in Murray Whelk's extension number to apologise for being late for his meeting. It bounced me to reception.

"You are in a queue, someone will be here to free you shortly," said the receptionist. I watched her say it.

"How did you know it was me?" She was about to put the phone down without answering. "I was trying to get Murray Whelk's office."

"You can't. There's a fault on the line. It has been reported as an incident and someone will attend to it in due course," she said.

"Why am I waiting so long?"

"You'll have to ask Mr Whelk about that," and she rang off.

Then Travis, one of the building supervisors, arrived with a bag of tools. But he didn't get me out. He was on his way to an earlier incident involving a Pot Noodle vending machine and a Belgian coin.

"I've met me target 'cause I've seen you inside half an hour and I've made an assessment of the situation," he said walking off towards the cafeteria.

"So, what's your assessment?"

"You can wait. The college doesn't revolve around you."

Are they coming to rescue me?" "The premises staff are at full stretch this morning. They have logged you as an incident and will get to you shortly." For what seemed like a very long time I was incident number 457, left to ponder whether the previous 456 incidents had happened over the year, this month or this week. And I was getting later for my meeting with the cross-college marketing task force committee. The fruits of this committee's regular brainstorming sessions were all around me as I stared hopefully into the foyer. There is the electronic message board with its blinking smiley face icons. After a bunch of smiley shapes have finished forming a pyramid and the word WELCOME comes up, a list of today's cancelled classes take over for the next five minutes. It's like being at a railway station. On the purple sofas in the waiting area a group of students sat and stared in my direction. Noticing that one of them was checking his text messages, I realised that I could use my mobile phone to contact the outside world. I tapped in Murray Whelk's extension number to apologise for being late for his meeting. It bounced me to reception. "I was trying to get Murray Whelk's office." "You can't. There's a fault on the line. It has been reported as an incident and someone will attend to it in due course," she said. "Why am I waiting so long?" "You'll have to ask Mr Whelk about that," and she rang off. Then Travis, one of the building supervisors, arrived with a bag of tools. But he didn't get me out. He was on his way to an earlier incident involving a Pot Noodle vending machine and a Belgian coin. "I've met me target 'cause I've seen you inside half an hour and I've made an assessment of the situation," he said walking off towards the cafeteria. "So, what's your assessment?" "You can wait. The college doesn't revolve around you."

webTitle: Rostrum: Consider the training at work

fields.headline: Consider the training at work
fields.standfirst: Private trainers need public cash and a level playing field too, Mr Blunkett says  Sylvia Merris-McDonald
fields.trailText: Private trainers need public cash and a level playing field too, Mr Blunkett says Sylvia Merris-McDonald
fields.body:
The recently announced plans to support vocational training Centres of Excellence are welcome. The provision of widely available, high quality, workplace delivered vocational training will help ensure that increasing numbers of young people and adults within the workforce can access relevant lifelong learning opportunities.

However, the Association of Learning Providers (ALP) believes that ringfencing these resources for further education colleges may not be the best way of ensuring participation by the groups concerned. Work-based training providers - private, voluntary and charitable sector - have unparalleled access to UK workplaces, acting as the de facto training/human resources department for hundreds of thousands of small and medium enterprises. This puts them in the best position to deliver the governments inclusion agenda.

Currently work-based providers deliver learning opportunities to over 300,000 young people per year via TECs and LECs, and to over 700,000 adult learners - the majority pursuing work-based, vocational qualifications - through college franchises. This represents the lion's share of the success of the widening participation agenda.

Therefore we believe that the DfEE could increase the value-for-money from public resources by providing increased support for the work-based sector. This need not require committing significant additional resources, but could be effected by delivering some of the promises of a "level playing field" made in the "Learning to Succeed" White Paper and the subsequent development of the new Learning and Skills Council.

This could be done first by ensuring the recently announced 9% increase in funding for the work-based sector that currently contracts with TECs is fully realised in the new unit price being developed under the LSC funding formulae. Providers can then ensure this is passed on to trainees in increased levels of support and not eaten up by ringfences and unachievable increases in volume.

Second, by ensuring that the first steps towards a level playing field for all post-16 providers are taken in the next contract year, and not delayed until after August 2002. A simple step would be to allow work-based providers to directly access limited volumes of support for trainees over 25 years of age. Currently this is restricted to colleges, or available only under heavily discounted college franchises. Collectively we could use this support to bring large numbers of new employees, with few or no formal qualifications, into learning.

Third, to ensure that the new funding formulae being developed for the sector do not have perverse consequences. It appears from the early draft that one of the unforeseen consequences may be the marginalisation of tens of thousands of the most vulnerable trainees who are pursuing non-framework based NVQ qualifications under the inspired title of "Other Training", and decreased participation levels for young people aged between 19 and 24.

Finally by establishing a Standards Fund - along the lines of the one available to further education- for work-based learning providers, to help support the quality of delivery and to stimulate new and innovative working practices in the sector.

In summary the Association of Learning Providers would like to work with the DfEE to fully realise the lifelong learning agenda and to materially add to the achievement of national learning targets. Learner choice and achievement can best be achieved by supporting and stimulating the whole work-based vocational training sector rather than favouring any single element within the mix of provision.

 Sylvia Merris-McDonald is press and communications officer for the Association of Learning Providers, is an alliance of national training associations and training providers which, between them, deliver 80% of work-based, vocational learning across the UK .

webTitle: What big game is David Blunkett hunting?

fields.headline: Wild idea
fields.standfirst: What big game is David Blunkett hunting?  Simon Midgley  finds out
fields.trailText: What big game is David Blunkett hunting? Simon Midgley finds out
fields.body:
Was David Blunkett simply trying to get a response from his dog Lucy? His allusions to a wildcat certainly left humans baffled at the Association of Colleges annual conference in Harrogate.

The education secretary was answering questions after his speech. What was being done to get employers ready to receive students that colleges were training? At which point, Blunkett cited the US Wildcat programme. For most of his audience he might just as well have mentioned the beast of Bodmin.

Lewisham College's principal, Ruth Silver, however, knows this mysterious beast. Her college in south-east London has been piloting a British version of the programme with a group of unemployed ethnic minority women from Deptford.

And some of her staff have popped over to the States to observe the American original. There, a whole pack of Wildcat programmes train unemployed people for specific jobs with specific employers - to be bank tellers with Citibank, for instance. Trainees in New York are prepared to pass the teller's exam in three months. So far the programme has a 100% pass rate and all trainees have been guaranteed jobs. The pass rate for the same exam among people who come straight off the street is as low as 2-3%.

By focusing exclusively on a specific job - rather than giving a broad education - the programme can achieve quick results. New York inner-city financial sector employers have found that the programme delivers people who can do the job and that retention rates are excellent.

Wildcat, one of the largest intermediary service providers in New York, has a wide range of programmes which vary from training people for street cleaning to training for jobs in the financial services industry with $28,000pa starting salaries.

Femi Bola, head of learning at work in Lewisham College, says the college started piloting this demand-led strategy for getting people into work, this summer.

With the help of the Wildcat organisation, which the government has brought to Britain to help implement New Deal, the college obtained descriptions of real vacancies for entry-level administrators from KPMG, the professional services company.

Bola then developed a course to provide the necessary skills for the job, eg Microsoft word, Excel, Access and Powerpoint, electronic diary management, communication skills, client focus and team working.

Out of 16 unemployed women who began the first nine-week course, 12 completed it. Eleven of these now have 16-week internship jobs with local companies. KPMG accepted six on internships. During the internships the employees are paid for four months by the college with the hope that in February they will be given jobs.

Bola says: "Whether they stay at KPMG or not, it's an experience that is going to enrich them and it will also change places like KPMG because they will have to think more widely about the kinds of people they employ.

"If you start with the employer and work backwards it works. I think it's good because it offers people a real opportunity to get a job. It's not just saying we will train you and then you take your chance in the open market."

webTitle: Ex-lecturer taps into a rich seam for her thriller plots

fields.headline: Colleges of crime
fields.standfirst: Ex-lecturer taps into a rich seam for her thriller plots, reports  John Crace
fields.trailText: Ex-lecturer taps into a rich seam for her thriller plots, reports John Crace
fields.body:
Malcolm Wicks can start opening the champagne. Sophie Rivers has moved on from William Murdock College in Birmingham to take a postgraduate degree at the University of the West Midlands. Never mind that Sophie and both institutions are entirely fictitious, her progression is still cause for celebration. Not only is it an acknowledgement that there is, as the government keeps telling us, a natural thoroughfare from further to higher education, it is, more importantly, an admission that furthereducation is beginning to get its house in order.

As well as being an English lecturer and work placement liaison officer, Sophie is an amateur private eye and in her last six outings has dedicated herself to uncovering murder, corruption and fraud in further education colleges. Her creator is Judith Cutler, who was herself an English lecturer at the Matthew Bolton College in Birmingham for over 28 years before she took early retirement in 1996, and she openly confesses that when she started writing the series two years earlier she didn't exactly have to look too far for her plotlines.

"When the colleges were incorporated in 1993, mischief was absolutely rampant within the sector," she says. "Almost every day we would get to hear of some new scandal. There was the principal and marketing manager of Stoke College who were found running a pub in Wales. There was the Catholic college in Birmingham accused of discriminating against Sikhs and Muslims. There was the college in Derby which bought a nightclub and where nepotism was rampant. There was the principal who operated by email out of his home in the West Indies. There was the principal who recruited dozens of overseas students, hired a hall of residence to house them, placed them in the college as home students and pocketed the difference. The list goes on and on; half the stuff I couldn't use because the readers just wouldn't have believed it and the books would have ended up more Tom Sharpe than mystery thrillers."

The stories may sound funny in the retelling, but Cutler finds them anything but. A college losing £11m may have a comic element, but the implications on innocent people's lives, homes and careers can be catastrophic. Despite the improvements, Cutler still doesn't believe that further education can be given a totally clean bill of health. Although former colleagues who have moved into managerial posts try to lace their conversations with positive spin, she still hears plenty of discontent from the grassroots. Mostly, though, it's about pay scales, administrative overload and conditions of service these days, rather than corruption on a grand scale, so in her latest outing, Dying by Degrees, Sophie has moved on to pastures new. Not that Cutler has had the courage to tell her sources that the move may be permanent. "They seem to like having someone on whom they can unload all their further education angst," she confides, "and I don't want to disappoint them."

Cutler started work in local government in the mid-60s. Her boss told her she would be bored to death within three months and suggested she teach at the local further education college. So she left her desk at 5.30 on a Thursday evening and at 9.00am the following morning she was teaching A-level English. "I can remember the first text I taught," she says. "It was a play called Tobias the Angel. I can't for the life of me remember who wrote it, though."

She spent many happy years at Matthew Bolton College, and it was only towards the end that things went pear-shaped. She was badly beaten up by a student after she ticked her off for jumping up and down in the lift, and, shortly after she returned to work a male student shoved his hand up her skirt as she was climbing the stairs.

"My initial response was to lash out," she says, "but I was suddenly aware that he and his friends could attack me, so I did nothing. In that same moment, I decided to take early retirement. I've heard the college has improved recently, but I've never wanted to go back." And neither, it seems likely, will Sophie.

 Dying by Degrees is published by Headline this week.

webTitle: Blunkett, sets out his programme for battling  illiteracy and innumeracy

fields.headline: David and Goliath
fields.standfirst: Secretary of state for education,  David Blunkett, sets out his programme for slaying the giants of illiteracy and innumeracy
fields.trailText: Secretary of state for education, David Blunkett, sets out his programme for slaying the giants of illiteracy and innumeracy
fields.body:
Millions of adults in this country have difficulty reading well or understanding maths. They struggle with everyday tasks like reading a bus timetable, following the instructions on a medicine bottle or managing the family budget. As a result, they are more likely to be unemployed or get stuck in low paid jobs. Many are unable to engage with their communities.

This is not unique to Britain, as the Florida recount debate highlighted on these pages recently showed. But we have a moral and economic imperative to do something about it. We cannot tolerate a situation in which millions of our fellow citizens lack the skills they need to play a full part in society, to obtain a job and help their own children to succeed.

We cannot hope to prosper in the global knowledge economy with such a long tail of weak skills in the workforce. So, in 1998, we promised to double the numbers taking part in basic literacy and numeracy programmes to 500,000 by 2002. We are on course to meet that target, with 390,000 adults participating this year. We are committed to spending at least £150m more a year on tackling this problem by 2003. Our new cabinet committee, the Ministerial Group on Adult Basic Skills, which met for the first time in November, has set a new target to reduce the overall number of adults with weak literacy and numeracy by 750,000 by 2004.

We need to ensure that this money will be well spent. Last year Sir Claus Moser's visionary report, A Fresh Start, spelt out huge weaknesses in the provision of adult basic education. Generations of neglect had meant that there were no clear standards, tests or basic curriculum for adult literacy and numeracy. Teachers were poorly trained, if at all. Government funding was uncoordinated. Despite the pioneering efforts of the Basic Skills Agency and others, no single body was in charge of the issue. There had never been clear national leadership to tackle the problem.

We are changing that. A new Adult Literacy and Numeracy Strategy Unit has been created in my department to develop and implement government policy. It will work closely with the Learning and Skills Council, which will have dedicated basic skills officers at local and national level. Targets will be set and progress against them clearly monitored.

Today we publish a paper that will lead to a comprehensive national strategy for tackling poor basic skills. I am seeking to consult widely, and invite views on all the issues involved. To ensure that we know what works best on the ground, there will be pathfinder projects in each English region, starting in March 2001.

These projects will test out key elements of the government's new policies: national standards and tests, a basic skills curriculum and training for teachers and volunteer mentors. We need to make a particular effort to reach key groups including those in low-skilled jobs or without work. Family literacy programmes will also help parents to help their children.

We need to be radical and imaginative. Adults want to study at times and in places that are convenient for them, so we will ensure that their learning choices are rich and varied. Teaching and learning will take place in libraries, schools, shopping centres and other community locations, as well as in colleges: diverse options for study, but always meeting high standards. We will also test new teaching materials that respond to people's interests, using hobbies and leisure interests in teaching materials to engage and interest people. And we will make use of IT as a gateway to literacy and numeracy skills.

Many people will readily admit to lacking IT skills, and the public appetite for them is strong, so we will harness the potential of new technologies in the pathfinders.

Trade unions and employers have a critical role in helping those in the workplace whose lack of basic skills undermines their productivity, and holds back improvement in economic performance. We will build on the success of the Union Learning Fund to expand the role of learning representatives in encouraging those who lost out the first time round to embrace learning as the route to security and progress at work. And Learndirect will work with employers, particularly small and medium sized ones, to ensure that their employees get access to cost-effective basic education.

We will also strengthen arrangements for "screening" those on New Deal programmes from next April. Those with poor basic skills will be referred to provision that is suitable for their needs. Those in receipt of Job Seekers Allowance need more help too. We therefore intend to test out whether incentives to participate in basic education will help these individuals get and keep jobs.

The adult basic skills problem is deep-seated, and is as great a challenge as the one we faced in improving primary school literacy and numeracy. But we have shown in schools that with determination and purpose, we can overcome the legacy of past failure. We need the expertise and energy of all concerned as we move to the next stage and prepare to launch a national crusade to tackle the problem. We will succeed if all those involved understand the scale of the task and work together to achieve our goals.

webTitle: Groundbreaking e-lecture on Second World War

fields.headline: War of the words
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod reports on a groundbreaking e-lecture on the German defeat in the 1939-45 war
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod reports on a groundbreaking e-lecture on the German defeat in the 1939-45 war
fields.body:
Today a new type of lecture is being delivered. You can hear it again tomorrow and the day after that if you are really keen. Niall Ferguson, Professor of Political and Financial History at Oxford University, is putting forward some provocative ideas about why Germany lost both world wars. But it is the accompanying technology of his "e-lecture" that its promoters hope will break new ground and find a place in the mushrooming world of webucation.

The student logs on to a website. The screen is split into four. Top left, there's the talking head; to his right, synchronised slides. Bottom right is a synchronised transcript, with embedded footnotes. And bottom left a lists of relevant web links.

For Richard Halkett, one of three founders of Boxmind.com, this kind of virtual publishing means the student can get the best of both worlds - hear the lecturer and study the subject on the printed page, pausing the lecture to pursue footnotes or web links.

"Any students can use it. We don't see ourselves as replacing existing institutions but supplementing them," said Halkett who, with two fellow Oxford graduates, got funding for the venture in April.

For instance, Ferguson shows how colossal the economic superiority of the Allies was in both wars, but also that in both wars Germany and her allies killed many more men than they lost.

Germany and her allies managed to kill 35% more of the other side than they themselves lost in the First World War: 5.4m compared with 4m. In the Second World War the percentage difference in - to use a macabre phrase - the net body count was a staggering 144%. Expressed as a ratio, the Axis out-killed the Allies by 2.4 to 1. And that takes no account of the fact that the majority of World War II fatalities were civilians. Here the net body count was even more awesomely in favour of the Axis: to the tune of 8 to 1.

Ferguson argues that that victory in war goes not to the side that kills the most men, but the side that persuades the other side to surrender.

It was mass surrender that signaled the end of the Russian war effort in 1917, the German war effort in 1918 and the French in 1940. Finally, it also signalled the end of the war in 1945. He asks if psychological warfare finally won the Second World War -by persuading Axis forces that surrendering was safe.

German and Japanese soldiers proved so reluctant to surrender even when it was obvious that they could not hope to win because in two key theatres of the war - the Eastern Front and the Pacific - surrender had become too dangerous.

A "take no prisoners" culture had taken root, which had its origins in the killing fields of the First World War, but which became official policy in a number of armies in the Second World War. Ferguson shows that the practice of "taking no prisoners" was well known to British soldiers in the First World War and Australian and American soldiers in the Second.

"The Marines' battle cry on Tarawa was 'Kill the Jap bastards! Take no prisoners!" In his diary of his experiences in New Guinea in 1944, the famous aviator Charles Lindbergh observed: "It was freely admitted that some of our soldiers tortured Japanese prisoners and were as cruel and barbaric at times as the Japs themselves. Our men think nothing of shooting a Japanese prisoner or soldier attempting to surrender."

webTitle: Fee debts are boosting the middle-class presence in the law

fields.headline: Brief triumph
fields.standfirst: Fee debts are boosting the middle-class presence in the law, says  Eileen Sheridan
fields.trailText: Fee debts are boosting the middle-class presence in the law, says Eileen Sheridan
fields.body:
Just when it looked as if the nation's legal profession was losing its stuffy middle-class image, the problem of funding for postgraduate studies may suddenly reverse the trend.

The jury is still out on this one, but both the Law Society and law colleges are concerned that working-class students, ethnic minorities and mature students may back off from becoming lawyers simply because of the cost.

The government's decision to cut funding at first-degree level poses a challenge for students who want to take on postgraduate law studies when they already have a debt mountain to their name. Unlike accountants and doctors, who have financial backing from their employers while they continue their studies, law students are largely left to shift for themselves.

About one-third of postgraduate law students are signed up either to big city law firms or barristers' pupillages and have their fees paid, but these are still most likely to be students from privileged middle class backgrounds, say experts in the field.

"Our statistical studies showed that the students who went to Oxbridge colleges were the ones who got their fees paid by firms," says the Law Society's equal opportunities spokesman Jerry Garvey, "whereas students from new universities and from more disadvantaged backgrounds, who are more likely to be mature students, women and ethnic minorities, have to find other means of finance. So it looks as though those bursaries and sponsorships which are available are going to students who don't necessarily need them."

Qualifying as a barrister or solicitor is a costly process. There are two routes in. Students can take law as a first degree and follow this up with a Legal Practice Certificate (LPC), which means a year's further study and a fee of anything up to £6,000. Graduates with degrees other than law - and 50% of big city firms recruit non-law graduates - have to take a Post Graduate Diploma in Law (PGDL) conversion course, with fees up to around £5,000, before they can study for their LPC. So fees alone can be as high as £11,000.

The Law Society's own Trainee Solicitor's Group under Aviva Gully mounted a big campaign to persuade the government to release funds to local education authorities so that some public funding was available for the less-well-off, but was met with a stony silence.

"The law has always had this image as expensive and the idea is that if you want to become a lawyer you come from a rich background and you don't need that extra help," says Garvey. And the struggles of self-funding students who have to work and study at the same time are reflected in their academic success.

"A disproportionate number of students who are working during their courses fail and have to take re-sits," he adds. "It is a very intensive course and if you are working as a security guard at night, say, then you can't devote as much time to your studies."

The University Careers Advisory Service has already noted that the number of mature students in all subjects is falling since the cut in funding for fees, and there is now a watching brief on how this will affect postgraduate student numbers.

Dick Lidwell, chair of the legal profession committee for the Association of Graduate Careers Advisory Services, says that postgraduate law student numbers are still holding up.

His message is to research the profession thoroughly: "Find out what the profession is and decide if you have the skills and interest before embarking on an expensive exercise and then not going into the profession."

Big city firms are looking for people with intellectual skills and strong personal skills which are supported by their extracurricular activities.

"It is also important to have good commercial sense," he says. "But if you want to be a high-street lawyer then you will need sensitivity and good interpersonal skills. Written and verbal skills are important for everybody."

A Law Society study showed that the biggest deciding factor in job success was work experience in the profession.

Law remains a popular option, and colleges are responding to the costs issue by means of their own. Britain's premier institution, the College of Law, which has campuses at London, Guildford, Chester and York, has a mission to provide legal training for students from all backgrounds.

The director at Guildford, Imogen Burton, says: "Ten to 15 years ago there was a lot more public funding from local authorities. This has all but dried up now. There are few sources of funding other than career loans from banks and sponsorship from the larger, mainly commercial firms.

"We are concerned particularly for students who want to specialise in other areas than corporate law."

The College of Law has negotiated preferential rate loans with NatWest Bank for students and offers flexible part-time training for LPC and PGDL courses. "Recently we have developed popular block weekend courses at our branches in Guildford, York and Chester to suit students who have to work to finance themselves."

And Burton is optimistic about the future: "New technology will help more students do more learning from home. The college is in the forefront of developing website and CD-rom learning."

webTitle: A radical plan to persuade job seekers to improve basic skills

fields.headline: Hidden benefits
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston  reports on a radical plan to persuade job seekers to improve basic skills
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston reports on a radical plan to persuade job seekers to improve basic skills
fields.body:
The government is considering withholding unemployment benefit payments from claimants with poor basic skills who refuse to get help with improving them.

The radical proposal is part of a new national strategy ministers hope will reduce the number of adults with poor literacy and numeracy by 750,000 by the year 2004.

In Guardian Further, the education secretary, David Blunkett, today outlines his strategy for helping the seven million adults officially reckoned to possess inadequate literacy and numeracy.

A new Cabinet committee, chaired by Blunkett, has been constituted to focus on the problem which ministers see as the next huge task, now that systems are in place to boost literacy and numeracy in primary schools.

The education secretary has laid out his consultation paper, Skills for Life, which he is publishing today - coincidentally designated Number Day as the culmination of the DfEE's Maths Year 2000.

The paper is the precursor for a "comprehensive national strategy for tackling poor basic skills". It outlines a package of "pathfinder projects" to be piloted in each region which will indicate to government which approaches would prove most effective.

Among these, ministers will be seeking to establish how best to help recipients of Job Seekers Allowance.

"We therefore intend to test out whether incentives to participate in basic education will help these individuals get and keep jobs," Blunkett says.

One way which could be explored could be to make payment of the benefit dependent on "willingness to improve basic skills", a departmental source said. This could be as simple as testing claimants and requiring those identified with inadequate literacy and numeracy to enrol for appropriate programmes.

The Moser committee, chaired by Sir Claus Moser, chairman of the Basic Skills Agency, debated the notion of linking state benefit payment to personal willingness to upgrade basic skills. Its subsequent report, A Fresh Start, published in March last year, which revealed that one adult in five in this country is not functionally literate, and an even grimmer picture for numeracy, stopped short of recommending any such connection.

"... benefit claimants are entitled to assessment of their basic skills and the offer of effective provision to improve their skills," it said. "Whether they take up the offer must, of course, be their own decision."

Earlier this year the Basic Skills Agency suggested that a straight cash payment of £100 would be the most effective inducement to motivate adults with poor basic skills to improve them.

Addressing the Agency's annual conference in Westminster yesterday, Sir Claus said he was very cheered that the government had attached great importance to the basic skills problem since his report, but that not enough had been done since then to help the adults concerned.

He said he hoped that the new national literacy and numeracy test announced a year ago by further education minister Baroness Blackstone would speedily be available.

Sir Claus called for a diversity of provision, because many adults with basic skills problems were unwilling to go to college for classes. Employers should be motivated to enable staff to improve literacy and numeracy, perhaps with financial assistance.

webTitle: What exactly is America's Ivy League

fields.headline: Ivy-clad elite
fields.standfirst: It's a byword for top-notch, but what exactly is America's Ivy League, asks  David Cohen
fields.trailText: It's a byword for top-notch, but what exactly is America's Ivy League, asks David Cohen
fields.body:
A trademark battle in the New Zealand courts has revived the intriguing question of whether many people outside the US fully understand what the term Ivy League really means.

In Wellington this month, the governing body of the group of elite American universities known as the Ivy League won a long-running case to keep its name sacrosanct after a New Zealand business tried to use the term to promote a new line of fashion accessories.

The high court in Wellington overturned an earlier ruling in January that had allowed the company Pacific Dunlop Asia to use Ivy League as the commercial name for its clothing, footwear and headgear.

Central to the judgment was the issue of name recognition. Pacific Dunlop first registered the words Ivy League for commercial purposes in New Zealand in 1996, claiming that it could not be proven that the term had any "strong and well-recognised brand" in New Zealand, or indeed anywhere outside of the US. The universities, represented by the Council of Ivy League Presidents, sued the company.

"The crucial point here is that Ivy League is not a generic term," said Allan Bowie, a lawyer and trademark specialist. "There are only a certain number of universities that can call themselves the Ivy League. They have an administration and the power to generate income through [their own] merchandise."

The court agreed, saying that the country had enough "well-educated people" for genuine confusion to be created over the origin of the merchandise.

As is the case in Britain, however, it is something of an open question how well the origins of the Ivy League, much less its present-day constitution, are understood by most antipodeans, well-educated or not.

The term is most often used as loose shorthand when referring to the most academically desirable and highly ranked among the 2000-odd institutions of higher learning in the US. But, strictly speaking, neither of these appellations are entirely accurate.

The eight private institutions covered by the term are, indeed, venerable, and all are located in the northeastern region of the US. They are Brown (in Rhode Island), Columbia (New York City), Cornell (upstate New York), Dartmouth College (New Hampshire), Harvard (Massachusetts), Pennsylvania (Philadelphia), Princeton (New Jersey) and Yale (Connecticut). Harvard was established in the 1600s, Cornell in the 1800s and the six others during the 1700s.

The origins of the name remain obscure, with the most likely guess being that it belonged to an old athletics competition between the institutions in the game which Americans still insist on calling football. Stanley Woodward, a reporter with the now-defunct New York Herald Tribune, probably coined the phrase for general usage in the early 1930s.

In 1945 the presidents, or vice-chancellors, of the eight universities signed an agreement for formal sporting fixtures between their institutions, which became a fully fledged league competition from 1953. Some of the sports still played competitively between them include baseball, fencing, ice hockey, squash and wrestling.

Big in terms of both their international reputation for academic excellence in the liberal arts and the size of their endowments - none of the Ivy League institutions have endowment assets worth less than $2bn, and many boast several times that amount - these universities are comparatively small in the numbers of undergraduate students they select. The largest, Cornell and Pennsylvania, enrol barely 10,000 undergraduates each, the others half that, and competition for places is predictably stiff.

While most dictionaries attach social and intellectual prestige to their general definitions of the Ivy League, the member institutions have not always fared so well when put under the microscope.

In recent years, the most widely-respected of America's annual league tables, published by the magazine US News & World Report, has included non-Ivy League universities in its top places - only six this year were drawn from the north-eastern stable.

Gordon Gee, president of Brown University and head of the Council of Ivy League Presidents, said he thinks "without a doubt there's a sense of complacency" in the Ivy League as a whole.

In addition to overseeing a number of academic and athletic issues between the member institutions, the council is registered for trading purposes as a non-profit organisation. As the New Zealanders discovered to their cost in early November, there remains nothing slack in the manner in which it jealously guards the high reputation its member universities still enjoy - even if everyone abroad might not always fully understand the finer details.

This year's US annual league table of top universities

Rank / University

1* / Princeton University

2*- / Harvard University

2*- / Yale University

4 / California Institute of Technology

5 / Massachusetts Institute of Technology

6- / Stanford University (California)

6-* / University of Pennsylvania

8 / Duke University (North Carolina)

9* / Dartmouth College

10* / Columbia University

* = Ivy League

Source: U.S. News & World Report

fields.headline: Modern times
fields.standfirst: Last week John Kay, the former director of Oxford's fledgling Said Business School, argued that the university's outdated structure was blocking the school's development. This week  Anthony Hopwood,  his successor, says Oxford is wary of change - but the new wins out in the end
fields.trailText: Last week John Kay, the former director of Oxford's fledgling Said Business School, argued that the university's outdated structure was blocking the school's development. This week Anthony Hopwood, his successor, says Oxford is wary of change - but the new wins out in the end
fields.body:
It is ironic that John Kay's recent criticism of the university comes just eight weeks after Oxford introduced a raft of fundamental reforms to its structures and operation. A new governance structure is already changing how decisions are made.

The financial implications of this have still to feed through, but no one need have any doubts that the changes now occurring are very significant ones. They are influencing the conduct of business and attitudes are changing. Indeed, the Oxford that I work in today is appreciably different from that which John Kay left 18 months ago. For a new department of the university like the Said Business School (SBS), such changes are important.

There is no doubt that these changes are facilitating the serious introduction of management studies into the university. Unlike the complex arrival of economics, the fraught introduction of medicine and the much contested recognition of English as a subject for teaching, management studies has had a much speedier and less contentious arrival.

In the past year alone, there has been a 30% increase in MBA students. In every year of the programme we have had one of the highest average GMAT entry scores in Europe. This year ten Rhodes Scholars are on the programme. Within one year we have had a 60% increase in companies recruiting at SBS. The undergraduate programme is now one of the most oversubscribed in the whole university and the faculty is expanding with appointments of international stature at all levels.

Areas of academic strength are already emerging. An extremely impressive new building is going up near the centre of the city. No one who knows Oxford could have imagined that within a few years management students would be at 29 of the university's 39 colleges with faculty at 22 and shortly at 26. Yet this is indeed the case.

No university has been without problems in establishing a business school, and it would have been foolhardy to expect the process of introducing a new subject into such an ancient institution to be completely unproblematic. Seen in these terms, there is no doubt that John Kay identified some key issues. Equally, however, very real progress has been made in tackling these and the substantial achievements of staff and students at SBS today demonstrate that John was wrong to contend that "creating an institution within Oxford which could compete with major international business schools was impossible".

The key to moving forward was to introduce the general possibility of flexibility across the whole university. That has been done at the professorial level and is also emerging for others.

The result is that this year we were able to make a number of high-profile appointments - including Professor Paul Willman, a senior academic from the London Business School, and Professor Steve Woolgar, the UK's leading authority on the impact of e-technologies.

Governance structures for the school similar to those desired by John Kay are now likely to be implemented with the enthusiastic support of some of the most senior people in the university. And the university's new management arrangements require rigorous strategic plans and operating budgets. Now, however, they are looking for more than just a vision. The new approach demands both a vision and an action plan simultaneously. And, of course, the technical planning for the operation of our new building is in hand. Consultants are being appointed and the school has just advertised for a director of operations. Overall a much more businesslike approach is evident.

A mass of other changes is transforming the University of Oxford. Real progress is being made, although in my mind it remains an open question as to whether the resolution of the specific problems cited by John Kay had to await the programme of reforms.

John Kay undoubtedly found working with the grain of a complex academic institution frustrating. Just before departing he had attempted to embody his frustration in a new definition of his role as "a non-executive Chairman Director". This would have enabled him to adopt an external focus for his role at Oxford whilst maintaining his consultancy, journalism and speech-making interests. But that redefinition was not acceptable to his immediate colleagues, senior and junior, and John departed.

He set in motion, however, processes that have resulted in the successful establishment of management studies in the university in an amazingly short period of time. Rather than striving for autonomy, SBS has started to develop the intellectual and practical linkages which its setting in a major international university enables, and from which the school itself and the wider university will inevitably benefit.

By hosting the Oxford Science Enterprise Centre, it aims to be a catalyst for the commercial development of scientific knowledge. The school wants to be known as one that takes science seriously. By building links with the law faculty, it wants to be in a position to play a role in the creation of the new bodies of knowledge that are emerging at the interface between law and economic management.

Starting to develop links with specialists in international relations and area studies, the school will provide a more substantive base for the study of business in its global context. The aim at Oxford is to have a business school that can relate to the wider university in a serious and productive way. This is now starting to happen.

John and I share the view that introducing management studies to Oxford is of real importance, not just to Oxford, but also to knowledge, to business and to the wider intellectual community.

When I was a member of the ESRC's Commission on Management Research a few years ago, I, along with all the other members, was amazed that no one could identify any significant British contribution to management knowledge since business schools had been established. All the major contributions had stemmed from university and similar departments outside the contexts of self contained business schools - the Aston School of contingency theory, the research of Joan Woodward at Imperial, research on product innovation and operations research at Sussex, socio-technical systems at the Tavistock Institute, and so on.

The key challenge at Oxford is to forge the basis for an intelligent business school - one that is known for what it knows. To do this, SBS needs the wider university and, in today's rapidly changing world, the university needs a business school. Undoubtedly a lot remains to be done to achieve such high goals, but it has now been accepted that the Said Business School should be in the intellectual and physical centre of the university. That is a major achievement.

webTitle: Grapevine: Amlwch primary school in North Wales

fields.headline: How fast can a centipede sprint?
fields.trailText: Amlwch primary school in North Wales
fields.body:
Last Saturday 12 children from Ysgol Gynradd Cemaes, a 100-pupil primary school at Amlwch in North Wales, were at Imperial College in London to be presented with prizes by Professor David Bellamy.

The Anglesey school has beaten 70 other Key Stage 2 groups from all over England, Wales Scotland and Northern Ireland to win the Ward Cup for their original, hands-on natural history project.

"We organised a minibeast race," explains Katie Halil, 11. "We worked with animals like earwigs, wood lice, ants, centipedes, millipedes and spiders. My job was to look after the earwig which we found near the posh plants at the school entrance," she says seriously.

The project was the idea of Raymond Reynolds, a retired headteacher who comes into Ysgol Gynradd Cemeas as a volunteer to help headteacher Richard Jones with non-National Curriculum extension work. "My aim was to make the children more aware and more respectful of wildlife," Reynolds says. "So few explore beaches or look at what's under their feet these days."

The challenge for Reynolds, who has been an enthusiastic naturalist and collector of natural history books since childhood, was to make studying minibeasts seem fun and modern. For Kim Latham, 10, who was in charge of an ant, animal welfare was paramount. "We found three of each animal so that they wouldn't be lonely and they wouldn't get tired. We raced each one once then worked out an average speed for that sort of creature." At the end the minibeasts were returned to the spot they'd been taken from.

The work was cross-curricular. "We timed the bugs with a stop watch and then made graphs," says Andrew Heathcot, 10. The children also used CDT skills to make an accurately-measured, dowelled racing board 90cm long with "slips" for animals to wait in before the race.

"My favourite bit was the art work we did," says Kirrie Roberts, 9. "I painted a picture of the place where we found the centipedes. It was full of dried leaves and I found it fascinating to look at." The children collaborated on a large poster which included a map of the school, their creatures, their habitats and some descriptive writing. They made models and a victor's wreath from material found in the habitat.

So what natural history did they learn? There was a chorus saying there are different sorts of ladybirds with varying number of spots, that an earwig's tail is designed to keep off predators and that a centipede has 32 legs not 100. "Making a passport for each animal put all the learning together," adds Reynolds.

The Ward Cup is one of several awards made annually by Blake Shield British Naturalists' Association Trust. The Imperial College ceremony is sponsored by Royal and SunAlliance. Fifty other sponsors, including RMC, Earthwatch Institute, Weetabix and a long list of publishers, help with prizes of books, posters, videos and T-shirts so everyone is rewarded as well as winning things for their school. Winning groups also get a sponsored residential field trip.

This year the Blake Shield - the Ward Cup equivalent for 11-16 year olds - has been won by Dulwich College Preparatory School, London, for a detailed investigation into the stomata on different leaves and their role in disease.

The scope of Blake Shield BNA Trust is growing. This year there is a prize for a sixth-former for a wildlife photograph or art work and an accompanying essay. Next year there is to be a trophy sponsored by Anglian Water for a group wildlife project for 5-7s.

So who won that nail-biting race in Anglesey? The centipede. It covered 90cm in eight seconds.

fields.headline: A lucrative line
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod  and  Nick Tester  on new ways of making universities pay
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod and Nick Tester on new ways of making universities pay
fields.body:
Tory proposals to privatise universities by endowing them with massive funds from the sale of mobile phone licences are being studied seriously by vice-chancellors.

The former Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals, now renamed Universities UK, has, until now, been scornful of the idea proposed by the Conservative leader, William Hague. Even Oxford and Cambridge, which already have considerable private endowments, have been sceptical. But the vice-chancellors decided in a meeting last Friday that the endowment plan should be investigated properly alongside a series of funding options they are weighing up in the approach to the expected general election. These include tripling tuition fees for wealthy families, letting universities charge their own top-up fees and the sort of graduate payments introduced in Scotland after the Cubie report.

In the Tory pre-election manifesto in September, Hague said that money from government auctions such as the £20bn sale of mobile phone licences would be used to set up a series of endowment funds for individual universities across Britain. The universities would not be allowed to touch the capital, but they would be allowed to use the interest "to make whatever financial arrangements they like".

The proposal, entitled Recovering Excellence, would give British universities the financial freedom to restore their reputation as the finest higher educational institutions in the world, he said. Universities would be able to set their own pay rates "to attract the world's best academics and researchers" - but they would not be allowed to set their own rate for tuition fees. A Conservative working group under MP Oliver Letwyn is developing the proposal.

Endowments were a prudent use of future one-off capital receipts. "They represent better value for money than simply putting those receipts into paying off government debt because, invested in universities, they would generate a better return than the rate of interest on government debt."

The vice-chancellors want to be in a position to respond to any proposals from a position of knowledge, said Sir Howard Newby, president of Universities UK. They are working out costing for options and also researching student attitudes to debt before formulating options acceptable to the next government.

British universities came under attack last week for the high fees they charge Commonwealth students.

The Commonwealth Education Ministers' triennial conference in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada, aired resentment at the treatment of students from poor countries in contrast to the low-cost fees enjoyed by European Union students and warned students would look elsewhere - either to degrees in other Commonwealth countries or to e-learning courses.

The "astronomic" rise in fee charges for foreign students "helped weaken the shared commitment to and appreciation of Commonwealth values," said Commonwealth secretary-general Don McKinnon. UK universities ignored the issue at their peril, he said, with "daunting consequences" for future recruitment levels.

Legally, EU students are treated as home students when it comes to paying fees and are liable only for the means-tested £1,050 fee in contrast to the full-cost fees charged to overseas students which range from £5,000 a year for an arts degree to £14,500 for medicine.

A high proportion of an estimated 350,000 overseas students now studying in the UK are doing so as a result of a European Union agreement. The 45 education ministers (representing countries with about one-third of the world's population) agreed to expand its scholarship and fellowship scheme dramatically.

Secret talks between Commonwealth leaders, Hewlett-Packard and Pearson in Halifax last week resulted in a £850m deal. Pearson has extensive experience in producing education materials for teachers and students, and ministers hope the venture will transform the chances of millions of potential learners in the world's most deprived parts.
