webTitle: How do you manage university with a child?

fields.headline: Who  cares?
fields.standfirst: Lifelong learning is the big buzz word - but what if you've got a child?  Kate Coxon reports
fields.trailText: Lifelong learning is the big buzz word - but what if you've got a child? Kate Coxon reports
fields.body:
When Amanda Williams (see below) began the final year of her BA degree with a four-month-old baby, there was no nursery on her campus and no childcare places in the area. She had two options: she could drop out, or she could take her baby into lectures and classes for a year, and do all her work at night. She chose the second route, went on to get a first and is now doing a part-time PhD.

According to the Daycare Trust, the majority of UK universities and colleges feel there is not enough childcare provision at their institution to meet demand. While around 71% of institutions offer some provision, more than 40% were aware of students needing to drop out because of a lack of, or difficulties with, childcare. Most have long waiting lists and many parents who need a childcare place have difficulty getting one.

For students who do succeed in finding childcare, the next problem is paying for it. Although many institutions with childcare provision offer subsidised rates to students, if there are no spaces they have to look elsewhere. With a full-time place in a private day nursery costing between £80 and £200 a week, it is not surprising that student parents face greater hardship than almost any other category of students.

Earning extra money by taking paid work in the evenings or holidays is often not an option for students with children.

Measures announced by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, to widen access to higher education and tackle student hardship are coming into effect this present academic year. Full-time mature students, especially those with children, are one of the groups being targeted for help.

A means-tested non-repayable access bursary of up to £1, 000 to help mature students with dependent children with costs such as childcare and travel is available, and there is a new means-tested grant towards children's school meals.

Mature students will also no longer be required to take out a hardship loan before receiving assistance from a hardship fund, which is non-repayable. The amount of income which mature students can have disregarded when they are assessed for entitlement to student support has been increased from £820 to £7,500.

But discretionary grants - such as access and hardship funds - are problematic for student parents. It is difficult to budget if you don't know how much you are going to get or when. Payments are often one-off lump sums, and parents are usually billed monthly for childcare.

Students are unable to claim the Childcare Tax Credit, paid to low-income working families on Working Families Tax Credit, worth up to £70 a week for parents with one child and £105 for those with two or more children. But from 2001, a new Childcare Grant of up to £100 per week per child will be introduced for student parents, largely replacing the £1,000 bursaries. It will be means-tested and based on actual childcare costs.

As yet, little is known about the grant, but if it follows the form of the Childcare Tax Credit as is suspected, it will pay only for registered childcare costs and will exclude informal childcare provided by friends, relatives and other non-registered carers.

Yet many student parents depend on informal childcare or a mixture of formal and informal childcare arrangements. Lone parents in particular are known to use higher levels of informal childcare. They are also likely to experience the greatest hardship of any students, according to research by Professor Claire Callendar, professor in social policy at South Bank University.

Margaret Creear, of the lone parents' organisation Gingerbread, says: "Educational opportunities are immensely important to enable lone parents to break out of the benefits trap, and we need to be flexible in supporting those lone parents who do enter higher education."

Postgraduates and part-time students (excluding trainee teachers) cannot apply for the childcare grant, or many of the other measures.

According to Jeremy Hoad of the National Postgraduate Committee: "Childcare costs represent a significant barrier to the increasing numbers of graduates wishing to retrain after starting a family. Postgraduates are also not eligible for student loans and this seems directly at odds with the lifelong learning agenda."

The traditional image of student life does not include babies in lecture halls. There is also arguably a difference between being poor without family responsibilities, and raising a family on £20 a week, as one student I spoke to did. But unless childcare provision is increased and students are given the means to afford it, many parents won't make it as far as the lecture hall.

A double life

Amanda Williams, 28, is a part-time PhD student in an arts-related field at a university in the south-west of England. She has a four-year old son. As a part-time student and lone parent, she is able to claim income support, but has been able to study only because her department set up a hardship fund to pay for her son's playgroup fees before he became eligible for a free nursery place.

As an undergraduate, the problem was no childcare. As a postgraduate student parent, what I really notice is the grinding poverty.

I had to apply for a social-fund loan because we couldn't afford to eat and this is now being deducted from my benefits. I can't afford books or attend conferences, and I need an internet connection to work from home, which costs. There is an incredible gulf between my academic and my social status - as a lone parent on benefits, you're at the bottom of the pit. This is my route out of the poverty trap and I'm grateful, but there must be thousands of other lone parents who just can't afford to study.

Kirsty Bauckham, 35, is in the second year of a computing degree at Oxford Brookes and is president of the Sprogs society. She is a single parent with one daughter, Natalie, seven.

I used to work at the University of Kent in Canterbury - it was a dead-end job and a computing degree was something I wanted to do for myself. I only had one O-level, so I did an access course to get into Oxford Brookes.

My daughter was due to start school when I began my degree, so the first thing was finding her a place. But you couldn't get a school place until you had fixed accommodation: I approached the university accommodation office, hoping there'd be somewhere in halls for student parents. They were quite negative and sent me off to Oxford Brookes housing association, who help students who can't get places in halls.

The day before the summer term finished they rang and said they'd found me somewhere, so I rushed around looking at schools and chose the one nearest to the university. The school gates open at 8.50am, so I drop her then run up the hill for 9.00am lectures.

After a while of paying a standard rent I discovered the university does have three student-parent flats in halls, and one came up and I got it for £1,300 a term - though unfortunately it's six miles from the campus.

At the university they have a financial aid office who've helped out with £1,100, non-repayable, this year. I get a student loan of £3,790 a year, and a dependent's grant of £3,175 a year from LEA, and work a few hours a week to earn extra.

The university does have a nursery, but Natalie is too old for it - if I have a late lecture I pay for her to go to an after-school club. Oxford Brookes has a fantastic half-term playscheme for older children, though.

The daily nursery doesn't open until 8.45am and closes at 5.10pm: it needs to be open longer. We also need more student-parent flats. My biggest fear now is that next year the computing department is moving to another campus seven miles away - so all the parent students will be late for lectures. Nine o'clock is a bad starting time for anyone with children.

Siobhan McSorley, 22, graduated this year with a 2.1 in Sociology and Anthropology from Oxford Brookes University. She is a lone parent and has a four-year-old daughter, Billie.

I had Billie before I went to university, and this influenced the course I chose and the university. I knew that I had to get on a course at the university in my home town as without a partner I would need my parents' support in looking after Billie. I was lucky, as Brookes has a nursery, which charges on a sliding scale, and there was a place. Brookes also has Sprogs - a group for student parents which organises activities for children and gives you contact with other parents. I also took a job in the student union bar so I could meet people. But if I hadn't had my parents to look after Billie I would have been paying all my wages straight to a childminder.

Although many institutions with childcare provision offer subsidised rates to students, if there are no spaces they have to look elsewhere. With a full-time place in a private day nursery costing between £80 and £200 a week, it is not surprising that student parents face greater hardship than almost any other category of students. Earning extra money by taking paid work in the evenings or holidays is often not an option for students with children. Measures announced by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, to widen access to higher education and tackle student hardship are coming into effect this present academic year. Full-time mature students, especially those with children, are one of the groups being targeted for help. A means-tested non-repayable access bursary of up to £1, 000 to help mature students with dependent children with costs such as childcare and travel is available, and there is a new means-tested grant towards children's school meals. Mature students will also no longer be required to take out a hardship loan before receiving assistance from a hardship fund, which is non-repayable. The amount of income which mature students can have disregarded when they are assessed for entitlement to student support has been increased from £820 to £7,500. But discretionary grants - such as access and hardship funds - are problematic for student parents. It is difficult to budget if you don't know how much you are going to get or when. Payments are often one-off lump sums, and parents are usually billed monthly for childcare. Students are unable to claim the Childcare Tax Credit, paid to low-income working families on Working Families Tax Credit, worth up to £70 a week for parents with one child and £105 for those with two or more children. But from 2001, a new Childcare Grant of up to £100 per week per child will be introduced for student parents, largely replacing the £1,000 bursaries. It will be means-tested and based on actual childcare costs. As yet, little is known about the grant, but if it follows the form of the Childcare Tax Credit as is suspected, it will pay only for registered childcare costs and will exclude informal childcare provided by friends, relatives and other non-registered carers. Yet many student parents depend on informal childcare or a mixture of formal and informal childcare arrangements. Lone parents in particular are known to use higher levels of informal childcare. They are also likely to experience the greatest hardship of any students, according to research by Professor Claire Callendar, professor in social policy at South Bank University. Margaret Creear, of the lone parents' organisation Gingerbread, says: "Educational opportunities are immensely important to enable lone parents to break out of the benefits trap, and we need to be flexible in supporting those lone parents who do enter higher education." Postgraduates and part-time students (excluding trainee teachers) cannot apply for the childcare grant, or many of the other measures. According to Jeremy Hoad of the National Postgraduate Committee: "Childcare costs represent a significant barrier to the increasing numbers of graduates wishing to retrain after starting a family. Postgraduates are also not eligible for student loans and this seems directly at odds with the lifelong learning agenda." The traditional image of student life does not include babies in lecture halls. There is also arguably a difference between being poor without family responsibilities, and raising a family on £20 a week, as one student I spoke to did. But unless childcare provision is increased and students are given the means to afford it, many parents won't make it as far as the lecture hall. A double life Amanda Williams, 28, is a part-time PhD student in an arts-related field at a university in the south-west of England. She has a four-year old son. As a part-time student and lone parent, she is able to claim income support, but has been able to study only because her department set up a hardship fund to pay for her son's playgroup fees before he became eligible for a free nursery place. As an undergraduate, the problem was no childcare. As a postgraduate student parent, what I really notice is the grinding poverty. I had to apply for a social-fund loan because we couldn't afford to eat and this is now being deducted from my benefits. I can't afford books or attend conferences, and I need an internet connection to work from home, which costs. There is an incredible gulf between my academic and my social status - as a lone parent on benefits, you're at the bottom of the pit. This is my route out of the poverty trap and I'm grateful, but there must be thousands of other lone parents who just can't afford to study. Kirsty Bauckham, 35, is in the second year of a computing degree at Oxford Brookes and is president of the Sprogs society. She is a single parent with one daughter, Natalie, seven. I used to work at the University of Kent in Canterbury - it was a dead-end job and a computing degree was something I wanted to do for myself. I only had one O-level, so I did an access course to get into Oxford Brookes. My daughter was due to start school when I began my degree, so the first thing was finding her a place. But you couldn't get a school place until you had fixed accommodation: I approached the university accommodation office, hoping there'd be somewhere in halls for student parents. They were quite negative and sent me off to Oxford Brookes housing association, who help students who can't get places in halls. The day before the summer term finished they rang and said they'd found me somewhere, so I rushed around looking at schools and chose the one nearest to the university. The school gates open at 8.50am, so I drop her then run up the hill for 9.00am lectures. After a while of paying a standard rent I discovered the university does have three student-parent flats in halls, and one came up and I got it for £1,300 a term - though unfortunately it's six miles from the campus. At the university they have a financial aid office who've helped out with £1,100, non-repayable, this year. I get a student loan of £3,790 a year, and a dependent's grant of £3,175 a year from LEA, and work a few hours a week to earn extra. The university does have a nursery, but Natalie is too old for it - if I have a late lecture I pay for her to go to an after-school club. Oxford Brookes has a fantastic half-term playscheme for older children, though. The daily nursery doesn't open until 8.45am and closes at 5.10pm: it needs to be open longer. We also need more student-parent flats. My biggest fear now is that next year the computing department is moving to another campus seven miles away - so all the parent students will be late for lectures. Nine o'clock is a bad starting time for anyone with children. Siobhan McSorley, 22, graduated this year with a 2.1 in Sociology and Anthropology from Oxford Brookes University. She is a lone parent and has a four-year-old daughter, Billie. I had Billie before I went to university, and this influenced the course I chose and the university. I knew that I had to get on a course at the university in my home town as without a partner I would need my parents' support in looking after Billie. I was lucky, as Brookes has a nursery, which charges on a sliding scale, and there was a place. Brookes also has Sprogs - a group for student parents which organises activities for children and gives you contact with other parents. I also took a job in the student union bar so I could meet people. But if I hadn't had my parents to look after Billie I would have been paying all my wages straight to a childminder. (Some names have been changed)

fields.headline: Shining example
fields.standfirst: Last week, 38 new 'Beacon' schools were created. So, what's so great about them, and can they really help bad schools get better?  Phil Revell  reports
fields.trailText: Last week, 38 new 'Beacon' schools were created. So, what's so great about them, and can they really help bad schools get better? Phil Revell reports
fields.body:
The roof may be leaking and the staffroom is short of bodies, but one thing schools have in abundance is government initiatives. From the first days of the Thatcher reforms, teachers have dreaded the arrival of the latest ringfile binder. National curriculum documents, action zones, specialist schools, fresh start, sure start, excellence in cities, literacy and numeracy - all were heralded with the same relentlessly positive prose, arranged around colourful pictures of teachers working with improbably small classes in new buildings.

Literacy and numeracy initiatives were prescriptive in the extreme. Teachers were told how and what to teach with timings down to the last minute. Last week's Ofsted report on the National Literacy Strategy would seem to justify the approach. It hailed the "transformation" of reading standards in primary schools, alongside improving results in maths.

But lost in the arguments between Chris Woodhead and David Blunkett over exactly who could claim credit for the literacy strategy was the education department's announcement of 38 new Beacon schools. This is an initiative with a difference.

"It's the best thing to come out of the DfEE in ages," says Anna Kendall, headteacher of Christchurch primary school in Chelsea, which has been given £37,000 to promote best practice in its area. Teachers can visit Christchurch to see how a successful small primary school approaches things like literacy and numeracy. The money pays for cover staff for both schools. "Now that good schools have got the literacy and numeracy initiatives under their belts they are in a position to do something for others," says Kendall.

Beacon schools were launched by the then Schools Standards minister, Stephen Byers, in 1998. They were to be "centres of excellence committed to sharing the secrets of their success ... a guiding light for others to follow." The profession reacted with weary cynicism. Teachers' associations bemoaned the prospect of successful schools being rewarded with more money while struggling schools were named and shamed.

But a National Foundation for Education Research (NFER) evaluation of the first Beacon schools found that something strange was happening: "Many of the early achievements of Beacon schools are not ones which were necessarily fully anticipated." The researchers found that schools soon got over their worries about elitism and got on with something they had longed to do for years - visiting other schools to see successful teachers teach.

Moat Farm junior school in Sandwell is one of the most successful schools in the country. Educational establishment of the year in 1999, the school won an "Oscar" for its ICT in last year's teaching awards and head Malcolm Chesney has been one of the select few invited to Highgrove House to discuss education issues with the Prince of Wales.

"We became a Beacon school after a visit by Chris Woodhead," says Chesney. "He assumed we were one already." The oversight was soon remedied and Moat Farm received the letter from Michael Barber at the DfEE inviting it to apply.

Teachers at Moat Farm are used to rubber-necking visitors and there was already a relationship with a school in special measures. "What was willingly done before is now paid for," says Chesney. Along with other Beacon school heads he was sensitive to the possibility that other schools might resent both the Beacon status and the suggestion that they needed a hand up from their neighbour. "There could have been resentment, but it didn't happen," he says. "The process works both ways. Our staff have learnt a lot as well, they come back with ideas." Chesney argues that the opportunity to see other teachers put initiatives into practice is invaluable and far more useful than the usual methods of in-service training, which generally involve a course, a power point presentation and a lot of theory. "I'd rather see people go out and spend a day in another school than go on a course," he says.

It's a view echoed by Sue Wood at Girlington primary school in Bradford, an inner city school with a predominantly Muslim intake. "It's very powerful to bring people into a real situation," she says. Girlington always had an open door policy, but the Beacon funding has allowed Wood to make the visits more worthwhile. Teachers get some time to put the lesson into context, then they observe and afterwards they can talk things through with the classroom teacher.

"It's not about sitting down and being lectured," says Wood. "It's not 'This is how you should do it' - it's 'This is how we do it'. We've never said that we are the best school; we're still working hard to raise standards ourselves."

Experts in school improvement have seen this practical school-based training as one of the strengths of the programme. "This is a powerful way to deliver good practice," says Peter Early, reader in education management at London's Institute of Education. "Coaching is one of the most effective forms of training."

Teachers' time for professional development is woefully limited, with just five days a year set aside for training, most of which is taken up with whole school issues. Individual training often has to take place in twilight sessions at the end of the school day. "One of the real constraints on the profession is the limited time for professional development," Early argues. But he is concerned about what happens to visiting teachers inspired by their visit to a Beacon school. "Does it get followed up?" he asks. "What happens to those teachers when they return to their schools?"

The answer isn't clear. Beacon schools do have to submit an annual report and the DfEE says that partner schools are asked for their assessment of the usefulness of the link. But heads have remarkable freedom to shape the initiative. "Nobody is telling me how to do it," says Kendall. "It's up to the head. Nobody has come back and raised value-for-money issues."

For David Hart, at the National As sociation of Head Teachers, that remains one of the scheme's weaknesses. "The concept is perfectly sound, but the practice leaves something to be desired," he argues. Indeed, there doesn't appear to be a great deal to stop a Beacon school from taking the money without doing much to assist its neighbours. According to the NFER evaluation, one school spent its allowance on ICT equipment - ostensibly to facilitate communications with partner schools - whilst another used the cash to finance closer links with its feeder school.

The three Beacon schools highlighted here have all spent most of their additional budget on cover. Wood uses it to fund supply teachers whilst Kendall has hired a part-time teacher to provide cover for staff out of class on Beacon duties - a move which means that children have a familiar face to take over when their regular teacher is missing. Chesney has appointed a Beacon co-ordinator who regularly spends time at Moat Farm's partner school.

One head of a secondary school with links to another Beacon school, however, believes little of benefit has actually resulted. "We're in the same market competing for the same kids," he says. "They're not really going to ignore that." He shares with other heads the concern that Beacon status is likely to make a school even more attractive to parents and that neighbouring schools are likely to suffer as a result.

Hart emphasises the point. "The majority of heads would want to disseminate good practice," he says. "But there's an inherent conflict between spreading good practice and the market forces approach." Few schools are happy about their best staff being away from lessons for too long.

Primary schools are to some extent insulated from the competitive market that dominates secondary schooling and there's a clear impression that it is the primary sector which has made the most of the Beacon school programme. With no free periods, primary teachers have grabbed the chance to leave their classrooms and visit other schools. Beacon primaries the Guardian has spoken to have been inundated with requests.

"There is a question about how you maintain your own standards whilst helping other people," says Kendall. "But this is a real model for staff development. I dread losing the money; it has made an enormous difference to the way we work." Kendall stresses the way the programme has put teachers in charge for the first time since the reform process started. She has been allowed to structure the programme to suit the needs of her school and visiting teachers can set their own agenda.

It's a far cry from the didactic, prescriptive approach teachers have endured for so long. "Perhaps we're being trusted," she says.

webTitle: When tragedy strikes, how do headteachers cope

fields.headline: Softly, softly
fields.standfirst: Inside the school gates, 600 shocked pupils. Outside, press and politicians demanding answers. When tragedy strikes, how do headteachers cope, asks  John Crace
fields.trailText: Inside the school gates, 600 shocked pupils. Outside, press and politicians demanding answers. When tragedy strikes, how do headteachers cope, asks John Crace
fields.body:
A week ago, 10-year-old Damilola Taylor was murdered on his way home from an after-school computer club. Three days earlier, five A-level students from King Edward VI College in Nuneaton were killed in a car accident. This isn't the way a life story is supposed to end and, thankfully, for most of us it doesn't. But early death is nowhere near as uncommon as we might like to think.

In 1998, 7,487 young people in the UK aged 19 or under died prematurely through illness, accident or murder. This figure is no statistical anomaly, and it doesn't take a genius to work out that, over the course of a five-year period, few schools will escape losing at least one of their pupils. The potential for anxiety, grief and disruption among both staff and children is self-apparent and yet there are few protocols for handling such a situation.

The National Union of Teachers issues no guidelines whatsoever, while the best the DfEE can offer is a few general emergency procedures that includes the catch-all "schools have sometimes found it helpful to contact local community support services and to seek professional advice". In other words, it's up to schools to make it up as they go along.

On the day after Damilola Taylor was murdered, the Oliver Goldsmith school in Peckham, south London, was besieged by journalists and TV crews who remained encamped outside the gates for the next four days. The head teacher, Mark Parsons, appeared in a state of shock as he was ambushed into making an unprepared statement to TV, and by the end of the week Southwark education authority made a point of taking him out of the firing line, and left Bola Ogun, chair of governors, to deal with the media fallout.

"We're all in a state of shock," said Ogun. "Staff and pupils still can't comprehend what's happened and it's almost as if they're hoping they will wake up and feel it's been a bad dream. The media have been very difficult to deal with; some journalists have tried to get into the school without authority and others have offered children up to £200 for a photo of Damilola's classroom.

"The bullying issue has made things even worse. Damilola's brother and cousin talked through what had happened with Mark on the day after the murder, and I think they were comforted that the proper procedures had been observed. We have a duty to protect the children in our care, but Damilola needed wider protection from society. Something went tragically wrong and it is the school that is wrongly being held to account."

Keith Butterworth, principal of King Edward VI College, knows how Ogun feels. He found himself totally unprepared for some of the consequences of the car accident. "We've had hate mail, the receptionist has been abused by an anonymous caller, we've had a video and charity box stolen by someone who reckoned we'd be preoccupied elsewhere and we've had journalists ringing up pretending to be members of staff," he says.

Butterworth's first step was to work closely with the police to deflect as much attention from the families and the college as possible. "We arranged for a press conference for the Monday morning, so we could release a prepared statement and so members of staff and students wouldn't be met by the press on the way into college," he continues. "We also held a meeting of staff, students and governors on the Sunday, during which we decided to cancel lessons for Monday and make Tuesday a half day. In their place we organised a series of tutor groups where students could come to the college, talk things over and leave messages for the families"

The college was also closed last Friday. "We initially did this as a mark of respect to remember the event a week on," he says, "but it's turned out to be a good idea in other ways, as we had all underestimated just how physically and emotionally exhausting the week would be." The college is also alert to the long-term effects on the students, and universities and exam boards have been asked to take the accident into consideration over the course of the coming year.

The possibilities for getting it wrong are endless. A south London primary school was devastated at the start of this term when it discovered that one of its children had drowned on holiday. The school decided to hold an assembly to mark the young girl's death and to allow the other pupils the opportunity to express their own feelings of grief for her. "It was embarrassing at times," said one of the teachers. "One of the boys who spoke in front of the whole school said, 'She was a bit of a slag, but I'll miss her,' while one of the girls started talking about how she had been bullied by this girl."

Children have not yet learnt the adult language of obsequy and sometimes have little concept of an appropriate response to death. Similarly, they may well struggle to come to terms with what it means: younger children may just see it in cartoonish Tom and Jerry images, while older kids frequently interpret death as punishment and fear that if they behave badly they, too, will die. How then can you best contain a child's feelings?

"No one should ever try to normalise the death of a young person," says Julia Fabricius, director of the Anna Freud Centre. "It is a terrible event and it is important to stress just how terrible and unusual it is. Children should be given all the available information about what has happened, but shouldn't be forced to talk about it if they don't want to. Similarly, children should be offered counselling, but not be made to have it. There are a huge variety of responses to grief, and it's important to recognise that the normal grieving process can last for up to two years. So even if a child appears initially to be OK, teachers and parents should be alert for any changes in mood or behaviour."

How a school responds may well depend on how expected or unexpected the child's death may have been. In the course of the past three months, two children at Ysgol Dyffryn Nante, a Welsh comprehensive with just 430 pupils on register, have died of long-term illnesses. Both deaths were tragedies for their family and friends, but there was at least time to prepare.

"We'd had time to talk to the children about the possible outcomes," says head teacher Dewi Jones. "Cancer and death had been discussed as part of the personal health and social education syllabus, and connections had been made."

It was a very different matter, though, when a third pupil died suddenly a few weeks ago. "He went home from school laughing on the Friday afternoon," Jones continues. "The next day he had an asthma attack and died. I was extremely worried about what effect his death might have on the rest of the school - that the sight of his empty desk on the Monday morning might create a snowball of anxiety."

Over the weekend Jones contacted the local authority's director of education and they arranged for a Cruse-trained welfare officer and an educational psychologist to be present at the school first thing on the following Monday morning. The pupils were then told what had happened and were invited to talk to the two support staff if they felt like it. Some went in groups of 10, some in pairs, some singly; others declined the offer. "Everything was organised in consultation with the family," he continues. "We held a service for the whole school, and we arranged visits to the family for those who wanted to meet them. Both the pupils and the family found this very helpful and on the day of the funeral the whole school stood in the field beside the road as the procession went past."

One woman who knows rather more than she would want to about child death is Daryl Peek, the former head teacher of Northbourne Church of England primary school. In 1996, one of her pupils was brutally murdered in an attack that made front page news. Josie Russell survived, but both Megan and their mother died. Like Keith Butterworth at King Edward College, she too found the intrusion of the media hard to handle. "We couldn't function as a school," she says. "We were besieged by reporters and photographers and many of the children were extremely frightened."

Peek had been informed of the murders on the previous night, and had called in Kent LEA, which sent two educational psychologists to the school to help cope with the situation when the news was officially released.

"We decided to tell the children everything, so they wouldn't feel excluded," she says. "Our main focus, though, was to help them deal with it in their own way and to explain that there was no right or wrong way of feeling upset. "We also explained that it was OK to carry on laughing, and that they needn't feel guilty if they did."

Importantly she also recognised that some children might have ambivalent feelings for Megan and Josie, and in order that these could be expressed appropriately she suggested they be written down and then burnt.

The lasting effects of such traumas on children are hard to gauge. All one can confidently predict is that the better the school copes with the situation, the less the long-term impact. There are plenty of professionals with experience of dealing with these problems. So why has no one yet thought of asking them to work together to produce a definitive set of guidelines for all schools?

Do the right thing

Suggested guidelines for schools, written by the Candle Project, part of the St Christopher Hospice, which works with bereaved children in south-east London.

 Communicate with other parents. They will hear from their children; it will come better as a letter from you.

 Talk to the child's parents. Would they like the school to collect cards, letters etc from pupils, staff and other families and deliver or send them on? When appropriate, ask the family how they feel about pupils, family and staff attending the funeral. Keep them informed of what is happening at the school.

 Meet as a staff group, even if you only have a short time. Is there anyone in the staff group who finds this particularly upsetting? Bereavement brings up strong emotions for everyone.

 Think about how you will mark the event in school: maybe a special assembly or meeting with children in their tutor groups. Allocate a quiet corner or room, where children can go if they need to leave lessons and ensure it is staffed. Think about cover for the staff who are particularly affected by the child's death; they may also be the ones sought out by the most distressed pupils.

 Arrange a further staff meeting within a week to monitor things.

fields.bodyText: A week ago, 10-year-old Damilola Taylor was murdered on his way home from an after-school computer club. Three days earlier, five A-level students from King Edward VI College in Nuneaton were killed in a car accident. This isn't the way a life story is supposed to end and, thankfully, for most of us it doesn't. But early death is nowhere near as uncommon as we might like to think. In 1998, 7,487 young people in the UK aged 19 or under died prematurely through illness, accident or murder. This figure is no statistical anomaly, and it doesn't take a genius to work out that, over the course of a five-year period, few schools will escape losing at least one of their pupils. The potential for anxiety, grief and disruption among both staff and children is self-apparent and yet there are few protocols for handling such a situation. The National Union of Teachers issues no guidelines whatsoever, while the best the DfEE can offer is a few general emergency procedures that includes the catch-all "schools have sometimes found it helpful to contact local community support services and to seek professional advice". In other words, it's up to schools to make it up as they go along. On the day after Damilola Taylor was murdered, the Oliver Goldsmith school in Peckham, south London, was besieged by journalists and TV crews who remained encamped outside the gates for the next four days. The head teacher, Mark Parsons, appeared in a state of shock as he was ambushed into making an unprepared statement to TV, and by the end of the week Southwark education authority made a point of taking him out of the firing line, and left Bola Ogun, chair of governors, to deal with the media fallout. "We're all in a state of shock," said Ogun. "Staff and pupils still can't comprehend what's happened and it's almost as if they're hoping they will wake up and feel it's been a bad dream. The media have been very difficult to deal with; some journalists have tried to get into the school without authority and others have offered children up to £200 for a photo of Damilola's classroom. "The bullying issue has made things even worse. Damilola's brother and cousin talked through what had happened with Mark on the day after the murder, and I think they were comforted that the proper procedures had been observed. We have a duty to protect the children in our care, but Damilola needed wider protection from society. Something went tragically wrong and it is the school that is wrongly being held to account." Keith Butterworth, principal of King Edward VI College, knows how Ogun feels. He found himself totally unprepared for some of the consequences of the car accident. "We've had hate mail, the receptionist has been abused by an anonymous caller, we've had a video and charity box stolen by someone who reckoned we'd be preoccupied elsewhere and we've had journalists ringing up pretending to be members of staff," he says. Butterworth's first step was to work closely with the police to deflect as much attention from the families and the college as possible. "We arranged for a press conference for the Monday morning, so we could release a prepared statement and so members of staff and students wouldn't be met by the press on the way into college," he continues. "We also held a meeting of staff, students and governors on the Sunday, during which we decided to cancel lessons for Monday and make Tuesday a half day. In their place we organised a series of tutor groups where students could come to the college, talk things over and leave messages for the families" The college was also closed last Friday. "We initially did this as a mark of respect to remember the event a week on," he says, "but it's turned out to be a good idea in other ways, as we had all underestimated just how physically and emotionally exhausting the week would be." The college is also alert to the long-term effects on the students, and universities and exam boards have been asked to take the accident into consideration over the course of the coming year. The possibilities for getting it wrong are endless. A south London primary school was devastated at the start of this term when it discovered that one of its children had drowned on holiday. The school decided to hold an assembly to mark the young girl's death and to allow the other pupils the opportunity to express their own feelings of grief for her. "It was embarrassing at times," said one of the teachers. "One of the boys who spoke in front of the whole school said, 'She was a bit of a slag, but I'll miss her,' while one of the girls started talking about how she had been bullied by this girl." Children have not yet learnt the adult language of obsequy and sometimes have little concept of an appropriate response to death. Similarly, they may well struggle to come to terms with what it means: younger children may just see it in cartoonish Tom and Jerry images, while older kids frequently interpret death as punishment and fear that if they behave badly they, too, will die. How then can you best contain a child's feelings? "No one should ever try to normalise the death of a young person," says Julia Fabricius, director of the Anna Freud Centre. "It is a terrible event and it is important to stress just how terrible and unusual it is. Children should be given all the available information about what has happened, but shouldn't be forced to talk about it if they don't want to. Similarly, children should be offered counselling, but not be made to have it. There are a huge variety of responses to grief, and it's important to recognise that the normal grieving process can last for up to two years. So even if a child appears initially to be OK, teachers and parents should be alert for any changes in mood or behaviour." How a school responds may well depend on how expected or unexpected the child's death may have been. In the course of the past three months, two children at Ysgol Dyffryn Nante, a Welsh comprehensive with just 430 pupils on register, have died of long-term illnesses. Both deaths were tragedies for their family and friends, but there was at least time to prepare. "We'd had time to talk to the children about the possible outcomes," says head teacher Dewi Jones. "Cancer and death had been discussed as part of the personal health and social education syllabus, and connections had been made." It was a very different matter, though, when a third pupil died suddenly a few weeks ago. "He went home from school laughing on the Friday afternoon," Jones continues. "The next day he had an asthma attack and died. I was extremely worried about what effect his death might have on the rest of the school - that the sight of his empty desk on the Monday morning might create a snowball of anxiety." Over the weekend Jones contacted the local authority's director of education and they arranged for a Cruse-trained welfare officer and an educational psychologist to be present at the school first thing on the following Monday morning. The pupils were then told what had happened and were invited to talk to the two support staff if they felt like it. Some went in groups of 10, some in pairs, some singly; others declined the offer. "Everything was organised in consultation with the family," he continues. "We held a service for the whole school, and we arranged visits to the family for those who wanted to meet them. Both the pupils and the family found this very helpful and on the day of the funeral the whole school stood in the field beside the road as the procession went past." One woman who knows rather more than she would want to about child death is Daryl Peek, the former head teacher of Northbourne Church of England primary school. In 1996, one of her pupils was brutally murdered in an attack that made front page news. Josie Russell survived, but both Megan and their mother died. Like Keith Butterworth at King Edward College, she too found the intrusion of the media hard to handle. "We couldn't function as a school," she says. "We were besieged by reporters and photographers and many of the children were extremely frightened." Peek had been informed of the murders on the previous night, and had called in Kent LEA, which sent two educational psychologists to the school to help cope with the situation when the news was officially released. "We decided to tell the children everything, so they wouldn't feel excluded," she says. "Our main focus, though, was to help them deal with it in their own way and to explain that there was no right or wrong way of feeling upset. "We also explained that it was OK to carry on laughing, and that they needn't feel guilty if they did." Importantly she also recognised that some children might have ambivalent feelings for Megan and Josie, and in order that these could be expressed appropriately she suggested they be written down and then burnt. The lasting effects of such traumas on children are hard to gauge. All one can confidently predict is that the better the school copes with the situation, the less the long-term impact. There are plenty of professionals with experience of dealing with these problems. So why has no one yet thought of asking them to work together to produce a definitive set of guidelines for all schools? They will hear from their children; it will come better as a letter from you.  Talk to the child's parents. fields.headline: Internet know-how
fields.standfirst: Subscription services
fields.trailText: Subscription services
fields.body:
A couple of weeks ago, I received an email from Rhys Evans, who has come up with a simple, effective and free service for teachers - a weekly email called News from Everywhere. In Evans's own words, it "presents facts and asks questions" and "challenges some of the assumptions behind the mainstream media". Last week NfE , which you can subscribe to, tackled children's rights, BSE, nuclear power, workaholism, language and biodiversity. All are good jumping-off points if you have to plan a timely assembly, are worried about the demands of the new citizenship element of the National Curriculum or teach sociology, business studies or geography.

It's also a service you can recommend to pupils, especially those with a slow net connection or those who need to save money on phone bills by reading emails offline. Guardian Unlimited puts out its own round-up of daily news, the Wrap. A teacher once told me that the best way to achieve a high grade in A-level general studies was to read the broadsheets every day. If that's true, the Wrap should certainly be on the syllabus.

If you'd like your news in French, the newspaper Libération sends out a weekly summary which might even tempt students to read the full text online. Germany's Der Spiegel sends out a similar daily email which can be ordered. Students of Russian and Chinese can keep up with local events via EINmedia.

Science students, meanwhile, can receive New Scientist's outline of "the hottest stories" each week - look for the small box on the top right-hand corner of the page. A-level candidates in economics and business studies can sign up for FT.com's daily briefings, but some students may have to lie about their age, as only those born before 1975 can join FT.com's registration system.

There is an email discussion group for secondary maths teachers, although I couldn't find free services for other teachers. If you are aware of any, let me know - they could become a site of the day on Education Unlimited. Lastly, don't forget to check the small print on sign-up forms or you may receive an unexpectedly large portion of spam.

Next week: Troubleshooting

webTitle: Long Welsh words could be road hazard

fields.headline: Long Welsh words could be road hazard
fields.trailText: The language which includes some of the world's longest words is threatening to cause problems because drivers might take too long to absorb new electronic warning signs.
fields.body:
The language which includes some of the world's longest words is threatening to cause problems because drivers might take too long to absorb new electronic warning signs.

The potential danger on motorways in Wales has prompted the Welsh assembly to commission scientific tests on the likely impact of planned bilingual text. Academics at Leeds University's institute of transport studies are using driving simulators to see how quickly drivers take in a message like: "Slip roads at next five junctions closed because of fog and flooding" when screened in Welsh and English.

The fears follow government approval of new Variable Message Signs on British motorways, with up to four lines of illuminated electronic text. The screens are the direct result of the need for complex, lengthy and changing messages on motorways, with which conventional painted signs cannot cope.

"But when a message gets too long people slow down, and that can be dangerous," said Fergus Tate, who is running the project with Oliver Carsten.

Repeating an already long message in another language is exacerbated by the fact that Welsh and English share the Roman alphabet. Tests at Leeds with a tachistoscope - an instrument for measuring how much the eye can absorb in very small units of time - suggest drivers could delay potentially fatally while disting-uishing between the two.

The worst case scenario involves the first Anglesey exit of the A5 dual carriageway - to Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch.

fields.headline: A porn reader
fields.standfirst: Should we care that a porn baron has become a press baron? When Richard Desmond bought the Express, Jeanette Winterson bought some of his other titles. Here, she unpicks the message in the magazines.
fields.trailText: December 5 2000: Should we care that a porn baron has become a press baron? When Richard Desmond bought the Express, Jeanette Winterson bought some of his other titles.
fields.body:
When was the last time you looked at a girlie magazine? We see them subliminally every time we walk into a newsagent and we think we know enough to talk about them even when we never open one. My own view was fairly relaxed until I spent the weekend in the company of The Best of Big and Black, Only 18, 40 Plus, X-treme, Nude Readers' Wives, Forum and The Very Best of 50 Plus.

Feminism seems to have had no effect on pornography. There is much more of it than in the 60s and 70s, and it has become both mainstream and acceptable. I travel a lot, here and abroad, and at airports and railway stations, I have noticed the old top shelf is often double the size and halfway down. What does this signify? That more men buy porn than ever before? That men are shorter than they used to be? That women want it in their face? That pornography is just a lifestyle magazine?

Reading the message is not easy. In the white corner are the likes of Andrea Dworkin and Catharine MacKinnon who have argued, with varying degrees of success, in the American courts and media, that all pornography is violence against women. In the red corner are the good-time guys, such as Hugh Hefner, Paul Raymond, Richard Desmond, who claim it's just business as usual and the girls enjoy it. Desmond has recently bought the Express, further blurring the line between business and exploitation. When a porn baron takes over a national newspaper, how do we read the signs?

Desmond would argue, as they all do, that there is no exploitation. The sex industry fulfils a need and pays a wage. We won't go into the differential between how much most of the women are paid and how much most of the men make, as photographers or agents or publishers. Even if the women took their real share of the money, the industry is still an exploitative one. Why? Because it exploits every woman on the planet. The majority of women do not want to pose for sleazy magazines, nor do they want to be thought of in those terms. I know men claim they can think of their wife in one way and a sex model in quite a different way, but the message is uniform. This is what women are for. Take their clothes off and they're all the same. They want sex all the time. They want it from strangers. They want it from you.

I know two men who use pornography regularly. One travels home on the same train as I do and sometimes I have to sit next to him. I am often the only woman in the small first- class carriage and the camaraderie of pinstripe and gin and tonic is stifling enough, without having Hustler by my elbow. The man is discreet, he is polite, but it makes me uncomfortable. I told him so on one occasion and he said, kindly: "It's not about you."

The second man I know through his girlfriend. She feels undermined by the magazines by the bed, but can't say anything because she'll lose him. He tells her she's not liberated and doesn't have a sense of humour. What's interesting is that her despair and my discomfort are dismissed by both men as our problem. Pornography is not the problem. We are.

This is the message of the magazines. Far from being sex that dare not speak its name, and hiding in a brown wrapper, soft porn is as ordinary as a page three girl. The success of the pornographers has been to use their nursery vocabulary - "romp", "giggle", "tease", "tug", "playful", "girls", "bounce", "cuddly", "toy", "spank", "naughty" - as a defence as well as a turn-on. There's nothing threatening here. It's just a "frolic".

Mixed in with the nursery is the adolescent graffiti of toilet walls - "horny", "wank", "pussy", "cum", "spunk", "tit", "suck", "hole". It's as easy to read as a tabloid headline and about as intelligent. Before I'm told I shouldn't be taking my brain to bed, let me say that none of the women in the magazines I've read this weekend has any brains - or maybe their brains are removed for the photographs and put back afterwards. I couldn't care less about naked women all over the place - a woman's body is never offensive - I care that these women are made to look stupid, sound stupid and act stupid. That's what's degrading - not waving your arse in the air, but being turned into a stupid cunt.

Sorry for the language but how often do you hear it on the streets? Now you know why.

Let's look at the pictures. There's not a lot of variety. How can there be? Once you've shot it every way up, a body is just a body. To disguise this sameness, and to justify the growing quantity of porn, the titles become the most inventive thing in the magazine. What's the difference between 40 Plus and 50 and Over? There isn't one. What does Nude Readers' Wives have that X-treme doesn't? Nothing.

Weirdly, porn-lingo is always ahead of porn-pics in selling the stuff. It's rather like the way kids love to repeat the first handful of words they learn. The vocabulary of shelf-porn is dick-shrinkingly tiny, but it's a multiple orgasm to pornographers and their readers. Take away the titles and suggestive coverlines, and I would defy anyone to tell which magazine they are looking at.

For me, the most disturbing element in all the drying sameness is the shaved pubic hair. How many women actually shave their pubic hair? According to the sex mags, all of us. In real life, the only females without pubic hair are little girls. Do you remember the story of Ruskin's impotence? The only naked women he had seen before his marriage were Greek statues and they, of course, are hairless. When he got married, he recoiled in horror from his wife's bush and never went near her again. Are our private parts so scary that we either have to turn them into pre-pubescent fantasies or preparation for the operating theatre?

The lesbians are no different. That is, the tease-lesbians who take up an astonishing amount of bed-space in men's porn. Men are threatened by lesbians - they get on in the world and they might get off with your wife. In porn-land, lesbians are safe sex-toys, who blither about how much better it is with a boy on hand (or somewhere) and act about as aroused as a castrated guinea pig. They always have lots of floppy blonde hair. They have long fingernails, too, which tells me they never put themselves where a man has right of way.

Right of way is what porn-land is all about. It may be that men's insecurity in a changing world, where their role and power has been reduced, prompts the need for a fantasy world that offers itself as reality. A world where men are on top. A world where sex-barter is the only exchange between men and women. It's a comforting, closed world where women are at once everywhere and excluded. It's a conservative world, where for all the panting poses, there is neither freedom nor change.

Week after week, it's the same old stuff, and I don't mean the women, I mean the way they are represented. Women change. Pornography stays the same. At least heterosexual porn does. The battle to get gay porn in the high street is not about morals, it's about what upsets existing fantasies. It's fine to see women playing at being lesbians, but what if they really fancy each other? Anyone who has looked at gay men's porn will realise what's radical about it is the self-conscious theatre. Nobody pretends it's real life. Queers don't need to prop up assumptions of male and female, so when it comes to sex, we know how to have fun. If you're a porn-reading straight male, that's even worse than having to deal with a real woman.

It looks like those mad old feminists were right after all. That top shelf isn't about sex, it's about power.

It's fine to see women playing at being lesbians, but what if they really fancy each other? Anyone who has looked at gay men's porn will realise what's radical about it is the self-conscious theatre. Nobody pretends it's real life. Queers don't need to prop up assumptions of male and female, so when it comes to sex, we know how to have fun. If you're a porn-reading straight male, that's even worse than having to deal with a real woman. It looks like those mad old feminists were right after all. That top shelf isn't about sex, it's about power.

fields.headline: Maurizio Pollini
fields.standfirst: Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.trailText: Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.body: When he exploded on to the international scene 30 years ago, Maurizio Pollini played lots of Schumann - Etudes Symphoniques, the F sharp minor Sonata, the C major Fantasy - and played it peerlessly, combining rigour and imagination in exactly the right proportions. Since then, in his London appearances at least, he has tended towards other composers, especially Beethoven, but in his two recitals at the Festival Hall this season he has returned to Schumann, and to some neglected pieces at that. Next April he is due to play the early Allegro Op 8 alongside Kreisleriana; here he gave a rare outing to the Concert sans Orchestre, also known as the Sonata No 3 in F minor, Op 14. It is a strange work, both wonderful and unsatisfactory, another part of the great outpouring of piano music from the late 1830s, when Schumann was forcibly separated from Clara Wieck. He later revised and expanded it, but Pollini played the first published version in three movements built around a central set of variations on a theme by Clara herself - the emotional heart of the work. The first movement is an embattled conflict between Schumann's natural flights of fantasy and his determination to tackle sonata form, the finale a brilliant Presto, written as a tribute to the great virtuoso Moscheles, and as demanding as anything he wrote. The F minor Sonata is the kind of piece that needs a Pollini, someone to take a grip on the structure yet master all its technical challenges, and he did exactly that. It had been prefaced by more Schumann, the Davidsbundlertanze, in which Pollini had seemed surprisingly nervous, pushing through lyrical movements when they cried out for expansiveness, never allowing the effect of one magical phrase to settle before launching into the next, and sometimes understating the melodies that well up beneath dazzling figuration. Liszt followed. The B minor Sonata - prefaced by a pair of the late short pieces, Nuages Gris and La Lugubre Gondola, long-time Pollini favourites - was immense, ferociously precise, intense and insistent in the slow movement, and superhumanly fast in the climactic double fugue, a performance of take-it-or-leave-it integrity. The encores were Chopin - the D minor Prelude, glittering, turbulent; and a Nocturne, sung with wonderful purity of line. Altogether one of Pollini's finest recent London recitals.

fields.headline: Django Bates
fields.standfirst:
Nottingham University
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Nottingham University
Rating:*****
fields.body: For Django Bates, the jazz composer and keyboard wizard, music has always been a playground. At Nottingham University, his darting right hand reeled off convoluted fragments of blues, jazz and classical virtuosity, while his left hand flicked knobs and pulled levers on a strange tower of gadgets beside him. The box of tricks oozed an enthralling barrage of electronic textures, inspiring Bates to lean into his microphone and make noises like a panting dog. In the midst of this bewildering blur of movement, he somehow found time to do a silly little dance and to conduct the band with a desperate flailing arm. Strictly speaking there are two bands - Bates's Quiet Nights and the Smith Quartet - though they were seamlessly fused together inside Bates's gurgling tapestry of sound. Centre stage was Swedish singer Josefine Cronholm, who captivated with a pure and ethereal voice. The two violins, viola and cello of the Smith Quartet alternated between classical lyricism and edgy "Theme from Jaws" style modern scraping. A jazz trio of saxophone, bass and drums completed the picture, these being the components of Bates's group Quiet Nights. They played a range of pieces: some familiar, some strange and some familiar but seriously messed with. Into this last category must fall Paul Anka's My Way, which featured a rapping bass player, jungle rhythms and a ridiculously knotty arrangement. This music was a psychotic jigsaw which dissected and fused together swing, rock, free jazz, chamber music and the greatest hits of the BBC Radiophonic Workshop. Through it all what was most striking was Bates's use of juxtaposition and contrast, and his constant thwarting of expectations. When the quartet glided smoothly, the keyboards were spiky and neurotic. When the electronic ambience washed in, the saxophone and drums twittered anxiously. Heart-wrenching emotions were conjured up in near silence, and mad, free-style instrumental aggression had the audience shouting with laughter. Bates himself was warm and genial, and his cohorts were having such a good time that their faces glowed with pleasure. This was modern ensemble playing of the highest calibre, contemporary composition at its most vital, and a thrilling show not to be missed.

fields.headline: E*TRADE launches self-select Isa
fields.trailText: Online investment house E*TRADE has launched a self-select maxi ISA which will let investors channel their stocks and shares purchases into a tax-free wrapper, thereby maximising returns.
fields.body:
Online investment house E*TRADE has launched a self-select maxi ISA which will let investors channel their stocks and shares purchases into a tax-free wrapper, thereby maximising returns.

Because it is self-select, investors can have complete control over what goes into their ISA, picking and choosing only the shares they want. As such, E*TRADE hopes it will appeal to the 88% of adults who, in a recent NOP-commissioned study, said they would like more control over their finances.

Wannabe-investors will need to be financially savy enough to know which shares to pick, but E*TRADE is confident that its educational information, content and tools will help investors make decisions.

Changes can be made with self-select ISAs: you can buy and sell shares throughout the year, changing the content of the ISA and bypassing the requirement that you only take out one ISA with one provider in any given year. Problem is, at £14.95 a trade, too many changes would start getting expensive.

However, any changes you do make will be instant. Your new purchase will be confirmed and your portfolio updates as soon as the trade goes through.

The online share dealing market has been growing exponentially recently. Abbey National subsidiary Aitken Campbell recently announced an online operation which will charge between £10 and £45 per deal and which will differentiate itself from its rivals by being one of the few services to list investor names on the shareholder register of the firms they invest in.

Most online share dealing services use anonymous nominee accounts, which means investors don't always have access to the full range of shareholder services.

But whilst companies are falling over themselves to offer online services, how many people will use the services is less clear.

The findings from a joint survey by Egg and Mori suggests finance companies still have a long way to go if they are to convince the majority of the population of the virtues of online personal finance.

Banking looks set to be the most popular online financial service, with just under a quarter of the population saying they would feel comfortable accessing their bank account on the net.

Whilst 22% would consider buying a mortgage over the internet whilst buying insurance and making online investments appeals to only 19% and 15% respectively.

That being said, people often surprise themselves once they are online and start buying products and services which they did not intend to use. For example, 18% of respondents said they intended to use online banking when they first connected to the net.

In reality, 22% of cyber-surfers use online banking, suggesting that 4% of new internet users only saw the attraction of the service once they were online.

It's a similar story with digital TV. Most people get it so they can watch more channels, but once it's installed, they start accessing other services. Some 3% of respondents said they intended to use their TVs for banking when they bought them: 4% actually do.

Generally speaking, suppliers of digital TV services should be more worried about take-up as the survey also uncovered a preference for using PCs. Egg says: "Despite it being the more familiar interface, people are generally less comfortable with the idea of receiving such services via their television than via their PC."

But this could just be beginner's nerves. Egg continues: "This possibly reflects their relative unfamiliarity with the technology, rather than a more general apprehension of the product. If digital TV penetration climbs to levels comparable with the internet, it may become a much more widely accepted channel for these services."

Either way, the PC is currently winning the online financial services battle. Only 17% of respondents said they would be happy doing TV banking, compared to 24% happy to do PC banking.

It's a similar story with other financial products. Some 22% said they would search for a mortgage over the net, whilst only 16% they would use the TV. And while 19% said they would consider buying insurance through their PCs, only 14% said they would use the TV for the same service.

webTitle: Huge job losses if Abbey falls to Lloyds

fields.headline: Huge job losses if Abbey falls to Lloyds
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Up to 30,000 job cuts and more than 700 branch closures are in prospect if Lloyds TSB mounts a £20bn bid for Abbey National and prevents a union with Bank of Scotland, City sources calculated last night.
fields.body:
Up to 30,000 job cuts and more than 700 branch closures are in prospect if Lloyds TSB mounts a £20bn bid for Abbey National and prevents a union with Bank of Scotland, City sources calculated last night.

As Lloyds TSB's advisers were reported to have approached Abbey about talks over a possible deal, leading analysts estimated that it could save as much as £600m a year and effectively eradicate its prey's entire 30,000 workforce.

More conservative estimates put the job toll at 15,000. When Royal Bank of Scotland took over NatWest it admitted that 18,000 jobs would be shed.

In recent research, analysts at Merrill Lynch described the overlap between Lloyds and Abbey as "almost total". They concluded that the likely outcome was BoS would remain independent and Abbey be taken over by a "third party".

The political consequences of such job losses and the fact that a combined Lloyds and Abbey would have more than 30% of current accounts were said by one source to be a factor against Lloyds.

As speculation about Lloyds TSB's plans for Abbey mounted after the bank's late night emergency board meeting on Sunday, Abbey's shares jumped 41.5p to £11.45.

While Lloyds TSB refused to issue any statement about the outcome of its board meeting, speculation mounted that Lloyds had made tentative approaches towards Abbey, whose advisers are also talking to Bank of Scotland.

Abbey and BoS are trying to find a form of merger that would solve the sensitive issue of which bank's management should run a combined entity.

The management issue has been regarded as one of the main sticking points for a combination of Abbey and BoS, whose talks have failed to reach a conclusion after a month.

webTitle: B&B sellers settle for a windfall worth £609

fields.headline: B&B sellers settle for a windfall worth £609
fields.trailText: Carpetbaggers were disappointed yesterday after weak demand for Bradford & Bingley shares resulted in a windfall of just £610, rather than their earlier hopes of payouts above £800.
fields.body:
Carpetbaggers were disappointed yesterday after weak demand for Bradford & Bingley shares resulted in a windfall of just £610, rather than their earlier hopes of payouts above £800.

Just over 1m B&B account holders - 38.5% of the total eligible for shares - opted to sell immediately, and will be sent cheques for £609.65 (after a £10 dealing charge) next Monday.

The individual parcels of 250 shares per customer were sold at auction on Friday for 247.86p per share, and in first-day trading yesterday sank lower to end the day at 244p, valuing B&B at just below £1.7bn.

The price was well below analysts' expectations and fell short of the estimate earlier this year by B&B's adviser, Goldman Sachs, of a 259p-326p range, suggesting windfalls of up to £815.

The float leaves Nationwide Building Society as the only sizeable mutual lender, and yesterday it went on the offensive against B&B.

It said that the £610 windfall would be eaten up in just 13 months for someone with a £100,000 mortgage because of higher interest rates. When B&B was a mutual it maintained a low standard mortgage rate but has now raised it to match the level of the quoted banks.

Yesterday B&B's chief executive, Christopher Rodrigues, shrugged off the low float price, pointing out that the FTSE 100 index had fallen by 11% since the beginning of the year when the range was set. He said the volume of customers selling on the first day was unsurprising, given the closeness of Christmas, and was about average for building society floatations.

However, few analysts are bullish on the price prospects for the 1.7m B&B customers who decided to hold their shares.

B&B's strategy is to become a niche player in direct lending, and expects to see the bulk of its profits in future to come from acting as a broker for other lenders.

But Rob Thomas of UBS Warburg said: "B&B is changing from being a mortgage bank to a broker, effectively dumping the part of the business currently providing most of the profits. You have to put a lot of hope into the valuation on the distribution [broker] part of the strategy, which currently only makes 15% of group profit."

He also dismissed talk of a "takeover premium" on the shares as B&B has a five-year protection from a hostile takeover.

"If there is a deal out there, it would have been done already and before the beginning of the takeover protection," he said.

The takeover protection is only in regard to unwanted predators, and the bank can opt for a friendly merger.

fields.headline: The Verve man rises again in style
fields.standfirst:
Richard Ashcroft
Apollo, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Richard Ashcroft
Apollo, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Considering that the Verve used David Essex's Rock On as their intro tape, Richard Ashcroft is surely familiar with the tale of Jim Maclaine, the superstar rocker played by Essex in the 1970s. In the films That'll be the Day and Stardust, he traced Maclaine's rise and fall, from working-class rock hero to washed-up casualty, who ditched his band and ended up marooned in egomania. Lately, it has seemed that these films provide an eerie premonition of Ashcroft's own career.

Since the Verve imploded in 1998, his solo steps have become gradually more faltering. Where the Verve trail-blazed from Wigan's backstreets, his Alone with Everybody album has been derided as the work of a cosseted superstar, whose domestic bliss in a £500,000 mansion has resulted in creative sterility. More worryingly for Ashcroft, the album has seriously underperformed, hence two nights at the Apollo, a far cry from the enormous outdoor shows his band played.

An obviously stung Ashcroft declared: "This is for all of you that are still here. Don't believe the hype... I haven't got my pipe and slippers." Then, he delivered a performance full of the passion and anger that typified his rise.

First clad in a designer black leather jacket that resembles a neckbrace, when Ashcroft stripped to a T-shirt it felt like a metaphorical removal of the corporate guff (kitchen-sink productions, flashy videos, industry-only gigs supporting Madonna...) that has surrounded his solo infancy. Although criticism of the album may irk him now, the live renditions prove the reviewers' point. Stripped of their bloated FM sheen, songs such as Brave New World and You're on My Mind sound - more or less - as good as anything he wrote in the Verve.

The set divided into solo songs and solo-penned Verve classics, with the much grumbled-about session musicians taking a low profile as Ashcroft tore his material open. His stark voice found fabulous new poignancy in lines such as "All this talk of getting old..." from Drugs Don't Work. By the end, the entire audience was singing with him, and the encore of History/Bitter Sweet Symphony sounded unearthly and spine-tingling.

His past is still too great a part of his future, and Ashcroft has career decisions to make, but to paraphrase an old Verve hit, he is a Lucky Man - the fire, once again, in his hands.

Richard Ashcroft is at the Olympia Theatre, Dublin (003 531- 677 7124), tomorrow and Thursday, and then tours.

fields.headline: Players/Roddy Buchanan
fields.standfirst:
Dundee Contemporary Arts
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Dundee Contemporary Arts

Rating: ****
fields.body:
When David Beckham's tattoo is front page news, you know sport has gone beyond being about winning, losing, taking part. Roderick Buchanan, in his first major solo exhibition, is transfixed by this "beyond" - the unofficial games played on city streets, the mad allegiance to a team, the theatrical grace of a sporting movement.

To take sport as a central theme as Buchanan does here, transforming the vast gallery space into a maze of games, is a risky strategy. He can tell us little we don't already know about the psychology of sport or the way we flag up our identity through following a team. But, though these concepts lurk in some of his work (especially in Work in Progress, portraits of amateur footballers in Italian team shirts), this is not really Buchanan's interest.

Several works make this clear. Peloton, a large-scale projection of coverage of the 1998 Tour de France, distils the three-week race into four hours, editing out everything but aerial coverage. With no winners or losers, no close-ups of key cyclists, the event loses its sportiness and becomes a purely visual spectacle as the riders snake their way through the countryside like a huddle of insects. The same interest in the economy of movement shapes Change Up, an installation showing an ice-hockey team in rehearsal. As they swoop round the two goals and sweep across the ice, their manager tells them to "change up" - go faster. It is compellingly hypnotic: you are caught between the two goals, with the players weaving round you, the only sounds their cries of encouragement and frustration, and the noise of the skates on ice. It steals the show.

Much of the work here has been seen before, most notably the sweetly nostalgic video Gobstopper - showing the child's game of holding one's breath through the Clyde Tunnel - for which Buchanan won Becks Futures earlier this year. Sodastream, a video of pop bottles being dropped and smashed, powerfully evokes teenage street corner boredom, and is typical of Buchanan's work: a deceptively simple idea, with a visual treat (the way the fizz spreads out and retracts when it hits concrete; the different colour fizzes made by different drinks) and strong emotional engagement.

These same principles lie behind Out, Buchanan's first 35mm film, commissioned by DCA for the exhibition. A brief, beautiful work, it follows a rollerblader's descent through a multi-storey car park. There are arty reference points (the car park looks like a mini-Guggenheim; skaters used to use the site now occupied by DCA before the arts centre was built), but really the film is interested in the moment of anticipation before the descent begins rather than any end point. Just as it should be, it is the taking part, and not the winning, that matters to Buchanan, and the visual, rather than physical, thrill of it all.

Until February 4. Details: 01382 606220.
fields.bodyText: When David Beckham's tattoo is front page news, you know sport has gone beyond being about winning, losing, taking part. Roderick Buchanan, in his first major solo exhibition, is transfixed by this "beyond" - the unofficial games played on city streets, the mad allegiance to a team, the theatrical grace of a sporting movement. To take sport as a central theme as Buchanan does here, transforming the vast gallery space into a maze of games, is a risky strategy. He can tell us little we don't already know about the psychology of sport or the way we flag up our identity through following a team. But, though these concepts lurk in some of his work (especially in Work in Progress, portraits of amateur footballers in Italian team shirts), this is not really Buchanan's interest. Several works make this clear. Peloton, a large-scale projection of coverage of the 1998 Tour de France, distils the three-week race into four hours, editing out everything but aerial coverage.
